webTitle: Media giants line up European league

fields.headline: Media giants line up European league
fields.trailText: Manchester United, Arsenal and Liverpool were yesterday linked to a European super league with a possible starting date of the season after next.
fields.body:
Manchester United, Arsenal and Liverpool were yesterday linked to a European super league with a possible starting date of the season after next.

Behind the idea are four of the biggest players in international media: Rupert Murdoch, Kirch, Canal Plus and Telefonica of Spain.

The league would comprise 16 clubs, each guaranteed an income of about £15m a season plus £750,000 a point. The basic figure is only marginally more generous than the money available to a successful club in the current Champions League but the extra payments for points won would make it a more lucrative proposition.

All the games would be televised on pay-per-view and, though the tournament initially would be a closed competition, further clubs would be invited to join once it became established, with Chelsea and Celtic - not Rangers, oddly - pencilled in from Britain.

The planners are mindful that the clubs would not want to break away from Fifa and Uefa in order to join such a league. The two governing bodies would consequently need to be persuaded to sanction the new competition, which would replace the Champions League and run alongside domestic competitions.

Two years ago Media Partners put forward a similar scheme but Uefa refused to back it, although European football's governing body was forced to accede to some of the clubs' demands over finance and self-determination to head off a breakaway. Yesterday Uefa did not deny the existence of the latest plan, saying only: "We have seen the reports but we cannot comment on things in the press."

Fourteen clubs head the list based on individual pulling power and geographical spread to optimise television income: Manchester United, Arsenal, Liverpool, Bayern Munich, Bayer Leverkusen, Borussia Dortmund, Juventus, Milan, Internazionale, Real Madrid, Barcelona, Paris St-Germain, Oporto and Ajax. The reserve list includes Chelsea, Celtic, Valencia, Deportivo la Coruna, Lazio, Hamburg, Anderlecht and Marseille.

It is understood that initial contact has been made with some of the prospective clubs but none yet in Britain.

fields.headline: Tricks of the trade
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Phil Howe, 24 marketing services officer
fields.body:
Phil Howe, 24 marketing services officer

I took a job on a rolling temporary contract two years ago and I've just been made a permanent member of staff. The job was temporary because the department was uncertain of its direction, but I saw that my job had the potential to change. There's no point going hell for leather to make yourself indispensable if the full-time job just isn't there. I put in as much time and commitment as a permanent member of staff even though I missed out on their perks, and began to be identified with long-term projects. Once I had gathered enough evidence, I sent an email to my boss asking for a permanent job and got it.

Debbie Hunter, 40 administrator

I got a temping job for a few months in a rather disorganised company. I liked my boss but found the work dull, so I found things that needed fixing and fixed them. I started by redesigning the company's training pack and newsletter, and went on to update the computers and filing systems. I turned a temp job I didn't really want into a permanent one that I did. At first some colleagues were resentful and would take over my work when it started to look interesting and take the credit. Because I was a just a temp I couldn't object but it was obvious to my boss what was happening. I've just been offered a permanent contract and a firm job description, so no one can take over my work again. You just have to be patient and prove yourself if you want a permanent job.

Rachel Riley, 29 management consultant

I had a six-month contract to work on a specific project, so I decided to make a two-year plan that included ways of getting in new business. I started to dangle ideas in front of my boss of what I might achieve if I were made permanent. I'd say to him, "wouldn't it be sad if I wouldn't be able to fulfil these?" I would often talk to my boss about the implications of my work in one or two years' time to get him used to the idea of me staying. He started telling me that I couldn't possibly do all this work in six months and offered me a permanent job. It's important to let your employer realise they need to keep you on rather than asking for the job directly. It gives you a better footing when you're negotiating salary and terms.

Heather Green, 38 IT consultant

I got a seven-week office management contract with an IT company. The company was developing a specialist CD-rom but had no skills to take it forward. It wasn't something I was supposed to be involved in, but it was interesting so I asked questions about costs, target markets and support and offered solutions. I made my boss realise I had skills that the company needed and eventually he created a post. People often don't give 100% when they are on a temporary contract. I could have done the seven weeks' work, stuck to my job description and left; instead I offered my skills and ideas and was prepared to do the best I could right from the beginning.

fields.headline: HSBC in $1bn Merrill tie-up
fields.standfirst:
British bank and American broker join forces to service high net-worth individuals
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Britain's most powerful bank, HSBC, is joining forces with the world's biggest stockbroker, Merrill Lynch of the US, to create a new global online banking and investment services company aimed at wealthy investors.
fields.body:
Britain's most powerful bank, HSBC, is joining forces with the world's biggest stockbroker, Merrill Lynch of the US, to create a new global online banking and investment services company aimed at wealthy investors.

The two companies are pouring $1bn (£600m) into the stand-alone venture, which will be based in London and will target those with "investable assets" of £60,000-£300,000 who are keen to make their own investment decisions.

While the company - which has yet to be named - will be internet-based, a network of "kiosk-style" branch offices across the country is planned, and there will also be a telephone call centre.

The HSBC-Merrill venture will be introduced first in the UK later this year, leading to similar ventures in Australia, Canada, Germany, Hong Kong and Japan.

It will not operate in Merrill Lynch's US home territory, where the investment powerhouse already has a strong business servicing high net-worth individuals. The new bank should break even within five years, the venture partners said.

Shrugging off recent market turmoil in internet stocks, which has inevitably damaged the wealth of many of HSBC's and Merrill's potential clients, the new bank is claimed to be the first global online financial service offering combined personal banking and investment services - promising to meet all the financial service requirements of its up-market clientele.

The launch comes amid predictions that across Europe, the Far East, Japan and Latin America, the number of households on the net that are also active investors is expected to grow more than four-fold in the next decade to 50m.

In Europe alone, the number of online banking and investment accounts is predicted to exceed 14m by 2004. The core product will be a deposit account paying a competitive rate of interest through which customers will be able to invest in shares, unit trusts, bonds and other financial products. In time, the service will be extended to include mortgages, bill payment, credit cards and insurance.

"It will be aimed at people who want to manage their finances online, who are confident investors and want to make active decisions themselves," said HSBC.

The two banks yesterday showered praise on each other and the suitability of the match. "We complement each other perfectly," declared Merrill Lynch chairman David Komansky.

Both banks were at pains to quash any suggestion that the deal might be a precursor to an all-out merger of Merrill and HSBC - a financial marriage that has been rumoured in the past. "We have not had any conversation beyond the establishment of the 50-50 joint venture," declared HSBC chairman Sir John Bond. "There is no further agenda whatsoever."

Notwithstanding recent moves within its British subsidiary First Direct, HSBC has been slower to offer online banking than many of its competitors, and some observers expressed surprise at its willingness to set up such a joint venture before it has started an internet banking service for its customer base in Britain. It has been concentrating on its digital TV banking service which went live in the autumn, although an internet service is promised for later this year.

For Merrill Lynch, which transformed its presence in the City seven years ago with the takeover of market makers Smith New Court and which now controls around a quarter of all stock market dealings in London, the deal will raise its profile among the British public. On the share dealing front, the new move will set it head-to-head in competition with other US stockbroking groups such as Charles Schwab and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, which have been steadily building up their online presence in the UK.

The new venture will combine Merrill Lynch's strength in investment services and research with HSBC's global network, according to the two banks. "By combining resources, our two companies are able to serve customers in more markets, more quickly and more effectively than either one could on its own," they said.

webTitle: Lloyds TSB 50p surcharge catches rivals off guard

fields.headline: Lloyds TSB 50p surcharge catches rivals off guard
fields.trailText: Lloyds TSB surprised its rivals yesterday when it revealed that the cost of withdrawing money from its cash machines will be just 50p.
fields.body:
Lloyds TSB surprised its rivals yesterday when it revealed that the cost of withdrawing money from its cash machines will be just 50p.

The surcharge, which will be levied on its rivals' customers when they use its network of cash machines, is 50p lower than the £1 which Barclays had set out as a possible levy.

Lloyds TSB is the first major bank to set its charge following the recent controversy over the cost of charging for money withdrawals from the Link cash machine network after an attempt by Barclays to introduce a £1 surcharge.

A senior banker last night said that Lloyds' 50p level was likely to be adopted by rival banks and unlikely to cause angst at the office of fair trading, which has threatened banks with a competition inquiry over unfair charges.

But Peter Ellwood, chief executive of Lloyds TSB, stunning his rivals with his announcement before the Treasury select committee of MPs yesterday, admitted that the 50p charge would still allow the bank to make a "very small profit".

While Don Cruickshank, the former telecoms regulator who has conducted a review of banking for chancellor Gordon Brown, continued to insist yesterday that the cost of cash withdrawals was 30p, Mr Ellwood claimed the figure should be 38p.

Some banks and other financial firms, including Co-operative Bank, with smaller cash machine networks pledged yesterday to maintain their stance of levying neither a surcharge nor disloyalty charge on their customers.

Matt Barrett, the chief executive of Barclays, told the committee of MPs that he had been surprised by "flak" the firm received for its attempt to introduce surcharges instead of disloyalty fees last year.

The bank later said it was costing it £2m a month not to charge its own customers for using rival machines before introducing a surcharge on rival customers next year.

Mr Barrett refused to be moved from his bank's stance that the £1 surcharge was a "stake in the ground", saying he needed "time to reflect" on the surprise Lloyds TSB move.

Bill Dalton, the chief executive of HSBC's UK bank, said the bank had not determined the level at which it would set its charge.

Lloyds TSB said its 50p surcharge on its rivals' customers would replace the £1.50 disloyalty fee now paid by 4% of its customers when they use a rival's cash machine.

webTitle: Barclays chief says his salary is a bargain

fields.headline: Barclays chief says his salary is a bargain
fields.trailText: Matt Barrett, chief executive of Barclays, yesterday insisted he was worth every penny of his multi-million pound pay package as he admitted the bank's 171 branch closures this month were just the beginning.
fields.body:
Matt Barrett, chief executive of Barclays, yesterday insisted he was worth every penny of his multi-million pound pay package as he admitted the bank's 171 branch closures this month were just the beginning.

Responding to a barrage of questions from the treasury select committee of MPs, Mr Barrett estimated the closures had saved £10m, equated by one MP to one day of the bank's profits.

Mr Barrett, who fielded most of the questions even though he was accompanied by counterparts from Lloyds TSB and HSBC, said when asked how much he cost the bank that he was "a bargain".

He understood how high his pay must look to the public because he had started out on £500 a year and worked hard. "These are not ill-gotten gains."

He was unrepentant about branch closures, saying customers should not be asked to cross-subsidise each other.

Peter Ellwood, chief executive of Lloyds TSB and the only one of the bankers to stay on to hear evidence from Don Cruickshank, the banks investigator, repeated his bank's pledge not to close any more branches where it is the last in an area.

Bill Dalton of HSBC said his bank was opening branches, not closing them. All three pledged to have basic bank accounts aimed at the financially excluded, as sought by the government, available by the end of the year.

Mr Barrett received support from Mr Cruickshank, who said Barclays was matching previous branch closure programmes by its rivals after being one of the worst performing banks in recent years.

fields.headline: Credit unions win bank support
fields.trailText: Plans to create a "central services" function for credit unions will be presented to the government next month by a consortium led by Co-operative Bank.
fields.body:
Plans to create a "central services" function for credit unions will be presented to the government next month by a consortium led by Co-operative Bank.

Along with Royal Bank of Scotland and Abcul, the lobby group for credit unions, the plan is likely to build in some government funding as well as backing from rival banks.

Creating a central services function, which would help credit unions with their administration, the banks would be striving towards one of the goals set out by the the government to foster further development of credit unions and tackle social exclusion, said Mervyn Pedelty, chief executive of Co-op Bank.

Co-op, which prides itself on an ethical stance, already provides banking facilities to 60% of the country's credit unions and is working at setting up basic bank accounts for the socially excluded.

Reporting a 20% rise in pre-tax profits to £88.6m, Co-op plans to unveil an "exciting" range of mortgage products with an "ecological edge" in the summer.

The bank said it had already attracted 120,000 customers for its Smile internet bank since its launch six months ago. That helped contribute to a 14% rise in new customer accounts during the year.

Mr Pedelty said the bank was continuing with its plans to install cash machines, which customers can use without a charge, in the convenience stores run by the Co-operative Wholesale Society.

fields.headline: Angry young fruitcakes
fields.standfirst:
Six by Seven
Manchester University
****
fields.trailText: Six by Seven are probably the angriest band rock has produced since Nirvana. Real anger - as opposed to the cosmetic variety - is scarce. Bizarrely, singer Chris Olley appears to find equal gravity in the horrors of Blair's England and the minutiae of his own body. When he delivers the line "Give me something to believe in" with exactly the same fury as "I've got a really bad fuckin' haircut", pop is witnessing the emergence of either a genuine fruitcake or someone on a rare, exhilarating mission.
fields.body:
Six by Seven are probably the angriest band rock has produced since Nirvana. Real anger - as opposed to the cosmetic variety - is scarce. Bizarrely, singer Chris Olley appears to find equal gravity in the horrors of Blair's England and the minutiae of his own body. When he delivers the line "Give me something to believe in" with exactly the same fury as "I've got a really bad fuckin' haircut", pop is witnessing the emergence of either a genuine fruitcake or someone on a rare, exhilarating mission.

Six by Seven are a cult phenomenon here, with an impressively devoted group of fans, but they're becoming popular in America and it's easy to see why. Their blistering sound - like Radiohead's only because it is rooted in the UK post-punk of Magazine and Modern English - is so big that Manchester University often struggles to hold it. This is not always a good thing. At times the band seem to lose their way in power. But at their best - the restrained, keyboard-driven Candleland - they could certainly take angst into the stadiums.

At the centre of the fury, the permanently stooping Olley is, at around seven foot tall, unmissable. It's probably coincidence that his guitarist, Sam Hempton, could audition for Ken Dodd's Diddymen, but their awkwardness together adds to a sense of both dark theatre and black comedy. At times, they could be Little & Large directed by David Cronenberg, but the tension builds between them to provide a dizzying climax. Future concerts may be promoted by Don King or Harvey Goldsmith, but this is an impressively determined band with a long-term shot at rock's heavyweight title.

Six by Seven play the Astoria, London WC2 (020-7434 0403), tonight.
***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: Poor sales hit WH Smith shares

fields.headline: Poor sales hit WH Smith shares
fields.trailText: High street books retailer WH Smith yesterday responded to calls from City analysts to spell out its online strategy - and ended the day with almost 5% wiped off its stock market value as a result of other problems.
fields.body:
High street books retailer WH Smith yesterday responded to calls from City analysts to spell out its online strategy - and ended the day with almost 5% wiped off its stock market value as a result of other problems.

Weaker than expected half-year profits, bad news on music and video sales and stock problems in the group's US outlets, sent the share price down 17p to 357p - a far cry from their 778p peak of a year ago, when the market fleetingly regarded the 208-year-old company as a hot internet stock.

Chief executive Richard Handover said he was not worried about the share price. "It doesn't give me a heavy heart", he said. "It just pisses me off".

The retailer was reporting half-year profits of £101m, down from £105m last year, compared with City expectations of £110m. "We had strong performances in the core categories of books, magazines and stationery, where we had good sales growth and share gains," Mr Handover said in a statement. "But in common with our competitors, we had poor sales and margins in music and video."

Music sales were down 13% and video sales fell 8%, reducing profits by £8m.

webTitle: No one wants to buy Kwik Save

fields.headline: No one wants to buy Kwik Save
fields.trailText: Somerfield's grand recovery plan took another knock yesterday as the struggling supermarket chain admitted it had received no realistic offers for 350 Kwik Save stores put up for sale last autumn and was therefore taking them off the market.
fields.body:
Somerfield's grand recovery plan took another knock yesterday as the struggling supermarket chain admitted it had received no realistic offers for 350 Kwik Save stores put up for sale last autumn and was therefore taking them off the market.

The decision to take back the stores and devote management time to trying to make them function as profitable discount stores was made by new chairman John von Spreckelsen, recruited from the rival supermarket chain, Budgen, earlier this month, and his new chief executive Alan Smith, a former pubs executive.

"Shareholder interests will be better served by focusing our activities on retail skills and eliminating external diversions", said Mr von Spreckelsen.

The Kwik Save stores which were on the market have a book value of £335m - about to be cut to £215m - and became part of the Somerfield group as part of a £1bn merger deal which is passing into City folklore as one of the most disastrous in corporate history.

The acquisition was based on merging the two groups under the Somerfield fascia and selling more high-margin foods. But the plan backfired badly, and sales slumped. At some Kwik Save outlets sales plunged by more than 30%. The group's share price has plunged from 450p to less than 50p.

Somerfield - which has since lost its top three executives, including chief executive David Simons - hatched a survival plan based on selling its 110 biggest Somerfield superstores and the 350 worst Kwik Saves in order to concentrate on carving a new niche as a convenience store group.

However, earlier this year it revealed it had been unable to find buyers for more than 40 of its superstores, and yesterday's admission that the Kwik Save sale had also been aborted will fuel speculation that the group will be a takeover target.

The company will now continue with 558 Somerfield outlets and more than 700 Kwik Saves, each with its own management team.

In recent days there have been suggestions that Mr Simons might front a bid from Deutsche Bank to take the grocer back into private ownership, but yesterday Somerfield said it had not received any approach from either party.

fields.headline: Ethics-free Essex man
fields.standfirst:
Jump Mr Malinoff, Jump
Soho Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText: Amid the grot and grime of Soho a spanking new theatre has arisen. And for anyone who remembers the original Soho Poly, a cramped basement off Oxford Circus, it is astonishing to think it has grown into this spacious 180-seat playhouse and writers' centre in Dean Street. Fittingly, its first full-length production is also winner of the 1998 Verity Bargate award. It was Bargate who kicked off the idea of a West End fringe space devoted to new work.
fields.body:
Amid the grot and grime of Soho a spanking new theatre has arisen. And for anyone who remembers the original Soho Poly, a cramped basement off Oxford Circus, it is astonishing to think it has grown into this spacious 180-seat playhouse and writers' centre in Dean Street. Fittingly, its first full-length production is also winner of the 1998 Verity Bargate award. It was Bargate who kicked off the idea of a West End fringe space devoted to new work.

Toby Whithouse's play is a relatively engaging piece about the lack of ethics in Essex man. Set in a greasy spoon in Southend run by a Russian immigrant family, it deals with attempts to escape from a stifling background. Nick Malinoff, who has to cope with an alcoholic mother, an absentee father and a crippled uncle, sees a way out when an estuary villain offers him the chance to do a spot of London arson. To the dismay of his doting younger brother and his moralistic uncle, he swallows the bait, but one waits to see if family honour will triumph over voracious greed.

Whithouse clearly knows his Essex. To a no-hoper like Nick, who earns his living in a local car showroom, the West End seems as glamorous as Moscow did to Chekhov's three sisters. His chum Dougie, a Mephistopheles of the Essex marshes, also accurately embodies a certain kind of intransigent Thatcherite selfhood.

As an actor himself, Whithouse knows how to write juicy dialogue. He's less good on the mechanics of plot: you feel it's a mistake to keep the Russian mother as a disembodied off-stage voice, and for the cafe to lack visible customers. The play's moral dilemma, hingeing on whether his brother and uncle should shop Nick to the cops, is also sketched in, rather than fully debated.

But the play earns its keep through its social accuracy and evocation of seaside desperation. Jonathan Lloyd's production is well acted by Justin Salinger as the Porsche-hungry Nick, Paul Chequer as his hero-worshipping younger brother and Robin Soans as the Russian uncle who represents old immigrant values. Betjeman wrote of Essex's "sweet, uneventful countryside"; Whithouse's play suggests that its towns are somewhat sour, ethics-free zones.

Until May 13. Box office: 020-7478 0100. ***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: What's in a name?
fields.standfirst:
Meet the catering supervisor. She makes tea. In the old days, she would have been called the tea lady, but not any more. Esther Addley on the brave new world of job titles
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Meet the catering supervisor. She makes tea. In the old days, she would have been called the tea lady, but not any more. Esther Addley on the brave new world of job titles.
fields.body:
Ask Ro Pocock what she does for a living, and she'll tell you she's a "members only". Her colleague is a "makes things happen". Another colleague is a "managing directors" - "because that's exactly what she does, she manages the directors" - but the joke doesn't quite work since there isn't a director in sight. Look instead for "man of ideas" and "the pathfinder".

At the Fourth Room, the marketing consultancy where Pocock is based, job titles are an individual, idiosyncratic affair. No one is a secretary or a manager, and there are certainly no executives. Even the receptionist is called "the welcome". "I do have to make a joke when I give people my card and they say 'hmm, members only,'" says Pocock, whose job translates as something between membership and marketing manager. "People are very intrigued by what on earth it means."

It used to be only loony left councils who went in for creative job titles. Back in the good old days a binman was a binman, and anyone who thought otherwise was just pretentious or humourlessly PC. Even 20 years ago, it was a hackneyed joke that road cleaners with ideas above their station would describe themselves as sanitation technicians. All very self-important and bathetic, like calling a spade a manual rotivation implement.

These days, however, we're all at it. Don't like telling people at dinner parties that it's your job to do the photocopying? Why not describe yourself as a "reprographics engineer". Spend your days tapping into a screen? Your CV probably reads something like "technical systems envisioner". Say it with confidence, and the chances are your fellow dinner party guests will be impressed enough not to press you for an explanation. At which point, of course, you would have to mumble, "Um, it's something in IT."

In the new working world nobody wants a traditional job title. Traditional job titles are static things, prescriptive and limiting. They put us in boxes and remind us we're not quite where we'd promised ourselves we'd be by this stage in our life. What we want instead is a string of active verbs, the longer the better; zingy, non-specific names which, when translated, mean something like "hands-on doer" or "really busy person".

It may seem largely cosmetic, but the title under which one works is enormously important to staff morale. This week a survey reported that 70% of office workers would be prepared to forgo a pay rise for the sake of a more "motivational" title. Given that the humble tea lady can be instantly promoted to "catering supervisor" without a change in function - and without an increase in pay - it's not difficult to see why increasing numbers of employers are happy to go along with the new workplace nomenclature.

It's not only about making people in work feel happier about the job they are doing. Recruitment consultants admit that they often advise client companies to change details of job specifications to improve the chances of filling the position. "People want to go into the roles, but they are not always so keen when the roles have titles that are traditionally quite junior," says Jane Littlefield of Joslin Rowe, a City recruitment specialist. She adds that the company routinely advertises for "desk assistants", "team administrators" and "information co-ordinators" - each of which would have been called team secretary a few years ago. "It's partly supply and demand," she says. "There's lots of jobs out there, and people don't want to do something that sounds lowly. We can really sell a job on the basis that it's called something that sounds impressive."

It may largely involve cosmetic tweaking, but the stigma frequently attached to traditional job titles can cause real problems in recruitment. This week the Royal College of Physicians recommended that a new role of "health care practitioner" should be created, in part to fill the yawning gap caused by a crisis in nursing recruitment.

"The problem is that nursing does not attract many men or ethnic minorities," says Professor Michael Orme, chairman of the working party that produced the report. "The term 'nursing' puts them off." Health care practitioner, the logic goes, sounds a bit more technical and less girlie than nurse, and would be more likely to appeal to techie blokes and manual workers willing to retrain - even though the role, requiring two years' training instead of three, would actually carry less responsibility than that of a basic RN.

The Americans, of course, are a step ahead in imaginative job titles: there one can find "growth officers", "reality facilitators" and the intriguingly named "vibe envisagers" if one looks hard enough. A Virginia-based marketing company, Play, is a pioneer: all staff choose their own titles, resulting in a "check, please", a "whatif" and a "Houston we've got a problem". The idea is to make everyone feel part of the creative process, whereas traditional titles can divide people into creative and non-creative roles. The ice-cream company Ben and Jerry's also allows workers to pick their own titles: you can be "flavourmeister" or "serving supremo" if you so wish. The jokey irony - and the point of it - is that you work for an ice-cream company and your job is to make or serve ice-cream. Supremo is certainly better than server, especially if you're not getting paid a whole lot to do it.

"Our work is how we identify ourselves," says Ben Williams, a chartered occupational psychologist based in Edinburgh. "As soon as we hear what a person's job is, we stereotype them. As jobs are getting more and more computerised and electronically controlled, so we are becoming more like battery hens serving the system." More imaginative job titles, he suggests, are a way of asserting one's individuality and indispensability.

Cynicism doesn't entirely explain it, however. The workplace has changed dramatically in the past couple of decades, says Littlefield, and people are simply not doing the same jobs as they were 20 years ago. "Secretaries are still seen as very junior roles," she says. "Even the term PA, which lots of junior workers once aspired to, has connotations of 'take a memo Miss Jones'. The fact is that workplace hierarchies are very much flatter these days - managers will do a lot of their own admin, and support workers will be doing management-type jobs." Aside from carrying an element of stigma, many traditional titles are simply inaccurate in describing what today's workers actually do.

Michael Wolff, founder and "head of imagination" at the Fourth Room, thinks the workplace pecking order can be done away with altogether by being a bit more creative about the titles used for staff. "It's incredibly important to break down hierarchy, as I think it is demeaning to people - and not just junior people. I have seen people really demeaned by the title of managing director in a company in which they are not the CEO, where the title is offered as an excuse to pay them less. By the time you are a 'chairman', for instance, your title says that you are good at running meetings. That's nonsense. The point of language is to energise, not to put a label and a limit on things."

But he will admit he hasn't always got it right. "Some of the titles we have are wrong. They veer into being witty for the sake of it, and that isn't the point. The point is to affirm people in what they are there to do." Pocock for one isn't entirely convinced about being a "members only". "My title is difficult because it encompasses so much. I wanted 'by appointment', but they didn't like that one."

fields.headline: More than decoration
fields.standfirst:
Shobana Jeyasingh Dance Company
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
***
fields.trailText: Reading about Shobana Jeyasingh's latest work, Surface Tension, we get the idea that surface is the operative word in the title. The programme note promises a work that is essentially, and decoratively, all show. In fact, tension turns out to be a much more apt label for what happens on stage. This isn't a virtuoso display piece that rolls exuberantly off the dancers' bodies: it is a work that seems held together by an act of will.
fields.body:
Reading about Shobana Jeyasingh's latest work, Surface Tension, we get the idea that surface is the operative word in the title. The programme note promises a work that is essentially, and decoratively, all show. In fact, tension turns out to be a much more apt label for what happens on stage. This isn't a virtuoso display piece that rolls exuberantly off the dancers' bodies: it is a work that seems held together by an act of will.

Jeyasingh's score is a piece for tape and prepared harpsichord by Kevin Volans which is almost a collage of different sound energies. High-pitched oscillations of electronic noise snake over the surface of percussive blocks of sound while the live harpsichord manoeuvres its way between them.

It is a score which demands a constant, nervous attention from its audience, and Jeya- singh's dance exists in a taut relationship to it. Sometimes the dance cuts loose in flights of correspondingly free activity, but often it twitches with anticipation as to where it will be taken next. Much of the choreography is created out of tiny, edgy effects. A twist of one dancer's wrist or a tilt of her torso sets up a rhythmic spark with another dancer's activity, so that the stage is often alive with jagged squibs of movement.

At the other extreme, Jeyasingh stretches out her movement like an elastic band. The dancers traverse the stage in slow, drawn-out lines, hovering in moments of stillness before their bodies snap back into action.

Within this interaction of pure space and energy, individual parts of both dance and music are mesmerising, and made all the more so by the hot, tropical lighting, which bathes the stage in a sunset of colours. Yet, on first viewing, Surface Tension feels more like rehearsal notes than a completed work. It is fascinating in its procedures but lacks the focus, the singleness of vision to create a powerful identity.

The new piece is paired with Palimpsest, created in 1996 but redesigned, with great panache, by the team who worked on Surface Tension. For all its interior drama, its impression of collusion between the dancers on stage, this actually looks like a far more virtuoso work. The performers fly between extremes of fleet-footed speed and delicately coiled decoration. It is a densely woven piece of dance and it makes an excellent showcase for Jeyasingh's current company. Having lagged technically behind her best invention in the past, they are now beginning to look as sharp and versatile as Jeyasingh's own vision of them.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

Yet, on first viewing, Surface Tension feels more like rehearsal notes than a completed work. It is fascinating in its procedures but lacks the focus, the singleness of vision to create a powerful identity. The new piece is paired with Palimpsest, created in 1996 but redesigned, with great panache, by the team who worked on Surface Tension. For all its interior drama, its impression of collusion between the dancers on stage, this actually looks like a far more virtuoso work. The performers fly between extremes of fleet-footed speed and delicately coiled decoration. It is a densely woven piece of dance and it makes an excellent showcase for Jeyasingh's current company. Having lagged technically behind her best invention in the past, they are now beginning to look as sharp and versatile as Jeyasingh's own vision of them. ***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: Lying back and thinking of England

fields.headline: Lying back and thinking of England
fields.standfirst: Graham Thorpe chose not to tour South Africa last winter. At 30, his career is at a crossroads
fields.trailText: Those who do not know him might conclude that Graham Thorpe is a man without emotion, for at the crease he is as about as demonstrative as Anthony Hopkins's butler in the Remains of the Day.
fields.body:
Those who do not know him might conclude that Graham Thorpe is a man without emotion, for at the crease he is as about as demonstrative as Anthony Hopkins's butler in the Remains of the Day.

There might be an occasional twitch of the eyebrow and even a waggle of the jaw that threatens to break into an expression but never quite makes it.

For the most part, though, this is a poker player in whites. He wears that countenance of practised disinterest long since mastered by a seated snooker player as he waits for his opponent's break to come to a pocket-rattling end.

Thorpe, in fact, has enough aggression to sink a small battleship. He probably has as much as Ian Botham or Darren Gough. In a quiet sort of way. If he were a footballer, and he almost became one, the game would be a crimson blizzard of red mists and red cards and, one suspects, the likes of Roy Keane and Dennis Wise would not have everything their own way.

"If I was a footballer I'd get stuck in, to be honest," he says, with a sinister chuckle. "Football is such a combative game and you can get rid of all this energy. Especially where I played, which was in the middle of defence and in central midfield." As a footballer he was good enough to play for England Under-18s.

"But I'm a cricketer who fields at slip and bats in the middle order. Everyone has taught me to keep my emotions under control. Channel it, everyone says, channel it, channel it.

"It's very frustrating because sometimes I feel like punching down walls. One day, I'll probably explode. Even if I was a bowler I'm sure I'd be abusing hell out of people.

"But as a batsman I just can't rise to every bowler's bait. I just can't go beating up bowlers every over. It's not the done thing. Besides, if I behaved that way I'd be a goner. But that doesn't mean I don't have aggression."

Because his emotions are stored so compactly, because they appear as neat and self-contained as his strokeplay, there are some who perceive lack of passion and an introversion that sit uncomfortably beside the collective ethic of a team game.

These same people point to his decision not to tour South Africa last winter to support their suggestion of a lack of commitment. Last summer Mike Gatting, then a Test selector, said Thorpe brought nothing to the table bar runs.

This argument overlooks the unique nature of cricket: this is not so much a team game as an individual game played within a team context. It also conveniently forgets the fact that Thorpe is popular with those who know him best.

The 30-year-old has been an outstanding county player for Surrey, as his team-mates are quick to point out, and as his approaching benefit season will doubtless reflect. As for England, the captain Nasser Hussain is not only his closest friend in flannels but also his greatest admirer, which is why his return will not be long delayed.

Some of his supporters, however, do add the codicil that he should be a more wholehearted tourist; touring must be not only tolerated but outwardly enjoyed, if only for the sake of others on tour. Three years ago he was one of the players who did not make the most of Zimbabwe, at that time a delightful country to be in.

Thorpe started his Test career with a century and was England's best and most consistent middle-order batsman for most of the 90s. Left-handed, and technically sound, he has an attacking range that extends beyond the one-day game.

It first showed itself at Test level in Barbados six years ago, when he made 84 from 129 balls, and continued against South Africa in the summer. The following winter, in Australia, he scored 444 runs at 49.33.

But his recent Tests have brought disappointment. He has averaged only 29 in his last 14 games and his last series, against New Zealand last summer, produced only 93 runs from six knocks. After this he made himself unavailable for the Test series in South Africa. The selectors, rightly, did not choose him for the one-day games that followed and then omitted him from the chosen 12 centrally contracted players.

Looking at the soft centre of England's middle order last winter this might appear a perverse decision. But it is one that might now bring the best out of him.

"I feel I have a fresh challenge, and maybe this is is something I need at this stage. I'm in a good state of mind. I feel hungry. I had a good run in Test cricket and then, in West Indies two years ago, I suffered back problems and the game became a bit of a struggle. Ten winters away on the trot can take it out of you.

"Now I feel I've had a good break. I haven't touched any equipment all winter. I don't regret not touring last winter. I know it was the right decision for me and my family.

"I've put myself in the position of the selectors, and if I was one and I had a player taking a winter off I too might doubt his commitment. Can we trust him, will he do it again, I would ask myself. But this was a one-off. If selected, I will be available for future winter tours.

"Just don't expect me to be something I'm not, to make small talk and go running around the field slapping everyone on the back. Because it's not me. It's a bit like telling Goughie to stop smiling. I do my bit in the dressing-room, which is not seen on TV."

Many would be perfectly happy if Thorpe continued just to bring runs to the table.

fields.headline: ICC calls match-rigging summit
fields.trailText: The International Cricket Council has responded to calls for an investigation into corruption in the game by announcing an emergency summit meeting in London in a fortnight's time.
fields.body:
The International Cricket Council has responded to calls for an investigation into corruption in the game by announcing an emergency summit meeting in London in a fortnight's time.

The executive board of the world governing body will meet at Lord's on May 2-3 to discuss match-fixing allegations, which have come thick and fast in the week since Hansie Cronje was sacked as South Africa's captain for accepting payments from an Indian bookmaker.

The announcement comes hard on the heels of an appeal last week from Lord MacLaurin, the chairman of the England and Wales Cricket Board, requesting such a meeting. Yesterday MacLaurin welcomed the response.

"I am sure that everyone who cares about cricket will be pleased that ICC has acted promptly and decisively in calling this emergency meeting," he said. "I firmly believe that we need an urgent get- together of all the Test-playing countries to address the issues involved and take steps to restore people's faith in the game. Cricket is rightly proud of its tradition of fair play and we must do everything we can to ensure that match-fixing is stamped out and players found guilty of cheating are severely punished."

Announcing the decision, the ICC president Jagmohan Dalmiya stressed the concerns of the game's administration. "ICC directors around the world are extremely con cerned at the damage to the image of the game by the flow of allegations about players being involved in receiving payment from bookmakers," he said in a statement. "A summit meeting must be held to consider what further steps are needed to rid our sport of this major problem."

He also urged those players and officials who claim to have been approached by bookmakers - Bob Woolmer, the former South Africa coach, and Raymond Illingworth, once England manager, are recent examples - to produce evidence.

"While in most cases these are unsubstantiated allegations it is vital that any person who has firm evidence comes forward to the ICC, our code of conduct commission or the governing body in each country," Dalmiya said.

The ICC president is also planning meetings today with the president and officials of the cricket board in India, the country whose illegal gambling sparked the scandal.

Though MacLaurin is pleased with the speed of the ICC's response, Justice Malik Mohammad Qayyum, the judge who conducted a two-year investigation into corruption in Pakistani cricket, has expressed disappointment that his report has gathered dust for six months. The report, which strongly implicates a number of players, was handed over last September but no action has been taken by the Pakistan government, the cricket board or the ICC, and none of its content made public.

Qayyum interviewed 75 wit nesses in an investigation that began in 1997 before submitting his report to the Pakistan president Rafiq Tarar, who is also patron of the Pakistan cricket board.

"I am convinced that some of the Pakistani players are involved in match fixing," says Qayyum. "They deliberately threw a few games. I have recommended punitive actions against these players, including life bans. The saddest part is that some of the players against whom I recommended life bans are still playing."

fields.headline: Blair bolsters ailing peace process
fields.trailText: The Good Friday agreement is still the "only show in town", Tony Blair said today as he arrived in Northern Ireland to try and revive the ailing peace process.  Nonetheless, the prime minister, who is holding individual meetings with all sides this afternoon, ruled out an early breakthrough in the deadlock over decommissioning and devolution.
fields.body:
The Good Friday agreement is still the "only show in town", Tony Blair said today as he arrived in Northern Ireland to try and revive the ailing peace process. Nonetheless, the prime minister, who is holding individual meetings with all sides this afternoon, ruled out an early breakthrough in the deadlock over decommissioning and devolution.

"When people say that the Good Friday agreement is in tatters, it is nonsense," he insisted this morning. "The basis of the Good Friday agreement remains." He added that the issue of public confidence in decommissioning "still had to be dealt with". Mr Blair, who will meet the Irish premier Bertie Ahern in Dublin this evening, along with Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson, said he would keep trying to make the peace process work but was anxious not to raise expectations of an imminent deal.

He said: "I think we all know to raise expectations would be wrong because there are really difficult issues to work through. I just want to emphasise to people that I am here to listen and to talk to people, to learn what the concerns are and to go back over the ground again." Meanwhile, Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble insisted that Mr Blair must obtain guarantees from the IRA that they will decommission.

"The obligations [of the republican movement] were set out clearly in the agreement, obligations which we expected when we formed the administration were part of the Mitchell Review that they would honour and they have failed to do so. That is why we are here," he said as he arrived at Hillsborough Castle for talks with the prime minister.

Mr Trimble's party has voted to link any return to power sharing with republicans to the retention of the Royal Ulster Constabulary name, which the government has ruled out. Sinn Fein will urge the government to restore the suspended power sharing Stormont executive.

There is no sign that the Provisionals are prepared to give up their weapons and it seems extremely unlikely there will be any progress before May 22, the date by which the agreement anticipates disarmament could be completed.

Anti-agreement UK unionist leader Robert McCartney, who was not meeting Mr Blair today, said the prime minister's previous promises on decommissioning remained "dishonoured and unfulfilled". He added: "There are no words in any language which are a substitute for actual deeds of decommissioning."

SDLP leader John Hume today revealed that his party had put forward its own proposals for an implementation plan to resolve the political impasse. These consisted of the two governments indicating how they would fully implement the Patten report on policing; reform of the criminal justice system; guarantee human rights and equality and achieve normalisation in Northern Ireland by scaling down militarisation.

The party also called for a pro-Good Friday agreement party to affirm a commitment to taking part in the operation of all devolved institutions and to work constructively and in good faith with the international disarmament commission to achieve decommissioning.

Mr Hume said his party's proposals had been well received by the prime minister.

Sinn Fein's Conor Murphy said before meeting the prime minister that his party would be protesting against the decision to suspend the political institutions at Stormont in February. The Newry and Armagh MLA said: "We also intend to seek some certainty from Mr Blair that the British government will not suspend the institutions again as a result of a unionist veto if they are re-established."

Mr Trimble said after his meeting that Mr Blair "was not in a position to outline to us any specific proposals or to give the details about the matters that have been discussed in the background." "Our impression is that it has not yet reached any degree of precision, which is why I hope that in the course of these discussions later today that republicans will make it clear to the government what they are going to do and when they are going to do it," he added.

fields.headline: Barcelona 5 - 1 Chelsea (agg 6 - 4)
fields.body:
1 Gianluca Vialli has picked a relatively defensive midfield in Dennis Wise, Didier Deschamps, Jody Morris and Roberto di Matteo - there's no room for Gustavo Poyet or Dan Petrescu, both of whom are on the bench. Meanwhile, Patrick Kluivert is back in the Barca side, despite a running dispute with boss Louis Van Gaal, and captain Josep Guardiola, Michael Reiziger and Boudewijn Zenden all return with him. Barca kick off in front of a capacity 98,000 Nou Camp crowd. There's a bit of an atmosphere.
1 Albert Ferrer is booked for not much. He'll miss the next game if Chelsea progress.
2 Rivaldo sends Figo free down the right - nearly a good cross but it sails out for a goal kick.
4 Philip Cocu finds Zenden on the left - Ferrer sweeps up.
4 Rivaldo walks past Morris as though the Chelsea youngster isn't there. He sweeps a Beckhamesque ball out to Zenden - his cross is useless. This time.
5 Zenden feeds Cocu down the left - the Dutchman swings a wonderful ball which just evades the lunging Kluivert.
8 Chelsea buy some time - Flo and Di Matteo win a free kick between them. Ferrer's free kick finds Flo near the right-hand corner flag, but Puyol nips in to wheech the ball away.
9 Figo runs ominously at Babayaro, who fortunately wins a free kick. Chelsea rocking down the flanks. In a different way, so are Barca.
11 Kluivert flicks to Rivaldo. Who flicks out wide to Zenden. Who flicks the ball past Ferrer and slides in a cross which is only just knocked away by Leboeuf.
12 Figo cuts in from the right and charges towards the penalty area. He plays an adroit one-two with a back-to-goal Kluivert and is upended in the box by Desailly. Fairly, as it turns out.
14 Morris, Zola and Deschamps keep hold of the ball for all of ten seconds. The home side are harrying Chelsea very well indeed.
16 Flo wins a high ball and flicks out to the onrushing Zola - he misses the chance of a volley but wins a throw. From it, Chelsea win a free kick. It's scrappy and it comes to nothing, but it causes a brief flurry of bother in the Barca box. A useful couple of minutes for the Chelse, who are breaking up Barca's slick play for a while at least.
20 Good possession from Barca, but they can't get the ball out to the flanks - where they look dangerous - at the moment.
20 The cheekiest moment of the night so far as Babayaro throws a saucy dummy in his own box to calmly clear a through ball.
22 It's catching - Rivaldo diddles Leboeuf with a fancy hip shimmy - clear space. His piledriver flies high and wide to De Goey's left.
24 GOAL Barcelona 1 - 0 Chelsea A foolish Deschamps lunge on Rivaldo gives Barca a free-kick in the centre 25 yards out. Rivaldo welts it left to right around the wall - it pings back to the left off Babayaro's head, wrongfoots De Goey and bounces into an empty net. At the same time, someone switches the Nou Camp "on".
28 De Goey comes to punch a looping cross - he meets it but sends it in the direction of the onrushing Zenden. Luckily his hoof is too high and flies over the bar.
30 Figo sends Deschamps one way and then the other. He rolls the ball out wide to Kluivert whose cross is slid out for a corner. The most composed Chelsea defending since the goal sees the corner easily cleared.
32 Flo is sent a ball to chase down the right wing - he bravely wins it but there's no support. Puyol eventually runs away, cackling.
33 Desailly takes charge - he barges Zenden out of the way and storms up the pitch. His belief sparks the best Chelsea move so far - Wise, Flo and Morris knock it about for a bit, allowing Morris a shot. It's off target, but that's better.
34 Cocu, in no trouble, passes back to Hesp - Ferrer charges down the keeper's clearance. Goal kick. Are Chelsea picking their game up?
40 Perhaps - because Chelsea win a corner. Zola sends it in only for Hesp to flap under it. Flo meets the ball at the far post but misses the empty net. A real chance.
43 Babayaro concedes a corner under no pressure. From it, Desailly gets him out of jail with a towering header.
45 GOAL Barcelona 2 - 0 Chelsea With time running out in the first half, Figo, coming in from the left, makes a late dash into Chelsea territory. He turns the entire away defence inside out to create space in the box, and passes to Kluivert, waiting on the edge of the area. The ex-Ajax man hammers a real pearler against the base of De Goey's right-hand post - it comes arrowing straight back out to Figo, who calmly takes two touches to make some room for himself and passes the ball into an empty net.
45 Figo's goal is the last kick of the half. Chelsea must now score to stay in the competition.

46 Chelsea set the ball rolling for the second half. Lambourde on for Ferrer. For some reason, Wise is now a bit uptight - he hacks down Rivaldo. From the free kick, Figo whips in a cross which is missed by Leboeuf and sails towards Kluivert, two yards out. 47 Wise, the feisty little fella, now flies in on Cocu. Yellow card. Yawn.
49 Rivaldo is left to run free down the centre. He beats Leboeuf to the left is one-on-one with De Goey... who saves! It's a brilliant smother to keep Chelsea in the game.
51 Wise finds space down the right. His shot is easily dealt with by Hesp. But it's a good move. A minute later, Babayaro is found in acres down the same channel - have Chelsea spotted something?
52 Figo slides in on Deschamps and earns a booking - if Barca progress he's out of the semi-final first leg.
54 Leboeuf nearly finds Zola with a long ball through the middle. Chelsea are looking more creative this half - which is not difficult, granted.

67 Barca pass it about for a bit but they're being pushed back by a determined Chelsea midfield whose improvement is nothing short of outstanding.
70 Zenden cuts infield just like Figo did before half-time for his goal - this time, the Chelsea defence take a deep breath and work hard to close him down.
73 Dani on for Zenden.

No matter - the referee has already blown for a penalty so it won't count. webTitle: White farmers 'enemies of the state', says Mugabe

fields.headline: White farmers 'enemies of the state', says Mugabe
fields.trailText: Hours after a second farmer was killed in Zimbabwe's land dispute, President Robert Mugabe today described white landowners as "enemies of our people" who wanted to "reverse our revolution and our independence".
fields.body:
Hours after a second farmer was killed in Zimbabwe's land dispute, President Robert Mugabe today described white landowners as "enemies of our people" who wanted to "reverse our revolution and our independence".

In his pre-recorded television address - to mark the 20th anniversary of independence - the president promised to redistribute the country's best farmland and failed to order war veterans to end their sometimes violent occupation of white-owned land.

Mr Mugabe also signed into law a constitutional amendment adopted by his parliament 10 days ago that allows him to take white-owned farms without paying compensation.

The president's televised speech offered two vastly different messages. In the first, English version Mr Mugabe expressed regret for the deaths but said white farmers' resistance to land reform had "created frustrations leading to the current spate of farm occupations". He said he was talking to the farmers and the war veterans to try to solve the crisis.

In a second version of the speech, delivered in Zimbabwe's native Shona language, Mr Mugabe thanked the war veterans for moving on to the farms.

He said that the white farmers should not have opposed a constitutional referendum in February that would have allowed the state to seize their land without paying compensation. The referendum failed and squatters, led by veterans of Zimbabwe's independence war, began occupying the land soon afterwards.

"They have behaved as enemies of Zimbabwe, and I told them that we were full of anger. The entire community is angry and that's why they have the war vets seizing land," said Mr Mugabe, who met the farm leaders yesterday.

"I told them it requires real transformations on their part in a positive way for us to accept them as allies wanting to live side by side and until then we will continue to regard them as enemies of our people."

The farmer who died this morning was Martin Olds, 42, who was shot and beaten by a crowd that moved on to his land in the early hours.

The wounded Mr Olds called for help on a radio, but his besiegers kept medical workers away until it was too late, said David Hasluck, director of the Commercial Farmers' Union, which represents white farmers.

Three days ago squatters shot dead David Stevens, a white farmer and supporter of the Movement for Democratic Change, the main opposition party. Five other farmers who tried to help him were severely beaten.

The murder of Mr Olds was condemned by Britain's foreign minister Peter Hain, who said the death showed that the crisis in Zimbabwe was "spiralling out of control".

But Mr Mugabe blamed Britain for many of his country's woes and accused Labour of reneging on promises made by the previous Conservative party administration.

Mr Hain and foreign secretary Robin Cook were also criticised for "inaction" by the Tories, who urged the government to seek the urgent help of the Commonwealth in finding a peaceful solution to the violence in Zimbabwe.

Mr Hain today told the House of Commons foreign affairs select committee that Mr Mugabe had indicated to fellow African leaders that he might be willing to accept Commonwealth observers at the coming elections, whose date he has not yet announced.

The foreign minister welcomed the development and said that Britain would be happy to supply observers to any international monitoring body.

He dismissed as "knee-jerk gestures" calls for sanctions against Zimbabwe and for its suspension from the Commonwealth, and condemned what he termed "inflammatory" language from the Conservative party.

He said Britain acknowledges that there is "massive unfairness" in land distribution in Zimbabwe - with 4,400 white farmers owning 30% of agricultural land - and is ready to discuss what aid it can give to the land reform process. But there was no pot of money set aside for the Zimbabwean authorities to claim and no question of Britain simply providing compensation for land seizures.

fields.headline: William Hague's full speech
fields.standfirst: "Common Sense on Asylum Seekers" - What the Conservative leader told the Social Market Foundation
fields.trailText: The Conservative leader's speech to the Social Market Foundation
fields.body:
Britain has a long tradition of providing hospitality to men, women and children fleeing persecution. From Flemish Protestants seeking refuge from Spanish rule, to the Huguenots a century later, to the French émigrés escaping the guillotine, to the thousands of Jews escaping Russian pogroms and persecution in eastern Europe in the late nineteenth century, this country has given a safe home to people in fear of their lives.

Not every refugee who came to our shores admired Britain's own social order or political institutions. Karl Marx dreamed of world revolution in the sanctuary of the Reading Room of the British Museum. But then, as Isaiah Berlin observed, in Britain "foreign revolutionaries were on the whole left unmolested, provided they behaved themselves in an orderly and inconspicuous manner."

This tradition is rightly a source of national pride and it has also brought important benefits to our country. When Nazi tyranny drove many European Jews to our shores, Britain became home to some of the foremost mathematicians, scientists, historians and musicians of the age.

Even in my own lifetime, we saw the arrival here of tens of thousands of Ugandan Asians, refugees from the dictatorship of Idi Amin. Ted Heath's decision that we keep our promise and let them settle here was brave, honourable and right. And those refugees from Uganda, with their skills, enterprise and diligence have contributed enormously to the prosperity and cultural and political life of our country.

There is Tarique Ghaffur, the Deputy Assistant Commissioner of the Metropolitan Police; Asif Din, the former Warwickshire cricketer; Manubhai Madhvani, the fantastically successful industrialist; and our own prospective parliamentary candidate in Northampton, Shailesh Vara.

Each new group of settlers has enriched our islands. Each has widened and advanced our sense of what it means to be British. And I am determined that we should never abandon our proud tradition of offering sanctuary to those who are fleeing injustice and wrong.

Yet that tradition is now under threat as never before. Not because our people have lost their sense of hospitality; not because we are unwilling to honour our obligations to genuine refugees; least of all because the British people are racist or xenophobic. The problem confronting us is that a system to identify and protect refugees which was designed half a century ago is near collapse in today's utterly different world.

In fact it was nearly 80 years ago that the first attempt was made to establish an international system to deal with refugee issues. In 1921 the League of Nations appointed the Norwegian explorer Nansen as its High Commissioner to help Russian refugees. In the immediate aftermath of the Second World War, the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Agency and, later, the International Refugee Organisation were established to find homes for the literally millions of displaced people in Europe.

Finally, in 1951, the United Nations High Commission for Refugees came into being. In the same year, the Geneva Convention provided for the first time a universal definition of the term "refugee" in place of the previous international practice of trying to define and help particular national groups.

It is worth noting that the authors of the 1951 Convention expected that the refugee crisis was capable of solution within a relatively short space of time. Refugee status could be claimed only in respect of events which had occurred before January 1st 1951. Countries ratifying the Convention could choose (and most did) to restrict their obligations to European refugees and the High Commissioner's mandate was originally limited to three years.

Sadly, events have turned out otherwise. Despite the defeat of Nazism and the collapse of Soviet tyranny, political and religious persecution are as familiar today as in the world of 1951. In 1967, the Bellagio Protocol extended the provisions of the Convention to post-1951 events and to non-Europeans.

The definition of a refugee included in the 1951 Convention is now accepted by practically every country in the world and it was written into British law through our 1993 Asylum and Immigration Appeals Act. Under the Convention, a refugee is someone who has a " well-founded fear of being persecuted for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion, is outside the country of his nationality and is unable or, owing to such fear, is unwilling to avail himself of the protection of that country".

The Convention goes on to list the obligations of states towards people who have been granted refugee status. Most important is the principle that a refugee may not be returned to a country where he or she risks persecution. Other articles of the Convention deal with such matters as identity documents, employment, education and welfare. In general, European countries, including Britain, have given refugees rights similar to those enjoyed by their own countrymen and it is precisely because the rights granted to refugees are so important and because we take our obligations to genuine refugees so seriously that the current breakdown in our asylum system matters so much.

For most of the post-war era, the framework established in 1951 has worked well. Someone who had climbed the Berlin Wall, someone who had fled to the West after the Hungarian Uprising in 1956 or the suppression of the Prague Spring in 1968 clearly came within the scope of the Convention. The number of people seeking asylum was relatively small and cases were usually clear-cut.

All that has now changed. Over the last dozen or so years, developments in communications have transformed the opportunities available not just for western businessmen or tourists but for economic migrants worldwide. Television has become the parish notice-board of the global village. People living in poor and unstable countries can watch images of the prosperity and relative security of life in Germany or Britain or the Netherlands every night of the week on their TV screens.

Cheap mass air travel makes emigration a practical possibility for ever larger numbers of people. Global communications mean that you can look beyond the next town or even the next country. Migration across continents has become easier than at any time in human history.

In Europe, these profound social and technological changes have taken place at the same time that the disintegration of the Soviet Empire has brought down the physical and political barriers to emigration. People no longer need to flee Warsaw or Sofia for fear of persecution but there is nothing now to stop them seeking to emigrate for economic reasons.

Throughout Western Europe, the asylum system has proved a soft target for people trying to get round the usual immigration controls. Because the 1951 Convention imposes on each government a duty to assess every application on its merits, a claim for asylum has proved an effective way to gain temporary entry to another country and then to delay or avoid removal or deportation.

The official Home Office statistics show that in 1988 there were just under 4,000 applications for asylum in this country. By 1996, the last full year before Labour took office, that figure stood at 29,000. Last year, the number of claims was more than 71,000.

"Common Sense on Asylum Seekers"
The Conservative leader's speech (part one)
fields.trailText: "Common Sense on Asylum Seekers:" the Conservative leader's speech to the Social Market Foundation
fields.body:
We Conservatives have already committed ourselves to a policy of automatically detaining asylum seekers who come from countries which we know to be safe in reception centres until their cases are decided.

Now we have decided that it would be right to go further. So the next Conservative Government will detain all new applicants for asylum, whether port applicants or in-country applicants, in reception centres until their cases have been determined. There will be a cost in providing the centres, but I am convinced, not least by the experience of our European neighbours, that this policy will have a significant deterrent effect on those thinking of travelling here without a well founded case. In fact, we estimate that overall, our new system would reduce the cost of at least £600 million that asylum currently imposes on the taxpayer.

Second, we shall take action to speed up asylum decisions and appeals. A report commissioned by the Home Office from the consultants Vantagepoint identified massive and unnecessary delays in the system. Let me give just two examples. Under the present arrangements, an asylum seeker who arrives in Dover or at Heathrow is interviewed at length by an Immigration Officer. He then has to refer the case to the Immigration Directorate of the Home Office, in Croydon, for the papers to be reviewed and a decision made. If these two roles of interviewer and decision taker were merged, we should be able to remove delays of between five and twenty days in around fifteen to twenty thousand asylum cases each year.

The Vantagepoint report has been on the Home Secretary's desk for the last nine months. We ought to implement its recommendations speedily on the handling of cases, and that asylum interviews should be tape-recorded. Incredible as it may seem, the usual practice is for the interviewer to record manually what is said by the applicant. It is sixteen years since the Police and Criminal Evidence Act required police interviews to be recorded on tape. The extension of that arrangement to our asylum and immigration system is long overdue.

Third, we shall amend the law to deter applications by people who have come from a country which is manifestly safe. It is extraordinary that we receive applications for asylum from countries which have now been formally accepted as candidates for EU membership. How can we say, on the one hand, that we accept that a country has the rule of law and good government that would qualify it to join the EU and, on the other, that we believe its citizens to be suffering systematic persecution? A future Conservative Government will draw up a list of countries where we judge the rule of law is being properly enforced and from which we will not normally accept asylum applications. We shall write into the law a presumption that a claim is unfounded if the applicant has either travelled directly from or began his journey in a safe country.

Fourth, we shall also make clear to our European partners that we expect them to take seriously their obligations under the Dublin Convention.

In theory, under the Convention, asylum seekers should be dealt with by the first safe country they reach, regardless of where they choose to make their application. In practice however, this policy becomes unenforceable when migrants destroy their tickets so that it is difficult to prove exactly where they came from.

Despite our geographical position, we saw in 1999 a surge in applications here which was not matched anywhere else in the European Union. Some of this, of course, is accounted for by refugees who have come directly to Britain from non-European ports of origin. But we are still left with thousands of people who have travelled illicitly through safe and prosperous parts of western Europe before choosing to declare that they are victims of political persecution.

Something is going badly wrong when migrants are prepared to cross the length of the continent of Europe, without once being detained, in order to lodge their asylum claims in the United Kingdom. For every genuine refugee, the priority is surely to get out of a particular country, not to get in to one.

There will be a few legitimate exceptions, for example someone may be joining other members of his family who have reached Britain by a different route. But barring such exceptional circumstances it is surely reasonable to expect anyone fleeing persecution to apply for sanctuary as soon as he reaches a safe country. I hope that that can be done in co-operation with our European neighbours.

The next Conservative Government will press for intergovernmental agreement among the EU states not to turn a blind eye when their countries are being used as a stopover for asylum seekers transiting to a neighbouring country. We must call on our European neighbours to take the Dublin Convention seriously.

We must also call on the British legal profession not to take international law to absurd lengths and interpret it in a way not recognised in other countries. It is very odd that our courts have on occasion decided that perfectly civilized countries in Western Europe such as, in one recent case, France, are not 'safe' places to which refused asylum seekers can be deported. If we cannot get the current international system to work properly we may have to begin to work with other countries to change that system.

Fifth, when people have been refused asylum they should be removed from this country without delay. What is the point of spending all this time and money on assessing whether asylum seekers have a genuine case, when nothing is done with those who do not and when, in the meantime, those with bogus claims learn how to disappear into the melting pot of society?

In the last six months for which there are figures, there were just over 10,000 asylum decisions. Only 12 per cent were granted asylum. Another 11 per cent were allowed exceptional leave to remain. 77 per cent - 8,000 asylum seekers - had their claims turned down. Yet during the same period, fewer than 4,000 actually left the country.

The Home Office admit that they know of at least 20,000 asylum seekers who have absconded. Some reports suggest it could be much higher.

That will take a burden off the police, and simplify the process of removals. The Removals Agency will be largely composed of Immigration Service staff, assigned permanently and full-time to removals duties, with their own chain of management and sense of purpose. We need to make clear to everyone that people whose claim for asylum is not justified will, quite simply, not stay in Britain.

Sixth, we need to make sure that there is a dose of common sense in the way the existing law is applied. We need deterrence - but measured deterrence, which is likely actually to make a difference to the way people behave.

There are penalties for businesses who illegally employ people who have no right to be in the UK. They are not being applied properly. We would make sure that they are applied, because the prospect of finding illegal work is one of the things that attracts abusive asylum applications.

This automatic penalty does not distinguish between those who deliberately set out to evade the law, an offence already covered by criminal law with a penalty of up to 10 years in jail, and those who are the innocent victims of unscrupulous racketeers. We will seek to make the system fairer.

Between eighty and ninety per cent of asylum applications are currently being refused because they have no foundation. The system we have today is not firm, it is not fair, and it is not efficient. It is weak and it is arbitrary. And it is losing public support.

Some people feel this doesnt matter. They would rather I didnt talk about it. They are wrong.

A democracy that sets rules and doesnt enforce them loses the respect of its own citizens and the international community.

A system of law that is arbitrary and unfair will break down.

A tolerant, welcoming society too weak and inefficient to determine whom it wants to welcome will decline into an intolerant and unwelcoming society.

By itself, of course, the asylum crisis is not big enough to do this. It cannot destroy something as robust as British democracy and rule of law. But it can damage the rule of law and establish deeply damaging precedents.

In other words the crisis in the asylum system damages many things that we value most dearly about our country. It damages many of the very things that distinguish this country from the places refugees are fleeing from.
