fields.headline: Evolution not revolution
fields.standfirst: The Scot Nats play a canny game
fields.trailText: The Scot Nats play a canny game
fields.body:
Is the Scottish National party going cool on independence? Merely to ask the question may sound ridiculous: surely an independent Scotland is the very raison d'etre of the SNP. But, as we report on the news pages today, the party leader Alex Salmond has touched off a frenzy of tea-leaf reading among the Kremlinologists of Edinburgh. They have spotted a shift in Mr Salmond's rhetoric, away from the old slogans of a separate Scotland and towards a new admiration for the halfway house that is devolution. In a speech last week, the SNP leader barely mentioned the nationalist dream of independence, preferring instead to sing the praises of the new parliament at Holyrood. One bright spark set out to count how many times Mr Salmond had used the i-word in the first six months of the new legislature's life. The answer: twice.

It is not difficult to spin this as the abandonment of the Scottish nationalist crusade. One can even construct a theory to explain it. Stung by their failure to translate a one-time poll lead over Labour into victory in last year's Holyrood elections, the Nats have decided to drop the policy that stands between them and the voters' affections. Just as New Labour dumped clause 4, so a New SNP is about to drop its vote-repelling credo - the break-up of Britain. Plaid Cymru no longer demands complete independence for Wales: now the SNP is simply taking the same step.

Plausible though that may sound, it is not right. Something far subtler is at work. Nationalism no longer amounts to the crude call for a Scottish state, with its own passports, army and seat at the United Nations - between Saudi Arabia and Senegal. Instead it increasingly sees itself as a gradual process, beginning with the existing parliament. Mr Salmond has realised that his best hope is not to do down the chamber, but to say it's working so well - why not let it grow? Scots will not hand Edinburgh politicians more power as a reward for failure, only as a prize for success. The SNP leader avoids the trap of praising Labour - the majority party in the parliament - by casting the chamber as the vigilant watchdog which holds the Labour-dominated executive to account. That way the parliament is a hero, and so is the SNP which forms the official opposition. Judged like this, the Nat strategy is less a move away from independence - more a canny way of getting there.

fields.headline: Grid for learning
fields.trailText: What happened to the National Grid for Learning?
fields.body:
Two years ago, the government decided to create a special place for teachers, where they could share ideas, collaborate in online projects, download lesson plans and save hours of admin and planning time. It would be the portal of choice for all teachers, and be called the National Grid for Learning.

Sadly, this promised land never truly arrived. Teachers were left wandering the web looking for a place where they felt at home - if they could afford to do so. Those who did penetrate the elusive portal of the NGfL found a barren space which was difficult to navigate. Parents have fared rather better since the launch of the colourful and relatively accessible www.parents.dfee.gov.uk.

But what went wrong with the grid? To begin with, too many government agencies were producing information but failing to offer teachers a path through it: the Department for Education, Ofsted, British Educational Communications and Technology Agency, and the Teacher Training Agency (to name only a few) produced their own sites. The Virtual Teachers' Centre was a laudable attempt to gather together all this activity, but it remains dour, dull and difficult to use.

"We're going to use the net in a much bigger way," promises a DfE spokeswoman. How? "Our computer system will increasingly recognise who you are, and will give you information relevant to your needs." When? "It would be a bad thing if we had a date before we decided what it's going to look like." But don't worry. "There's very good news on these fronts."

The Virtual Teachers' Centre subject hubs are expanding and the EASEA project for electronic distribution of documents is also being given a boost.

That's not good enough,says Jerry Glazier, chairman of the National Union of Teachers' ICT working group. "Nothing spreads so quickly in this profession as good ideas... Everything in the grid needs to be relevant and easy to use." If the site were right and - crucially - if every teacher were routinely given a laptop (rather than having to pay for half of it themselves) and training, he says, their workload could be cut.

It's over to the NGfL Content Unit, then, to produce a decent portal before someone else does. Meanwhile, the site does contain some useful subject links, deep down, and ideas for incorporating ICT into national curriculum subjects. Here's how to find them: go to the VTC link above, choose the curriculum subject option, click on ICT on the left, then choose the kind of help you're looking for. If you have ideas for improvements, email: webkeeper@ngfl.gov.uk.

fields.headline: Multi-millionaires of the world unite
fields.standfirst: Why the furore about Premiership footballers earning a basic salary of £409,000 a year? Most of them deserve to earn far more, argues Sean Ingle
fields.trailText: Every time an inflation-busting salary increase for Premiership footballers is announced, middle England seems to collapse in collective apoplexy. Even the most rational of folk can be heard pondering whether these 'crazy' and 'unsustainable' wage increases will ruin our national game.
fields.body:
Every time an inflation-busting salary increase for Premiership footballers is announced, middle England seems to collapse in collective apoplexy. Even the most rational of folk can be heard pondering whether these 'crazy' and 'unsustainable' wage increases will ruin our national game.

No-one puts the opposing view. Surely the only disappointing thing about today's survey in the Independent - which reveals that the average salary of a Premiership player is £409,000 per week, and that around 100 players earn over £1m - is that the top footballers aren't earning a whole lot more.

That's not an argument you'll hear many people make, outside of the PFA at least. But once you strip away the misconceptions and the prejudices that surround the issue of players' pay, you realise that it isn't as simple as readers of the Daily Mail would like to think.

The first thing to realise is that the majority of the wealth generated by football doesn't find its way to the players - it ends up in the pockets of the chairman and shareholders.

Fair enough you might think. But ask yourself this question: which man has done more to make Manchester United the club they are today - Martin Edwards or Roy Keane? Most pundits would go for Keane, but in the money stakes it's been Edwards who has benefited far more.

When Edwards became chairman of United he inherited a £1m stake from his father. Since the club's boom he has made nearly £100m in share sales, while still retaining £60m in stock. Now contrast that with Keane - who despite his £53,000 a week basic salary, would have to play for another 58 years to earn the same sum.

That situation isn't unusual. The Sunday Times rich list does not feature a single footballer in its top 1,000 - but 30 chairman and directors are included.

A second point is that - contrary to popular belief - footballers' salaries are actually fairly middle of the road when compared to other sports or forms of entertainment.

In a recent survey by Forbes magazine, for example, Ronaldo was the only footballer to make their list of sports highest earners. Above him were Michael Schumacher, Lennox Lewis and Tiger Woods - all of whom earn at least ten times as much as Keane. Furthermore, the average NBA wage is £1.6m, four times that of a Premiership footballer.

Where the critics do have a point is over salaries in the lower divisions. Players in the Second and Third Divisions earn on average £52,000 and £37,000-a-year respectively - which is unsustainable considering the amount of revenue in the lower leagues.

But that's hardly the fault of players: the real guilty party is the Premier League, who have ensured that less and less money is distributed down to the lower clubs. As a result, many clubs face a constant battle against bankruptcy.

Unfortunately a lot of the arguments against Premiership pay boil down to simple old-fashioned snobbery. Many people of a certain class just can't accept that a person who earns his living from kicking a ball around - and has never been to university for God's sake - should earn as much as a someone who who makes his money by crunching numbers in the City.

Those people should remember that Premiership players are the elite few who, out of all the millions of young kids who dream of becoming professional footballers, have actually made it - and they deserve to be rewarded for doing so.

sean.ingle@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Bonus ball, Rollover and Jackpot
fields.trailText: GREEN IS THE COLOUR
fields.body:
GREEN IS THE COLOUR

Gianluca Vialli reckons that tonight's Big Cup match-up with Barcelona is "the most important match in [Chelsea's of] Chelsea's history". Which must amuse Bobby Campbell, mastermind of the Blues' 1990 Zenith Data Systems Trophy triumph. Anyway, Luca has got it into his head that if C's of C can beat this bunch of Dutch strollers this evening, his team can pat themselves on the back. Not to mention the back pocket.

The west London footballing boutique have already pocketed over £5m from Uefa for simply qualifying for the quarter-finals. If they beat Barca they will get another £2m - absolutely free! (although they will have to subscribe to the Uefa book club for a minimum of five years). Add to that another £1m from TV rights for the semi-final and another potential £5m if they win the trophy itself and you can see why Kuddly Ken Bates is getting excited.

Which would, in turn, explain why Luca isn't contemplating defeat. "We can win it," he said today. "We have to play the same way as at Stamford Bridge. We have to show the same fearless mentality." To that end, Jody Morris looks likely to keep Gustavo Poyet out of the side and Luca is also tipped to pick Roberto Di Matteo over Dan Petrescu. Barcelona meanwhile will be able to pick the orifice they have their P45 shoved up if they lose. It should be an interesting game.

NEVILLE'S BRUSH WITH EVIL

The Fiver would like to assure its readers that today's launch of SecuriFiver (the footballer's first stop for violent self-defence) and the revelation that Gary Neville has been the subject of abuse and attacks from indignant Liverpool fans are in no way connected. Unlike our new Electric Scouse-o-prod which comes with all connecting wires included for the bargain price of £299.99.

"I keep getting death threats," Neville revealed during a grilling by the Official Manchester United Magazine. "After the recent Liverpool game my car nearly got turned over going through Salford Quays by about five Scousers," he went on, as if this was a unique experience.

Neville doesn't have the best of relations with the denizens of Anfield Road, he called them names in another interview and got very excited when Ole Solskjaer dumped the Reds out of the Cup last season. But that doesn't mean he should be forced to live in fear. Although it would keep him on his toes.

Gordon Taylor does not agree. The head of the PFA believes Neville's difficulties are in fact "a sad reflection on society today" and that the lesson for players "is to be extremely careful on places where they go when they're relaxing". Brendon Batson, Taylor's deputy, concurs. "People have to take care of their own personal safety," he said as the Fiver unveiled its unique two-headed mace (£499.99). "There is a lunatic fringe out there." Yeah, and it's flopping onto Gary Neville's forehead as we speak.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"We stand by the fact that we regrew John Hartson's hair using Minoxidil, the only approved drug in Britain for hair regrowth, combined with our laser therapy treatment." Carl Howell, managing director of the Advanced Hair Studio, finally speaks out on the issue that's got them all talking.

OUT ON A LINDA

Hello there dear readers, this is Lynda Lee Fiver with another reactionary rant against those greasy-haired, pot-smoking louts that pass for professional footballers these days. Why don't you yobs all take a bath? Go-on then, I'm waiting. And while you're at it, I hope you all drown.

Oh reader, please excuse my temper! There I was, relaxing with my cat, Wiggles, and a mug of Organic Green Tea, when my Elephant grey eyes passed upon a report that Premiership footballers are now earning a basic salary of £409,000 a year. Apparent around 100 of this number get over £1m. Just for kicking a spherical object around a muddy field! I bet they haven't even been to Cowes for God's sake. Why don't they get a proper job? Preferably in an structurally-unsound factory.

The survey, in the Independent newspaper, also revealed that First Division players earn £128,000 a year, while their counterparts in the Second and Third Divisions earn £52,000 and £37,000 respectively. With that kind of money they'll be moving into Hertfordshire next - and bringing their domesticated rodents with them!

Oh how I rue the day that the cane was banned from our schools.

Officials at PSV Eindhoven believe that Ruud van Nistelrooy will join Manchester United this summer. Club president Harry Van Raaij believes the only thing that would prevent the completion of the deal would be United buying Patrick Kluivert instead.

Arsenal are preparing a £9m bid for Brazilian international Roque Junior. The 23-year-old centre back, who played for Palmeiras against Manchester United in Tokyo earlier this season, is seen as a long-term replacement for veteran skipper Tony Adams.

Bryan Robson has travelled to the continent to try and tie up deals for Bayer Leverkusen striker Olivier Neuville, Hertha Berlin midfielder Sebastien Deisler and Fiorentina defender Paul Okon. "It's the busiest I've been in five years," said Robson. "A lot of players I am interested in are at top clubs so they will cost big money."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

Mark Bosnich's hopes of being fit for United's Champions' League quarter-final second leg at home to Real Madrid tomorrow are receding. The Australian goalkeeper has aggravated a stomach injury that he picked up while swimming and Raimond van der Gouw looks set to replace him. But Jaap Stam and Roy Keane have shaken off knocks and will play.

Everton's Scotland international Don Hutchison has not ruled out the prospect of signing a new deal at Goodison. He has also dismissed talk of a move to Leeds - even though David O'Leary is believed to be ready to bid £2.5 million for him.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger has said he believes France striker Nicolas Anelka should have stayed in London. "I think Nicolas left us too early. webTitle: Hague's asylum pledge leads Tories further into wilderness

fields.headline: Hague's asylum pledge leads Tories further into wilderness
fields.standfirst: William Hague's promise to herd all asylum seekers into detention centres will keep the Tories on the political margins for the foreseeable future, argues Guardian political correspondent Nicholas Watt.
fields.trailText: William Hague's promise to herd all asylum seekers into detention centres will ensure the Tories remain on the political margins for the foreseeable future, argues Guardian political correspondent Nicholas Watt.
fields.body:
Some of William Hague's more devoted admirers believe that Downing Street has single-handedly orchestrated a campaign to portray their hero as an extremist.

Veterans such as John Major and Michael Heseltine, who have led the calls for the Tory leader to return to the centre ground, have been ensnared in a Blairite trap which grossly distorts Mr Hague's views, his supporters say. However, Mr Hague's provocative intervention on asylum seekers shows that he needs no help from Downing Street's spinmeisters in casting himself as an extreme rightwinger.

In a speech tonight to the rightwing Social Market Foundation, Mr Hague will pledge that a Tory government would herd all asylum seekers into detention centre regardless of their plight. For good measure, the Conservatives would also establish a "removals agency" to eject asylum seekers from Britain the moment their applications are turned down.

Amid a general outcry at the shrill nature of Mr Hague's speech, the Tories attempted throughout the day to tone down his message. Mr Hague said that he was not stoking up racial divisions, because members of minority communities had told him of their anger at the way in which the ayslum system was being abused.

The Tory chairman, Michael Ancram, said that the detention centres would be pleasant places. "There would be food and clothing," he said.

But Labour wasted no time in portraying Mr Hague as extreme. The home secretary, Jack Straw, said that Mr Hague was exploiting the asylum issue, adding: "It is a cruel deception from a deeply cynical party."

Ministers will be privately delighted that Mr Hague shows no sign of returning to the political centre ground, where elections are won. But they will be forgiven for wondering what strategy the Tory leader thinks he is following, particularly after an ICM poll in today's Guardian found that the asylum row was having little impact on voters.

Mr Hague hopes that his pledge will prove to be a vote winner because of a growing feeling that Britain has become a "soft touch" for "bogus" asylum seekers attracted by generous benefits.

In the longer term, however, his speech will undermine the Tories' efforts to reach out beyond their traditional white, middle class base, ensuring that they remain on the political margins for a long time to come.

webTitle: London survives market nerves as technology stocks fall further

fields.headline: London survives market nerves as technology stocks fall further
fields.trailText: More than £35bn was wiped off the value of London share prices yesterday but fears of panic selling failed to materialise.
fields.byline: Jill Treanor, Larry Elliott, Jane Martinson in Washington and Justin McCurry in Tokyo
fields.body:
More than £35bn was wiped off the value of London share prices yesterday but fears of panic selling failed to materialise.

However, despite soothing words from leading politicians, there were warnings of worse to come.

The tense day of trading was the first chance investors in London had to react to the record-breaking declines of all three major stock markets in the US on Friday.

Fears of large falls in London were exacerbated by hefty drops in Tokyo early yesterday morning, although the FTSE-100 index of leading shares eventually ended 183.5 points - 3% - lower at 5,994.

The index had suffered a rollercoaster ride throughout the day. At one point, before the US markets opened, the London market was down more than 260 points.

Shares in London regained some of their value after some stocks on Wall Street recovered. However shares of blue-chip and technology companies in the US ricocheted throughout a tense morning session which left the Nasdaq technology index nursing five-week losses of 34%.

In London, the techMARK index - made up of the e-commerce stocks - fell another 4% to 3,390. Analysts used Lastminute.com, the high-profile internet firm, as illustration of where most of the pain in the stock market was being felt. The stock market debutant has lost 70% of its value since flotation last month.

Among the stocks that were hardest hit yesterday were telecoms companies such as Energis, which fell 214p to £25.01. But it was not all bad news - hand-held computer maker Psion ended the day 172p higher at £28.02, but still well off its recent highs.

Few escaped what had been seen as the tussle between "old" and "new" economy stocks. Experts said it was the first real test for the new, small speculators who have invested heavily in dot.com companies. They were being urged not to be too hasty in cutting losses.

Trevor Greetham, strategist at Merrill Lynch, said: "We are at a turning point. The market will gyrate all over the place. If investors have a concentrated portfolio in technology stocks, then they need to have some old economy stocks. To get there, don't phone the broker straight away and sell everything."

Robert Buckland, UK strate gist at Salomon Smith Barney, the investment bank, acknowledged that the markets "were not out of the woods yet", but said he was advising clients to buy stocks at some levels.

After Friday's turbulence on Wall Street, sparked by a surprise rise in inflation, political leaders sought to calm nerves as the world's leading finance ministers and central bankers met to discuss the state of the world economy.

President Bill Clinton and the US treasury secretary, Larry Summers, offered an upbeat outlook for the US economy, which analysts interpreted as an attempt to head off fears that the US would suffer a similar crash to that of the Japanese stock market in 1989.

While City analysts offered a range of views about the future of the market, there appeared to be consensus that the events were a timely reminder to new investors that stocks can go down as well as up.

fields.headline: Fight for fitness
fields.standfirst: Taebo is the latest exercise craze to arrive here from America. A mishmash of martial arts and aerobics, with a bit of circuit training thrown in, fans claim it will transform your body in a month. Couch potato Claire Wallerstein  tried it - and became an addict overnight
fields.trailText: I was born lazy. I didn't even walk until I was three, and for most of my life have made an effort to spend as much time as possible supine on a sofa drinking cocktails.
fields.body:
I was born lazy. I didn't even walk until I was three, and for most of my life have made an effort to spend as much time as possible supine on a sofa drinking cocktails.

That's not to say I never wanted a body like Jennifer Aniston's. But being too poor to join a gym, I'd always been stumped. I lack the hand-eye coordination for ball sports, yoga sends me to sleep, and aerobics always seemed more of an insane leotard fashion contest than a means of keeping fit.

Needless to say, I would have choked on my cocktail if a fortune teller had told me I was going to become a slave to an American fitness guru called Billy Blanks and his creation, taebo. But I did.

My eyes aren't glazed over, and I haven't been brainwashed. I can't even be completely sure that making taebo compulsory in schools would bring about world peace. But I do think this man is some kind of genius. So does Jennifer Aniston. And if anything could make my body look even vaguely like hers, it must be verging on the miraculous.

Blanks, America's dominant martial artist in the 80s, was dyslexic and taunted because of a hip joint anomaly as a child. He overcame this to become a black belt in six different martial arts, won a raft of international gold medals and appeared in movies and on TV, most notably the kickboxing episode of Ally McBeal.

The taebo idea came to him 20 years ago while he was going through his moves to dance music - and noticed how quickly he became breathless. He started teaching it 12 years ago in California, and now trains a whole host of celebrity converts including Pamela Anderson, Brandy, Brooke Shields - and Jennifer Aniston.

In the States, the man is huge. He has his own pay-per-view television channel, Taebo TV, and his video, launched two years ago, has sold 30m copies. In the street he needs bodyguards to protect him from mobs of adoring fans - women who say he's made them feel empowered, and men who say he's made them feel manly. Both sexes agree he has revolutionised their bodies.

My own obsession began a year ago while I was living in the Philippine capital, Manila, where it's easier than ever to avoid exercise, thanks to the hideous traffic, heat, almost total lack of parks, and choking pollution. A Spanish friend had heard about taebo classes starting at a local dance studio, and was keen to try it. She didn't want to be the only huge, red-faced, sweating white devil in a gym full of well-toned, giggling Filipinos, so I went along too.

The teacher, Vanessa, was a petite, charming woman with the face of a cute little chipmunk. She also had the kind of back muscles to shame a stevedore, like a pair of sleeping pythons on each side of her spine.

She had trained in New York to teach a kind of taebo called power boxing, which, she explained, was basically a mixture of tae-kwon-do and kickboxing moves set to aerobic speed dance music, along with a bit of circuit training and floor work incorporating the principles of Pilates. "You won't recognise your body within a month," she said. I smirked. Little did she know that after this class I would be back to my life of sofas and cocktails.

First off was the warm-up, and then some demonstrations and advice on punching and kicking. "You may find you get quite carried away, but the most important thing to remember is never to lock or snap your elbows or knees," Vanessa warned.

The class progressed through punches in single, double and half time, uppercuts, hooks, elbow swings, speed bag punches, strong punches, shuffling, side kicks and front kicks. There were push-ups, sit-ups, and all manner of running on the spot and arm movements that made me feel my limbs were exploding with lactic acid.

Cardiovascular exercise had surely never been so painful, but Vanessa would brook no wilting, and darted around, yelling: "Hit the guy in the chin!" and: "Come on, draw blood!"

It was an extraordinary experience. At first we were all a bit self-conscious, but within no time I could see the utter absorption on everyone's faces reflected in the huge gym mirror. Some people looked genuinely, sneeringly, Taxi Driver unhinged as they beat their imaginary opponents to a pulp. Others were grunting with determination. There was an awful lot of laughing and pointing, too, though - when we could catch our breath, of course.

"My God," my friend said afterwards. "I never knew how much frustration and aggression I must have bottled up all the time. I've only just realised that I normally have a constant, slight tightness in my chest - and the only reason I've noticed is because now it's gone." I was physically shattered, but had truly never experienced such an adrenalin or endorphin rush from exercise.

Like mad pyramid scheme salesmen, we begged all our friends to come along - as everyone else had clearly done, too. By the next class, the gym was heaving. I started going twice or even three times a week.

Within a fortnight, real muscle definition started to appear from the depths of the quivering lard covering my upper arms and stomach. Aside from the stamina and control I developed, being able to leap in the air and kick a spot millimetres from someone's nose turned out to be a very successful party trick. One woman told me that taebo gave her the kind of high she had previously only got from shoplifting or designer drugs.

My boyfriend was less than impressed with me practising my kicks on him, but even he had to admit the effects were amazing. I was calmer, more confident, and yet had enough energy to go out dancing till dawn three nights a week. And thanks to the support from those strengthened stomach muscles, the low-level back pain I'd suffered for a few years disappeared completely.

I was bereft when I left the Philippines - and a large part of this was due to leaving taebo. But the mania is starting to take off here, too. When launched in Britain six months ago, Billy Blanks's video went straight to number one and has stayed there. His second video goes on sale this week, and taebo-style classes will soon be coming to a gym near you.

He overcame this to become a black belt in six different martial arts, won a raft of international gold medals and appeared in movies and on TV, most notably the kickboxing episode of Ally McBeal. The taebo idea came to him 20 years ago while he was going through his moves to dance music - and noticed how quickly he became breathless. He started teaching it 12 years ago in California, and now trains a whole host of celebrity converts including Pamela Anderson, Brandy, Brooke Shields - and Jennifer Aniston. In the States, the man is huge. He has his own pay-per-view television channel, Taebo TV, and his video, launched two years ago, has sold 30m copies. In the street he needs bodyguards to protect him from mobs of adoring fans - women who say he's made them feel empowered, and men who say he's made them feel manly. Both sexes agree he has revolutionised their bodies. My own obsession began a year ago while I was living in the Philippine capital, Manila, where it's easier than ever to avoid exercise, thanks to the hideous traffic, heat, almost total lack of parks, and choking pollution. A Spanish friend had heard about taebo classes starting at a local dance studio, and was keen to try it. She didn't want to be the only huge, red-faced, sweating white devil in a gym full of well-toned, giggling Filipinos, so I went along too. The teacher, Vanessa, was a petite, charming woman with the face of a cute little chipmunk. She also had the kind of back muscles to shame a stevedore, like a pair of sleeping pythons on each side of her spine. She had trained in New York to teach a kind of taebo called power boxing, which, she explained, was basically a mixture of tae-kwon-do and kickboxing moves set to aerobic speed dance music, along with a bit of circuit training and floor work incorporating the principles of Pilates. "You won't recognise your body within a month," she said. I smirked. Little did she know that after this class I would be back to my life of sofas and cocktails. First off was the warm-up, and then some demonstrations and advice on punching and kicking. "You may find you get quite carried away, but the most important thing to remember is never to lock or snap your elbows or knees," Vanessa warned. The class progressed through punches in single, double and half time, uppercuts, hooks, elbow swings, speed bag punches, strong punches, shuffling, side kicks and front kicks. There were push-ups, sit-ups, and all manner of running on the spot and arm movements that made me feel my limbs were exploding with lactic acid. Cardiovascular exercise had surely never been so painful, but Vanessa would brook no wilting, and darted around, yelling: "Hit the guy in the chin!" and: "Come on, draw blood!" It was an extraordinary experience. At first we were all a bit self-conscious, but within no time I could see the utter absorption on everyone's faces reflected in the huge gym mirror. Some people looked genuinely, sneeringly, Taxi Driver unhinged as they beat their imaginary opponents to a pulp. Others were grunting with determination. There was an awful lot of laughing and pointing, too, though - when we could catch our breath, of course. "My God," my friend said afterwards. "I never knew how much frustration and aggression I must have bottled up all the time. I've only just realised that I normally have a constant, slight tightness in my chest - and the only reason I've noticed is because now it's gone." I was physically shattered, but had truly never experienced such an adrenalin or endorphin rush from exercise. Like mad pyramid scheme salesmen, we begged all our friends to come along - as everyone else had clearly done, too. By the next class, the gym was heaving. I started going twice or even three times a week. Within a fortnight, real muscle definition started to appear from the depths of the quivering lard covering my upper arms and stomach. Aside from the stamina and control I developed, being able to leap in the air and kick a spot millimetres from someone's nose turned out to be a very successful party trick. One woman told me that taebo gave her the kind of high she had previously only got from shoplifting or designer drugs. My boyfriend was less than impressed with me practising my kicks on him, but even he had to admit the effects were amazing. I was calmer, more confident, and yet had enough energy to go out dancing till dawn three nights a week. And thanks to the support from those strengthened stomach muscles, the low-level back pain I'd suffered for a few years disappeared completely. I was bereft when I left the Philippines - and a large part of this was due to leaving taebo. But the mania is starting to take off here, too. When launched in Britain six months ago, Billy Blanks's video went straight to number one and has stayed there. His second video goes on sale this week, and taebo-style classes will soon be coming to a gym near you.

fields.headline: Prescription for a free lunch
fields.standfirst: A new report says GPs are sent 56,000 pages of promotional material by drug firms each year. Does any of it influence them? Of course it does, says  Dr Theodore Dalrymple
fields.trailText: A diligent researcher has estimated that the average GP in this country receives 56,000 pages of advertising material from pharmaceutical companies every year through the post. Since this is only an estimate (in fact, an extrapolation from a count of pages received over a period of four months), the true figure might be only 42,000; on the other hand, it might be 70,000. It seems hardly to matter.
fields.body:
A diligent researcher has estimated that the average GP in this country receives 56,000 pages of advertising material from pharmaceutical companies every year through the post. Since this is only an estimate (in fact, an extrapolation from a count of pages received over a period of four months), the true figure might be only 42,000; on the other hand, it might be 70,000. It seems hardly to matter.

I should like to be able to say that none of this material has any effect whatever upon the prescribing habits of doctors: that each and every prescription was the outcome of a purely rational decision based solely upon the patient's diagnosis and a scientific consideration of the relative advantages and disadvantages of the various possible drugs.

As we know, however, many extraneous considerations come into prescribing decisions. For example, prescriptions for psychotropic medication - antidepressants, tranquillisers and so forth - are handed out to young men in our inner cities not because the drugs will do them any good, but because they want them, and their doctors are afraid of them. A little bit of what they fancy is the easiest way to get them out of the surgery. And fear is a great prescriber.

As for advertising, we doctors are surrounded by it. It seeps into our lives like damp into walls. Although I do not see company representatives and throw all promotional material straight into the bin, I find that on my desk on which I write this there is a stand for pencils advertising an antidepressant, a clock advertising another antidepressant, two pens advertising respectively an antibiotic and a drug for dementia, and a memo pad advertising Viagra. I have never prescribed Viagra and quite possibly never will; but if I ever have to, it is most unlikely that I shall have forgotten its name. What, then, is the little memo pad for?

More important, how did it get there? I have never seen a representative of the company that manufactures this drug. Do drug companies employ itinerant people to scatter promotional material in the dead of night? It puts me in mind of evangelists who used to leave leaflets in trains, in the days when carriages had compartments.

Almost all medical meetings are now sponsored by drug companies. The very sandwiches (or quiches) one eats at them are paid for by these firms. It must be admitted that the quality of the catering has improved immensely since the companies took over from the NHS, which (I am convinced) once had a secret underground facility for making sandwiches for every hospital in the country, since all NHS sandwiches were exactly the same. But is it right that as we prescribe, we should be accumulating quiche for the future?

As a hospital doctor, I am sometimes offered trips to meetings abroad, all expenses paid. Once - but only once - I succumbed to our national obsession with getting something for nothing; it is curious, is it not, how even quite prosperous and well-fed people are willing to make considerable efforts to obtain a free meal of only moderate quality?

I discovered on my trip that there were doctors whose proud boast it was that they had been around the world without having spent a single penny of their own money. They greeted one another with questions such as "Did you go to Prague?" or "I missed Venice, what was it like?" They were completely mystified when I decided to go out to dinner with some acquaintances in the city to which I had travelled, a dinner for which I should have to pay myself; for what was the point of going on a drug company trip if you ended up paying anything for yourself? They even sent a bill to the drug company for their taxis to the airport. And they ate and drank for the same reason that people first climbed Mount Everest: because it was there.

I can't even remember now what drug it was that the companies were promoting in that far-off luxury hotel. The lectures about it were deadly dull and held in an overheated conference hall in which most people went to sleep, dreaming of the next table d'hte.

I vowed never to go on such an outing again: and, most unusually, I have stuck to my resolution. If I really want to go to Rio or Florence, I'll pay for myself. And needless to say, I am not in the least influenced in my prescribing by any promotional material whatever: though just now and again, on those rare occasions when I am stuck for an answer, I cast my eye around my desk for inspiration.

fields.headline: Seeing is believing
fields.standfirst: Ultrasoundings
fields.trailText: Week 20
fields.body:
Week 20

I seem to have an early memory of seeing an ultrasound test on Playschool. Through the square window: a mummy exposing her globe of a belly with the navel inside out like the North Pole and a baby glowing on a screen ...

It can't be a real memory because it's in colour (70s beige and green) and we had a black and white telly till I was eight. I think that picture, with the doctor swishing the magic wand, the woman smiling, is a bit of Jungian flotsam - a mark of how much the ultrasound, rather than, say, the christening, has entered our collective unconscious as an icon of motherhood. Certainly it is the event most people ask after, though perhaps they want to get over as quickly as possible the moment when you press yet another blurred ultrasound photo into their palm.

It all makes for an excited atmosphere in the waiting room which, in my town, is indeed 70s green and beige. It's a shared moment: women bring their partners, their children or, if they are teenagers, their mothers. Lots seem to be. I think, as I think in all NHS waiting rooms, about how old, tall, well-nourished and rich I am, and how glad that I don't have acne any more.

No one chats much because you're advised to turn up with a full bladder to raise the uterus and, this being the NHS, there's a queue. We focus on old Hello! magazines with exquisite concentration and, if we still can, we cross our legs.

The image on the ultrasound screen doesn't look like a baby. It looks like outer space, with the nurse's indicator moving randomly over galaxies, black holes, the Milky Way, settling on a constellation she declares to be a brain. Then I see it, too, clear as Orion in the sky: the outline of a head, a nose, a moving arm, and the whole thing is as teary and epiphanic as generally advertised. Baby waves: we giggle. It briefly occurs to me that the horror of finding something wrong or something missing in this much-hyped moment must be extreme.

They did give me a little black and white photo to take away. I'm very fond of it: Baby in profile to the waist (they don't tell you gender in my hospital), lying on his/her back, hands raised in benediction, very peaceful and ancient-looking. They certified that he/she was an "active singleton", which pleases me, since most of my friends are active singletons, too. They also gave me - and this I was unprepared for - a set of her measurements, together with a graph so I can chart them against the national average. My baby's girth, I learn, is in the 97th percentile of largeness, but his legs only in the 55th. She is the shape of a power lifter, in other words, of a sumo wrestler, of Ganesh the Elephant God.

Already, I am worried. I had wanted, above all things, for my baby to inherit from his father the long, fleet legs that allowed him to sprint past playground tormentors and grow up with an intact body image. Already, I am talking myself into maternal self-blame: that long abdomen and those short limbs are mine, and they're hopeless in trousers and stumpy round the track. Baby will never be able to wear hipsters and PE teachers will torture him, and it will all be my genetic fault. I expect the nurse spent ages on the brain because the self-doubt cortex was abnormally large.

And this is only Baby's first measuring. She will be given national scores at birth, at four, at 11, at 16. Never, in fact, have mothers had access to such a wide spectrum of scores: not just physical but mental, psychological, genetic. I'll know whether or not Baby is smiling, burping, crawling, drawing, relating to his peers, playing games or recognising farmyard noises at the right time.

It's not that I'll blame him, either. Instead, I'll debate endlessly whether it is my genes that are causing it, or something in the too stimulating/not stimulating environment I provide, or even the glass of champagne I drank at the millennium, since the latest survey says that embryos whose mothers drink don't respond so well to whistles in the womb.

I wish I knew none of these things. Or knew them and didn't care. I wish I could accept this first child as if he were the last of seven and love him and nourish him and be equably, vaguely surprised when he turned out to have long legs or short ones, to enjoy chemistry or be a champion sprinter. I wish I could keep looking at him like a constellation of immeasurable stars and be awed and moved each time they took on a human, recognisable form.

fields.headline: The definitive guide
fields.standfirst: What works?
fields.trailText: The definitive guide to treating common ailments
fields.body:
The definitive guide to treating common ailments

No 24: Complications of diabetes

About 2% of people in the UK are known to be diabetic and numbers are growing. Among the possible complications are renal disease, which can cause kidney failure; retinopathy, which can cause blindness; and foot ulcers, which may lead to amputation. Yet these problems can often be prevented with regular health checks and treatment where necessary.

Renal disease

Increased glucose in the blood, a symptom of diabetes, is associated with progressive damage to the kidneys, although symptoms may not show up until the kidneys are on the point of failure. A US study of people with non-insulin dependent (NID) or "type two" diabetes, the most common form, found more than 1% developed renal failure over 10 years. But the problem can be detected in its early stages by urine tests for raised levels of protein.

Researchers, after assessing numerous studies, recommend people with NID should have urine tests at least annually. Surveys suggest less than two-thirds do. Blood pressure and blood glucose levels - added risk factors for renal disease - also need monitoring. Where protein levels are abnormal, ACE inhibitors - normally taken to control blood pressure - can reduce renal disease, according to studies. Intensive treatment programmes, which combine ACE inhibitors, control of blood pressure, blood glucose and lipids (fats), diet advice, exercise and quitting smoking, can significantly reduce renal disease in people with low, but above normal, protein in urine, another major study shows.

Retinopathy

Diabetic retinopathy is the most common cause of acquired blindness in working-age people in industrialised countries. The problem occurs when blood vessels in the retina become blocked, causing new vessels to form. It often goes undetected in early stages. One study has estimated that annual eye tests and treatment with lasers could prevent 260 cases a year.

Foot ulcers

About 15% of people with diabetes develop foot ulcers due to nerve damage or reduced blood supply. These can lead to serious infections and - for up to 15% of sufferers (2% of all diabetics) - amputation. Regular inspections and careful foot care can substantially reduce amputations, a large trial has shown.

fields.headline: A different person
fields.standfirst: A car crash left Nick Monroe with such severe head injuries that he was not expected to survive. He tells how he learned to live with brain damage that radically changed his character
fields.trailText: A car crash left Nick Monroe with such severe head injuries that he was not expected to survive. He tells how he learned to live with brain damage that radically changed his character
fields.body:
Before the car crash I was extremely motivated and focused. My future was pretty much mapped out as a high achiever in the world of sport. I was 21, about to enter my second year studying for a degree in physical education and English at university.

But nothing ever prepares you for the unexpected in life. While touring France in a car in August 1994 the driver dozed off at the wheel at 70mph. I was asleep when we hit a tree head on. Wearing a safety belt undoubtedly saved my life, but my head took the full brunt of the force. Though my lower body ended up in the engine block, my forehead smashed into the dashboard, breaking it in half. My skull shattered into 50 parts. I don't remember anything of the crash, though I was lucid immediately after impact.

At first, neurosurgeons at Marseilles hospital signed me off as another road statistic - the front lobe of my brain was virtually irreparable and in intensive care I was too weak for surgery. But 72 hours later, doctors decided I was stable enough for surgeons to piece back together the bits of skull bone like a jigsaw puzzle. For the next five weeks, I suffered from post traumatic amnesia - even today, the actual crash is a blank.

Then a month later at Brooks Hospital, south London, I underwent a second critical operation. Doctors had to remove the pieces of skull to make way for continuing brain swelling and fix a membrane tear because fluid began leaking through my nose. Those 11 weeks in hospital were extremely hazy, as were the subsequent months convalescing at home.

There was no outside provision for help, so my parents were left to care for me around the clock. I was sleeping 18 hours a day and felt like a zombie. I'd lost just under three stone in weight and resembled a prisoner of war. I was extremely irritable and aggressive.

With up to one million people in the UK a year attending hospital with a head injury, there is a common misconception that head injury victims suffer brain damage and lose IQ points. Yet IQ often remains unaffected and in fact the damage is often largely psychological. I suffered from frighteningly quick and frequent mood swings. I'd turn vile and vitriolic in an instant - swearing, shouting, criticising, almost in tears because I couldn't cope with the intensity of so many raw emotions.

Yet I had always been so patient, calm and level-headed. Now I felt completely at the mercy of my emotions. It was so extreme: I'd feel hysterically happy or bitterly upset. I'd laugh or cry in an instant. I was behaving totally out of character. Bored and frustrated, I craved outside stimulation and in September 1985 I decided to go back to college convinced I could pick up from pre-crash days - convinced nothing had changed.

But I was psychologically a different person, with no awareness of my own situation, the new limitations and potential difficulties. I didn't even know I had a short-term memory problem until a few weeks into my course when it became obvious I couldn't cope. The crash had somehow damaged my body clock, so I was still going to bed at 3am and not waking until midday. I missed all the morning lectures and felt very de-motivated, unwilling to catch up. It was a downward spiral. I couldn't concentrate or contribute during the six hourly daily lectures and, because of the head injuries, was excluded from playing many sports - football, rugby, squash, diving, underwater swimming, gymnastics.

For the first time in my academic life I was underachieving so badly I was forced to give up the course by spring. I hadn't experienced failing before and, out of character, began spending money I didn't have impulsively and recklessly. I had no job, no social group, no career, and no prospects. It was obvious I needed rehabilitation, yet there was nothing available locally on the NHS. Instead, in August 1986, I started a 13-month private residence rehab programme, which cost £40,000, paid for by insurance damages. I was lucky. A psychologist had assessed and negotiated the compensation. Failing that, there was no other available or nearby option to help aid my recovery.

By now I was totally unmotivated, lacked confidence and any self-discipline. The treatment worked on that bit by bit - forcing me to get up early, wash and brush my teeth or play computer games when the programme is set to fail, so the player has to constantly deal and learn with their limitations. Rehab for head injuries is critical sooner rather than later. Afterwards, I immediately worked as an assistant newsagent rising at 4.30am six days a week for five months, then as a record shop sales assistant, interacting with new confidence with customers. Next I was a youth worker helping all the local youth organisations.

Meanwhile, my father won his tireless campaign to the local health council and social services to recognise head injuries as a separate "hidden" disability and set up a local branch of Headway in 1992. I've learnt to write lists obsessively and prioritise - the only way I can remember everything. Psychologically, my behaviour is less acute, though irritability, low tolerance and surface emotions are still evident.

For personal guidance, I worked out a structure for my life and lowered my expectations, then gradually came to terms with my limitations by identifying them and working within them. Now I lead a full, rewarding and productive life because I have set different goals to achieve. Up to 15 times a day, I am reminded of my brain injury - albeit for a split second. You can never escape or forget it. Yet with the uninitiated in society, the lack of awareness surrounding head injuries tends to invite a negative attitude through ignorance or insensitivity. Though I am registered disabled, I want to be treated like anybody else.

Head Injury, the Facts, Gronwall & Wrightson, published by Oxford University Press, £8.99.

I was 21, about to enter my second year studying for a degree in physical education and English at university. But nothing ever prepares you for the unexpected in life. While touring France in a car in August 1994 the driver dozed off at the wheel at 70mph. I was asleep when we hit a tree head on. Wearing a safety belt undoubtedly saved my life, but my head took the full brunt of the force. Though my lower body ended up in the engine block, my forehead smashed into the dashboard, breaking it in half. My skull shattered into 50 parts. I don't remember anything of the crash, though I was lucid immediately after impact. At first, neurosurgeons at Marseilles hospital signed me off as another road statistic - the front lobe of my brain was virtually irreparable and in intensive care I was too weak for surgery. But 72 hours later, doctors decided I was stable enough for surgeons to piece back together the bits of skull bone like a jigsaw puzzle. For the next five weeks, I suffered from post traumatic amnesia - even today, the actual crash is a blank. Then a month later at Brooks Hospital, south London, I underwent a second critical operation. Doctors had to remove the pieces of skull to make way for continuing brain swelling and fix a membrane tear because fluid began leaking through my nose. Those 11 weeks in hospital were extremely hazy, as were the subsequent months convalescing at home. There was no outside provision for help, so my parents were left to care for me around the clock. I was sleeping 18 hours a day and felt like a zombie. I'd lost just under three stone in weight and resembled a prisoner of war. I was extremely irritable and aggressive. With up to one million people in the UK a year attending hospital with a head injury, there is a common misconception that head injury victims suffer brain damage and lose IQ points. Yet IQ often remains unaffected and in fact the damage is often largely psychological. I suffered from frighteningly quick and frequent mood swings. I'd turn vile and vitriolic in an instant - swearing, shouting, criticising, almost in tears because I couldn't cope with the intensity of so many raw emotions. Yet I had always been so patient, calm and level-headed. Now I felt completely at the mercy of my emotions. It was so extreme: I'd feel hysterically happy or bitterly upset. I'd laugh or cry in an instant. I was behaving totally out of character. Bored and frustrated, I craved outside stimulation and in September 1985 I decided to go back to college convinced I could pick up from pre-crash days - convinced nothing had changed. But I was psychologically a different person, with no awareness of my own situation, the new limitations and potential difficulties. I didn't even know I had a short-term memory problem until a few weeks into my course when it became obvious I couldn't cope. The crash had somehow damaged my body clock, so I was still going to bed at 3am and not waking until midday. I missed all the morning lectures and felt very de-motivated, unwilling to catch up. It was a downward spiral. I couldn't concentrate or contribute during the six hourly daily lectures and, because of the head injuries, was excluded from playing many sports - football, rugby, squash, diving, underwater swimming, gymnastics. For the first time in my academic life I was underachieving so badly I was forced to give up the course by spring. I hadn't experienced failing before and, out of character, began spending money I didn't have impulsively and recklessly. I had no job, no social group, no career, and no prospects. It was obvious I needed rehabilitation, yet there was nothing available locally on the NHS. Instead, in August 1986, I started a 13-month private residence rehab programme, which cost £40,000, paid for by insurance damages. I was lucky. A psychologist had assessed and negotiated the compensation. Failing that, there was no other available or nearby option to help aid my recovery. By now I was totally unmotivated, lacked confidence and any self-discipline. The treatment worked on that bit by bit - forcing me to get up early, wash and brush my teeth or play computer games when the programme is set to fail, so the player has to constantly deal and learn with their limitations. Rehab for head injuries is critical sooner rather than later. Afterwards, I immediately worked as an assistant newsagent rising at 4.30am six days a week for five months, then as a record shop sales assistant, interacting with new confidence with customers. Next I was a youth worker helping all the local youth organisations. Meanwhile, my father won his tireless campaign to the local health council and social services to recognise head injuries as a separate "hidden" disability and set up a local branch of Headway in 1992. I've learnt to write lists obsessively and prioritise - the only way I can remember everything. Psychologically, my behaviour is less acute, though irritability, low tolerance and surface emotions are still evident. For personal guidance, I worked out a structure for my life and lowered my expectations, then gradually came to terms with my limitations by identifying them and working within them. Now I lead a full, rewarding and productive life because I have set different goals to achieve. Up to 15 times a day, I am reminded of my brain injury - albeit for a split second. You can never escape or forget it. Yet with the uninitiated in society, the lack of awareness surrounding head injuries tends to invite a negative attitude through ignorance or insensitivity. Though I am registered disabled, I want to be treated like anybody else. Contacts Headway - the brain injury association - 4 King Edward Court, King Edward Street, Nottingham NG1 1EW. fields.headline: Dear doctor
fields.standfirst: Dr Ann Robinson on health
fields.trailText: Dr Ann Robinson on health
fields.body:
Scared to start a family

Q After recent work-related stress, my husband developed a rash on the shaft of his penis, along with neuralgia and tingling in the penis and soreness in the scrotum. One doctor said it was thrush but a second said the symptoms pointed to genital herpes. I have had cold sores round my mouth but we have been careful to avoid oral sex when I had the sores. We had hoped to start a family this year but are now afraid to. Please advise us what to do next.

A It may have been genital herpes, which causes tiny blisters, often heralded by burning of the skin, swollen glands and feeling unwell. Persistent pain after they have healed is unusual and your husband may like to try lignocaine gel. If it was herpes, it may have been your husband's first attack, or a recurrence triggered by stress. He may have caught herpes during oral sex even if you didn't have a cold sore at the time because the virus can persist even if no blisters are apparent.

If you have never had genital herpes, you can have a blood test to check that you have antibodies to both types of the virus. It can be dangerous for a baby to be delivered vaginally if you are having a first attack of herpes, but if you have antibodies in your bloodstream already, it means you won't have a first attack when you give birth. You need to ask your GP to refer you to a specialist genito-urinary or sexually transmitted diseases clinic. After a few basic tests, you should be reassured and ready to try for that pregnancy.

For more info, call the Herpes Virus Association on 020-7609 9061.

I want my immunity back

Q I have myeloma, cancer of the blood cells, which has been successfully treated with chemotherapy and an autologous stem cell transplant from my own bone marrow. My blood counts have largely recovered but I am rarely without a heavy respiratory infection. Oral antibiotics are a help but I feel my immune system has been devastated and wonder what I can do to help it recover.

A Professor Grant Prentice, haematologist at the Royal Free Hospital, says that myeloma affects your immune system because it attacks plasma cells in the bone marrow. Myeloma causes bone pain, anaemia and kidney damage. Chemotherapy, radiotherapy and autologous marrow transplants aim to halt the progress of the disease. Allogenic transplants from a donor can offer a cure. After a transplant such as yours, immunity may be further impaired for up to a year. However, after that, if your disease is in remission, you should bounce back. Meanwhile, don't smoke, eat a balanced diet and exercise. Professor Prentice does not advise extra supplements or a special diet. If you develop a serious viral illness like shingles, you may be knocked for six so seek urgent expert help.

Three jabs or one?

Q We have a daughter who has just turned one. With that date came an invitation for the MMR jab. We have heard that the vaccines are available in their constituent parts and would be happier to pursue this option. Could you tell me whether these vaccines are available individually?

A I don't think giving three separate jabs instead of one is kind to your child, or scientifically valid. The proposed link between autism and MMR hasn't been supported by other studies. Worries about measles and Crohn's disease have been largely disproved. Moreover, there is no evidence to suggest that giving the three components (measles, mumps, rubella) separately makes them safer. You can get the rubella jab in this country but the mumps jab on its own is less effective than the strain in MMR, and the measles is not available at all. I think the jabs should be offered separately to those that want it; but I would choose the single MMR.

webTitle: Seven out of 10 office staff prefer grander job title to pay rise

fields.headline: Seven out of 10 office staff prefer grander job title to pay rise
fields.trailText: Seven out of 10 office workers would consider forgoing a pay rise if they were offered a more pompous job title instead, a survey found yesterday.
fields.body:
Seven out of 10 office workers would consider forgoing a pay rise if they were offered a more pompous job title instead, a survey found yesterday.

Filing clerks would do without more money if they could become "data storage specialists". Tea ladies want to be "catering supervisors", product designers "envisioners" and creative assistants "chief imagination officers".

The most numerous of them all, secretaries, want to be called "executaries". The survey by the consultants Office Angels covered 1,500 office workers.

Its results confirm that the snobbery among manual workers, which led dustmen to try to transmogrify themselves into "refuse disposal operators", has penetrated deep into their white collar colleagues.

The spur is that 70% of employees believe people they meet after work judge them instantly by their titles. The consultants said this had been accelerated by a spread of self-important US-style job titles and by wordier job descriptions in e-commerce posts.

Around 70% of those questioned said that they might give up a bigger pay cheque for a more "motivational or professional" job title to make their role seem more dynamic and inspirational.

But the same number said snobbery about titles caused envy at work. Some 90% of employers agreed this was true, although most of them defended titles as essential to the structure of a firm.

Judi James, author of the Office Jungle, said of the survey yesterday: "New job titles can make people feel more valued and motivated, as well as more confident in social situations. But a title should reflect the job being carried out and not just become a meaningless label."

fields.headline: The Pokemon phenomenon
fields.standfirst:
Find out more about the movie on Film Unlimited
What are the Pokemon? A bluffer's guide
fields.trailText: Tuesday, 3pm: Film Unlimited editor Xan Brooks on the critters that are sweeping the nation. Plus: a bluffer's guide to the Pokemon.
fields.body:
Moral-majority types hunting a link between screen violence and the real McCoy may have finally found their smoking gun with the release of Pokemon: The First Movie. On screen, the animated fable tells the story of an ideological showdown between good and bad Pokemon. Off-screen, the phenomenon was the subject of a rather more grubby encounter on the streets of Swindon when two 10-year-olds were allegedly robbed of £200 worth of Pokemon cards at knife-point. The alleged 13-year-old culprits have duly been charged, and local police have advised that Swindon nippers henceforth keep their cards under lock and key at home.

Were this an isolated incident, we may still give Pokemon the benefit of the doubt. But the Pokemon craze has already amassed a number of casualties. Numerous British schools have banned the cartoon critters (the stars of both trading cards and Game Boys) from their premises (on one occasion after a child's arm was broken in a Pokemon-related dispute). In the US, too, the characters are the cause of pitch battles between avaricious schoolkids. Most notoriously, the TV cartoon has been held directly responsible for the hospitalisation of a phalanx of Japanese children: in 1997, some 685 viewers suffered epileptic seizures brought on by the animation's unique brand of red and blue strobe-lighting. Clearly, the Pokemon are not a force to be messed with.

Short for 'pocket monsters', the phenomenon first appeared four years ago in the form of a Nintendo GameBoy. From here, the winsome cartoon munchkins quickly spread out into TV, trading cards, comic-books and (as of this year) movies. Kids can follow the adventures of the rudimentarily designed heroes and are encouraged to collect the full 150 Pokemon on a series of illustrated cards that sell for £2.50 for a pack of five. In the US, the arrival of The First Movie caused a frenzy among the nation's pre-teens. One ticket giveaway caused the entire Warner Bros voice-mail system to crash under the weight of an estimated 70,000 messages per minute.

In terms of youth trends, of course, Pokemon is nothing new. The past decade has witnessed a series of computer games repackaged as bona-fide feature films, from Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles at the start of the 90s, through Super Mario Brothers and Mortal Kombat. Paramount Studios are currently planning a big-budget film treatment of Tomb Raider starring Oscar-winner Angelina Jolie as kick-arse virtual heroine Lara Croft. None, though, have triggered quite so much mass hysteria as the winsome, mewling, button-eyed Pokemon.

Could it be that there's a lesson in all of this? Because while the old screen-violence debate has been rumbling since the year dot, conservative pressure groups have traditionally targeted the adult end of the market: your Natural Born Killers, Crashes and the like. Maybe they're picking on the wrong movies. A few years ago a Birmingham schoolboy hanged himself due (at least in part) to an obsession with The Lion King. The Gloucestershire home of serial killer Fred West was full of Disney videos. Now along comes Pokemon. Whether screen violence begats real violence is still up for debate. But if it does, if a link can conclusively be proved, it seems much more likely to stem from the family rack of your local Blockbuster and infect pre-teens as much as lone adult gunmen. It's that innocuous fodder you have to keep an eye on; the little folk who cause all the trouble.

Pokemon: a bluffer's guide

What exactly is Pokemon?
Pronounced POH-KAY-MOHN, it started life in Japan four years ago as a Nintendo GameBoy computer game. In Japanese, Pokemon means 'pocket monster'. Its creator Satoshi Tajiri locked himself away for three years until he came up with the idea, and it took another five before it was ready for the shops.

What is the aim of the game?
The hero of the game is a 10-year-old boy called Ash Ketchum who is already a Pokemon trainer, but desperately wants to be a Pokemon master. To become a master he needs to catch all 150 Pokemon monsters lurking on Pokemon Island. He does this by zapping them with a Poke Ball. Ash is accompanied by Pikachu, a rodent who unleashes thunderflashes when annoyed.

So, just another daft children's craze then?
Hardly. Pokemon may eventually go the way of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, Cabbage Patch Dolls, Tamagotchis, Furbies etc etc, but not yet. The craze has spawned a £3bn industry and has spread to the US and now Britain. The game has been followed by toys, cards, video games, a cartoon series and a film. There is, inevitably, a Pokemon website - www.pokemon.com.
Nick Hopkins

fields.headline: Art galleries
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about art on the net
fields.trailText: 1. The art world takes a step nearer the orthodoxies of e-commerce as two of its strongest brands (sorry, galleries) go into partnership to sell their wares online.
fields.body:
1. The art world takes a step nearer the orthodoxies of e-commerce as two of its strongest brands (sorry, galleries) go into partnership to sell their wares online.

2. New York's Museum of Modern Art is launching a collaboration with Britain's Tate Gallery to offer such items as Bauhaus-inspired teapots to design-lovers on both sides of the Atlantic.

3. As is the case with most e-entrepeneurs, Tate director Sir Nicholas Serota hopes the new enterprise can become the Amazon.com of the international furniture and lighting world.

4. The Tate, which opens its acclaimed modern art gallery on London's Bankside (pictured) next month, is going from strength to strength.

5. Now buy the t-shirt.

6. Their collection, which includes work by Francis Bacon, Henri Matisse and Turner Prize winner Steve McQueen is, however, not for sale.

7. For that kind of thing you would have to turn to an online auction such as crisis-hit Sotheby's.

8. Many web designers have an art school background but art on the net is often restricted to older paintings and sculptures scanned into computer files.

9. Web-specific work, called digital art, has its own galleries online and often plays with the feelings of uncertainty and paranoia many feel on the net.

10. But is it art?

webTitle: European markets slide after early recovery

fields.headline: European markets slide after early recovery
fields.trailText: European markets slipped back in nervous trading today after an early bounce amid concerns that the global rally sparked by the US on Monday would fizzle out.
fields.body:
European markets slipped back in nervous trading today after an early bounce amid concerns that the global rally sparked by the US on Monday would fizzle out.

The battered technology, media and telecommunications sectors held on to early gains, but many "old economy" shares in traditional manufacturing and finance failed to take a lead from their peers' recovery in the US yesterday.

Earlier, Asia's shaky stock markets rebounded, with only Japan's Nikkei ending lower, following big gains in the Dow Jones and Nasdaq indices in the US on Monday.

But the Dow Jones industrial average was expected to open (2.30pm our time) as much as 100 points down and the technology-heavy Nasdaq about the same, dashing hopes of a sustained rally. A series of earnings reports due from leading American technology companies, such as Intel and IBM, is expected to dominate US trading.

By mid-morning, the pan-European Eurotop index of 300 shares was up 2.89 points, or 0.19%, at 1,539.09, while the narrower Euro Stoxx index of 50 blue chip euro zone shares was up 30.43 points, or 0.61%, at 5,010.09.

"People were never going to chase this market up and then have it come back in their face," said the London head of sales at a leading European brokerage.

Among leading European markets, London's FTSE 100 was up 0.01%, Frankfurt's Dax was down 0.4%, and Paris's CAC was down 0.3%. European shares were led by technology, media and telecommunications stocks, with the DJStoxx technology index up 2.6%, media 2.3% and telecommunications 1.25%. All three had earlier been more than 3% higher.

Britain's Marconi was the biggest gainer, up 6.1%, followed by Finnish telecommunications firm Nokia, up 5.5%, and Dutch firm Philips Electronics NV, which gained 5%. Earlier, Asian markets had recovered most of Monday's losses following a sharp recovery in US shares. Japan's Nikkei 225 index closed at 18,969.52, down 39.12 points or 0.21% after rising as much as 1.7% early on.

Hong Kong's Hang Seng index rose 3.5% to 15,278.32, boosted by demand for China Telecom (Hong Kong). Korea's KOSPI index - Asia's biggest casualty in Monday's sell-off - surged 5%, while Australia's S&P/ASX 200 bounced back 2.5%.

US stock futures fell in early trading amid concern that yesterday's rally may not represent the start of a sustained rebound. Analysts said that yesterday's rise did not mean that the market had hit bottom and that companies had to report staggeringly good profits for shares to move higher.

Japan's Nikkei 225 index closed at 18,969.52, down 39.12 points or 0.21% after rising as much as 1.7% early on. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index rose 3.5% to 15,278.32, boosted by demand for China Telecom (Hong Kong). webTitle: Siege at London immigration appeal court

fields.headline: Siege at London immigration appeal court
fields.standfirst: 11am: Listen to Gwyn Topham's eyewitness audio account of the siege
fields.trailText: Armed police and riot squads were called to Britain's immigration appeals HQ today after a knife-wielding Turkish asylum seeker threatened to kill himself.
fields.body:
Armed police and riot squads were called to Britain's immigration appeals HQ today after a knife-wielding Turkish asylum seeker threatened to kill himself.

A police armed response unit, including a hostage negotiator and two ambulances, rushed to Rosebery Avenue in Clerkenwell, east London, at 10.23am fearing staff might be trapped inside.

However, Scotland Yard confirmed later that the floor of the building had been successfully evacuated before the siege began as the refugee demanded to be allowed to stay in the UK.

Earlier, the man had been granted an adjournment in his appeal hearing to submit medical reports after the Home Office rejected his asylum application. He is thought to have a history of mental illness

A squad of 20 riot police with shields and batons, backed by armed officers, entered the office block.

The incident ended peacefully an hour later when the man, believed to be a Kurd in his early 30s, gave himself up after being allowed to speak to his pregnant wife. He emerged with a blanket over his head and was driven off to hospital in a police van to be treated for a cut to a hand.

Judge Hubert Dunn QC, the chief immigration adjudicator who was in the building at the time, said: "There was a Turkish case applying for refugee status. We have been informed by his advisers that he was on medication and did not take it this morning.

"His application for an adjournment was granted by the adjudicator and outside the court he produced a knife and asked to be granted what he called 'immigration status', meaning refugee status, and it was a very threatening and alarming situation.

"The man had a sharp knife pointed at his own throat for half an hour."

Taylor House has 21 courts and is also responsible for centres in west London, Birmingham, Leeds., Manchester, Cardiff, Havant, Glasgow and Belfast.

Appeals are decided within four months and the total nationally will top 60,000 this year - more than 25% up on the 48,000 last year.

Judge Dunn denied the increasingly bitter political debate over asylum seekers had heightened tensions in the appeals system. "We stay totally out of the politics and therefore I would not say there has been an increase in tension," he said.

fields.headline: Could South Africa be next?
fields.standfirst: Liz McGregor analyses crucial differences which mean the current land dispute in Zimbabwe is unlikely to be replicated in its southern neighbour
fields.trailText: Liz McGregor analyses crucial differences which mean the current land dispute in Zimbabwe is unlikely to be replicated in its southern neighbour.
fields.body:
White farmers in Zimbabwe today, white farmers in South Africa tomorrow? The question is a fair one, given the similarities in land distribution between the two countries. In both, whites own most of the best land and their ownership is rooted in wars of conquest. Even land that has changed hands subsequently remains largely in white hands. Blood was shed to create the current territorial configuration so it is unsurprising, if deeply disappointing, that blood is being shed to create a new one.

In both South Africa and Zimbabwe, whites hold land individually: one man (and invariably it is a man) is lord of thousands of arable acres. Blacks' claims to land tend to be collective: thousands of people, nominally from the same tribe, herded into what is usually arid, mountainous or rain-starved territory.

And in both countries, the amount of arable land amounts to a very small proportion of the total. Most of it is infertile. Hostile climates - years-long droughts followed by flash floods - further confound any efforts at cultivation. Increasingly, land in South Africa is being given over to wild animals, which were born to its inhospitable conditions and thrive in them. They are now being profitably farmed for hunting, tourism and meat.

In both countries, land ownership has always been highly political. In South Africa, as well as seizing vast tracts of arable land from blacks to give to whites, the apartheid government handed out huge subsidies to the Afrikaner farmers who made up the heart of the ruling National party.

Most black workers were treated like dirt but those on the farms were invariably the most abused. Workers were not infrequently beaten to death by their bosses; they were paid barely enough to feed their families; education and health care were rudimentary. Ditto in Zimbabwe. And in both countries, the tables are now turned: black farmer workers back the government of the day, which in turn courts their votes.

Attachment to land is visceral and highly emotional. Tribal religions embrace ancestor worship. Ancestral graves are usually in tribal homelands and are sacred. Afrikaners, the white tribe of South Africa, also tend to be rural people, with a fanatical attachment to the land.

But there are differences between the whites of Zimbabwe and their southern neighbours which make the latter more secure. Zimbabwean farmers form a small, discrete, racially homogenous group who generate envy by their comparative wealth. Whites have been in South Africa much longer; they form a much bigger proportion of the population and are far more integrated. Many identified with the black struggle against white supremacists and fought alongside their black countrymen. They are part of the new government. And, crucially, Nelson Mandela, unlike Robert Mugabe, instituted a programme of land reform as soon as he came to power. In fact, the land minister responsible for carrying it out was a former white activist, Derek Hanekom. A substantial proportion of land appropriated from blacks by the South African apartheid government has been bought back from white owners and given back to the original black owners, who were also given grants to buy the tools and seeds they needed to make a success of it. It was a fraught process, involving much painstaking negotiation. But if the mess in Zimbabwe is any indication, the effort was infinitely worthwhile.
