fields.headline: Village cricketer wins Oscar
fields.trailText: In the average season a decent club cricketer might expect to pick up an award or two. Leading 2nd XI wicket-taker, perhaps, or maybe Best Teas. But on Oscars night in glitzy Hollywood, amid a sea of champagne and cleavage, opportunity knocked in a big way for Sam Mendes of Shipton-under-Wychwood CC. He walked off with the Academy Award for Best Director, one of five Oscars for his debut film American Beauty.
fields.body:
In the average season a decent club cricketer might expect to pick up an award or two. Leading 2nd XI wicket-taker, perhaps, or maybe Best Teas. But on Oscars night in glitzy Hollywood, amid a sea of champagne and cleavage, opportunity knocked in a big way for Sam Mendes of Shipton-under-Wychwood CC. He walked off with the Academy Award for Best Director, one of five Oscars for his debut film American Beauty.

Mendes's cricketing highlight came in 1997, when Shipton, from Oxfordshire, reached the Village Championship final at Lord's. Wisden says that they overcame Milstead in the semi-final "thanks to a late flurry from Sam Mendes, the well-known theatre director, who hit 48 from just 26 balls". The final didn't go according to the script, though. In a sombre affair overshadowed by the death of the Princess of Wales that morning, Caldy, from the Wirral, beat Shipton by 56 runs. Mendes, batting at No. 7, managed only 8 in the forlorn run-chase although, as our picture shows, he certainly looked the part before he was spectacularly bowled.

Mendes, now 34, was a more than useful allrounder in his days at Magdalen College School in Oxford. Wisden records that he made 301 runs and took 37 wickets in 1981, and improved on that the following year when, as captain, he had 601 runs at 40 and 46 wickets at 15. And after another good year in 1983 (552 runs and 37 wickets) he played for The Rest against the Southern Schools, one of the selection matches for the England Schools team. Batting for a while with John Stephenson, Mendes made 28 in the second innings before being bowled by William Tebbit, offspinning son of former Cabinet minister Norman.

Mendes said recently that in his teens he was on course to go professional, but he didn't have the stamina to play cricket six days a week. One report suggested that he played at Cambridge with Mike Atherton, but the Former England Captain couldn't remember that, and was slightly unimpressed by our suggestion that it might have been in a college game: "I'm afraid I never played an inter-college match at Cambridge."

Sir Aubrey Smith, who captained England once before moving to Hollywood for a distinguished film career, never quite won an Academy Award, so WCM asked Sir Tim Rice, a triple Oscar-winner himself, whether he thought Mendes was the best cricketer to lift one. "I should think so," he confirmed. "He scored an excellent 59 for Harold Pinter's Gaieties against my Heartaches CC a couple of years ago." Sir Tim baffled most of Hollywood when he thanked Denis Compton in his own Oscar acceptance speech, but Sam Mendes stuck to a more traditional line and length, remembering his colleagues at London's Donmar Warehouse Theatre as well as the usual family and friends.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

This piece appears in the May edition of Wisden Cricket Monthly, currently on sale at all good newsagents in the UK and Ireland, priced £2.90

fields.headline: Mighty mouse
fields.standfirst: From the outside, the brave new world of genetics is all about computers and cutting edge technology. In fact, it's dependent on something much simpler: mice. Obese mice, diabetic mice, musclebound mice, even fluorescent mice. And now, reports  James Meek, a bitter legal battle over a new variety
fields.trailText: From the outside, the brave new world of genetics is all about computers and cutting edge technology. In fact, it's dependent on something much simpler: mice. Obese mice, diabetic mice, musclebound mice, even fluorescent mice. And now, reports  James Meek, a bitter legal battle over a new variety
fields.body:
In October this year, a jury in San Francisco will make a decision in one of the new millennium's most bizarre and complex court cases. Teams of elite lawyers will have spent weeks studying and arguing over crates of laboratory notes, letters and emails, prised from the reluctant hands of some of America's leading medical researchers. The case is a landmark battle between the public and the private sector - between a rapidly growing Dublin-based pharmaceutical firm, Elan, and an influential non-profit medical research organisation, the Mayo Foundation. At stake in this epic struggle: who owns a mouse.

Few people have heard of mouse TG2576. But the mouse, and its descendants, are mighty mice. Pound for pound, they are probably the most expensive animals in the world: a breeding trio of males is said to be worth more than half a million pounds. TG2576, also known as the Hsiao Mouse after its creator Karen Hsiao-Ashe, is precious because it is demented. It is born to contract Alzheimer's disease. Dr Hsiao-Ashe, of the University of Minnesota, designed it that way.

Known as a "transgenic mouse", its genes, and thus the genes of its offspring, are artificially altered so that its cells produce a mutant human protein which has been implicated in Alzheimer's. When the mice are 10 months old, they begin, reliably, to get senile. They forget things they were just taught. A mouse with Alzheimer's disease is a gateway to beating the illness. That makes it valuable to the millions of Alzheimer's sufferers around the world (500,000 in the UK, 4m in the US), to the researchers trying to find a cure, and to the shareholders of the firms trying to get cures to market.

The Minnesota-based Mayo Foundation - which provides Hsiao mice at cost to academic researchers around the world, and sells them to commercial companies - refused to say how much the private sector was prepared to pay for the animals. But Mayo neuroscientist Steven Younkin, one of Hsaio's collaborators, says: "Let's take a figure of, say, $2m. Do you think any firm working seriously on a treatment with a potential annual market of $150bn is going to stop for $2m? It's a drop in the bucket."

One of those firms is Elan. Its share price has shot up since it began trials of a vaccine which may prevent or treat Alzheimer's. The vaccine was developed with the help of another, secret strain of Alzheimer's mouse which Elan created. Unlike the Hsiao mouse, the Elan mouse is not universally available, and not for sale. But keeping its mouse under lock and key is not enough for Elan: it wants to prevent distribution of the Hsiao mouse as well, accusing Mayo of infringing Elan's patents on a third strain of mouse. Hence the court battle.

Elan refuses to say what its ultimate goal is in suing Mayo. "It is Elan's policy to enforce its intellectual property rights," says company spokesman Max Gershenoff. "Beyond that we cannot comment on any on-going litigation." Mayo's Dr Younkin was more forthcoming. Like other researchers across the US, he has been ordered to make research notes and data available for the case. (One indignant colleague told the journal Nature that he would rather go to prison than surrender his notes.)

"I think [Elan's] strategy is, 'Let's make sure we make all the money we possibly can, and if it slows down research, that's too bad. We've got our shareholders to worry about,'" says Dr Younkin. "Karen decided on day one that she was giving her mouse to any academic researcher who asked for it."

Mice have never been so big. The world of medical research, and much of the rest of the world besides, is agog at the wondrous possibilities for miracle cures and extended lifespans offered by the great project to decipher the 3bn letter genetic code which makes humans humans - the human genome project. On the outside, it is a work of robotics and computers, of dizzyingly powerful microscopes and cell manipulation machinery. On the inside, it's about mice. The machines churn out the genes: only the mice, whose genetic make-up is humblingly similar to our own, can tell us what the genes do.

"At conferences people are swapping their mice around, arranging marriages between mice," says Dr Denis Alexander, who has helped design mice to investigate the human immune system at the Babraham Institute outside Cambridge. "You can't even measure how much slower research would be if it wasn't for the transgenic mice. The genome project would be throwing out all these genes and you wouldn't be able to do experiments. To do it the traditional way, you'd be talking about hundreds of years of work. If we didn't have these mice we'd still be in the immunological dark ages."

The mice are not as nature made them, but mice as men and women fabricated them. In the early days of patent mice, there were mutant mice: researchers would bombard hordes of mice with radiation or put special chemicals in their drinking water, pick out chance mutations which seemed interesting, and breed the mutants up. This was how the Obese Mouse, the Diabetic Mouse and the Muscular Dystrophy Mouse were produced. Others, like the Nude Mouse, were made by simple inbreeding. Then, from the 1980s onwards, came transgenic mice - mice with genes added, usually human genes - and knockout mice, which have genes taken away to see what will happen.

The total number of man-made mice strains is impossible to calculate, because many firms have made mice in secret. But one guess is 2-3,000, with new mice being announced every week, all mimicking some human flaw. There are Huntington's disease mice and cystic fibrosis mice, mice that get cancer, mice with bad hearts, diabetic mice and asthmatic mice.

Not all the mice are doomed to suffer from birth. In 1997, US scientists produced a "Schwarzenegger" knockout mouse with two to three times normal muscle mass. Another supermouse was kitted out with a human gene which made it resistant to heart disease. Last year, Italian scientists announced a knockout mouse which lived up to a third longer than conventional mice; in the US, the Mahogany Mouse ate and ate and stayed thin.

Other knockout mice - neurotic mice, mice susceptible to cocaine addiction - have led researchers to make contested claims about the relationship between mental states and genes. Faith in the mouse as model for human frailties is extraordinarily strong among scientists. If there were to be a common epitaph on the graves of biotech companies whose bold new treatments for people failed, it would be: "It worked on mice." Yet there is a powerful feeling in some research camps, like the Alzheimer's camp, that the long-awaited pay-off for sick humans is on the horizon, and the mice are to be thanked.

"The mice they've made are the most important advances in disease research to have been made in recent years," says Dr Simon Lovestone, a British Alzheimer's researcher. "It's no exaggeration to say drugs will be made that will actually treat this disease within five or 10 years."

Figures from the home office, which keeps scrupulous records on every mouse which passes through British labs, tell their own story. Since 1977, when 3.3m scientific "procedures" on mice were carried out, the number has more than halved to 1.6m. But in the 90s, the number of procedures on transgenic and knockout mice soared, from only 48,000 in 1990 to nearly half a million in 1998. In the rush for gene gold and prizes, the increase is expected to continue. Scientists can get mouse embryos or full-grown mice by post; they can even order them over the internet.

"You can just go through the web, make a request for a particular mouse strain and we will send it off to you," says Professor Steve Brown, of the Medical Research Council's big mouse house at Harwell. Prof Brown's speciality is deaf mice.

Researchers love tailor-made mice for many reasons. Because their natural lifespans are short, the effects of their altered genes show up early. They breed quickly. They don't take up much space. And scientists don't take as much flak from animal rights campaigners and anti-vivisectionists for using them. They're more like people than flies or worms are, but not as genetically close to us as monkeys, or as emotionally close as dogs.

Besides, research teams have overwhelmingly powerful allies - the human sufferers from disease and their relatives. With Alzheimer's alone, that means campaigners against animal experiments in Britain must always be looking over their shoulders at the suffering of half a million people and the anguish of millions more family members. Some of these, doubtless, would rather see the disease left unconquered in humans than have a single mouse given the condition artificially for their sakes. But, historically, the public has always been readier to accept animal suffering to alleviate human suffering than to entertain hunters and gourmands or to test cosmetics.

While wary, scientists are not particularly defensive where mice are concerned. At the Babraham Institute, Dr Alexander rarely sees his mice; genetically modified to have a failed immune system, they are kept in an airtight, windowless, germ-free world. No one can have access to them without stripping, showering, shampooing and going through an airlock. "They are very well looked after. I call it mouse paradise myself," he says. "They get fed, watered, looked after, the temperature is controlled and there are no cats. What more could a mouse want?"

Dr Lovestone, who formerly worked with mice, says: "Sometimes you have this cognitive distance. You look after the mice fabulously carefully, and then you come home and spread poison around to try to get rid of mice from your own house."

This was how the Obese Mouse, the Diabetic Mouse and the Muscular Dystrophy Mouse were produced. Others, like the Nude Mouse, were made by simple inbreeding. Then, from the 1980s onwards, came transgenic mice - mice with genes added, usually human genes - and knockout mice, which have genes taken away to see what will happen. The total number of man-made mice strains is impossible to calculate, because many firms have made mice in secret. But one guess is 2-3,000, with new mice being announced every week, all mimicking some human flaw. There are Huntington's disease mice and cystic fibrosis mice, mice that get cancer, mice with bad hearts, diabetic mice and asthmatic mice. Not all the mice are doomed to suffer from birth. In 1997, US scientists produced a "Schwarzenegger" knockout mouse with two to three times normal muscle mass. Another supermouse was kitted out with a human gene which made it resistant to heart disease. Last year, Italian scientists announced a knockout mouse which lived up to a third longer than conventional mice; in the US, the Mahogany Mouse ate and ate and stayed thin. Other knockout mice - neurotic mice, mice susceptible to cocaine addiction - have led researchers to make contested claims about the relationship between mental states and genes. Faith in the mouse as model for human frailties is extraordinarily strong among scientists. If there were to be a common epitaph on the graves of biotech companies whose bold new treatments for people failed, it would be: "It worked on mice." Yet there is a powerful feeling in some research camps, like the Alzheimer's camp, that the long-awaited pay-off for sick humans is on the horizon, and the mice are to be thanked. "The mice they've made are the most important advances in disease research to have been made in recent years," says Dr Simon Lovestone, a British Alzheimer's researcher. "It's no exaggeration to say drugs will be made that will actually treat this disease within five or 10 years." Figures from the home office, which keeps scrupulous records on every mouse which passes through British labs, tell their own story. Since 1977, when 3.3m scientific "procedures" on mice were carried out, the number has more than halved to 1.6m. But in the 90s, the number of procedures on transgenic and knockout mice soared, from only 48,000 in 1990 to nearly half a million in 1998. In the rush for gene gold and prizes, the increase is expected to continue. Scientists can get mouse embryos or full-grown mice by post; they can even order them over the internet. "You can just go through the web, make a request for a particular mouse strain and we will send it off to you," says Professor Steve Brown, of the Medical Research Council's big mouse house at Harwell. Prof Brown's speciality is deaf mice. Researchers love tailor-made mice for many reasons. Because their natural lifespans are short, the effects of their altered genes show up early. They breed quickly. They don't take up much space. And scientists don't take as much flak from animal rights campaigners and anti-vivisectionists for using them. They're more like people than flies or worms are, but not as genetically close to us as monkeys, or as emotionally close as dogs. Besides, research teams have overwhelmingly powerful allies - the human sufferers from disease and their relatives. With Alzheimer's alone, that means campaigners against animal experiments in Britain must always be looking over their shoulders at the suffering of half a million people and the anguish of millions more family members. Some of these, doubtless, would rather see the disease left unconquered in humans than have a single mouse given the condition artificially for their sakes. But, historically, the public has always been readier to accept animal suffering to alleviate human suffering than to entertain hunters and gourmands or to test cosmetics. While wary, scientists are not particularly defensive where mice are concerned. At the Babraham Institute, Dr Alexander rarely sees his mice; genetically modified to have a failed immune system, they are kept in an airtight, windowless, germ-free world. No one can have access to them without stripping, showering, shampooing and going through an airlock. "They are very well looked after. I call it mouse paradise myself," he says. "They get fed, watered, looked after, the temperature is controlled and there are no cats. What more could a mouse want?" Dr Lovestone, who formerly worked with mice, says: "Sometimes you have this cognitive distance. You look after the mice fabulously carefully, and then you come home and spread poison around to try to get rid of mice from your own house."

webTitle: A week of cricket - for half the population

fields.headline: A week of cricket - for half the population
fields.standfirst: Catherine Hanley on an innovation by ICC which left women on the sidelines
fields.trailText: So that was ICC's Cricket Week. Sky Sports broadcast a special series of quizzes, reminiscences, documentaries called Cricket Around the World, and finished up with coverage of Asia v Rest of the World. But did anyone else notice something missing from all these programmes?
fields.body:
So that was ICC's Cricket Week. Sky Sports broadcast a special series of quizzes, reminiscences, documentaries called Cricket Around the World, and finished up with coverage of Asia v Rest of the World. But did anyone else notice something missing from all these programmes?

The Asia v Rest of the World game was a fantastic advert for cricket, an enthralling match, enjoyed by a large crowd, which went down to the last ball. Shame there were no women there to see it, really. Throughout the entire day I managed to spot only one woman in the stadium, and she was one of the sponsors in the presentation party.

At various times in the week I watched some of the Cricket Around the World programmes, showing the development of the game in different countries. Here again, very few women or girls were in evidence, except in New Caledonia, where a non-traditional form of cricket has arisen which the commentator rather disdainfully described as a 'women's game'. All the other features I saw involved male cricketers of various ages. ICC's ambassadors and other coaches interviewed spoke in a very PC manner about training 'children', 'kids' or 'youngsters'. But let's be honest: what they actually meant was 'boys'.

All this demonstrates three things. One: there aren't enough women watching the game. Two: there aren't enough women playing the game. And three: ICC aren't doing enough about it. If they're going to develop cricket around the world, why concentrate on only half the population? There are many reasons why ICC ought to be encouraging girls to play - not least that girls might actually be glad of the opportunity. The old argument about women's cricket being less skilful or exciting would be negated: if it is less skilful then it's probably because girls aren't able to pick up the required techniques early in life, nor do they get the opportunity to practise. Encourage girls to play when they are young and the women's game can only get better.

A second reason, and perhaps one more to the taste of money-conscious cricket boards everywhere, is that women who have learned to play cricket are more likely to become paying spectators later on. A number of my friends who find cricket boring do so because they have no idea about the rules or how the game works. There's a huge untapped market out there of women who could be playing or spectating but aren't, and who won't be until attitudes change.

Ah, attitudes. The curse of any female cricket player or fan.

Let's get this straight: I am not, nor could ever be, a top-class cricketer - but then neither are many of the men who play for local clubs and villages every week. I do, however, stand up for my right to be able to play the game and enjoy it, something which is very difficult to do if there's no local club. I also defend my right to spectate at a game of any standard without being patronised or made to feel uncomfortable.

I watch a lot of cricket, for the simple reason that I love the game. I'll watch Tests, one-dayers, county games, club and village cricket, men's, women's ... hell, I'll stop by and watch Eckington Under-11s if I get the chance. But the same attitudes are found everywhere. Reasons I watch cricket do not include ogling the players (as suggested by someone sitting behind me at Old Trafford last year), or simply accompanying a male relative to a match, as assumed by the idiot in the suit who sat next to me at Headingley. Incidentally, I watched the entire match: he spent half of it in the hospitality tent.

Luckily, attitudes like this don't bother me too much. They do, however, bother a lot of women who might otherwise be paying good money to watch a game. ICC (and cricket authorities in general) are hitting their own wicket by not realising this and doing something about it.

Catherine Hanley is a postgraduate in medieval French literature at Sheffield University

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's tittle-tattle tied up in a bow
fields.trailText: The Mirror Leeds will look to spend £20m on strengthening their squad this summer. Olivier Dacourt and Carl Cort are manager David O'Leary's top targets as he hopes to avoid the burnout which has hampered his team's prospects this season. O'Leary also has his eye on Monaco's young Norwegian midfielder John Arne Riise.
fields.body:
The Mirror Leeds will look to spend £20m on strengthening their squad this summer. Olivier Dacourt and Carl Cort are manager David O'Leary's top targets as he hopes to avoid the burnout which has hampered his team's prospects this season. O'Leary also has his eye on Monaco's young Norwegian midfielder John Arne Riise.

Jason Euell has submitted his third transfer request to Wimbledon in six weeks. A source close to the England Under-21 international said: "Egil Olsen has said he won't keep an unhappy player, yet he continues to reject Jason's request. Jason is unhappy. So why do the club refuse him?"

West Ham's Marc Vivien Foe could make a £5m return to France this summer. Champions Monaco are interested in signing the Cameroonian international, and Harry Redknapp will be willing to sell as he needs money to complete the signing of striker Frederic Kanoute.

Planet football Officials at PSV Eindhoven believe that Ruud van Nistelrooy will join Manchester United this summer. Club president Harry Van Raaij believes the only thing that would prevent the completion of the deal would be United buying Patrick Kluivert instead.

The Sun Sunderland will make a second attempt to sign Wimbledon's Ben Thatcher. Peter Reid joins Liverpool, Spurs and West Ham in pursuing the £5m-rated left-back.

Major League Soccer will offer to take Paul Gascoigne on loan from Middlesbrough in a deal that would last until September.

Daily Star Martin O'Neill has promised to spend his £11m windfall from the sale of Emile Heskey - but only on top stars. "We've earned the right to look at quality players," said O'Neill. "I have to be on the lookout now for decent players at other clubs who aren't fitting in and may fancy it here."

Teamtalk Arsenal have denied they are interested in signing Bordeaux's French international striker Sylvain Wiltord. However the Gunners remain confident of obtaining Marseille captain Robert Pires' signature this summer.

fields.headline: Second white farmer shot dead
fields.trailText: A second white farmer was shot dead this morning, on the day Zimbabwe was due to celebrate two decades of independence from Britain.
fields.body:
A second white farmer was shot dead this morning, on the day Zimbabwe was due to celebrate two decades of independence from Britain.

Cattle rancher Martin Olds was the second farmer killed by squatters, who began taking over white-owned tracts of land in February.

The occupiers opened fire on Mr Olds about 0430 GMT, wounding him, said David Hasluck, director of the Commercial Farmers' Union, which represents white farmers. Mr Olds called for an ambulance by radio, but medical crews were unable to reach his home, which was surrounded by about 100 armed squatters, Mr Hasluck said.

After Mr Olds was shot, police chased the squatters away from his home in Nyamandhlvu, about 50 miles north of the western provincial capital, Bulawayo. They found the farmer, who was in his late 40s, dead from gunshot wounds.

The incident comes three days after the killing of David Stevens, a white farmer and supporter of the Movement for Democratic Change, the main opposition party to President Mugabe's regime. Five other white farmers were beaten Saturday near the Macheke farming district, 75 miles east of Harare. Police are searching for suspects, the state news agency reported.

"This thing will escalate until somebody takes a stand to stop it," said Chris Jarrett, a white farmer who lived near Mr Olds.

With the country suffering from its worst economic crisis and the violent occupations of white-owned farms by black war veterans, all national independence celebrations have been cancelled.

On Monday, President Mugabe abruptly summoned white farm leaders to his office and promised to personally intervene to "to get things back to normality" on the white-owned farms, said Tim Henwood, head of the farm union.

Government officials declined to comment on the president's first meeting with farm union officials since the occupations began two months ago. It was unclear whether Mr Mugabe's reported promise marked a reversal of his support for the thousands of armed black squatters who have occupied more than 900 white-owned farms.

But the president's televised address today, marking the anniversary of the country's independence, did little to defuse the tense situation in the country, "reminding" the nation that independence followed 90 years of "oppressive colonial settler rule" by Britain.

fields.headline: Fast track for Zimbabwe refugees
fields.standfirst: Straw clears way into UK for residents after farmer's murder
fields.trailText: Britain is preparing for an influx of Zimbabweans fleeing from the violent land battle which at the weekend led to the murders of a white farmer and two black members of the main opposition party.
fields.byline: Alan Travis  and  Andrew Meldrum  in Harare
fields.body:
Britain is preparing for an influx of Zimbabweans fleeing from the violent land battle which at the weekend led to the murders of a white farmer and two black members of the main opposition party.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, made clear yesterday that many of the new arrivals, who have British ancestry - if only one grandparent - are not expected to have to go through Britain's new "below the breadline" asylum system but instead will be given long-term permission to stay.

Both the European Union and the Commonwealth expressed extreme concern yesterday about the deteriorating situation in Zimbabwe, which is in danger of a descent into anarchy. Britain tried to ratchet up international pressure on the Zimbabwean president, Robert Mugabe, by pressing African nations to push for a "return to the rule of law" in the former British colony.

With the mood turning increasingly ugly in Harare, President Mugabe has remained unrepentant about the violence which has accompanied the occupation of at least 500 white-owned farms by supporters of his Zanu-PF party.

The widow of David Stevens, the farmer murdered at the weekend yesterday called on the world to persuade the Zimbabwean government to hold elections.

"We do need support from the outside world to be able to bring a democratic change," Maria Stevens said. "We need democratic countries to be our moral support."

Up to 20,000 Zimbabweans are believed to have the right to come to Britain. The long queues of those nervously applying to renew their British "certificate of entitlement" filled the halls of the offices of the British high commission in Harare's city centre yesterday.

"It was busy, very busy," said Richard Lindsay of the high commission.

Those who have a parent who was born in Britain are exempted from the asylum and immigration laws and can enter Britain freely on their Commonwealth passports, the Home Office said yesterday. They are entitled to claim British citizenship but have to obtain a certificate of entitle ment from the high commission before they travel.

The second group entitled to come to Britain without having to undergo the complex and lengthy asylum process, including dispersal and living on "below the breadline" vouchers, are those who can demonstrate that one of their grandparents was born in Britain.

Under the UK "ancestry regulations" those who can demonstrate a family connection are allowed to enter Britain for an initial period of four years without the need for a work permit. After four years they could apply to become a permanent resident.

"In many cases people from Zimbabwe may have grounds for coming here in any case because they have relatives who are British," said Mr Straw. "If their parents are British they have a right to come. It depends upon their ancestry."

webTitle: SNP takes European road to Scottish autonomy

fields.headline: SNP takes European road to Scottish autonomy
fields.standfirst:
Traditional Scottish nationalists have accused Alex Salmond of betrayal after the SNP changed its stance on independence. But Kirsty Scott argues that the party leadership has merely changed its tactics.

Talk of betrayal as SNP shifts stance on independence
fields.trailText: Traditional Scottish nationalists have accused Alex Salmond of betrayal after the SNP changed its stance on independence. But Kirsty Scott argues that the party leadership has merely changed its tactics
fields.body:
For the fundamentalists within the Scottish National party, freedom must always be the party creed. So it is little wonder that some are talking of betrayal over an apparent unwillingness by the party leadership to hammer home the independence message following the launch of the Scottish parliament.

In the first six months of the devolved body, the SNP leader, Alex Salmond, used the term "independence" just twice during speeches, and last week, during a speech to academics in London, he waxed lyrical, not about full autonomy, but about Holyrood with its partial powers.

But die-hards point beyond semantics to a recent strategy-shift on the means of securing independence as evidence that the leadership has softened its separatist stance.

In the past, the party planned to begin negotiations for independence as soon as they won an election in Scotland, before putting a final deal to the electorate in a referendum. Now, they would hold a referendum immediately after a successful election - before any negotiations were started.

The SNP leadership says the move merely ensures a positive outcome in a referendum, which stands a better chance of being won on principle rather than detail. It insists that independence remains the party's goal, and that to suggest otherwise is nonsensical.

But party leaders have good reason to tone down their separatist rhetoric, even if they are unwilling to admit they are doing so.

The independence of Braveheart fantasies no longer exists for Scotland. With Holyrood in place and the influence of the European Union growing, separation becomes not so much a clean break from Westminster as a way of merging into Europe. And the best route to Europe is through the Scottish parliament.

For all its first year hiccups, the nationalists see the Scottish parliament as their ticket to autonomy. Polls show Scots want the devolved body to have more powers than it has at present.

The job of Alex Salmond and his team is to convince voters that only the SNP can deliver autonomy. Banging on about freedom is unlikely to further that cause.

fields.headline: Témoin
fields.standfirst: Lahcen Mahroul, a Moroccan subject living in France, meets his king
fields.trailText: Lahcen Mahroul, a Moroccan subject living in France, meets his king
fields.body:
J 'ai été convié à la rencontre entre Sa Majesté le Roi Mohammed VI, alors en visite officielle en France, et 1300 membres de la communauté marocaine vivant sur le territoire français, en raison de mon dynamisme et de mon engagement au quotidien au sein de l'association que j'ai créée, Synergie Île de France, composée de Marocains ayant réussi professionnellement et souhaitant s'investir pour le développement du Maroc et des relations franco-marocaines.

Une quarantaine de Marocains et moi-même avons reçu, des mains du roi, la médaille du Mérite national. J'étais dans un état second, lorsque mon tour est arrivé. Mon cur battait la chamade ! J'étais bouleversé, rempli de joie et de fierté d'être ainsi honoré.

Contrairement à d'autres invités, je n'ai pas baisé la main du roi. Nous nous sommes serré la main très chaleureusement, à l'européenne, comme deux jeunes gens qui se sentent proches, s'apprécient, et partagent les mêmes ambitions pour leur pays !

Le roi m'a exprimé sa fierté de voir des jeunes comme moi réussir et véhiculer une image aussi positive du Maroc et des Marocains, intègres et intégrés. La reconnaissance du roi fait de moi un ambassadeur officieux du Maroc en France. Cet encouragement me pousse à m'investir encore plus pour construire un Maroc nouveau, jeune et dynamique, ouvert à la modernité et à la démocratie. Je me suis senti si fier de la confiance que le roi place en moi !

J'ai lu dans le regard du roi qu'il était également très fier et ému. Rencontrer ses sujets aussi fervents constituait le summum de sa visite officielle en France. Les instants que nous avons vécus resteront gravés à jamais dans nos mémoires. C'est l'un des meilleurs moments de ma vie.

mon coeur battait la chamade my heart was beating wildly
être convié à to be invited to
rempli de joie filled with delight
dans un état second in a trance

être intègre to be upright
fields.bodyText: J 'ai été convié à la rencontre entre Sa Majesté le Roi Mohammed VI, alors en visite officielle en France, et 1300 membres de la communauté marocaine vivant sur le territoire français, en raison de mon dynamisme et de mon engagement au quotidien au sein de l'association que j'ai créée, Synergie Île de France, composée de Marocains ayant réussi professionnellement et souhaitant s'investir pour le développement du Maroc et des relations franco-marocaines. Une quarantaine de Marocains et moi-même avons reçu, des mains du roi, la médaille du Mérite national. J'étais dans un état second, lorsque mon tour est arrivé. Mon cur battait la chamade ! J'étais bouleversé, rempli de joie et de fierté d'être ainsi honoré. Contrairement à d'autres invités, je n'ai pas baisé la main du roi. Nous nous sommes serré la main très chaleureusement, à l'européenne, comme deux jeunes gens qui se sentent proches, s'apprécient, et partagent les mêmes ambitions pour leur pays ! Le roi m'a exprimé sa fierté de voir des jeunes comme moi réussir et véhiculer une image aussi positive du Maroc et des Marocains, intègres et intégrés. La reconnaissance du roi fait de moi un ambassadeur officieux du Maroc en France. Cet encouragement me pousse à m'investir encore plus pour construire un Maroc nouveau, jeune et dynamique, ouvert à la modernité et à la démocratie. Je me suis senti si fier de la confiance que le roi place en moi ! J'ai lu dans le regard du roi qu'il était également très fier et ému. Rencontrer ses sujets aussi fervents constituait le summum de sa visite officielle en France. Les instants que nous avons vécus resteront gravés à jamais dans nos mémoires. C'est l'un des meilleurs moments de ma vie. fields.headline: Tortur Abitur?
fields.standfirst: Young Bavarians tell  Nicole Prestle  they are not happy about maths, German and a foreign language becoming compulsory subjects
fields.trailText: Young Bavarians tell Nicole Prestle they are not happy about maths, German and a foreign language becoming compulsory subjects
fields.body:
Wonnemonat Mai? Von wegen. Viele bayerischen Schüler fürchten diese kommenden Wochen, denn sie bringen unausweichlich auch die letzte Prüfung im Schulleben mit sich: das Abitur. Noch werden die Jugendlichen in Fächern abgefragt, die sie sich - mit gewissen Einschränkungen - selbst aussuchen durften. Zwei schriftliche Klausuren in den Hauptfächern, den sogenannten Leistungskursen, stehen an, eine weitere schriftliche und eine mündliche Prüfung in den Nebenfächern, den Grundkursen. Doch das könnte bald anders sein, denn: das Kultusministerium plant eine Reform der Kollegstufe. Vor allem mit Mathematik und anderen Naturwissenschaften stehen viele Abiturienten auf Kriegsfuss. Bisher konnten sie diese Fächer durch eine geschickte Wahl der Kurse beim Abitur noch außen vor lassen. Doch die Reform soll dieser Taktik einen Strich durch die Rechnung machen: Mathe, Deutsch und eine Fremdsprache sollen wieder zu Pflichtfächern werden, zwei weitere Richtungen können die Abiturienten selbst wählen. Mehr Allgemeinbildung ist angesagt. Was in Bayern noch Zukunftsmusik ist (die Reform tritt, wenn sie Realität wird, frühestens 2004 in Kraft), ist in Baden-Württemberg bereits beschlossene Sache. Los geht's dort ab 2002. Doch was Lehrer und Eltern gut finden, ist bei den Schülern längst nicht der Hit. Wir haben uns umgehört.

Fünf statt vier Abiturfächer. Kann diese Reform einer Spezialisierung entgegenwirken und das Allgemeinwissen von Schülern aufbessern oder überfordert sie die Prüflinge?

Natascha (14): Ich gehe selbst nicht aufs Gymnasium, sondern auf eine Förderschule. Aber daß die Schüler jetzt noch mehr pauken sollen, finde ich absolut blöd. Die ganzen Formeln in Mathe oder die Vokabeln in Fremdsprachen - das kann sich doch kein Mensch merken.

Michael (16): Ich gehöre genau in den Jahrgang, den die Reform einmal betreffen wird. Ich sehe darin allerdings keine Verbesserung. Man muß doch schon jetzt die meisten Fächer als Grundkurse belegen, nur daß man jetzt eben nicht in allen eine Prüfung ablegen muß. Aber das Wissen hat man doch trotzdem.

Ist das Wissen, das derzeit im Gymnasium vermittelt wird, ausreichend?

Andreas (13): Die Studenten kommen doch jetzt schon sehr weit mit ihrem Wissen. Warum sollte man also noch draufsatteln?

Michael: Naja, was man manchmal so von den Universitäten hört, ist schon fragwürdig. Zum Beispiel, daß manche Studenten eins und eins nicht zusammenzählen, oder keinen deutschen Satz sprechen können. Ich glaube, daß das alles nicht so schlimm ist, wie es immer heißt.

Natascha: Ich habe eine Freundin, die geht aufs Gymnasium. Die lernt jeden Tag von morgens bis abends. Ich glaube, die ist schon gescheit genug.

Christian (17): Ich denke, die Politiker haben einen Knopf in die ganze Sache gebracht: An der derzeitigen Debatte über Computerfachkräfte aus Indien sieht man doch, daß Leute mit Fachwissen gefragt sind. Jetzt will man mit dem Schulabschluß aber eine Spezialisierung verhindern und wieder das Allgemeinwissen stärken. Das widerspricht sich.

Seht Ihr Euch durch diese Pläne in Euren Wahlmöglichkeiten eingeschränkt?

Florian (12): Auf jeden Fall. Ich habe zum Beispiel den Horror vor Mathe. Eine bessere Lösung wäre, wenn man immer aus zwei Möglichkeiten auswählen könnte. Zum Beispiel eine Prüfung entweder in Mathe oder in Deutsch.

Andreas: Ich habe vor, in Deutsch und in Biologie Abi zu schreiben. Das geht ja auch nach der neuen Reform, glaube ich. Aber ich würde auch gerne Sport wählen, und damit sieht es schon schlechter aus.

Michael: In der Schule bin ich nicht gerade der Schlechteste, doch mein Abi-Schnitt wird sicherlich schlechter, wenn ich in Deutsch eine Prüfung schreiben muß. Und wenn man in der europäischen Konkurrenz auf einmal die schlechteren Abschlussnoten hat, kann das ja auch nicht Sinn der Sache sein.

Wird die Reform Jugendliche davor abschrecken, aufs Gymnasium zu gehen?

Christian: Kann ich mir gut vorstellen. Vielleicht gehen noch einige aufs Gymnasium, entschließen sich aber, schon nach der zehnten Klasse auf eine andere Schule zu wechseln, um dem Abi zu entgehen.

Natascha: Glaube ich nicht. Auch wenn man noch mehr lernen muß, setzt man dafür wahrscheinlich nicht seinen Abschluß aufs Spiel.

Würdet Ihr gerne etwas gegen die geplante Reform unternehmen?

Michael: Was mir stinkt ist, daß die Schülersprecher, die eigentlich etwas unternehmen könnten, alle in der Oberstufe sind. Deswegen interessiert sie das Thema gar nicht mehr. Sie schreiben dieses oder nächstes Jahr Abi in vier Fächern, und damit hat sich für sie die Angelegenheit.

Andreas: Wir haben mal kurz mit unserem Mathelehrer über das Thema gesprochen. Aber der findet die Reform gut. Ist ja auch klar. Das Abi hat er längst in der Tasche, und wenn Schüler lernen müssen, finden das die Lehrer immer gut.

Christian: Politisch kann man wohl kaum was unternehmen. Die Jungen in der CSU sagen nichts, weil die Idee von ihrer eigenen Partei kommt. Und die anderen Parteien, die können eh nichts ausrichten.

vor etwas abschrecken: to be put off from something
auf Kriegsfuß stehen: to be an enemy of, to hate
außen vor lassen: not to take into regard, to ignore
belegen: to choose a subject
draufsatteln: to do more, cram
einen Strich durch die Rechnung machen: to hinder somebody from doing something
fragwürdig: questionable
gescheit (coll): clever
die Kollegstufe: college grade
einen Knopf in etwas bringen (coll): to make a mistake
unausweichlich: inevitable
der Wonnemonat: month of bliss

webTitle: Farmer 'shot burglars like rats in a trap'

fields.headline: Farmer 'shot burglars like rats in a trap'
fields.trailText: A farmer accused of murdering a teenage burglar was a "man who was prepared to be a police force, investigating force, jury, judge and if necessary executioner", a court was told yesterday.
fields.body:
A farmer accused of murdering a teenage burglar was a "man who was prepared to be a police force, investigating force, jury, judge and if necessary executioner", a court was told yesterday.

A jury of six men and six women was told by the prosecution that the killing of Fred Barras, 16, at an isolated farmhouse last August, was not self-defence but murder by "a man willing to take the law into his own hands".

Tony Martin, 55, is accused of killing Mr Barras, a market trader from Newark, Nottinghamshire, during a late night bungled burglary. Mr Barras had entered Martin's property near Emneth, Norfolk.

Martin is also accused of attempting to murder, and unlawfully wounding, Brendon Fearon, 30, with intent to do him grievous bodily harm. He denies the charges, and another charge of possessing a firearm and ammunition with intent to injure life, but has pleaded guilty to the possession of a Winchester pump-action shotgun without a firearms certificate.

In her closing statement, Rosamund Horwood-Smart QC, prosecuting, told the jury that Martin lay in wait for the burglars and shot them like "rats in a trap".

She told Norwich crown court: "Mr Martin was a man that knew the power, force, and damage that a shotgun can inflict. He had that gun for one particular reason. He had that gun to use, if and when the occasion arose... to shoot any intruder who had the temerity to come in to his property, in to his home, on to his land."

Anthony Scrivener QC, defending, said Martin was a victim of crime who was acting in self-defence. He said the farmer had suffered a number of burglaries and had been visited by a "number of dangerous people" over the years. "He didn't want people to burgle his house. He was in a situation where he had to make some desperate decisions." The hearing continues.

webTitle: In brief and the latest casting news

fields.headline: In brief and the latest casting news
fields.trailText: Tim Robbins joins Being John Malkovich screenwriter's next project, a new director for the tale of a man who becomes a fish, Carrie-Anne Moss confirms Matrix involvement, Paul Newman's swansong, and the love life of Winona Ryder, episode 342.
fields.body:
Tim Robbins has signed to play a scientist in Human Nature, the new film scripted by Being John Malkovich writer Charlie Kaufman. Robbins will join Patricia Arquette and Welsh actor Rhys Ifans in what promises to be a madcap tale about a woman plagued by excess body hair and a boy raised as an ape in the jungle. Human Nature will be financed by a joint venture from New York indie production house Good Machine and the French media group Canal Plus. Michel Gondry is already down to direct.

Beavis and Butthead creator Mike Judge has been called in by Warner Bros with a view to co-writing and directing the studio's trouble-hit production The Incredible Mr Limpet. The eccentric part live-action part animation tale of a small-town nerd who becomes a fish who sabotaged Nazi U-boats, Limpet has been languishing in pre-production at Warners since the end of 1996. Last spring, original director Steve Odekerk quit over "creative differences", and last July Jim Carrey (who was due star as Mr Limpet) also bailed out. With Judge on board, Warners are expected to attempt to woo Carrey back on board. Judge made his name with the maverick TV shenanigans of Beavis and Butthead and King of the Hill, and made his directorial debut last year with Office Space (straight-to-video in the UK). Warners will be hoping that 'Limpet', will do better. But for now, they're probably just praying it will get made at all.

The Matrix franchise rolls on a-pace with the news that original star Carrie-Anne Moss has signed on to reprise her high-kicking role in two Matrix sequels, which begin production this autumn. Moss will join former cohort Keanu Reeves, and the Wachowski Brothers will once again direct. Moss will next play the role of Judi Dench's daughter in the Miramax production Chocolat, which begins shooting in France and England next month. Chocolat also stars Johnny Depp and will be helmed by Cider House Rules director Lasse Hallstrom.

Paul Newman fans take note: the 75-year-old actor plans to make one more film and then retire for good. Speaking on the David Letterman show, Newman said he would like to appear in one more movie, "as a swansong". Then, he said, "that will be it." The Oscar-winning actor was promoting his current role as an ageing bankrobber in the warmly received comedy-drama Where the Money Is when he dropped the bombshell. He also discussed the burgeoning success of his Newman's Own food business (most noted for its line of salad dressing). "It out-grosses my movies," quipped Newman. "It's humiliating."

The love-life of Winona Ryder: episode 342. Latest gossip links the elfin star of Girl, Interrupted with both Russell Crowe and Mark Wahlberg. Trouble is that she's officially still linked to long-time beau Matt Damon. The rumours were started, respectively by the magazine US Weekly and the tabloid paper The New York Post. US Weekly reported that Crowe and Damon almost came to blows over Winona at a post-Oscar party last month. The New York Post, meantime, speculated that Ryder had attempted to smooth over a purported career rivalry between Damon and Wahlberg, and ended up in bed with Wahlberg instead. Needless to say, both stories have been angrily denied by sources close to its respective stars. Dismissing the Wahlberg story, Damon spokeswoman Jennifer Glaisek could hardly contain her irritation. The nugget of gossip, she claimed, was "the dumbest story I've ever heard."

webTitle: Letters fail to crack Garbo's enigma

fields.headline: Letters fail to crack Garbo's enigma
fields.trailText: After all the fuss, it remained unclear last night whether Greta Garbo, the woman for whom the phrase screen legend might have been devised, was simply being coy when she said she wanted to be alone.
fields.body:
After all the fuss, it remained unclear last night whether Greta Garbo, the woman for whom the phrase screen legend might have been devised, was simply being coy when she said she wanted to be alone.

Previously private letters from Garbo to a friend, which some had hoped would confirm a lesbian relationship, turned out to be inconclusive. "The fact that the letters didn't say anything explicit, like 'I love you' or 'I need you', says a lot," said Karen Swenson, a Garbo biographer.

The star's grandniece, Gray Reisfield Horan, said: "I see nothing that refers to a liaison. I don't think there's much here to back it up. I only knew her to be interested in men."

The letters, opened on the 10th anniversary of Garbo's death at the age of 84, were written to the bisexual socialite and writer Mercedes de Acosta, whose own life was more notable for its associations than its achievements. De Acosta's circle included Eva Bartok, Cecil Beaton, Isadora Duncan and Igor Stravinsky. But it is her 55 Garbo letters, cards, notes and telegrams - part of a cache of 113 items which include poems, photographs and a tracing of one of the actress's feet - which have stimulated most interest recently.

Part of the collection will be on display from today until June 4 at the Rosenbach museum and library in Philadelphia. De Acosta gave the pieces to the institution 40 years ago on the condition that they should not be opened until 10 years after the death of Garbo or herself, whichever came later. The socialite died in 1968, Garbo 22 years later.

It had been suggested that the letters might offer some new insight into why Garbo retired from Hollywood in 1941 at the height of her fame. Instead, they mention travel plans, health, birthday wishes, diet and the meanderings of a 28-year friendship.

But Ms Swenson said that the book was not closed on the nature of their relationship. "People will interpret things however they want to," she said. "For anyone to have expected she would say anything explicitly was contrary to Garbo's nature."

"People will interpret things however they want to," she said. "For anyone to have expected she would say anything explicitly was contrary to Garbo's nature."

fields.headline: Oldman eyes role in Hannibal
fields.trailText: If negotiations are successful, the British actor would play the part of Mason Verger: a maimed, one-eyed, millionaire pederast whose level of wickedness makes Hannibal "the Cannibal" Lecter look a pussycat
fields.body:
As we reported on Friday,Gary Oldman is in negotiations to take a supporting role in Ridley Scott's adaptation of Hannibal. If successful, the British actor would play the part of Mason Verger: a maimed, one-eyed, millionaire pederast whose level of wickedness makes Hannibal "the Cannibal" Lecter look a pussycat in comparison.

In the bestselling novel by Thomas Harris, Mason Verger, having survived one of Lecter's attacks, plots a dastardly revenge on his former assailant. Verger plans to apprehend Lecter and feed him feet-first to a collection of "killer pigs" that he has imported specially from Sardinia.

The contents of the adapted screenplay, by Steve Zaillan, remains a closely guarded secret, but insiders have whispered that although the film-makers have tinkered with Harris's original ending, the basic plotline remains much as it is in the book.

The one hurdle that appeared to prevent Oldman from signing up for the film was the fact that the actor would have to take third billing behind Anthony Hopkins (as Lecter) and Julianne Moore (as FBI agent Clarice Starling). Discussions were thought to have broken down last week, but are now reported to be back on track. The role of Mason Verger, it would seem, is too succulent a morsel for Oldman to resist.

fields.headline: No: 1617 Christopher Robin
fields.body:
Age: Between four and six.

Appearance: Rosy-cheeked, cherubic little boy with floppy, blond fringe and short trousers.

Well, I must say, he's looking a bit rough for his age. Sorry, my mistake. I was talking about Christopher Robin, the character in AA Milne's Winnie the Pooh books, not Christopher Robin Milne, once rosy-cheeked, cherubic, etc, son of the author, who died in 1996, aged 75.

Easy mistake to make. One would have thought so. But no parallels should be drawn between the two.

Despite the fact that both were small and cute and had the same name? Well OK, there were a few similarities. But while Milne named the adorable little boy - playmate of Pooh, Tigger and Eyore - after his son, it seems he didn't intend readers to confuse the two.

Should have thought of that, shouldn't he? It does seem odd that he didn't foresee it. While Christopher Robin (fictional) enjoyed an idyllic childhood in a 100-acre wood with his furry little chums, Christopher Robin (fact) was having a rotten old time, mercilessly teased by his classmates for having a girl's haircut and a teddy bear as his best friend.

And dad didn't notice? On the contrary. While Milne was, by all accounts, an unemotional chap, a long-lost document has turned up at Sotheby's suggesting he was acutely aware of the hardship he caused his son. "It seems that the legal Christopher Robin has already had more publicity than I want for him," the author wrote in 1929.

It's not as if it's a common name. What was wrong with plain old Christopher? Milne gave his son two first names because, he admitted, he hoped he would play cricket for England, like WG Grace and CB Fry.

Lucky he didn't turn out to be a hairdresser, like Michaeljohn. Or a pop singer, like George Michael and Cliff Richard.

Don't say: "Hush! Hush! Whisper who dares! / Christopher Robin is saying his prayers."

Why not? Because he really, really didn't like it.

webTitle: For the love of a faint hearted feminist

fields.headline: For the love of a faint hearted feminist
fields.standfirst: In the 70s, her columns gave voice to women's mixed feelings about feminism. Now her work is being republished. Former women's editor  Liz Forgan pays tribute to the late, great Jill Tweedie
fields.trailText: In the National Portrait Gallery, next to Marco Pierre White, hangs a picture of five grey-faced hags grouped around a sofa. A pair of fat black-stockinged legs strikes a deadly diagonal across the composition. An air of deep gloom pervades. Who are these sombre witches and why does the picture still, seven years on, occupy a prime site on these walls of fame?
fields.body:
In the National Portrait Gallery, next to Marco Pierre White, hangs a picture of five grey-faced hags grouped around a sofa. A pair of fat black-stockinged legs strikes a deadly diagonal across the composition. An air of deep gloom pervades. Who are these sombre witches and why does the picture still, seven years on, occupy a prime site on these walls of fame?

The portrait is Sarah Raphael's depiction of a particular moment in the history of British feminism, personified in five women responsible for the Guardian's women's page in the 1970s. Like some sepia photograph from the trenches, it speaks of a vanished world, a world of gender politics, intelligent, ferocious and funny, of dungarees and liberation, wages for housework and female circumcision, sisterhood, patriarchy and battered women. Ancient history almost incomprehensible to a 25-year-old dot.com millionairess today.

The five women in the picture are Mary Stott, who began it all back in the 70s, columnists Jill Tweedie and Polly Toynbee, cartoonist Posy Simmonds and me, editor of the page (and owner of the regrettable legs). A week ago, four of the five reassembled in front of their likenesses to talk for Woman's Hour about the fifth, Jill Tweedie, who died of motor neurone disease soon after the picture was finished and whose illness breathes a pall of uncharacteristic misery over the scene.

The occasion was the republication of Jill's most brilliant book, In The Name Of Love, first published in 1979, a dazzling set of observations about love, sex, men and women which still stops you in your tracks 20 years on. Every platitude about gender differences is shaken to pieces through personal anecdote, true confession, anthropology, poetry and philosophy.

The book is a plea for liberation from all imposed shapes that twist the true nature of men and women. It is occasionally idiotic ("Before the industrial revolution, there was no Oedipus complex") but more often keenly acute. The men favoured by women have changed, she notes, since the arrival of the women's movement, with sugar daddies and macho men supplanted by baby-faced stars. Inequality is not just a matter of injustice but downgrades relationships into something functional. Far from needing to get in touch with their feelings, both men and women need to apply rationality to their lives and attitudes.

Women do not get an easy time. Passivity, manipulation and the retreat into sacrifice are exposed as despicable female manoeuvres. A woman who lives through her man is called a spiritual parasite. "That kind of love, so often called 'loyal' or 'self-sacrificing', I call the old-woman-of-the-sea syndrome. I'm afraid to get my feet wet. Carry me."

Her weekly column became an icon of all that was hairy and terrifying to men who found the women's movement a threat to their security. She was parodied, ridiculed and attacked. Mostly, though, she became a focal voice of women all over Britain who wrote to her in their thousands and took courage from her to look at the truth about their lives.

Jill's own life was full of disaster and tragedy as well as much happiness. She was implacably radical about her feminism but constantly tempered the grimness of the ideological struggle with hilarious tales of her own catastrophes. She could pour scorn like battery acid and defend the craziest of radical splinter groups just for love of revolutionary courage, but she was at bottom a wonderfully warm and balanced human being.

What women want above all, she wrote, "is to become real, to discard the mannered feminine mask and reveal the human being beneath, a person who is neither a Virgin Mary to be put on a pedestal, nor a Lilith to be obsessively desired, nor a Martha to wait at table; but simply a person sufficient unto herself, with her own talents and inadequacies, her own idiosyncrasies, good, bad or indifferent."

Men, as lovers, husbands, friends, sons, were as essential to Jill as her women friends. She was extremely beautiful and delighted in looking good, though the nature of that delight caused tortuous debate. Her radicalism never wavered but her honesty demanded that she explore the ambivalences feminists like her were scarcely able to confess to themselves, let alone to the world.

The result was Letters From A Faint-hearted Feminist, a new series of columns in which issues of central feminist ideology were put through the same critical wringer as the unthinking patriarchal orthodoxies that had been in her earlier columns. Could not you wear high heels with a boiler suit? Were beautiful clothes a gorgeous prison, or a legitimate choice for independent women? Was monogamy inevitably a road to servitude?

The cleverness of those columns was Jill's ability to admit to ambivalence, to weakness and to changing her mind without compromising her beliefs in equality, independence and the destructiveness of stereotypes. In their way, they were a bridge between the revolutionary battlefields of the 70s and the next generation who rightly took their freedoms for granted and saw no reason whatever to agonise about boiler suits or PhDs.

Jill never permitted despondency about the casual contempt in which the daughters of her contemporaries held the feminist movement. If they wanted to worship material gods and hurtle into marriage for the wrong reasons, that was the very freedom everyone had been fighting for, she said. In the end, she was optimistic that things got better: two steps forward and one back sometimes, but better.

"Looking about me," she wrote in 1989, "I see less ritual femininity and masculinity, and more human beings, less passion but more friendliness between the sexes, less dependency, more sharing. Despite setbacks, these things make a better breeding ground for real love than was available when I was young. The river may have gone underground for a little while, but it keeps on rolling, it keeps on rolling along." If so, it is no small thanks to Jill Tweedie.

webTitle: Jagger and Scorsese collaborate on film script

fields.headline: Jagger and Scorsese collaborate on film script
fields.trailText: Martin Scorsese is planning to collaborate on a film script with Rolling Stones frontman Mick Jagger. The picture - known variously as The Long Play and Snap - will be a satirical tale of life in the music business and will be produced by Jagger's own UK-based production company, Jagged.
fields.body:
Martin Scorsese is planning to collaborate on a film script with Rolling Stones frontman Mick Jagger. The picture - known variously as The Long Play and Snap - will be a satirical tale of life in the music business and will be produced by Jagger's own UK-based production company, Jagged.

The Jagger-Scorsese collaboration is not so unlikely as it at first appears. Scorsese's love of the Rolling Stones's music has been a matter of public record for some decades. The director memorably introduced Robert De Niro to the sounds of Jumping Jack Flash in 1973's Mean Streets, choreographed GoodFellas's cocaine fall-out to Jaggers's rendition of Monkey Man, and played Time is On My Side over the action of Casino.

For his part, Jagger has long dabbled in movie-making, attempting sporadic acting roles that have ranged from the impressive (Performance) to the execrable (Freejack). The 56-year-old singer has recently taken up a strong role behind the camera.

Jagged films currently has at least three films in development, including The Map of Love, a biopic of Dylan Thomas and Enigma, an adaptation of the Robert Harris thriller starring Kate Winslet, which is currently in production in the UK.

Jagger will write The Long Play (aka Snap) with both Scorsese and experienced scriptman Rich Cohen. He admits that the film's story is heavily autobiographical. "It's a comedy," Jagger has explained "about the perils of being at the top of your game in the rock'n'roll world and the pitfalls you encounter." The ageing rocker is rumoured to be keen to woo Jude Law to play his alter-ego.

fields.headline: Priceless life
fields.standfirst: Somerset
fields.trailText: The hedge alongside Back Lane is patchy - pale green where hawthorn is just in leaf, with darker green in other parts, splashes of white where Blackthorn has flowered, and stretches of still bare, wintry wood. We found seven kinds of woody growth, including Hornbeam, Buckthorn and Elder, in a 30-yard section. Sucha  frequency of types, according to the hedge-dater's rule of thumb (Hooper's Rule), suggests a venerable hedge. This one may have kept cattle in their place for hundreds of years.
fields.body:
The hedge alongside Back Lane is patchy - pale green where hawthorn is just in leaf, with darker green in other parts, splashes of white where Blackthorn has flowered, and stretches of still bare, wintry wood. We found seven kinds of woody growth, including Hornbeam, Buckthorn and Elder, in a 30-yard section. Sucha frequency of types, according to the hedge-dater's rule of thumb (Hooper's Rule), suggests a venerable hedge. This one may have kept cattle in their place for hundreds of years.

Further afield, on the verge, a milk bottle shape made of wood, eight feet tall and four feet wide and painted white, bears the words: "Doorstep 71p per litre... Farmer 16p per litre... Who's milking whom?" Across a ploughed field, fixed to the outstretched, tubular arms of a giant spreader is the legend: "16 families and 40 miles of hedge to support. Please buy British." A friend who helps a dairy farmer invited me to early morning milking to see the milk hosed directly into the slurry pit. Another dairy farmer leaned over the church pew to say that he had finally given up.

The early April weather has been sharply variable. After some days when new-born lambs had been dozing in warm sunshine, we shivered on the top of Ham Hill, over 300 feet up, our eyes watering in a bitter wind. The ground there is pitted from centuries of quarrying for the golden stone that built Montacute. We could just see Creech Hill, 18 miles to the east, and Alfred's Tower, a misty outline, 28 miles in the same direction.

Round a point or two to the north there was snow on the Mendips. We heard later that one farmer above Wells had lost 100 lambs in a six foot snowdrift. Another, in an operation that involved fire brigades and volunteers, had resuced over 80, his young son reviving the almost lifeless creatures by rubbing them with straw. The market price of each lamb was only a pound or two and the impulse to save them evidently not rooted solely in commercial calculation.

webTitle: High life on grass roof eco-semis

fields.headline: High life on grass roof eco-semis
fields.standfirst: Newsprint insulation key to DIY energy saving homes
fields.trailText: The neighbours are good friends, so at least they will not argue over whose turn it is to mow the roof.
fields.body:
The neighbours are good friends, so at least they will not argue over whose turn it is to mow the roof.

Last week the four of them, with a bit of help, braved downpours to lift 14 tonnes of soil to the top of a pair of eco-semis soon to be known as 17 and 19 Croft Crescent in Stoke-on-Trent, Staffordshire.

Slowly, to the amazement of the owners of conventional homes across the narrow cul de sac, the roof is being covered with turf. Wild flowers will be sown to create a pitched meadow.

Greg Stephens expects to move into 19 next month and hopes to spend some of the summer flat out on his lofty greensward while recovering from six months spent building the house with his partner, Kate Barfield.

"If you get down low on the roof when the leaves on the trees are out, you won't be able to see the incinerator or Stoke City ground," said Mr Stephens.

He will not want the sun to shine all the time because he will rely on Potteries rain, which will run from the roof into storage tanks under the conservatory, to flush his toilet and do his washing.

Their neighbours at 17 are the initiators of the scheme: Peter Wilshaw, co-founder of Greenbuilt, an environmentally friendly building company, and his wife, Susan Clarke.

"For a long time, I have wanted to live in a home that we built ourselves, was kind to the environment and was energy efficient," said Ms Clarke.

Mr Wilshaw has experience of similar projects and of training non-builders, including New Deal recruits and people with learning difficulties, in construction techniques.

"Susan found the site, and we have had a lot of support from the city's planners," he said. "The design is simple, and the houses should require only the kind of maintenance anyone with a knowledge of do-it-yourself could manage."

The houses, entirely without bricks, are based on a series of timber frames. The weight is carried on vertical wooden piles which rest on concrete rafts.

Both homes should be so energy efficient that a 75w light bulb should keep the bathroom warm. Heating bills are expected to be a third of those in a conventional house.

The secret of Croft Crescent lies in hundreds of kilograms of unread newspapers which have been turned into a highly effective wall insulating pulp. The top half of the homes is clad in untreated larch (with plenty of sap to keep out the damp and the bugs) and the bottom with board made from recycled paper and concrete.

"An unbelievable amount of timber was arriving every day in the early stages and every bit had to be unloaded by hand," said Mr Stephens. "It makes you very proud when you have carried every bit that goes into your own home.

"But it's not all hair shirts and yogurt here. We have plastic drainpipes and copper pipes for the heating. Local people have been friendly but cautious. But it would be silly not to think we are a bit odd."

Ms Barfield added: "It's been quite easy to be trained to do the construction work."

The sun came out as they took a break on a south-facing deck which takes full advantage of the sloping site. "This is where I'll play my banjo and drink gin and tonics," said Mr Stephens.

"It makes you very proud when you have carried every bit that goes into your own home. "But it's not all hair shirts and yogurt here. We have plastic drainpipes and copper pipes for the heating. Local people have been friendly but cautious. But it would be silly not to think we are a bit odd." Ms Barfield added: "It's been quite easy to be trained to do the construction work." The sun came out as they took a break on a south-facing deck which takes full advantage of the sloping site. "This is where I'll play my banjo and drink gin and tonics," said Mr Stephens.

webTitle: Castro orders Havana to play down Elian's homecoming

fields.headline: Castro orders Havana to play down Elian's homecoming
fields.standfirst: More about the Elian Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: If the Cuban authorities have their way, Elian Gonzalez will not be the centre of mass celebrations in Havana if the six-year-old is returned to his native island.
fields.body:
If the Cuban authorities have their way, Elian Gonzalez will not be the centre of mass celebrations in Havana if the six-year-old is returned to his native island.

The authorities recently told locals to remove a "welcome home Elian" banner which had been put up in his home town of Cardenas; after months of accusing his enemies in Florida of "psychologically torturing" the boy, Fidel Castro has promised to keep the crowds of well-wishers with cameras away from Elian, in deliberate contrast to the circus that has engulfed his residence in Miami.

For some in Havana, the saga cannot end soon enough. "Lets hope it goes back to normal and [Castro] doesn't find something else to substitute it with," said Alfredo Roldan, who said that he could not bear to watch television any more.

For Cuba's 72-year-old president, it has been a win-win situation from the start. The highly orchestrated rallies with their speeches blasting US decadence, high crime rates and consumerism have helped him to reinstate patriotism and revolutionary values within the island's youth.

It has also given him the perfect platform in the US to campaign against the Cuban-American leaders he regards as his real enemies, isolating them from Washington.

The Cuban leader has repeatedly compared the battle for custody with the 1961 defeat of the CIA-backed exiles' invasion at the Bay of Pigs. Appropriately, the invasion's anniversary was yesterday.

"They lack brains," he said, comparing Miami's Cuban exiles to the invading troops who got stuck in the mangrove swamps. "The more they move, the deeper they sink in the mud."

Behind the dispute lies the politics of Washington's 40-year-old trade embargo against Cuba, and President Castro blames the massive Cuban-American influence in US politics for the continuation of the embargo.

In a political twist, Cuban television has been portraying Bill Clinton, the attorney general, Janet Reno, and the US authorities as the good guys for the last few months, finally standing up to the bad guys in Miami.

The island's television has even suggested that anger within the Clinton administration with the Cuban-Americans in Miami could prompt the president to lift the ban on US tourists travelling to Cuba.

Ironically, this development may not serve President Castro well; a huge influx of US tourists and better relations with Washington could make it harder to maintain socialist values at home.

Even before the case broke, the government was trying to combat what it viewed as an invasion of US culture from across the Florida Straits, helped by the free circulation of family remittances made in US dollars.

The battle for Elian has not stopped this, a fact the Cuban leader cannot help but notice.

When he appeared live on television with the 12 classmates of Elian he was hoping to send to Washington with Elian's father last week, one of them was asked what music he would take to give Elian. "The Backstreet Boys," the six-year-old instantly replied.

webTitle: Elian echoes of Bay of Pigs fiasco

fields.headline: Elian echoes of Bay of Pigs fiasco
fields.standfirst: Anniversary stirs memories as dispute over boy drags on
fields.trailText: In a small, shaded square off Little Havana's Eighth Street, a cluster of Cuban exile veterans stood to painful attention yesterday as a pre-recorded bugle played in memory of the last time they were betrayed and humiliated.
fields.body:
In a small, shaded square off Little Havana's Eighth Street, a cluster of Cuban exile veterans stood to painful attention yesterday as a pre-recorded bugle played in memory of the last time they were betrayed and humiliated.

The Bay of Pigs invasion, an abortive CIA-backed attempt to win Cuba back from the Communists, took place on April 1 1961. The fledgling government in Havana survived and is still there today.

The US maintains its embargo somewhat half-heartedly, while most Americans have forgotten the bloody fiasco 39 years ago in which 200 invaders died and 1,200 were captured. But in Miami's Little Havana district, the home of many of the old Cuban exiles, the disappointment is keener than ever. Most of the veterans who turned out in their medals and campaign caps believe they are now fighting the Bay of Pigs all over again.

This time the battleground is not a swampy mosquito-infested cove; it is the fate of a little Cuban boy called Elian. But the enemy remains the same. Behind every edict, court order and government declaration aimed at sending Elian home, these old soldiers see the hand of Fidel Castro.

"In the case of Elian, we don't want to give Castro another victory in April. It would be another victory against the United States," said Oscar Martinez, who took part in the first air assault on Cuban forces. "We went to war to fight for freedom and democracy, and we want for Elian the same things, the things we wanted for our own children."

Rumours and information flow like electric impulses down Eighth Street (Calle Ocho), and yesterday's rumour was that federal agents would come that same night. They would pounce on the humble one-storey house a few blocks away, where Elian has been staying since he was ship wrecked last November, and take the boy away - back to his Cuban loyalist father and then back to Fidel Castro.

Many of the veterans from the Brigada de Asalto 2506, who spearheaded the invasion, swore they would be there all evening, and all night if need be, to repel the expected raid, putting their bodies between the US government and Elian.

Roberto Macia is not surprised to find Washington siding with Castro. He was part of the assault on San Blas in 1961, fighting inland from the beach and waiting for US air cover.

"The first day was good. We went in and took what we wanted," said Mr Macia, now 73. "But then they sank our boats and our supplies, and the others took off."He spent 20 months as a prisoner-of-war before being exchanged for humanitarian aid. He has spent the rest of his life in exile ruing what went wrong.

"Kennedy got scared and he backed off," was Mr Macia's judgement. "It's the same now. They're giving in to Castro. He is giving the orders."

The echoes of 1961 have grown deafening for the old men of 2506 Brigade. Both superstition and experience suggest that the second great betrayal will fall on the anniversary of the first. For them, it is their final battle.
