webTitle: Father and sons found dead after first access visit

fields.headline: Father and sons found dead after first access visit
fields.trailText: A father who was found dead with his two sons at their home had split up with his wife a few months ago, neighbours said yesterday.
fields.body:
A father who was found dead with his two sons at their home had split up with his wife a few months ago, neighbours said yesterday.

Police are working on the theory that Frank Fairless, 36, killed the boys at his home near Gainsborough, Lincolnshire, because he was depressed about the break-up of his marriage. He then hanged himself.

His sons Christopher, nine, and Oliver, six, were killed during their first overnight access visit to their father's house in Scotter since he split up with his wife, Claire.

The boys' bodies were found in their beds. Police discovered all three bodies on Sunday evening after they received a call from James Forrington, the children's grandfather, who was concerned about their safety.

The boys had been picked up by their father at 9am on Saturday for an access visit. They had been due to be returned to their mother at 5pm the following day, but when they had not arrived by 6.15pm, her family contacted police.

Mr Forrington said: "We can't take in what has happened. We know as little as anybody else."

At the time of the deaths, Mr Fairless's estranged wife was staying with her parents at their home a mile away.

Mr Fairless, a self-employed builder, built the detached cottage for his family four years ago. The couple named the property "Olverchris" cottage after their two sons.

The trio had been seen having lunch together at the Gamekeeper pub in Scotter on Saturday afternoon.

Neighbour Brian Welch, 70, said: "Everybody here is stunned. They were a friendly family and always had time for a chat. The two boys were cheery little things and very pleasant - I can't believe that they are gone.

"Most of the houses around here have young families and all the children in the area play together.

"It was meant to be their dream home. He built it himself and named it after the two boys.

"We knew Frank and his wife had split up about six months ago, but we never imagined for one moment anything like this would happen."

Detective Chief Inspector Graham White, of Lincolnshire police, who is leading the inquiry into the three deaths, said: "The officers went into the house with both the boys' grandfathers and discovered the body of a man hanging in the garage. A further search of the premises revealed the bodies of two children lying in their beds under the covers, in separate bedrooms.

"I'm not aware of any signs of violence or a struggle. We are clearly looking at the possibility he has killed the children and then taken his own life."

He added: "From the family's point of view it is a completely devastating situation for them and it is very difficult to begin to comprehend how they are going to come to terms with it.

"It was the first time that Mr Fairless had the boys for an overnight stay."

A Home Office pathologist carried out postmortem examinations on the bodies yesterday.

DCI White said it was too early to say how the boys met their deaths, but he confirmed the police were not looking for anybody else in connection with the inquiry.

He added that a number of handwritten notes were recovered at the scene.

Mrs Fairless was last night being comforted by her family and specially trained police officers.

webTitle: Telefonica bows out of phone auction

fields.headline: Telefonica bows out of phone auction
fields.trailText: Telefonica of Spain quit the British auction of third generation mobile phone licences yesterday declaring that soaring bids had made the cost of entering the UK phone market unprofitable.
fields.body:
Telefonica of Spain quit the British auction of third generation mobile phone licences yesterday declaring that soaring bids had made the cost of entering the UK phone market unprofitable.

Total bids for the five licences to be operated on the universal mobile telecommunications system yesterday reached £21.1bn.

"With the UMTS licences in the UK at these price levels, Telefonica believes it would be difficult to make such an investment profitable and therefore regards other growth opportunities as more attractive and creating more value for its shareholders," the company said.

Telefonica has already won a third generation licence in its home market and may look towards Germany, which is expected to be the next to sell such spectrum.

On Friday, Telefonica pulled out of bidding for a GSM licence in Turkey.

Six companies remain in the bidding in Britain. Vodafone battled yesterday with BT over licence B, which offers the most spectrum available to an established operator.

Both companies networks are already working at capacity and require additional spectrum to expand their customer bases.

BT bid up Vodafone for licence B, but Vodafone ended up with the highest bid yesterday at £5.66bn.

TIW, which is supported by Hutchison Whampoa of Hong Kong, offered £4.38bn for licence A.

The France Telecom-backed NTL Mobile bid £3.76bn for licence C, One2One bid £3.68bn for licence D and BT bid £3.73bn for licence E.

fields.headline: Today's TV
fields.trailText: Terrestrial
fields.body:
The Antiques Show 8pm, BBC2
How times have changed. Not so long ago, programmes about trinkets from bygone ages were all the rage. But that was before Charlie Dimmock sexed up gardening, and Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen did something garish and insubstantial to DIY shows. Sad really, because a couple of the segments here - a report on the Gilbert Collection (antiques worth £75 million recently donated to the nation by Arthur Gilbert) and a look at the paintings of faker Tom Keating - are infinitely more intriguing than yet another item on how to lay a lawn or tart up the spare bedroom.

Cutting Edge 9pm, Channel 4
In 1957, 11-year-old Moira Anderson disappeared from the Scottish town of Coatbridge. What happened to her remains a mystery, but Sandra Brown believes she knows what occurred. She thinks her own father (once jailed for having sex with a 13-year-old) should be prosecuted for murder. Her campaign to get the case reopened has caused deep chasms in her family. A harrowing film that all too graphically illustrates the dangers of not confronting the issue of child abuse.

Streakers 10.50pm, Channel 5
According to Erica Roe, famous for baring her chest at Twickers, streaking in front of a huge crowd is "a moment of feeling what it's like to be in The Rolling Stones or Genesis, up there on the stage". Leaving aside the question of why anyone would want to feel like a wrinkly rocker trading on past glories, this is a rather amiable film that has a lot in common with streaking itself: it's silly but curiously entertaining.

Passover: A Taste Of Freedom 12.25am, BBC1
In December 1938, as the world belatedly woke up to the true horrors of Nazism, the first of 10,000 Jewish children rescued from Germany arrived in Harwich. This powerful film, broadcast to tie in with the Jewish festival of Passover, tells the story of the children who braved the Kindertransport (Children's Transport).

webTitle: Judge bars supergrass claims for cash rewards

fields.headline: Judge bars supergrass claims for cash rewards
fields.trailText: Supergrasses who claim they have been short-changed in rewards for information have no right to sue, a high court judge ruled yesterday.
fields.body:
Supergrasses who claim they have been short-changed in rewards for information have no right to sue, a high court judge ruled yesterday.

The judgment was given in the case of Keith Robinson, an informant who claimed the sum of £33,574 with interest for an alleged breach of contract against customs and excise whom he said had promised him reasonable remuneration and expenses.

Mr Robinson, who ran a vehicle repair business in Leighton Buzzard, Bedfordshire, alleged that his customs "minders" had promised he would be handsomely rewarded after he agreed that a tracking device could be fitted in a Mercedes van that drug smugglers kept at his premises.

In the first case of its kind, Mr Justice Douglas Brown held that no contract existed and that, on grounds of public policy, "an informant cannot maintain a claim against the commissioners [of customs and excise] or indeed a chief officer of police in respect of any reward for information supplied".

Mr Robinson, who received just under £10,000 for information which led to the jailing of a drug smuggler for 10 years, complained that he had been promised that amount for the drugs conviction alone. He said he was owed far more for the help he gave in relation to an insurance fraud and other drugs offences.

He claimed he had at first only received £6,500 but had continued to provide information to customs, receiving a number of other payments, the highest of which was £500. In the end he had received a total of £9,150. He claimed he was "short changed" and that he had a legally enforceable contract which entitled him to more.

The judge, held that Mr Robinson, whom he described as "a highly unreliable witness", had not been promised handsome rewards or specific sums. He said there was no contract or any intention to create "legal relations".

Customs and excise denied that the money had been offered for the information leading to that arrest.

The judge said that when Mr Robinson had initially agreed to assist the customs officers and provide information he would have regarded any suggestion that he might mount a court fight over payment as "wholly inimical to his personal safety".

Mr Robinson had been told he could not receive a wage for being an informant and that he would only be paid through the reward system operated by customs.

To allow an informant to sue would involve the court in an examination of sensitive matters and the "unthinkable" disclosure of information, normally subject to public interest immunity, in the presence of a claimant "who was either a criminal or on the fringes of crime", the judge said.

The judge added that unscrupulous informants might bring claims with little or no merit with the object of forcing the authorities to settle rather than of revealing sources of information.

The judge granted customs and excise an order blocking the claim on the ground that he had no reasonable prospect of success.

After the tracking device had been fitted in the Mercedes van, Mr Robinson was told by conspirators that the plan was to import 20 tons of cannabis into Britain from Italy.

The van was stopped at Dover in July 1994 and three-quarters of a ton of the drug was seized.

The driver was convicted and jailed for 10 years. Mr Robinson claimed that his information had led to French police making three arrests and also seizing large amounts of drugs.

fields.standfirst: Hague plan to put refugees into detention camps
fields.trailText: William Hague will today intensify the political row over race relations when he declares that a Tory government would herd all asylum seekers into detention camps regardless of their plight.
fields.body:
William Hague will today intensify the political row over race relations when he declares that a Tory government would herd all asylum seekers into detention camps regardless of their plight.

In a clear signal that the Tory leadership remains unmoved by the recent calls for moderate language over race, Mr Hague will pledge to set up a "removals agency" to ensure that people who are refused asylum are ejected from Britain immediately.

Mr Hague's speech today follows a decision by Jack Straw to order more than 3,000 Kosovan Albanians, who were given temporary protection in Britain at the height of last year's war, to leave Britain by the end of this month.

The government's declaration of firm action against Kosovans who overstay came as a new Guardian/ICM opinion poll showed that the battle between Labour and Conservatives over asylum has had little impact on voters. When asked which party was talking the most sense about asylum, only 16% named Labour and 15% the Conservatives.

However, Mr Hague will make clear today that he believes the asylum issue provides fertile political territory for the Tories when he delivers his most provocative speech since becoming Conservative leader nearly three years ago. Mr Hague will pay lip service to political niceties by saying that Britain should remain a safe haven for people fleeing genuine persecution.

But the rest of his speech will be an assault on "bogus" asylum seekers, a highly emotive term after the black trade union leader Bill Morris warned last week that the government was giving "life to the racists" by using such language.

One senior Tory source described Mr Hague's speech as a major shift in policy which was designed to show that Britain would no longer be a "soft touch" for bogus asylum seekers under the Tories.

"We want to make clear that we will be tough on this to stop bogus asylum seekers trekking half way round the world with their American Express cards to come to Britain," the source said. "When genuine asylum seekers flee persecution they go to the first country that will take them rather than working out which country has the best benefits which, at the moment, is Britain. Look at the Von Trapps - did they worry where they went when they fled the Nazis?"

The government will distance itself from Mr Hague's speech today, with ministers likely to characterise its as another example of Mr Hague's extremism.

The poll findings came as Mr Straw disclosed that he is ready to take enforcement ac tion against Kosovans who do not go back voluntarily. Some 4,427 Kosovan Albanians came to Britain last year under the UN's humanitarian emergency evacuation programme. So far 1,151 have gone back to Kosovo. A further 403 have visited to see the condition of their old homes under an "explore and prepare" programme. Of this group some 332 have come back to Britain.

However, the home secretary demonstrated yesterday that he was prepared to be tough when he announced that he believed it was now broadly safe for Kosovans of Albanian extraction to return. They had been given temporary protection for 12 months and that would start to run out for the group between April 28 and early June. Their permission to stay would not be renewed unless there were exceptional circumstances. "Enforcement action will be taken in due course against those who do not go back voluntarily," said the home secretary. Those who remain will be "overstayers" who will lose all benefits and face deportation.

Mr Straw also criticised the main charities, including Oxfam and Barnardos, who have boycotted the asylum voucher scheme because of his insistence that no change is given to those who use the vouchers. He claimed their criticism was based on the mistaken belief that asylum seekers were given only one voucher but there were several denominations down to 50p.

Immigration rights campaigners, who are pressing for both Labour and the Tories to tone down their language over asylum, will take comfort from the the poll results which suggests that issue is not playing hard among voters as the local election campaigns intensifies. The voters are also unimpressed by the charge that either or both of the two main parties are being racist when they talk about the problem of asylum seekers. Only 16% say the Conservatives are racist on asylum and only 5% think Labour is racist on the issue.

The ICM poll results showing that asylum has yet to make much of a party political impact on the public showed that 20% believe that none of the main parties make sense when they talk about asylum. Only 12% said the Liberal Democrats made the most sense and 36% said they did not know, suggesting they do not know the difference between the parties on the issue.

The second question about whether the main political parties were seen to be racist over the issue also failed to produce much response. Some 36% thought none of the parties were being racist and 42% did not have an opinion.

ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,203 adults aged 18 plus by telephone on March 14-15 this year. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

webTitle: Heart baby dies after hunt for donor fails

fields.headline: Heart baby dies after hunt for donor fails
fields.trailText: A year-old girl died in hospital yesterday a week after a national appeal was launched for a heart donor.
fields.body:
A year-old girl died in hospital yesterday a week after a national appeal was launched for a heart donor.

Tace Corcoran-Rees from Ely, Cardiff, had been critically ill at the University hospital of Wales since she was admitted into the paediatric intensive care unit 12 days ago.

A spokesman for the hospital, in Cardiff, said last night: "Staff at the unit, and everyone at the trust, are saddened to learn of her death. In spite of a widespread appeal for a donor, sadly no suitable heart became available."

Kirsti Corcoran and Derek Rees, the child's parents, had made several public appeals for a donor. Tace, who had suffered from a serious heart condition after she contracted a virus when she was 10 weeks old, was admitted to hospital with an infection.

A helicopter had been on standby to take her to Harefield hospital in Middlesex where, last November, doctors put her on the heart transplant list.

The child's death came as Sally Slater, the six-year-girl who had a heart plant operation two weeks ago after a similar appeal, spoke her first words since entering hospital.

Sally had been given only hours to live before a donor was found, but has now been taken off her ventilator at the Freeman hospital, Newcastle upon Tyne. Yesterday, her parents said she had asked doctors for orange juice.

Her father, Jon Slater, from Malham, in North Yorkshire, said: "She said to doctors the word 'orange' and she has had a couple of sips.

"It is the first thing that she had taken herself not through an intravenous drip for nearly five weeks. It's encouraging, but we know the heart can still be rejected."

A spokeswoman for the hospital said that the child was breathing by herself.

webTitle: Saving the coal industry? It's the pits

fields.headline: Saving the coal industry? It's the pits
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Stephen Byers, the industry secretary, rose to make a statement about coal. "Goodbye!" said Nicholas Soames, which Tories always shout at him nowadays, though he seems to be safe for the time being.
fields.body:
Stephen Byers, the industry secretary, rose to make a statement about coal. "Goodbye!" said Nicholas Soames, which Tories always shout at him nowadays, though he seems to be safe for the time being.

What was startling was how very few Labour MPs there were behind him. Miners! The pits! Helmeted men shuffling through the morning darkness, their tins of snap at their sides! The shock troops of the Labour movement! It's as if a Tory government had decided to save Britain's last half dozen army units, and only a handful of their own backbenchers had turned up to give an opinion.

Dennis Skinner was there, of course, but as he pointed out, there were no mines left in his constituency. You would think this was a terrific blow, as if the MP for Tunbridge Wells (Archie Norman) had to confess to the death of all colonels drinking pink gin through bristly moustaches. A little bit of England would have gone.

The Tories, said Mr Skinner, had got a cheek opposing subsidies for the remaining mines, when they had called for hundreds of millions to go to farmers. "We should have taken the coal industry back into public ownership!" he yelled, and you could see the smug little smiles on the Labour benches. Dear old Dennis, coming up with yet another crazy idea! Whatever next? Re-nationalise the railways, I suppose! Like the gin-drinking colonels, Dennis seems to them a symbol of a vanished era - comical, to be sure, but admirable in his own funny way as well.

Mr Byers smiled a condescending little smile too, and said, "our option 15 was renationalisation, but we didn't take it any further".

He had made a statement in the sub-McKinsey management drivel which ministers affect these days. It is meant to sound American and cutting edge, but like British hot dogs, never quite works.

He spoke of "market diversity", "consents policy", and "energy parks". Firms in the industry were "players". As for the coal industry, it would need to "meet new challenges... to move forward, to manage change rather than be submerged by it, and" - we paused for a threatening roll of drums - "respond to the challenges ahead!".

This always means, "we have no real hope that the pits will survive, but at least we can't be blamed if they don't respond to the challenges". He finished by saying: "this is good news for hard working people and their families".

"Hard working people" is one of those phrases used by our government when they are painting one of their great capitalist realism canvases to be hoisted aloft before our wondering gaze. It implies honest, upright folk, men and women who don't want to sponge off the state, people who respond to the challenges ahead with a far-sighted gleam in their eye.

What it means, of course, is people who work all the hours god sends, with poor pay, lousy benefits and as much security as a field mouse at harvest time.

Still, Mr Byers knows that for the next few months at least, his main contender will be Angela Browning, and this must console him during those long nights when he wakes up sweating under the duvet.

Mrs Browning has the perpetual air of a middle-class woman complaining loudly to a police officer.

"His rationale was bogus, Madam Speaker!", she shouted, as if describing a doorstep mugger.

She began to mix her metaphors. "Our aim is to put all fuels on a level playing field," she declared.

"This department runs on a piecemeal basis, and conducts policy on the hoof!" she added. These weren't just being mixed; they were whizzed up in an industrial sized blender.

webTitle: Straw clears way for Harare influx

fields.headline: Straw clears way for Harare influx
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Britain is preparing for an influx of Zimbabweans fleeing from the violent land battle which at the weekend led to the murders of a white farmer and two black members of the main opposition party.
fields.byline: Alan Travis  and  Andrew Meldrum  in Harare
fields.body:
Britain is preparing for an influx of Zimbabweans fleeing from the violent land battle which at the weekend led to the murders of a white farmer and two black members of the main opposition party.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, made clear yesterday that many of the new arrivals, who have British ancestry - if only one grandparent - are not expected to have to go through Britain's new "below the breadline" asylum system but instead will be given long-term permission to stay.

Both the European Union and the Commonwealth expressed extreme concern yesterday about the deteriorating situation in Zimbabwe, which is in danger of a descent into anarchy.

Britain tried to ratchet up international pressure on the Zimbabwean president, Robert Mugabe, by pressing African nations to push for a "return to the rule of law" in the former British colony.

With the mood turning increasingly ugly in Harare, President Mugabe has remained unrepentant about the violence which has accompanied the occupation of at least 500 white-owned farms by supporters of his Zanu-PF party.

But representatives of the white farmers said Mr Mugabe assured them yesterday that he would act to restore order, although he stopped short of ordering squatters to leave occupied farms.

"I just get the feeling that he was feeling fairly determined to get the situation back to normal as soon as possible," Commercial Farmers' Union president Tim Henwood said after meeting Mr Mugabe.

Up to 20,000 Zimbabweans are believed to have the right to come to Britain on the grounds that their parents or grandparents were born in the country.

The long queues of those nervously applying to renew their British "certificate of entitlement" filled the halls of the offices of the British high commission in Harare's city centre yesterday.

The numbers of people going to the British consular office to inquire about their status as British citizens and their right to reside in Britain increased dramatically, presumably as a result of the weekend killing of a white farmer and the beatings of five others.

"It was busy, very busy," said Richard Lindsay of the high commission.

The rush of people included people renewing old British passports that had expired, others asking about their eligibility for British residency and some simply registering so they can be contacted in case of an emergency.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, one of Mr Mugabe's sternest critics, said yesterday that the secretary general of the Organisation of African Unity, Salim Ahmed Salim, had told him he would discuss the violence in Zimbabwe with southern African leaders.

Mr Cook said the Nigerian president, Olusegun Obasanjo, had also sent his foreign minister, Sule Lamido, to Harare to express concern at the violence.

"I'm very pleased that we have got the Organisation of African Unity also engaged in joining in that international pressure to try and secure an outcome in Zimbabwe that will enable us to find a way forward," Mr Cook said.

Most of those Zimbabweans who have a British connection are white, although some black and Asians also have had relatives in the UK.

Those who have a parent who was born in Britain are exempted from the asylum and immigration laws and can enter Britain freely on their Commonwealth passports, the Home Office said yesterday. They are entitled to claim British citizenship but have to obtain a certificate of entitlement from the high commission before they travel.

The second group entitled to come to Britain without having to undergo the complex and lengthy asylum process, including dispersal and living on "below the breadline" vouchers, are those who can demonstrate that one of their grandparents was born in Britain.

Under the UK "ancestry regulations" those who can demonstrate a family connection are allowed to enter Britain for an initial period of four years without the need for a work permit. A Home Office spokesman said last night that they had to be looking to work in Britain without recourse to public funds. After four years they could apply to become a permanent resident.

It was clear yesterday in London that Mr Straw and Barbara Roche, the immigration minister, have been briefed in detail by Home Office officials to expect a sudden significant rise in the numbers fleeing from Zimbabwe.

"In many cases people from Zimbabwe may have grounds for coming here in any case because they have relatives who are British," said Mr Straw. "If their parents are British they have a right to come. It depends upon their ancestry."

A steady, but small, trickle of asylum seekers have come to Britain in the last three months, with 50 arriving in March.

webTitle: Return trip for the limo of choice

fields.headline: Return trip for the limo of choice
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: The Zil has always been the limousine of Russian and Soviet leaders. Vladimir Putin brought two to London for his 24-hour visit.
fields.body:
The Zil has always been the limousine of Russian and Soviet leaders. Vladimir Putin brought two to London for his 24-hour visit.

Stalin had one with 3in thick windows. He also had the wing mirrors removed - they were redundant as no one would ever be so foolish as to overtake him.

The car started life in 1936 as the Zis - for Zavod Imeni Stalina - but Stalin was removed from the name in 1956 and it became the Zil in tribute to Ivan Likhachov, its designer.

It was the Cadillac of Russia and, with its plush leather interior and bullet-proof glass, was always the prestigious car for party apparatchicks. Outside they looked like US limos, inside they were more like Soviet hotel lobbies. But the Zil seemed to go out of fashion: Boris Yeltsin was normally seen in a Mercedes.

Its return seems to be high on Putin's list of reforms. The current model has a 7.7-litre V8 engine and costs about £75,000. It has seven seats, is fully armoured, weighs two tonnes, and has a top speed of about 118mph.

All very impressive - unless you care about the environment: a Zil will struggle to squeeze 10 miles out of a gallon of petrol.

fields.headline: Russia evades human rights issue
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Russia attempted to deflect western criticism of the visit of president-elect Vladimir Putin to London yesterday by announcing a new commission to investigate human rights abuses in Chechnya.
fields.body:
Russia attempted to deflect western criticism of the visit of president-elect Vladimir Putin to London yesterday by announcing a new commission to investigate human rights abuses in Chechnya.

As pro-Chechen demonstrators noisily protested outside Downing Street, Mr Putin made a passionate defence of Russia's offensive in Chechnya, warning that European countries were afraid of offending their own Muslim inhabitants: "Western Europe could pay heavily for this."

The former KGB officer held more than three hours of talks with Tony Blair at Downing Street and later had a 30-minute audience with the Queen at Windsor Castle.

Mr Blair gave a tentative welcome to the new commission and rejected criticism that he had put commerce ahead of human rights in inviting Mr Putin to Britain.

"Some say that because of our concerns about Chechnya we should keep some distance from Moscow. I have to tell you that while I share those concerns I believe that the best way to register those concerns and to get results is by engaging with Russia and not isolating Russia," he said.

Mr Putin, who claimed to have been unaware of the new commission until he heard about it from a news agency, said it would be made up of well-known figures in Russian life, such as the editor of Izves tia. It will disappoint those who had urged the creation of an international commission.

Russia's war against Chechen fighters is continuing amid widespread allegations of human rights abuses.

As Mr Putin flew home last night after less than 24 hours in Britain, both sides judged the visit a success.

It was Mr Putin's first visit to the west since winning the presidential election last month. He arrived late on Sun day and stayed in a Kensington hotel, close to the embassy.

In the morning, Mr Putin, a 47-year-old fitness fanatic, passed on his daily 45-minute run, leaving the new Russian ambassador, Grigori Karasin, to go jogging alone in Kensington park.

Mr Putin's first stop was the National Liberal Club in Whitehall to meet representatives from the Confederation of British Industry. Into this normally quiet corner of Westminster, Mr Putin brought a huge retinue.

webTitle: Blair's new push on Good Friday deal

fields.headline: Blair's new push on Good Friday deal
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is flying to Belfast today to meet the pro-Good Friday agreement parties as the push to restore devolved government picks up pace before Easter, a time that is highly symbolic in Northern Ireland's political calendar.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is flying to Belfast today to meet the pro-Good Friday agreement parties as the push to restore devolved government picks up pace before Easter, a time that is highly symbolic in Northern Ireland's political calendar.

Officials were playing down Mr Blair's visit, suggesting he would be "listening" and then going to Dublin for talks with Bertie Ahern, the Irish premier.

But it is Mr Blair's first foray to Northern Ireland since his week-long effort in July, which failed to get a breakthrough on paramilitary weapons - the third attempt in four months to secure devolution. The British and Irish governments, working frantically behind the scenes, are now close to thrashing out a common approach, in the wake of the Northern Ireland secretary's signal for a return to direct rule from Westminster two months ago.

The governments agree there is now little point in insisting on the IRA giving up arms before a resoration of the power-sharing executive, and that the May 22 deadline for complete decommissioning will have to lapse. However, they want the IRA to be clear about its intentions, and are pinning hopes on a statement that its terrorist war is over, which would be a crucial element permitting progress. It appears, however, there is no sign of such a commitment and there is also doubt over whether David Trimble, the Ulster Unionist leader, would buy that stance, and whether he could push it through his party. His proposed reforms to the Orange order link, which would strengthen his position, will not be debated until June.

A Downing Street spokesman said of Mr Blair's visit to Hillsborough Castle in County Down, scene of one of the failed set of negotiations just before last Easter: "He will be listening to all the parties. He will be bringing no blueprint. This is a stock-taking exercise."

The two governments' proposals will be floated with the parties, and Mr Blair hopes to achieve a clearer view of what each side might accept.

Sinn Fein and the Ulster Unionists were sparring ahead of Mr Blair's arrival. Mitchel McLaughlin, the Sinn Fein chairman, said his party would require written guarantees that the Northern Ireland secretary would not suspend the institutions again.

Mr McLaughlin said: "If we are going to set up the institutions now, we need to know that it is not an experiment, that it is not a trial period."

But Mr Trimble said that that statement was ridiculous, and he accused the republicans of constantly raising pre-conditions before they fulfilled their obligations under the agreement.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Satellite, cable and digital
fields.body:
Marx Brothers Night 9pm, TCM
A night dedicated to the greatest comedy troupe Hollywood has ever produced, but mixing their strongest films with their weakest. Go West and At The Circus show the lunatic incompetents past their peak. A Day At The Races and A Night At The Opera, however, couldn't be bettered: they were the first two big studio productions, and combine the brothers' best comedy sequences with the kind of large-scale Hollywood professionalism not seen since. And Harpo's piano and harp playing sequence in A Night At The Opera is pure magic. (WH)

There's Something About Mary (Peter Farrelly, Bobby Farrelly, 1998) 8pm, Sky Premier
Poor Ben Stiller. The girl of his dreams (Cameron Diaz, pictured) is taking him to the high school ball, until a nasty accident with his zipper ends the romance. Years later he employs Matt Dillon's private eye to track her down, but he starts making moves on her himself. The famous "hair-gel" amongst others scene shows that taste is far from the Farrellys' minds. The funny thing is, it's so funny.

Under The Volcano (John Huston, 1984) 3am, Carlton Cinema
Sombre adaptation of Malcolm Lowry's autobiographical tale of a self-destructive former British consul. Albert Finney is majestic as the doomed Geoffrey Firmin, who, in the Mexican village of Cuernavaca, on, appropriately, the Day of the Dead, is drinking himself to death. The sudden arrival of his wife (Jacqueline Bisset) offers only an illusory ray of hope. Gabriel Figueroa's superb photography captures both the vivid village celebrations, and the morbid shadows behind them.

Road To Singapore (Victor Schertzinger, 1940) 3.40am, Sky Cinema
First of seven Road movies in which rivals Bob Hope and Bing Crosby chase sarong girl Dorothy Lamour around the world. The clown and the crooner play a pair of bachelors who change their tune after setting eyes on Lamour, kitted out in her South Sea island gear: her hipcracking boyfriend Anthony Quinn is not amused.

fields.headline: Letters
fields.trailText: Harold Jackson writes: The fact that Robert Komer (Obituary, April 14) was, as his successor commented, "statistics-crazy", was borne out at my meeting with him in the wake of the 1968 Tet offensive in South Vietnam.
fields.body:
Harold Jackson writes: The fact that Robert Komer (Obituary, April 14) was, as his successor commented, "statistics-crazy", was borne out at my meeting with him in the wake of the 1968 Tet offensive in South Vietnam.

The US embassy in London had telexed to Komer's office in Saigon my reports of the devastating political impact in the villages. Komer called me in, and spent an hour in a convoluted explanation of his hamlet evaluation system and the 18 factors he could feed into two CDC 3100 computers to determine that a given village was, say, 82% pacified. It sounded quite mad, but I agreed to visit whichever village best represented the scheme.

The computer nominated Ngoc Diem, near Nha Trang. After a few phone calls, Komer suddenly asked if I wouldn't prefer somewhere nearer Saigon, but I insisted we stick to his original choice. It turned out that the Americans didn't control the airstrip there and, in the end, could only get me to Ngoc Diem in an armed convoy.

We arrived to find that the Vietnamese pacification team had buried their weapons and fled. The only remaining local official was about to join them, and grew increasingly agitated as I tried to talk to him; so did my American escorts. The unofficial but effective deal in that area was that the Vietcong took over at 5.30pm - and I was delaying the changeover.

Back in Saigon, I checked the status of Ngoc Diem that Komer was reporting to Washington. Category A, Mr President; no problem.

David Summerfield writes: I remember the actress Greta Gynt (Obituary, April 5) as a nightclub singer, singing a truly awful song in a film called Easy Money, a trilogy about people winning the football pools.

The song was called Lady Spiv. "When the lady, has the barrow,/ Her curves are neat, but her scales are narrow!/ She's feeding on champagne and oysters. She's a shady lady spiv./ She'll be your baby, but you gotta give, give!"

Believe it or not, this song was available on record.

Bryan West writes: Fiona MacCarthy gives a vivid account of the life of Father Brocard Sewell (Obituary, April 4). Her reference to "his last great work of scholarship, the St Dominic's Press Bibliography" is, however, less than accurate or fair. The biblio-graphy incorporated and corrected the work in Father Sewell's earlier simple checklist of 1979, but was almost entirely the result of original research by Michael Taylor, and was written by him.

fields.headline: Rosa Thornton
fields.standfirst: One woman's journey from revolutionary idealism to Stalin's slave labour camps
fields.trailText: When Rosa Thornton, who has died aged 74, was born in London, her young, East Ender father, Bill Rust, was leader of the Young Communist League. He named his daughter after the murdered German revolutionary, Rosa Luxembourg, but was himself soon facing a 12-month prison sentence for sedition and incitement.
fields.body:
When Rosa Thornton, who has died aged 74, was born in London, her young, East Ender father, Bill Rust, was leader of the Young Communist League. He named his daughter after the murdered German revolutionary, Rosa Luxembourg, but was himself soon facing a 12-month prison sentence for sedition and incitement.

Three years later, in 1928, Rust, the epitome of the dedicated British communist, set off for Moscow with his wife and child to work for the Comintern. Once there, Rosa aged three, promptly went down with scarlet fever; she recovered, but came out of hospital having forgotten how to speak English.

By 1930 the Rusts' marriage was over, and, back in London, Bill Rust was appointed as the first editor of the Daily Worker. In 1937, as Stalin's great terror reached its climax in the Soviet Union, Rosa's mother also came back to England. She promised to return for Rosa, but Bill suggested that the child would be better off in the Soviet Union. So their daughter was left at a boarding school for the children of top foreign communists, a few miles from Moscow - other pupils included the offspring of the future Yugoslav leader Marshal Tito, the future Hungarian leader Matyas Rakosi, and China's Mao Tse Tung.

By 1940, Rosa was living in a Moscow hostel for political immigrants, and loving it, with morning classes and evenings taken up with theatre, music and cinema. Then, in June 1941, came the Nazi invasion of the Soviet Union, and, within a month, the Luftwaffe was bombing Moscow. Her parents assumed she was safe but, amidst the chaos of war, the Soviet bureaucracy sucked her in, put her with a group of German exiles and sent her to the Soviet Union's Volga German republic, near the frontline.

On the Volga, Rosa made friends with Hannah, an older German Jewish woman. Hannah, weighing little more than seven stone, was physically weak; Rosa looked after her, and Hannah taught Rosa about survival. They shared a deserted house, and the 16-year-old worked 12-hour shifts in a canning factory.

Then, three months later, the militia came calling. Hannah, as a German, was to be deported to Kazakhstan. Rosa stood by her friend, and stumbled into one of Stalin's greatest crimes - the forced migration of hundreds of thousands of Volga Germans to the far corners of the vast country. For the rest of her life, one of Rosa's most insistent questions was, where are they now, the Volga Germans?

The two women travelled on horse and cart for 36 hours to Astrakhan, a transit centre for thousands of deportees. Then came three days on an open boat along the Caspian Sea to Guryev, followed by six weeks in railway cattle trucks. En route, a young woman nursing her four-month-old daughter, left the train to search for hot water. The train started without her - and Rosa was left, literally holding the baby. It took the mother a week to catch up, whereupon Rosa returned the infant alive and well.

Lice-ridden and close to starvation, they arrived in Kazakhstan, where Hannah and Rosa were separated. For two years, Rosa was worked close to death in the copper mines, pushing and emptying metal-laden rail trucks from 6am until after dusk. She never saw the sun. Back in London, oblivious to this suffering, her father was at the Daily Worker, still extolling the Soviet Union.

Malnutrition made Rosa half-blind, and turned her skin yellow. She avoided death only thanks to a letter that she wrote to a Moscow friend, asking that it be forwarded to someone in authority. It found its way to Georgi Dimitrov, general-secretary of the Comintern, and later ruler of communist Bulgaria. In spring 1943, a pass arrived, signed personally by Dimitrov. Weeks later, Rosa arrived in Moscow.

She told Dimitrov that she wanted to go to England, but would not leave until Hannah, and a dozen or so other Volga Germans, were rescued. Hannah was released, and Rosa boarded a convoy for Leith, from where she was sent to London. Neither the British government - then the wartime ally of the Soviet Union - nor the British Communist party had any interest in revealing what had happened to Rust's daughter, or news of cattle-trucks and deportations.

Rosa Rust was 19 before she had mastered English - after studying at the Regent Street Polytechnic - and, in later years, recalled how, in those early days, she had tried to post letters in bins marked "litter" and thought railway stations were called "Bovril" because that was what the posters said. After leaving the polytechnic, she worked as a translator for the Soviet news agency, Tass, until the Foreign Office closed it down in 1951. She married George Thornton, a brilliant young historian, whose career was later damaged by his association with Rosa and leftwing views.

Rosa soon discovered that she loved English poetry as much as she loved Pushkin, and became one of the most fluent and articulate people you could meet. All her life she could recite, among great swathes of other poetry, her first ever English poem: GK Chesterton's The Donkey. The passion and intensity of her voice, and the rhythm of the words, were given an extra dimension by her Russian accent.

Anyone who met Rosa sensed the inner strength that brought her out of Russia alive. And they too sensed the instinct of loyalty and rebellion that got her into the camps in the first place. She talked of it in a deep, clear voice full of great, gay Russian-sounding gusts of poetry and laughter.

She starred in the drama group she set up near Redcar, Yorkshire, where she and her husband lived. The actress Anna Calder-Marshall, who planned to present a one-woman show about Rosa's life, observed that there was only one person who could really play Rosa - and that was Rosa. She was, Calder-Marshall added, one of the most brilliant actresses she had ever met.

Rosa and George Thornton were devoted to each other for more than half a century, sharing a passion for drama and poetry, cricket and music, and walking by the sea. She died a Yorkshire grandmother with a Russian accent, leaving her husband, four grown-up children, and five grandchildren - who always called her "Babu", short for babushka, the Russian for grandmother.
Rosa Thornton (née Rust), born April 26 1925; died April 2 2000.

The passion and intensity of her voice, and the rhythm of the words, were given an extra dimension by her Russian accent. Anyone who met Rosa sensed the inner strength that brought her out of Russia alive. And they too sensed the instinct of loyalty and rebellion that got her into the camps in the first place. She talked of it in a deep, clear voice full of great, gay Russian-sounding gusts of poetry and laughter. She starred in the drama group she set up near Redcar, Yorkshire, where she and her husband lived. The actress Anna Calder-Marshall, who planned to present a one-woman show about Rosa's life, observed that there was only one person who could really play Rosa - and that was Rosa. She was, Calder-Marshall added, one of the most brilliant actresses she had ever met. Rosa and George Thornton were devoted to each other for more than half a century, sharing a passion for drama and poetry, cricket and music, and walking by the sea. She died a Yorkshire grandmother with a Russian accent, leaving her husband, four grown-up children, and five grandchildren - who always called her "Babu", short for babushka, the Russian for grandmother. Rosa Thornton (née Rust), born April 26 1925; died April 2 2000.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Radio
fields.body:
As Easter draws near, radio turns religious and along with the usual passion plays and masses a couple of sideways looks at the Bible and Christianity are included in the schedules. Crown Of Thorns (Radio 4, 9.30am) explores the flora and fauna mentioned in the Gospels. Botanist Paul Morrison visits Kew Gardens to find the tree which was used to make Christ's crown of thorns and comes up with two candidates: Paliurus Spina-Christi and Ziziphus Spina-Christi, both common in Palestine at the time.

This week's Lunchtime Concerts (Radio 3, 1.0pm) are devoted to lesser known religious works. Today's, The True Cross, features the Joglaresa ensemble performing live from London's Temple Church. In a programme of music from the time of the Crusades - cue ouds, shawms and tabors and a felicitous exchange of ideas between Christian Europe and the Muslim Middle East - we hear from both sides of the religious divide.

fields.headline: Jeremy James
fields.standfirst: Gifted modern dancer who matured into a choreographer of rich and energetic work
fields.trailText: The Australian-born dancer and choreographer Jeremy James, who has died aged 38, performed with some of Britain's leading groups - the Rambert Dance Company, the Siobhan Davies Dance Company, the Arc and DV8. Thus his first attempts at choreography were made in the spaces of a busy dancing career.
fields.body:
The Australian-born dancer and choreographer Jeremy James, who has died aged 38, performed with some of Britain's leading groups - the Rambert Dance Company, the Siobhan Davies Dance Company, the Arc and DV8. Thus his first attempts at choreography were made in the spaces of a busy dancing career.

James was that rare thing - a gifted stage performer who turned out to be equally talented at making dance for others. During the late 1980s and early 1990s, he became well-known to British audiences as one of the most interesting modern dancers on stage. His style of movement was shaped by a classical discipline, coloured by a dark energy and a sardonic wit that were very much his own.

Even in abstract works, he communicated the force of an intelligent and highly unpredictable personality, so his audience never quite knew when the brooding edginess of his expression would lighten with a flash of humour. He was a dance-maker with a passion for structure, and, in his recent works especially, won critical acclaim for the formal intricacy and emotional resonance of his compositions.

The bold physicality of James's style looked entirely modern, but he was actually trained in classical ballet. He attended both the upper and lower schools of the Royal Ballet and, after graduating in 1980, perfomed with London City Ballet (the small-scale touring company directed by Harold King), then with Australian Ballet and Western Australian Ballet.

During these years he danced several leading roles, including James in La Sylphide, Blue Bird in Sleeping Beauty and the Prince in Nutcracker. But his essentially maverick style was not suited to the traditional aesthetic of a ballet company, nor to its hierarchical structure, and in 1987 he returned to Britain to work in modern dance.

In 1996, he stopped working for other choreographers and concentrated on making his own work. His progress was fast, maturing in four years from a slightly self-conscious subversiveness to work that was rich in detail and controlled in energy. Most of his work was for his own group, though in 1998 he created a work for Rambert - Gaps, Lapse And Relapse - and was due to make another for that company later this year. In June, he was also due to premiere a work for the Royal Ballet at the Linbury studio theatre, his first return to the classical stage.

James's death was tragically premature for his family and friends. For the wider dance community, it also represents the loss of an exciting talent just as it was coming into its own.

Siobhan Davies writes:
Jeremy was truly loved for his vitality, humour and total lack of pretension. He enjoyed solving problems, both as a dancer and choreographer.

When structuring dance, one has the natural tendency to create movement in the foreground and support it with other, more transitional, in-between movement. There was nothing in-between about Jeremy, however. He danced in the present, carving complete movement in the air. We shall miss his enormous character and kindness, and the wealth of creative energy he would have continued to bring to his friends and to dance.

Richard Alston writes:
Jeremy was a maverick; he always seemed to arrive at moments of achievement by a deviant and quirky route. His view of life was direct, sometimes dauntingly so, but he could never hide a vulnerability which made us all love him intensely.

He never wanted a fuss. He would grin and pull a face if I complimented him on his work, but as a young choreographer, he was a talent I really enjoyed watching. We'll never know now how things might have developed, which is sad, but sadder for me is the fact that I have lost a genuinely sweet friend.

Jeremy James, dancer and choreographer, born August 4 1961; died April 5 2000.

fields.headline: Getting personal with... Aimee Mann
fields.trailText: Answer me
fields.body:
Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why? Only when I'm checking into a hotel and the road manager thinks a fan might stalk me.

Have you ever lied about your age and, if so, why? When I was 15, to get into bars.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad? Single white female seeks single white male with at least 10 years' therapy. Except I'm married so I wouldn't place an ad.

What was the last illegal thing you did? Jaywalked in LA. That's a serious risk. A friend of mine got a ticket for it on Christmas Eve.

What was the last kindhearted thing you did? Voluntarily gave my manager a 5% raise.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with? Tom Cruise. He's the nicest guy in the universe and he's unbelievably approachable. It might all be an act, of course.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with? JI. Someone in the music industry.

Has a critic ever made you cry? No, so far my reviews have all been good.

What would you advertise without a fee? The electric car. I want to stop the greenhouse effect.

What would you never advertise? Guns.

What wakes you up screaming at night? I was in a bad car accident a while ago which still makes me frightened. I don't scream though.

What takes you to a happy place? Getting off the Eurostar and driving through London. Forget Paris, London is the place.

 Aimee Mann's soundtrack to Magnolia is out on Reprise Records. Her single, Save Me, is released on 24 April .

webTitle: 'A society with no imagination is a monster'

fields.headline: 'A society with no imagination is a monster'
fields.standfirst: What is a group of Turkish refugees doing in an opera about the crucifixion? Director David Pountney tells all to  Tim Ashley
fields.trailText: What is a group of Turkish refugees doing in an opera about the crucifixion? Director David Pountney tells all to Tim Ashley
fields.body:
'It all began when I was a student," says David Pountney. "That's when I discovered Janacek. After that, I simply wanted to know what went before and what came since." The opera director, who next week is bringing Bohuslav Martinu's The Greek Passion to Covent Garden, is talking about one of his abiding passions - Czech music. "It speaks to me directly, intuitively. I was in Prague recently, and someone said to me: 'You're the man who's directed 14 Czech operas.' " He smiles with pride.

Pountney's relationship with Czech opera is symbiotic. He made his professional debut in 1972 with Janacek's Katya Kabanova at the Wexford festival. Between 1975 and 1980, he was at Scottish Opera - and it was his Janacek cycle that lingers in the memory. His much-imitated staging of Dvorak's Rusalka at the Coliseum in 1981 took London by storm, and was instrumental in forging the style of ENO's so-called "powerhouse" years, during which Pountney was director of productions.

Listening to him, you realise just how formative his discovery of Janacek has been. One constantly finds points of consonance between Pountney's productions (regardless of who wrote the actual opera) and Janacek's scores: the same combination of intelligent fixity, concise detail and dense emotion; a comparable insistence on peeling back the layers of the psyche and unflinchingly probing the human soul.

His work has caused a drastic reappraisal of Czech music. Rusalka - a variant of The Little Mermaid - was considered twee until Pountney unearthed the Freudian monstrosity beneath its surface. Janacek's Osud (Fate) was once deemed both a dramatic nightmare and a musical failure. Pountney proved that the piece made perfect sense. He will have to force London audiences to rethink The Greek Passion, too (his production opened at Austria's Bregenz festival last summer), for Martinu has a precarious reputation.

"He's the least Czech of Czech composers," says Pountney. "He's cosmopolitan." Pinning Martinu down is never easy. The music reflects the man, for he was in some respects nomadic, an eternal wanderer.

He was born (atop a church tower, famously) in the village of Policka in 1890, began composing when he was 10, and later played the fiddle in the Czech Philharmonic until a bursary took him to Paris to study in 1923. France was his home until 1940, when the Nazis arrived. He fled to the US, wound up in New York, and loathed it - but the experience of enforced exile radically affected his music. With the exception of his 1938 opera Julietta (Pountney directed it for Opera North last year), his best work dates from the end of his career. The Greek Passion occupied him from 1955 until his death in 1959.

On one level, the opera is a harrowing distillation of the experiences of his miserable last years. Ill with cancer, he was on the move again. In the US, he'd fallen foul of the McCarthyites. In Prague, meanwhile, the communist government had dubbed him "the servant of reaction". "He didn't know where to be," says Pountney. "He wrote the opera in something like 30 different addresses."

Dispossession is one of the central themes of The Greek Passion. The other is the messy bifurcation between the Christian message and the often appalling acts committed in its name. Unlike most Passion music, the opera throws the redemptive Easter message a fairly hefty challenge.

Its immediate source was the 1951 novel Christ Re-crucified by Nikos Kazantzakis, whose work can still whip up a storm, as Martin Scorsese discovered when he filmed The Last Temptation of Christ. Martinu wrote the libretto himself in English with Kazantzakis's approval.

The setting is the aftermath of the first world war, when there was still a Turkish presence in Greece and the political map of the Balkans was being redrawn. The church elders of a Greek village are casting their annual Passion play from among the local residents: the shepherd Manolios is to play Christ; a young widow of dubious morals is given the role of Mary Magdalen; her vicious, embittered lover takes on Judas. Their preparations are interrupted by the arrival of a group of refugees, victims of Turkish violence. The village authorities refuse them shelter, but the apostles of the Passion play side with the homeless. Life, art and scripture slowly intertwine and, at the end, Manolios-Christ is recrucified by his own community as the refugees are forced to move on.

"Kazantzakis was a communist," says Pountney. "The book was written to expose religion. Martinu is more equivocal. It's about how religious feeling produces both good and evil." When the production opened in Bregenz, however, it was the opera's political elements that struck the deepest resonance. With the horror of Bosnia fresh in everyone's minds, some critics thought Pountney had updated the work to the present. He hadn't, "but it's so actual you would think it was now," he says.

We are talking in one of the Royal Opera's rehearsal rooms, a white, antiseptic cube transfigured by Stefanos Lazaridis's phenomenal set. Vast gilded wooden pillars soar to the ceiling, intersected by vertical, cruciform bars. Ramps and walkways spiral up to vertiginous platforms. Incense burners, candles, banners and icons are propped against the walls. Pountney takes a prop Easter egg from a wicker basket, and rocks it between his hands. "The set is based on the stations of the cross," he says, "though we've only got seven platforms rather than 14. It also represents the stages of an itinerant miracle play. If you really want a reason to get into Pseuds Corner, it's also a double helix. It's life itself."

Life remained unkind to Martinu. He never saw The Greek Passion staged. In 1957, he offered the opera to Covent Garden, where the music director was his compatriot, the legendary Rafael Kubelik. Kubelik was keen, but the piece was turned down by the Royal Opera's board, for reasons that have never fully been established.

Martinu went away and rewrote the piece virtually from scratch. The second version was finally premiered in Zurich in 1961 and has remained until now the standard performing edition, though Pountney and the conductor Charles Mackerras (another ardent champion of Czech music, though he and Pountney have rarely worked together) are reverting to the original score.

Pountney finds "the sheer momentum" of the first version over whelming. "Martinu was one of the first composers to experiment with combinations of theatre and film. The first version has a cinematic approach - there's a collage-like feeling. It accumulates power through layering. Later, it all became much more conventional."

For Pountney, this is just the start: later this year he's off to Prague to stage The Soldier and The Dancer, a virtually unknown product of Martinu's Paris years. "It's very different," he says. "It's a kind of bizarre 20s cabaret. It's full of charlestons, jazz, black musicians. It's like the world of Josephine Baker - but the plot's based on Plautus. I haven't quite figured out how to make sense of it yet."

There is, perhaps, a reason for Pountney's devotion to The Greek Passion which runs deeper than his obvious love of the music. "Opera has a social and communal function," he says. It's a way of stating the political importance of the imagination. An opera house should be the property of the citizens, a place where they come to celebrate the imagination. A society with no imagination is a monster."

He could be talking about The Greek Passion itself. The opera catalogues humanity's dismal record of spiritual and political failure. Yet, as Manolios and his Apostles grow quite literally into their roles, it also celebrates the power of the theatrical experience to sharpen moral awareness, to heighten the imagination - and, ultimately, to change lives.

 The Greek Passion is at the Royal Opera House, London WC2 (020-7304 4000), from Tuesday till May 8.

fields.headline: Amanda Atha
fields.standfirst: Journalist in search of schools and scandals
fields.trailText: The journalist Amanda Atha, who has died aged 51, was a shrewd, graceful writer on many subjects, but was able to read the runes of all of them. She loved music (singing in Oxford and London choirs), fly-fishing, skiing, ecology, the property market, travel and education.
fields.byline: Marcelle d'Argy Smith and Ann Barr
fields.body:
The journalist Amanda Atha, who has died aged 57, was a shrewd, graceful writer on many subjects, but was able to read the runes of all of them. She loved music (singing in Oxford and London choirs), fly-fishing, skiing, ecology, the property market, travel and education.

In her last years, she carried most of the burden of the Good Schools Guide, a perennial volume originally commissioned from Sarah Drummond, who took on her fellow Harpers & Queen feature writer, Amanda. The two became joint editors of this first book of its sort, serialised by the Times as a strong card to play against the Independent, also newly launched in 1986.

Parents fell on this witty guide, which was also investigative journalism, being the result of months spent visiting 270 schools, interviewing all the heads, talking to pupils, telephoning parents and getting the information that would lead to placing children where they would thrive.

If a school refused their request to visit, Sarah or Amanda would pose as a prospective parent to nose around. Their frankness inevitably brought some legal panics - a frequent accompaniment of Amanda’s writing. Some pages of the guide had to be removed after it revealed where Salman Rushdie’s son was being educated.

The guide covered junior and senior schools, mostly private, some state. In later editions the proportion changed, and Atha wrote about state schools that were getting better results than the famous independents. In 1992, the Daily Telegraph started its own schools guide, but Atha maintained that hers and Drummond’s was the only completely objective volume - having no connection with advertising - and that their advisory service took no money from the schools recommended.

Amanda Atha was educated at Clifton high school, Bristol, and St Anne’s College, Oxford, where she read modern languages. She did intelligence work at the Foreign Office, and then got into publishing. Once in journalism, her love of travel - and her ability to coax freebies out of travel editors and companies - sometimes meant that her whereabouts were mysterious. On one occasion, a features editor, who had been told she was covering the Montreal Olympics, used the telephone number given him, and got through to a Caribbean island.

Amanda had good timing and great charm. She was incapable of personal aggression, and was welcomed into the most exclusive circles wherever she turned up on a story - for instance, in the Aga Khan’s Costa Smeralda on the Sardinian coast and at the 1983 British America’s Cup Challenge Ball at Newport, Rhode Island, where she interviewed a wriggling Peter de Savary.

Yet her gentleness belied her tenacity in research. She investigated the Forestry Commission and the Saatchi art collection for Harpers & Queen, analysing Charles Saatchi’s influence on the art world and whether the Saatchis’ art, bought by the company, was being exhibited as the family property of Charles and Doris Saatchi. This article, finally published in August 1984 after much legal attention, naturally alarmed the managing director of the National Magazine Co, Saatchi’s being then responsible for much of its advertising revenue.

fields.bodyText: The journalist Amanda Atha, who has died aged 57, was a shrewd, graceful writer on many subjects, but was able to read the runes of all of them. She loved music (singing in Oxford and London choirs), fly-fishing, skiing, ecology, the property market, travel and education. In her last years, she carried most of the burden of the Good Schools Guide, a perennial volume originally commissioned from Sarah Drummond, who took on her fellow Harpers & Queen feature writer, Amanda. The two became joint editors of this first book of its sort, serialised by the Times as a strong card to play against the Independent, also newly launched in 1986. Parents fell on this witty guide, which was also investigative journalism, being the result of months spent visiting 270 schools, interviewing all the heads, talking to pupils, telephoning parents and getting the information that would lead to placing children where they would thrive. If a school refused their request to visit, Sarah or Amanda would pose as a prospective parent to nose around. Their frankness inevitably brought some legal panics - a frequent accompaniment of Amanda’s writing. Some pages of the guide had to be removed after it revealed where Salman Rushdie’s son was being educated. The guide covered junior and senior schools, mostly private, some state. In later editions the proportion changed, and Atha wrote about state schools that were getting better results than the famous independents. She did intelligence work at the Foreign Office, and then got into publishing. fields.headline: Casting of the 1,000
fields.standfirst: Meanwhile, a very different Passion play is planned for Greenwich.   Lyn Gardner  reports
fields.trailText: Meanwhile, a very different Passion play is planned for Greenwich. Lyn Gardner reports
fields.body:
Jesus has misbehaved and been grounded by his mum, the donkey that's supposed to carry him into Jerusalem keeps biting people, and there isn't enough food for the 5,000. Then there are the bouncy castles - a neat device to show the Pharisees are on shaky ground, but not if the inflated sides hide them from the audience.

Such problems shouldn't faze John Doyle, a man who has organised Mystery cycles for both Coventry and York. But his latest biblical extravaganza, a Passion play to be staged in Greenwich, southeast London, is the biggest yet.

The Greenwich Passion Play has been two years in the making. It has a cast of almost 1,000 local people, most of whom won't have met until they take to the stage. The audience is expected to hit at least 3,000 for the one-off performance in Greenwich Park on Good Friday.

This event, which brings together seven stories from the Gospels - as well as seven Jesuses of different races, ages and genders - has grown out of a desire to create something that represents the local community in this millennium year. Whether or not the nearby Dome should have done this, it does not. But there lies the problem. In medieval times the Mysteries came out of the community. Is there such a thing in southeast London in the year 2000?

In York in the 14th century individual guilds of craftsmen were responsible for different parts of the Bible stories: the shipwrights made Noah's Ark and performed its story, the vintners staged the wedding feast at Cana, and the nail-makers enacted the fixing of Jesus to the cross. Doyle has tried to get something similar going, with a local Jewish dance group performing the Wedding Feast of Cana and a primary school doing the feeding of the 5,000 as a circus act with Jesus as a magician. But the fractured nature of modern city life means there are no natural communities to draw upon any more. Instead we have the Yellow Pages.

It would be nice to think that putting a stockbroker from Blackheath next to a road sweeper from Charlton would break down barriers and create a new community spirit. Doyle and his team know that's rather optimistic. But they do believe performance can bring people together. "Theatre," Doyle says, "is probably the biggest ritual we have left in our lives." To that end, he has insisted from the beginning that this Passion play isn't just about marshalling a huge number of people in the park on a Friday afternoon, but is a genuinely theatrical event that stands or falls on its artistic merits.

The temptation was to indulge in a quick fix of pyrotechnics, spectacle, doves and bouncy castles, but Doyle, who is famed for his award-winning, stripped-down stagings of big-scale musicals such as Cabaret and Into the Woods, has instead opted for a streamlined simplicity, with the stories enacted simultane ously on seven stages with help from a local gospel choir, the Salvation Army band, a rap group, and a steel pan orchestra. The central motif has become a couple of ladders that are used in every way you can imagine and are eventually used to create that cross on which Ben Thomas - the only professional actor in the cast and Britain's first black Lear - will eventually be crucified. Thomas will be left hanging on the cross as the rest of the cast and the audience depart, a lonely figure in the middle of the park.

In York seven centuries ago, the city council policed the standards of the Mystery plays, levying fines for delaying the procession, deviating from the script or plain bad acting. Fortunately perhaps,there will be no such penalties at Greenwich on Friday. "Getting 1,000 people together at all is a bit of a miracle," says Doyle, who believes there is something special about expending two years of energy on just one performance. "And of course the advantage if you only do it once is that nobody will know if something went wrong."

 The Greenwich Passion Play is in Greenwich Park, London SE10, from 12 noon on Friday. Box office: 01395 223400.

webTitle: Stolen Vichy millions to be returned

fields.headline: Stolen Vichy millions to be returned
fields.trailText: France is to compensate Holocaust survivors and their families after a government report published yesterday revealed that property and cash worth more than £800m was seized from the Jewish community during the second world war.
fields.body:
France is to compensate Holocaust survivors and their families after a government report published yesterday revealed that property and cash worth more than £800m was seized from the Jewish community during the second world war.

More than £200m of that is still held by the government and other financial institutions, according to an inquiry team headed by a Gaullist former labour minister, Jean Matteoli, which was allowed access to files sealed for more than 50 years.

Yesterday, the prime minister, Lionel Jospin, was handed 10 volumes of findings which said that restitution of confiscated property was important but was not the investigations's essential conclusion.

"Before it became a matter of money, spoliation was an act of persecution which led to extermination," the commission said, emphasising the Vichy regime's complicity in the murder of Jews.

Most of the property and money was seized under anti-semitic laws promulgated by Philippe Pétain's government, but personal articles worth another £20m were stolen from Jews awaiting deportation in French concentration camps.

More than 76,000 French Jews were sent to die in Germany. Only 2,500 survived.

The first attempt since the war to estimate the monetary cost of official persecution followed a policy change after the 14-year reign of Socialist president François Mitterrand ended in 1995.

The Jewish community blamed him for holding up reparations and obstructing the trials of collaborators. His Gaullist successor, Jacques Chirac, publicly condemned Vichy as a criminal regime and called for reparations.

The 11-member commission appointed by the then prime minister, Alain Juppé, included historians, diplomats and members of the Jewish community, including the Nazi-hunter Serge Klarsfeld and the president of French Jewish institutions, Jean Kahn.

They discovered that much of the looted property had been given back, but that Fr1.4bn of assets was still in government holdings and another Fr1bn in the hands of other financial instititutions.

Most of the stolen property cannot be restored because the owners were gassed after being transported to Germany in trains guarded by the French gendarmerie.

One key aspect of the report was a recommendation to use unclaimed funds to set up a foundation to encourage study of the period by teachers, historians and human rights workers.

This will be aided by the opening up of many previously inaccessible archives, including the Paris police records of mass round-ups and internments.

Applications for compensation will be heard by another commission headed by a judge, Pierre Drai, but no one is sure how many survivors and their families will apply.

An estimated 330,000 Jews lived in France during the war and many were subject to expropriations of homes and businesses.

Two statutes which banned French Jews from earning a living made it easier for Vichy to confiscate 80,000 bank accounts and seize 6,000 personal safes. More than 90% of this was given back after the war.

The inquiry team separated Vichy's legalised spoliation from mass looting by the Nazis.

Most of this stolen property, including 100,000 works of art, has been returned, but 2,000 paintings are still on display in French museums because their owners cannot be found.

The findings are online at www.ladocfrancaise.gouv.fr, which includes an exhaustive list of archives open to the public.

The most useful are the files of the general commissariat on the Jewish question, which carried out aryanisation programmes and recorded transactions to the last centime.

The address of La Commission d'indemnisation des victimes de spoliations, which will hear claims, is 66 rue de Bellechasse, 75007 Paris.
