webTitle: Cult papers reveal new massacre link

fields.headline: Cult papers reveal new massacre link
fields.standfirst: Documents show Ugandan sect leader 'inspired' by visits from Australian doomsday group
fields.trailText: The former Ugandan cult leader Joseph Kibwetere, now wanted for murder, was linked to an Australian doomsday group, the Marian Workers of Atonement, according to documents found at his home by the Guardian.
fields.byline: Giles Foden  in Mbarara and Anna Borzello in Kampala
fields.body:
The former Ugandan cult leader Joseph Kibwetere, now wanted for murder, was linked to an Australian doomsday group, the Marian Workers of Atonement, according to documents found at his home by the Guardian.

According to his wife, Teresa, she and her husband attended talks on supernatural manifestations given by the leader of the Australian group, William Kamm - whose spiritual name is "Little Pebble" - in Kampala, Uganda's capital.

Based in Nowra, New South Wales, the followers of 49-year-old Kamm share many beliefs with Kibwetere's cult, the Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God, at least 330 members of which were killed in a fire in their church at Kanungu, in western Uganda. Many others are believed to have died, but it was impossible to accurately count their charred remains.

Some 395 bodies, mainly of women and children, were later found in the compounds of three buildings run by the cult. Police believe that there are more dead, but have yet to resume their search because of lack of funds and equipment.

According to the documents, Mr Kamm held four meetings at the Kampala police mess between October 6 and 10, 1989 - when reports of manifestations of the Virgin Mary, an aspect common to both cults, were becoming frequent throughout Uganda and neighbouring Rwanda. Mrs Kibwetere said she had been in contact with Mr Kamm before she and her husband went to hear him talk. "We were interested in visions of His Blessed Mother... Little Pebble sent us these papers and I used to write to him. Then he came to Uganda and we went to see him in Kampala."

The couple's son, Rugambwa, said the visit made a strong impression on his father. "I remember them going, and when my father came back he said that Little Pebble had filled him with new hope."

The manifesto of the Kanungu cult - entitled A Timely Message from Heaven: The End of the Present Times, which was first published in 1991 - also names Little Pebble among those "from various countries who got revelations and visions of the chastisements that are coming".

Satanic prayers
Australian cultwatch groups have expressed a suspicion of links between Mr Kamm's group and the Ugandan cult. "All apocalyptic groups feed off each other, so I wouldn't be surprised to find some of William's messages among the documents. But it doesn't mean that it was necessarily William who made the group go off," said Wally Anglesea, who is based in Australia and has been monitoring the Little Pebble cult for the past 16 years. The activities of the cult, he said, had caused serious concern in Australia. His sister-in-law had been a member during the 1980s. "Yes, they are dangerous. Categorically, yes. The reason they are dangerous is the combination of weapons and paranoia and apocalypticism. It's a dangerous cocktail."

The documents found in the Kibwetere house are a mixture of dispatches from Little Pebble's Australian headquarters and apparently verbatim transcripts of the talks Mrs Kibwetere says he gave in Uganda. They also include a prayer for satanic exorcism.

The papers suggest that Mr Kamm was accompanied by a J Duff. According to Mr Anglesea, a James Duffy is head of security of the Little Pebble group, and also acts as the leader's bodyguard. A Ugandan, known only as Mr Iga, introduced the visitors. In a meeting on October 6 1989, Mr Kamm reportedly urged those attending - described in the documents as "the congregation" - to "not be surprised that the church in Uganda, Kenya, Tanzania or any other place is speaking against apparitions". He then called for those present to "join with Little Pebble of Australia". There are clear similarities between the Little Pebble and the Kanungu cults, apart from their claims of direct contact with the Virgin Mary (both refer to receiv ing these messages via a "voice box"). The symbol of the Ark is prominent in each of the cults. The followers of the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God called the church they entered before burning to death their "Ark". They also told friends and relatives that the Virgin Mary was coming to take them to heaven - also promised to Little Pebble's followers on their leader's website.

Papal aspiration
Mr Kamm founded his organisation - sometimes also referred to as Our Lady of the Ark and the Order of St Charbel - between 1970-72. He claims to be in contact with the Virgin Mary and Jesus Christ as well as other heavenly beings, from whom he says he receives a constant stream of prophetic messages. These are in a similar format to those purportedly received by Kibwetere and the five other leaders of the Ugandan cult.

Born in Cologne, Germany, Mr Kamm changed his name to Little Pebble in the early 1980s, perhaps in reference to the biblical St Peter, the Rock. He has for many years been in conflict with the established Catholic church in his local diocese of Wollongong and with the archdiocese of Melbourne. Among his many claims - on his website and in the Ugandan documents - are that he will be the next pope, and he claims that when he met Pope John Paul II, the pontiff confirmed it.

The Little Pebble website does show pictures of Mr Kamm meeting the Pope. But on July 17 1985, Archbishop Barbarito, the Pope's representative in Australia, sent the following message to Bishop Murray of Wollongong, who had already declared Kamm's movement inauthentic. The message, directly from Archbishop Edward Martin, then the Pope's chief secretary, read: "I ask you to inform Bishop Murray that though... Mr Kamm met the Holy Father... and took part with others of the faithful at the Mass in the Holy Father's private chapel, nevertheless he did not receive any approval of his alleged 'visions' on the part of the Holy Father."

In 1997, George Pell, Archbishop of Melbourne, issued a statement in which he made it clear that Little Pebble did not have the approval of the archdiocese.

The archbishop's statement ran: "Messages are alleged to have been received from this person in which great emphasis is placed on millennialism, warnings, signs, torments, days of darkness. Alleged private revelations are given importance above the revealed teaching of Scripture and the authentic guidance of the Church. Messages which are not consistent with the Word of God and the constant teaching of the Church are to be rejected."

The Ugandan connection also raises questions about the role of the country's police force in the Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God. Five former Ugandan police officers are known to have died in the Kanungu fire, and allegations have been made about local authority complicity in the cult's activities.

The acting inspector general of police, Stephen Oonyu, said that the police mess where the meetings were held had closed "sometime" during late 1989 or in 1990. But he added that any meeting of this kind would have required the authorisation of the inspector general at the time.

webTitle: Polish farmers declare war over EU membership

fields.headline: Polish farmers declare war over EU membership
fields.standfirst:
Thousands of smallholders claim they are being pushed to the wall in the Warsaw government's rush to negotiate with Brussels on entry
The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: Poland's politicians may be embracing early membership of the European Union but its farmers are furious about the move, which could wipe out their livelihoods.
fields.byline: Tony Paterson  in Augustow, north-east Poland
fields.body:
Poland's politicians may be embracing early membership of the European Union but its farmers are furious about the move, which could wipe out their livelihoods.

This week, as the European commission finalises its draft plan for the inclusion of Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Slovenia and Cyprus in the union, many of the fields around Augustow remain a wasteland.

"Polish agriculture is already ruined," said one farmer, Stanislaw Bojkowski, 67, who tills 50 acres near Augustow.

"Farming was worthwhile under communism, but Warsaw's European Union madness is driving us out of business."

He is not alone. According to estimates from the Polish Peasants' party, only 600,000 of the country's 2m farms will survive the process of joining the EU.

Yet Warsaw's liberal-conservative coalition government is adamant that Poland must join as soon as possible.

Mr Bojkowski is cultivating only half of his land this year - he cannot afford the fertilisers needed for the rest.

"The money I get for the wheat and potatoes I manage to produce hardly makes it worthwhile. The bulk of my income these days derives from my old-age pension," he said.

Two miles away, Mieczyslaw Suchocki, 43, has tried to offset his farming losses by taking a share in a grocery store.

In the 1980s his 74-acre farm, producing potatoes, wheat and tobacco, was subsidised by the state. A single tobacco crop earned Mr Suchocki enough to buy a car.

Now the terms of growing are set by the multinational British American Tobacco company. "Starting next year, BAT is only buying tobacco from farmers who plant and dry it with the special drying equipment we can buy from them.

"I would need a $10,000 loan to purchase the equipment and I simply can't afford it. Producing tobacco on a small scale is out," he said.

The collapse of small-scale farming is a dilemma faced by all the EU candidate countries but it is acute in Poland, where some 26% of the working population is in agriculture.

Roman Jagielinski of the Polish Peasants' party argues that the state must make social security provision for farmers forced out of business. He wants the rest to receive subsidies from Brussels.

But Brussels has so far turned a deaf ear. The common agricultural policy subsidy budget, which amounts to more than £25bn a year in direct aid to EU farmers, has been fixed until 2006.

It contains no provision for EU candidate countries, although Poland is still aiming for a 2003 entry date.

The anger of Polish farmers boiled over last year, when the militant agricultural workers' union Samoobrona (Self- Defence) staged countrywide protests against the flood of cheap EU imports.

This persuaded Warsaw to temporarily ban grain imports and raise the amounts paid for home-grown pork.

But the moves were not enough to satisfy Samoobrona's leader, Andrej Lepper, who will run as a candidate in the presidential election this autumn.

"Poland is not being treated as a partner by the EU. We are simply being used as a dumping ground for their surplus products," he said.

Two-thirds of large farm owners recently declared their readiness to take part in further militant protests.

fields.headline: Berlusconi wins Italy's vote
fields.trailText: Italy's centre-left government was reeling last night after Silvio Berlusconi's opposition bloc won landslide victories in regional elections.
fields.body:
Italy's centre-left government was reeling last night after Silvio Berlusconi's opposition bloc won landslide victories in regional elections.

The prime minister, Massimo D'Alema offered his resignation after the media magnate made a spectacular comeback on a platform of slashing taxes, cracking down on crime and cutting immigration.

But President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi rejected the offer and told him to seek a vote of confidence in parliament.

"I think it would be a mistake to dissolve parliament now, because the country needs stability at this moment," said Mr D'Alema. He will try to win the vote of confidence.

Euphoric conservatives hailed Mr Berlusconi for delivering a potentially knockout blow to the ruling coalition by sweeping the north and win ning three of the biggest contests elsewhere.

A dirty election campaign ended in disaster for the centre-left, which has a wafer-thin majority and faces intense pressure to call an immediate general election rather than wait until the due date of April 2001.

The right won eight of the 15 regional races, taking 50.7% of all votes cast, to the left's 45.1%. Some 30m of Italy's 56m population voted.

It was a triumph for the 63-year-old billionaire they call the Cavalier. Mr Berlusconi - whose eight-month premiership of Italy ended in 1994 after he was charged with corruption - brushed aside convictions as a Stalinist plot and branded his opponents dangerous Marxists who were opening the floodgates to illegal immigrants.

Canvassers of his Forza Italia party were issued breath fresh eners, told to smile and backed up by planes and trucks and a luxury liner that toured Italy. "This is not a cruise, it's a crusade," he told them.

Cutting a folksy figure against the austere prime minister, he offered his own meteoric rise from humble origins as an example to the country. "We are here to fight a battle to change an old state and to defend citizens' rights," he said. "It is a mission that has fallen on the shoulders of a little old man who, after working hard all his life thought that he could finally read the books he hadn't read yet, listen to his favourite music and play with his grandchildren."

The campaign degenerated into the ugliest in recent memory. Personal insults and accusations swamped efforts to debate policies.

Regional issues were ignored because Mr Berlusconi and Mr D'Alema, both anxious to stamp their leadership on fractious coalitions, turned the vote into a litmus test of national power.

The media tycoon formed a pact with the far-right National Alliance party and the Northern League, which wants devolved powers and fewer foreigners in Italy. Catholic church leaders condemned a policy of mandatory jail terms for illegal immigrants as redolent of the Austrian Freedom party.

Mr D'Alema, 51 on Thursday, predicted that the left would hold its nine regions but he was crippled by sniping from within his coalition, which includes social democrats, hardline communists, greens and ex Christian Democrats.

A reviving economy and a bold foreign policy was not enough for voters to warm to Mr D'Alema, an intellectual who is seen as aloof and sarcastic.

webTitle: Mugabe vents anger at growing opposition

fields.headline: Mugabe vents anger at growing opposition
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Eight members of Zimbabwe's new opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change, have been killed in the last two weeks and more than 100 others have been hospitalised during a vicious campaign of political violence waged by President Robert Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF party.
fields.body:
Eight members of Zimbabwe's new opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change, have been killed in the last two weeks and more than 100 others have been hospitalised during a vicious campaign of political violence waged by President Robert Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF party.

The opposition party is giving Zanu-PF its strongest challenge since it came to power at the country's independence in 1980 and this appears to have prompted the violence.

The weekend killing of a white farmer, David Stevens, is considered part of the wave of political violence, as Mr Stevens was an MDC supporter, which infuriated the local Zanu-PF supporters.

Far from urging his supporters to refrain from violence, Mr Mugabe on Sunday told members of his party to "hit out fiercely" against the opposition. However, Mr Mugabe expressed regret about the killing of Mr Stevens yesterday when he met privately with representatives of the country's 4,200 white farmers.

The president of the Commercial Farmers' Union, Tim Henwood, said Mr Mugabe wanted to get Zimbabwe "back to normal", but Mr Mugabe said he would not order squatters off white-owned farms. Mr Henwood also said police had not made any arrests for Mr Stevens' killing, despite several identifications of his abductors by local people.

The violence has cast a sombre mood over the country as it marks the 20th anniversary of its independence today. Recognising the sober atmosphere, the government cancelled today's celebration rallies. Instead Mr Mugabe will give a national address on television and radio.

In response to the violence, the MDC called an emergency meeting of its national executive last night to determine how to respond to the intimidation.

Two MDC members died on Saturday when a petrol bomb was thrown into their car in the Buhera area of south-east Zimbabwe. One of those killed, Tichaona Chiminya, 42, was a close aide to the MDC's president, Morgan Tsvangirai.

"[Chiminya] had gone to Buhera to drum up a rally over the Easter holidays for Mr Tsvangirai," said a MDC security officer, Job Sikhala. Mr Tsvangirai will run for parliament in Buhera.

"We have good identifications from people who witnessed the incident. It was people who are known in the area as officers of the central intelligence organisation," said Mr Sikhala. "It happened with police officers nearby, yet we have no reports of any arrests by the police."

The wave of arson, killings and violence has made it difficult for the party to campaign for the upcoming parliamentary elections that are expected in late May, although a date has yet to be set. Despite the intimidation, the party has attracted large and enthusiastic crowds to rallies throughout the country. In many provincial centres, the MDC has drawn bigger crowds than Mr Mugabe himself.

"We will have to exercise caution in the campaign," said Mr Sikhala. "But we cannot stop our God-given right to support a change in government.

"We have constitutional rights to freedom of assembly and freedom of speech. If they want to try to kill all of us, then God bless Robert Mugabe."

Security is tight at the MDC's offices in Harare. All visitors are frisked and checked by a metal detector before entering through the gate. "We must be vigilant," said Mr Sikhala. "It looks like the government is working for the total destruction of our party.

"It looks like the country is on the verge of anarchy, but in fact it is an ordered campaign against us," he said. "Mugabe knows he is losing and he is prepared to sink the entire country with him."

fields.headline: Austrian right 'playing with fire'
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Relations between Austria and the European Union deteriorated further yesterday when the European commission warned Vienna that any delay in budget contributions would be met with tough action.
fields.body:
Relations between Austria and the European Union deteriorated further yesterday when the European commission warned Vienna that any delay in budget contributions would be met with tough action.

The warning came after Austria's finance minister, Karl-Heinz Grasser, a member of the far-right Freedom party, threatened on Sunday to delay EU payments and stymie decision making unless the EU ends its political isolation of Austria.

"I do not want to push it so far that we could be condemned for violating the [EU] treaties. But there could be delays in the payment of our contributions. Being unpunctual, we can do that," Mr Grasser told the Kurier newspaper.

He went on to endorse calls by his former party leader, Jörg Haider, for Austria to use its veto to disrupt EU business.

But the commission yesterday warned Mr Grasser that he was treading on dangerous ground.

"We take such statements extremely seriously. People are playing with fire," said a senior EU source, who claimed Austria would be brought before the European court of justice. The source added: "We also send EU money to Austria and it would be strange if it did not cross our mind to review that."

Other commission sources ruled out any move to suspend payments to Austria, which are mostly in the form of structural aid for poorer regions. But they agreed that court action would be on the agenda.

Vienna is pressing for EU nations to unfreeze diplomatic ties, severed in February over the inclusion of the Freedom party in Austria's government.

webTitle: A welcome for Putin, the butcher of Chechnya

fields.headline: A welcome for Putin, the butcher of Chechnya
fields.standfirst:
Having talked about ethics, Blair shows how irrelevant they are

Crisis in Chechnya: special report
Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Having talked about ethics, Blair shows how irrelevant they are
fields.body:
When Tony Blair met Vladimir Putin yesterday, he said he would raise the subject of Moscow's atrocities in Chechnya. There's no reason to doubt that he did so, but equally no reason to suppose he had the slightest effect. He blew his powder at their first meeting in St Petersburg. In the full read-out of that wide-ranging conversation which London immediately supplied to Washington, what most struck the Americans was Putin's unyielding severity on Chechnya. It was harsher than they expected. The Russian replied to Blair's expressions of disapproval with brutal indifference.

This gives Mr Blair's protestations about his meeting yesterday an aura of empty piety. The words will have been spoken, but then the leaders moved on to other business. No doubt this was done with civility. Mr Putin studies his interlocutors with the care of a trained agent to touch the right buttons. When he first met Madeleine Albright, he broke the ice by talking about Munich. To the French foreign minister, Hubert Vedrine, he dwelt on Europe. James Wolfensohn, head of the World Bank, was favoured with a humouring of his love of classical music. So one may be sure the Third Way was batted between interpreters at the Downing Street lunch.

For that is what Mr Blair likes to talk about, irrespective of who is listening. Dialogue, in all and any circumstances, has become the hallmark of his foreign policy. Far from being a leader especially confined within the limits of what is supposed to be "ethical", he is ruthlessly dismissive of such fine points of propriety. Moral protest, such as Putin generated in Whitehall and elsewhere, will cut no ice. This contrast between the theory and practice of Blair presents a startling spectacle.

He's a fervent believer in his powers of persuasion. That's how he has conducted his European policy for three years. He's entranced by talk, and the spirit of this, after Britain's years of silence and/or aggression in EU councils and committees, is reciprocated. There's hardly a leader in the Union with whom he is not best friends, a trait which, a Foreign Office man once told me, had, in the innocent beginning, problems as well as virtues. Such was the pleasure and admiration Blair's early meetings produced that he would return from Europe convinced he had surmounted all the tiresome old problems. Everyone, it seemed, agreed with him. His success in dialogue made, perhaps makes, him believe that anything is possible.

He can't seriously imagine Chechnya is amenable to the same treatment. But the education of Mr Putin to the meaning of economic reform is more plausible. Engagement, for Blair, turns out to be in all circumstances preferable to ostracism. The concrete gains for Britain may be hard to detect. The suggestion that British business might get a head-start in the reformed Russian economy is as dubious in its premise as its conclusion: the economy has yet to be reformed, and business's success or failure against German and American competitors has never had much to do with sweet-talking politicians.

But for Britain to be first into Putin's Moscow is the kind of vacuous coup diplomats dream of. It also plays to the leader's ambition to be out in front. With the Queen enlisted to give tea to the butcher of Chechnya, we learn how far Mr Blair will go to establish priorities that are quite different from those with which he apparently began.

Under any other leader, this would be striking enough. Moscow is in breach of elementary international protocols. Putin contemptuously humiliated the UN human rights commissioner, Mary Robinson, refusing to acknowledge that she had any locus in Chechnya. The Council of Europe, to which Russia was admitted in hope of tying Russian freedoms to the standards of an international charter, takes such a serious view of the Chechnyan brutalities that her membership may soon be suspended.

Ignoring these signals, riding rough over their implications, could not normally be done with impunity. Even a morally uncluttered head of government - Chirac, say, or even Clinton - would experience embarrassment trying to clarify why he was prepared to welcome the leader who had so affronted international opinion. For Putin, let's be clear, is the winner here. Putative British contracts, or special Blairite third-way instruction, count for little beside the royal respectability the new Russian has been accorded without making a single concession to the legal order his country signed up to. This is what, by the canons of proper behaviour, needs to be explained away.

Blair, however, has another problem as well. He was going to be a different sort of leader, standing for something new in the grammar of foreign policy, an ethical dimension. He raised expectations. These have been betrayed many times over. Whether in Sierra Leone or Iraq or Indonesia, they look like a sick joke. The phrase, in fact, can now be seen as the most foolish platform from which any new government has ever launched itself into the international arena. But it stands in the record. It has not been glossed, still less repudiated, by ministers. It remains in the mind, as the benchmark by which these ministers said they would be judged.

This is what makes the Blair-Putin alliance so arresting. Having once talked about ethics, which neither Margaret Thatcher nor John Major ever did, Blair shows how irrelevant they are. He is wholly pragmatic, ruthlessly focused, hard-as-nails committed to the supreme relevance of his own persuasive role. The outrage expressed by many sincere people against this premature welcoming of Putin into the embrace of the western powers meets Blair's own passionate unconcern.

There is a case for getting on with Putin. He looks likely to be in power for some time. He may have a mandate for reform which brings legal order to a chaotic economic regime. Under him, Russia will be engaged in reassembling its presence on the world scene. By coming to London, he opens himself to western influence. On nuclear disarmament, he has an inescapable role. Britain, in this respect, has taken the chance to play her part as a proxy for Washington, which will even now have gobbled up a complete transcript of the London conversations.

What's more compelling is the ease with which Blair dumped his pretensions in order to achieve this. The case for sticks not carrots, against the perpetrator of Chechnyan barbarities, goes unheard, just as it did with Jiang Zemin, and might, in the right circumstances, with Saddam Hussein. Instead we get a lot of stuff about men of the same generation who are able to understand each other. New men. New bonds. Special chemistry. This has its possibilities. But ethics? Schmethics. A hard man is sucking up to a harder one, as Bismarck might have said.

Ignoring these signals, riding rough over their implications, could not normally be done with impunity. Even a morally uncluttered head of government - Chirac, say, or even Clinton - would experience embarrassment trying to clarify why he was prepared to welcome the leader who had so affronted international opinion. For Putin, let's be clear, is the winner here. Putative British contracts, or special Blairite third-way instruction, count for little beside the royal respectability the new Russian has been accorded without making a single concession to the legal order his country signed up to. This is what, by the canons of proper behaviour, needs to be explained away. Blair, however, has another problem as well. He was going to be a different sort of leader, standing for something new in the grammar of foreign policy, an ethical dimension. He raised expectations. These have been betrayed many times over. Whether in Sierra Leone or Iraq or Indonesia, they look like a sick joke. The phrase, in fact, can now be seen as the most foolish platform from which any new government has ever launched itself into the international arena. But it stands in the record. It has not been glossed, still less repudiated, by ministers. It remains in the mind, as the benchmark by which these ministers said they would be judged. This is what makes the Blair-Putin alliance so arresting. Having once talked about ethics, which neither Margaret Thatcher nor John Major ever did, Blair shows how irrelevant they are. He is wholly pragmatic, ruthlessly focused, hard-as-nails committed to the supreme relevance of his own persuasive role. The outrage expressed by many sincere people against this premature welcoming of Putin into the embrace of the western powers meets Blair's own passionate unconcern. There is a case for getting on with Putin. He looks likely to be in power for some time. He may have a mandate for reform which brings legal order to a chaotic economic regime. Under him, Russia will be engaged in reassembling its presence on the world scene. By coming to London, he opens himself to western influence. On nuclear disarmament, he has an inescapable role. Britain, in this respect, has taken the chance to play her part as a proxy for Washington, which will even now have gobbled up a complete transcript of the London conversations. What's more compelling is the ease with which Blair dumped his pretensions in order to achieve this. The case for sticks not carrots, against the perpetrator of Chechnyan barbarities, goes unheard, just as it did with Jiang Zemin, and might, in the right circumstances, with Saddam Hussein. Instead we get a lot of stuff about men of the same generation who are able to understand each other. New men. New bonds. Special chemistry. This has its possibilities. But ethics? Schmethics. A hard man is sucking up to a harder one, as Bismarck might have said.

fields.headline: Argentina unearths 90 torture victims
fields.trailText: A yellowing notebook stamped "Do Not Touch" led investigators this weekend to 90 corpses buried by the Argentine army in Lomas de Zamora cemetery, 28 miles south of Buenos Aires.
fields.body:
A yellowing notebook stamped "Do Not Touch" led investigators this weekend to 90 corpses buried by the Argentine army in Lomas de Zamora cemetery, 28 miles south of Buenos Aires.

The remains belong to suspects who were tortured to death under military rule, from 1976 to 1983.

Forensic experts found the marks of a bullet delivered at close range on all the corpses, which were buried in December 1976, at the height of state repression.

The cemetery's administrator, Juan Hrchan, was warned by his predecessor in the job to leave the anonymous tombs alone, as "subversives" were buried there.

He has received death threats since announcing the find and has been forced to move his family to a safer home.

The discovery rekindled hopes among relatives of the disappeared that they might still find the final resting place of their loved ones; an estimated 30,000 citizens were kidnapped and killed in 320 death camps across the country during the regime.

After the discovery, local government officials explained how they received frequent calls for burial space from army commanders based in the infamous Pozo de Banfield, located five streets away, where hundreds of suspects were tortured to death.

"It's one more small but positive step," said Laura Bonaparte, a spokeswoman for the Mothers of the Disappeared, the first group to protest against the disappearances.

webTitle: Ministers should 'let go control of NHS'

fields.headline: Ministers should 'let go control of NHS'
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Ministers should abandon their day to day control of the NHS in favour of a radical new system in which the health service would be run along the lines of the BBC, a report recommended yesterday.
fields.body:
Ministers should abandon their day to day control of the NHS in favour of a radical new system in which the health service would be run along the lines of the BBC, a report recommended yesterday.

As a first step to restoring public confidence in the health service, the report called for a new constitution which would enshrine the core values of the NHS and provide the basis for an outside board to run it.

The biggest shake-up in the 52-year history of the NHS was proposed yesterday by a commission chaired by the former Observer editor, Will Hutton, which was set up by the community health councils for England and Wales.

Mr Hutton said that the public's faith in the NHS had been damaged by a "rash of mistakes" such as the Bristol hearts scandal and the Shipman trial. An ICM poll found overwhelming support for the NHS, but a large proportion (62%) felt it needed to improve.

Confidence could be restored, according to the commission, if a written constitution was laid down which stipulated that NHS would be "free at the point of delivery" and all decisions would be made in a transparent process. This would provide the basis for an independent board to run the health service.

"At the heart of our proposals for reform lies one big idea; that the moment has arrived for the NHS to be given a constitution that sets out the principles around which we, the British, expect this great institution to be organised," Mr Hutton says in a Guardian article today.

"The NHS would then become a semi-independent public corporation with its own constitution entrenching the principles and values by which it is run. The nearest example is the BBC, although we believe our proposals improve upon some of the weakness from which the BBC suffers."

Mr Hutton's report makes a series of recommendations which would end the "democratic deficit that infects the entire institution". They include:

 Transforming local health authorities into elected bodies;

 Advertising all appointments to NHS trusts and primary care groups which would be made by committees reflecting the gender and ethnic balance of the community;

 Ensuring that complaints from patients and their families are handled by independent review panels;

Mr Hutton said: "People hold the NHS in high esteem but after the recent rash of mistakes, scandals, and under-funding they want their fatith restored. [This report] will help this great national institution focus on its patients and be explicity with government about what it needs."

The department of health was dismissive of the report last night. While formally welcoming it as a contribution to the debate on the future of the NHS, a spokesman took issue with Mr Hutton's proposal to dilute ministerial control. "It is not clear whether reducing parliamentary oversight of the NHS would make it more accountable to the public," a spokesman said.

Tony Blair believes that ministers must maintain a tight grip over the NHS because his survival will depend on whether he lives up to his pre-election pledge to save it.

However, the Liberal Democrats called on the government to adopt many of the Hutton recommendations. Nick Harvey, the party's health spokesman, said: "It is absurd for the health secretary to be involved in the day to day running of the NHS."

fields.headline: Evolution not revolution
fields.standfirst:
The Scot Nats play a canny game

Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: Is the Scottish National party going cool on independence? Merely to ask the question may sound ridiculous: surely an independent Scotland is the very raison d'etre of the SNP. But, as we report on the news pages today, the party leader Alex Salmond has touched off a frenzy of tea-leaf reading among the Kremlinologists of Edinburgh.
fields.body:
Is the Scottish National party going cool on independence? Merely to ask the question may sound ridiculous: surely an independent Scotland is the very raison d'etre of the SNP. But, as we report on the news pages today, the party leader Alex Salmond has touched off a frenzy of tea-leaf reading among the Kremlinologists of Edinburgh. They have spotted a shift in Mr Salmond's rhetoric, away from the old slogans of a separate Scotland and towards a new admiration for the halfway house that is devolution. In a speech last week, the SNP leader barely mentioned the nationalist dream of independence, preferring instead to sing the praises of the new parliament at Holyrood. One bright spark set out to count how many times Mr Salmond had used the i-word in the first six months of the new legislature's life. The answer: twice.

It is not difficult to spin this as the abandonment of the Scottish nationalist crusade. One can even construct a theory to explain it. Stung by their failure to translate a one-time poll lead over Labour into victory in last year's Holyrood elections, the Nats have decided to drop the policy that stands between them and the voters' affections. Just as New Labour dumped clause 4, so a New SNP is about to drop its vote-repelling credo - the break-up of Britain. Plaid Cymru no longer demands complete independence for Wales: now the SNP is simply taking the same step.

Plausible though that may sound, it is not right. Something far subtler is at work. Nationalism no longer amounts to the crude call for a Scottish state, with its own passports, army and seat at the United Nations - between Saudi Arabia and Senegal. Instead it increasingly sees itself as a gradual process, beginning with the existing parliament. Mr Salmond has realised that his best hope is not to do down the chamber, but to say it's working so well - why not let it grow? Scots will not hand Edinburgh politicians more power as a reward for failure, only as a prize for success. The SNP leader avoids the trap of praising Labour - the majority party in the parliament - by casting the chamber as the vigilant watchdog which holds the Labour-dominated executive to account. That way the parliament is a hero, and so is the SNP which forms the official opposition. Judged like this, the Nat strategy is less a move away from independence - more a canny way of getting there.

webTitle: Union attacks Woodhead over suicide of teacher

fields.headline: Union attacks Woodhead over suicide of teacher
fields.trailText: Chris Woodhead, the chief inspector of schools, was accused yesterday of contributing to the suicide of a primary teacher by allowing Ofsted inspectors to put too much pressure on staff during routine classroom visits.
fields.body:
Chris Woodhead, the chief inspector of schools, was accused yesterday of contributing to the suicide of a primary teacher by allowing Ofsted inspectors to put too much pressure on staff during routine classroom visits.

An emergency motion was tabled at the start of the annual conference of the Association of Teachers and Lecturers in Belfast regretting the death of Pamela Relf "as a result of Ofsted-induced stress". Miss Relf, 57, committed suicide in January by jumping into a freezing river.

An inquest heard that she had been depressed for some time, but broke down in tears after criticism from inspectors during their visit to Middlefield primary school in Eynesbury, Cambridgeshire. In a handwritten note, she said: "I am now finding the stress of my job too much. The pace of work and the long days are more than I can do."

The association's emergency motion said the case was "the tip of the iceberg as far as Ofsted's harm to teachers is concerned". It called for urgent research into "the victims of Ofsted".

Peter Smith, the association's general secretary, said he did not blame Ofsted for causing Miss Relf's death, but the visit from the inspectors may have triggered it. "She had a history of depressive illness. If Ofsted was responsible for the last straw, that doesn't mean it was responsible for the entire haystack," he said.

Mr Smith released copies of correspondence with Mr Woodhead, saying it showed the chief inspector was "off-hand, gratuitously offensive and insensitive" in his comments on the case.

On March 1, Mr Smith wrote criticising Ofsted for showing no sympathy to Miss Relf's family, or regret about the death of the teacher. By return of post, Mr Woodhead said his press officer had already expressed Ofsted's sadness, but this had gone unreported. "Why don't once in a while you stop and think before you put pen to paper?" he told the veteran union leader.

Mr Smith wrote back explaining that he was not accusing Mr Woodhead of causing the suicide and enclosing the address of Miss Relf's brother so that the chief inspector could send his condolences. After a follow-up letter from the association's leader on March 14, Mr Woodhead said he had decided to let the correspondence drop. The chief inspector enclosed a copy of a letter that he wrote, but did not send, on March 6, casting doubt on Mr Smith's "unwarranted and patronising assumption of moral superiority" and rejecting the suggestion that Ofsted should write to Miss Relf's brother.

Mr Smith said last night: "My advice to Mr Woodhead is never to put on paper anything he would not be happy to show for publication."

In a statement on the association's motion, Ofsted said it had consistently expressed sadness and sympathy about Miss Relf's death. "We too are human beings and recognise the human tragedy of her suicide." Whatever part the inspection played in adding to Miss Relf's depression, Ofsted "always recognised that inspection can be a stressful event".

Over recent years the inspe ction rules had been changed to reduce that stress as much as possible.

It was unclear how the conference will handle the emergency motion. Mr Smith said the wording was too strong because it could not be shown that the behaviour of inspectors caused Miss Relf's death. But the conference is likely to want to register its distaste for Ofsted-induced stress.

fields.headline: Police subdue protesters
fields.standfirst:
Meanwhile in Washington: Pressure eases on IMF
World Bank/IMF 2000 spring meetings page
Corporate Watch protest page
Environment News Service
Peacenet protest page
Independent Media Center protest page
fields.trailText: Police fired tear gas and made scores of arrests as they swept a hard core of anti-World Bank and International Monetary Fund protesters from the streets of the US capital yesterday.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson and  Larry Elliott in Washington
fields.body:
Police fired tear gas and made scores of arrests as they swept a hard core of anti-World Bank and International Monetary Fund protesters from the streets of the US capital yesterday.

The Washington DC police chief, Charles Ramsey, wrestled one demonstrator to the ground as the authorities took a tougher line following Sunday's largely peaceful rally.

As a meeting of the World Bank's development committee went ahead as planned, the national guard was seen on the streets for the first time since the protests began a week ago, to deal with stone and bottle throwing groups.

Protesters were surrounded by police and herded on to school buses. One police officer told those complaining about the arrests: "Yesterday was play day. Now it's time to go home."

The mood was less defiant as wet and bedraggled demonstrators faced phalanxes of police officers, many in riot gear, that had them compared to Power Rangers.

The authorities clamped down harder on protesters to avoid disruption to the centre of Washington on a work day. Many non-essential government workers were given the day off.

Benjamin Zawacki, an independent legal observer, said the day had started badly with a confrontation at the junction of 17th and I streets.

"The police were using their batons quite liberally. They were marching down the street, slapping their batons against the side of their boots, making a gestapo-esque sound."

The Bank's president, James Wolfensohn, yesterday told ministers on the development committee that the most urgent need was to find a global solution to the spread of HIV/Aids, which affects 50m people worldwide.

The Bank believes Aids has become a major development issue in many poor countries, particularly in Africa where five countries have infection rates of more than 20%.

Mr Wolfensohn wants to see steps taken to produce and distribute a low-cost vaccine that is affordable in the developing world.

Both Mr Wolfensohn and Stanley Fischer, acting managing director of the IMF, said they were happy to discuss issues with the protestors but insisted that there was no turning back from globalisation.

Mr Fischer said the Fund believed it had handled the financial crises of 1997-98 well and its beefed-up surveillance should mean there were fewer upsets.

The Fund and the Bank are urging rich countries to provide more generous trade concessions to poor nations.

However, non-governmental organisations said there had been little progress made in Washington over debt.

webTitle: When things wobble - just hang on

fields.headline: When things wobble - just hang on
fields.standfirst: Notebook: A reminder on market truths
fields.trailText: One thing that long term investors know is that stock market crashes are extremely rare events. There were a couple during the last century, maybe three of four, depending on your definition. Bear markets are more common, but not so much as to damage equities' reputation as the premier class of investment over just about any period during the past 100 years.
fields.body:
One thing that long term investors know is that stock market crashes are extremely rare events. There were a couple during the last century, maybe three of four, depending on your definition. Bear markets are more common, but not so much as to damage equities' reputation as the premier class of investment over just about any period during the past 100 years.

Yesterday's events told us that we have had neither a crash nor are we in a bear market. Shares prices stabilised.

There was a remarkable level of calmness to trading in both London and New York, and while investor confidence is still extremely fragile, market commentators are under a duty to report and reflect on this calmness - rather than simply hoping that hordes of greedy speculators are now going to be put to the torch.

It is beyond doubt that the markets witnessed an outrageous blow-out during the last couple of months of 1999 and the first couple in 2000.

Using rough figures, the "tech" indexes - the Nasdaq composite in the US and the Techmark 100 over here - have now fallen by just over a third from their early-March peaks.

At the same time, both are still about 50% higher than in the autumn, when "tech-fever" became an epidemic among private investors.

If the recent correction had damaged investor sentiment severely we might have expected prices to fall much farther from here.

But the evidence yesterday was that investors were creeping back into the market, using the opportunity to buy into what are perceived to be the bright stars of the new economy, but which looked prohibitively expensive just a few weeks ago.

These are brave people. There may be a few hidden horrors to come out over coming days, such as over-extended market players being forced to liquidate their portfolios.

And, all other things being equal, the trend for interest rates in the US as well as here is up.

At the same time, the move in some quarters to snap up so-called "old economy" companies also looks heroic.

Using old-fashioned fundamental analysis, food producers and the like are probably a good deal more exposed to rate/inflation increases than high technology firms.

If you are a cautious investor, rather than a gut-led speculator, the thing to do is to follow what, on balance, has been the most profitable approach to every market wobble in history: sit on your hands.

Bad at Barclays

After a two-week torrent of bad publicity, Barclays' new chief executive, Matt Barrett, addressed his staff last Friday in the form of a six-page letter. Apparently he is open to responses, so here goes:

Dear Matt, The emotionally charged and long-winded nature of your missive surprised us somewhat, especially when you were using it to hit out at the media for its emotion and hype. But now you are communicating (rather than just letting that Varley man take the grief), let us cut to the detail.

You make your points under three headings - social responsibility, branch closures and executive pay.

On social responsibility, we have some dispute with your comment that "gestures of goodwill fool nobody". Your rivals will tell you they fool quite a few people. Yes, when it comes to branch closures, it is true that high streets in small and rural communities are changing and that long-established players are facing competition from new (internet) entrants. It also fair to say that the government appears hypocritical, given that it too is closing post offices, hospitals and schools.

What is less clear, though, is why banks cannot turn being the last institution on the high street to their advantage, to steal customers from rivals and, who knows, make the bank the place to visit on the high street - maybe even share the space with an internet café.

You do not deal with the decision to axe all 171 branches on the same day, or the implications for jobs - which brings us to your own job and the remunera tion attached to it.

You describe reports on the possibility of a £30m payout as "hype and lunacy" even though (after a week with their calculators) your officials admit that such a reward is possible. You also fail to address the fact that the details had to be winkled out of an obscure and largely unread appendix to Barclays' accounts. Whether intentional or otherwise, the impression was given that the bank was trying to hide the facts.

This column has no problem with big rewards for big executive success. The line is that it is rewards for failure (or mediocrity) that have always rankled and always will. A ten-fold growth in Barclays' market capitalisation is a tough target, even for a £30m payout.

From here, to stand any chance of trousering the money, you will have to sharpen your act - especially in the area of public relations.

Yesterday's events told us that we have had neither a crash nor are we in a bear market. Shares prices stabilised. There was a remarkable level of calmness to trading in both London and New York, and while investor confidence is still extremely fragile, market commentators are under a duty to report and reflect on this calmness - rather than simply hoping that hordes of greedy speculators are now going to be put to the torch. It is beyond doubt that the markets witnessed an outrageous blow-out during the last couple of months of 1999 and the first couple in 2000. Using rough figures, the "tech" indexes - the Nasdaq composite in the US and the Techmark 100 over here - have now fallen by just over a third from their early-March peaks. At the same time, both are still about 50% higher than in the autumn, when "tech-fever" became an epidemic among private investors. If the recent correction had damaged investor sentiment severely we might have expected prices to fall much farther from here. But the evidence yesterday was that investors were creeping back into the market, using the opportunity to buy into what are perceived to be the bright stars of the new economy, but which looked prohibitively expensive just a few weeks ago. These are brave people. There may be a few hidden horrors to come out over coming days, such as over-extended market players being forced to liquidate their portfolios. And, all other things being equal, the trend for interest rates in the US as well as here is up. At the same time, the move in some quarters to snap up so-called "old economy" companies also looks heroic. Using old-fashioned fundamental analysis, food producers and the like are probably a good deal more exposed to rate/inflation increases than high technology firms. If you are a cautious investor, rather than a gut-led speculator, the thing to do is to follow what, on balance, has been the most profitable approach to every market wobble in history: sit on your hands. Bad at Barclays After a two-week torrent of bad publicity, Barclays' new chief executive, Matt Barrett, addressed his staff last Friday in the form of a six-page letter. Apparently he is open to responses, so here goes: Dear Matt, The emotionally charged and long-winded nature of your missive surprised us somewhat, especially when you were using it to hit out at the media for its emotion and hype. But now you are communicating (rather than just letting that Varley man take the grief), let us cut to the detail. You make your points under three headings - social responsibility, branch closures and executive pay. On social responsibility, we have some dispute with your comment that "gestures of goodwill fool nobody". Your rivals will tell you they fool quite a few people. Yes, when it comes to branch closures, it is true that high streets in small and rural communities are changing and that long-established players are facing competition from new (internet) entrants. It also fair to say that the government appears hypocritical, given that it too is closing post offices, hospitals and schools. What is less clear, though, is why banks cannot turn being the last institution on the high street to their advantage, to steal customers from rivals and, who knows, make the bank the place to visit on the high street - maybe even share the space with an internet café. You do not deal with the decision to axe all 171 branches on the same day, or the implications for jobs - which brings us to your own job and the remunera tion attached to it. You describe reports on the possibility of a £30m payout as "hype and lunacy" even though (after a week with their calculators) your officials admit that such a reward is possible. You also fail to address the fact that the details had to be winkled out of an obscure and largely unread appendix to Barclays' accounts. Whether intentional or otherwise, the impression was given that the bank was trying to hide the facts. This column has no problem with big rewards for big executive success. The line is that it is rewards for failure (or mediocrity) that have always rankled and always will. A ten-fold growth in Barclays' market capitalisation is a tough target, even for a £30m payout. From here, to stand any chance of trousering the money, you will have to sharpen your act - especially in the area of public relations.

webTitle: New managing director for Guardian Newspapers

fields.headline: New managing director for Guardian Newspapers
fields.trailText: Guardian Newspapers Limited announced the appointment of a new managing director yesterday. Carolyn McCall will succeed Caroline Marland at the end of November.
fields.body:
Guardian Newspapers Limited announced the appointment of a new managing director yesterday. Carolyn McCall will succeed Caroline Marland at the end of November.

Bob Phillis, the chairman of GNL, said the appointment came at a time of commercial success for the company. Advertising revenues for 1999-2000 were £25m ahead of the previous 12 months.

Mr Phillis paid tribute to Ms Marland, who has worked for the Guardian for 24 years, for her "extraordinary contribution" to the company.

He added: "Carolyn McCall has made a major contribution to the commercial success of both the Guardian and the Observer during the past three years, as well as overseeing the launch of our ground-breaking new media division in 1997. I am greatly looking forward to working with Carolyn and her new team as we embark on the next phase of the company's development."

Ms Marland said: "Carolyn is a dynamic operator and we can expect great developments at GNL with her at the helm."

Ms McCall, 38, said: "I am looking forward to building on the success of the Guardian, Observer and Guardian Unlimited. The really exciting thing is that GNL can no longer be called a newspaper company, it is a media company. There are so many new opportunities ahead.

"Guardian Unlimited is a highly successful award winning brand and GNL is launching Observer.co.uk to develop online the strong voice the Observer now has."

webTitle: Wickes fights off takeover bid from DIY rival

fields.headline: Wickes fights off takeover bid from DIY rival
fields.trailText: Wickes, the DIY retailer, yesterday came out fighting against a £285m takeover bid from Focus Do It All, arguing it controlled a high quality business with excellent prospects.
fields.body:
Wickes, the DIY retailer, yesterday came out fighting against a £285m takeover bid from Focus Do It All, arguing it controlled a high quality business with excellent prospects.

With a formal defence document being sent to shareholders, chief executive Bill Grimsey said the FDIA offer was "ludicrously low" and an attempt to secure its own survival.

He said: "The benefits are now beginning to flow from the £89m worth of investment (in Wickes) that has been made in all areas of the business over the last three years ."

The board was determined to prevent its rival taking over at a price that failed to recognise the high strategic value of the company in any process of industry consolidation.

FDIA had argued that Wickes could not survive on its own in a difficult climate. But Mr Grimsey said his company was generating large amounts of cash, £41m last year alone, and its future was secure.

Analysts said there was little new in the latest defence document but said the case for a higher offer - of perhaps as much as £5 - was compelling although the price would be affected by a falling stock market.

Nick Bubb of SG Securities said: "Wickes has got a relatively strong defence. One weakness is the cock-up of warehousing last year but they have overall a pretty good record. The FDIA offer is opportunistic."

Mr Grimsey has masterminded a significant revival in the fortunes of Wickes since he arrived in 1996 following an accounting scandal that has led to legal action against his predecessor Henry Sweetbaum.

Wickes, whose annual sales rose 6.2% to £571.8m in 1999, is the third largest player in the heavily competitive DIY market, behind Kingfisher's B&Q chain and Sainsbury's Homebase. But it is a market leader in some lines such as building materials and timber.

Shares in Wickes went ex-dividend and ended the day down 15p at 385p, falling alongside a depressed stock market. FDIA's offer at 375p per share on March 30 represented a 39% premium over Wickes closing price the day before.

fields.headline: WPP back on takeover trail
fields.standfirst: New York agency in talks about £2.5bn deal
fields.trailText: WPP was continuing discussions last night about sealing a £2.5bn takeover of New York-based agency Young & Rubicam which would make it the world's largest advertising and marketing group.
fields.body:
WPP was continuing discussions last night about sealing a £2.5bn takeover of New York-based agency Young & Rubicam which would make it the world's largest advertising and marketing group.

Talks between the two companies have resumed after breaking down in mid-March.

The earlier negotiations stalled over a lucrative severance package put in place for Y&R's higher ranking staff which was regarded by WPP as a poison pill.

The renewed talks suggest that the two sides might be moving towards resolution.

Sir Martin Sorrell, WPP chief executive, was understood to be in the US yesterday but a source close to the negotiations said the conclusion of a deal remained "a possibility and not a probability".

A merger would add a third advertising network to the Ogilvy & Mather and J Walter Thompson businesses owned by WPP.

It would also strengthen WPP's grip on the Ford account, one of the world's largest marketing budgets.

"It would be a good fit because Y&R is the only major network out there with no conflicts of any substance with WPP's client base," said one source.

Sir Martin is also keen to add Y&R's public relations businesses including Burson Marsteller and its direct marketing arm, Wunderman Cato Johnson, to his own.

Direct marketing, which includes junk mail and database marketing, operates at the less glamorous end of the industry but is also one of the fastest growing disciplines.

But the source played down suggestions that WPP was preparing a rerun of the hubris which characterised the industry in the 1980s by launching a hostile bid.

Y&R chief executive Tom Bell is thought to be resistant to a takeover and orchestrated the new severance package for top management in the event of a change of control at the start of the year. The so called "golden parachutes" could cost a buyer $50m.

Sir Martin took both O&M and JWT by force in the late 1980s and Mr Bell is understood to fear WPP will make a hostile bid.

Founded in Philadelphia in 1923, Y&R's clients today include Colgate-Palmolive, PepsiCo, Sony, Philip Morris and Mattel.

The advertising and marketing industry has gone through a long period of consolidation and is dominated by three groups, WPP, Omnicom and Interpublic.

Y&R was viewed as an obvious takeover target after suffering a slump in its share price of more than 40% since the beginning of the year.

Shares in WPP yesterday fell almost 7% to 832p, in line with the rest of the media sector.

webTitle: Labour accused of 'crude fudge' in coal deal

fields.headline: Labour accused of 'crude fudge' in coal deal
fields.standfirst:
Unions stunned as £100m package for troubled heartlands delays closure of two pits but deep mines still face doubt over long-term future
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Coal industry experts last night accused the government of a crude political fudge to buy time in Labour's troubled heartlands with a two year subsidy which ignored the long-term problems facing deep mines.
fields.body:
Coal industry experts last night accused the government of a crude political fudge to buy time in Labour's troubled heartlands with a two year subsidy which ignored the long-term problems facing deep mines.

The package of up to £100m, yet to be approved by the European commission, should delay the closure of Ellington, in Northumberland, and Clipstone, in Nottinghamshire, until after the general election.

But it will do little to secure the future of the 15 remaining deep mines in England, and the big coal-fired power stations they serve, because ministers have backed away from supporting a multi-million plan to develop "clean coal technology".

Without this technology, which greatly reduces carbon and sulphur dioxide emissions, many coal-fired power stations could close by the end of the decade, predicted Andrew Cox, editor of UK Coal Review. That would signal the end of mining.

Yesterday's aid package marked a U-turn for the embattled trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers and his energy minister Helen Liddell. They had been insisting that subsidies were not on offer.

Unions, while welcoming the policy shift, were stunned. "We met Stephen Byers and Helen Liddell after the closure decision and it was a clear-cut 'no' to any aid," said Ian Lavery, secretary of the National Union of Mineworkers in Northumberland. "That has been their line throughout. They said it was up to the own ers, not the government, to keep it open."

Yesterday Mr Byers, whose North Tyneside consituency lies close to Ellington, defended the aid as a means of helping the coal industry through a "period of transition" caused by further reorganisation of the energy market. It is dependent on how the European commission interprets the treaty governing state subsidies to industry although the government will defend the aid as compensation for unfair overseas competition.

Mr Byers said: "Germany, which has the largest coal industry in the community, produces about 20% more coal than we do with nearly 10 times the labour we have.

"The German industry benefits from massive government subsidies and the French and Spanish coal industries also benefit from government subsidies." But he warned that it was up the coal industry "to find its own place in a competitive energy market".

The industry faces upheaval in the lifting of restrictions on building new gas-fired power stations - the main competitors to coal generation - with the introduction of new electricity trading arrangements shortly, leading to "greater energy efficiency".

The Conservatives accused Mr Byers of acting to shore-up Labour support. Nick Gibb, the shadow energy minister, added: "It's part of Labour's election strategy. This is all about propping up Labour heartlands three weeks before the local elections."

Last year in Wansbeck, the area closest to Ellington, the Liberal Democrats came within five seats of taking control of the local council. Up till then Labour controlled all 45 seats.

Dr Cox accused the government of staging a U-turn purely for short-term political reasons. He said Ellington needs investment of up to £20m for underground development and new equipment to secure its future. Local markets had all but disappeared.

"This is only a short term measure," he said. "The only thing that will save British mining is a big investment in 'clean coal' technology and, although Labour promised help in opposition, it has offered no financial support in power. They have wasted this entire parliament doing nothing."

The country's biggest coal producer, RJ B Mining, immediately lifted its threat to close Ellington and Clipstone collieries and said additional jobs should be created there.

Richard Budge, chief executive, said: "This will provide stability for out mining operations as a secure supply of coal to power generators for many years to come." Company insiders said between 3,000 and 4,000 jobs had been secured.

The City was pleased that the government had committed itself to ending the ban on new gas-fired power stations. It was relaxed about the coal aid package which was deemed politically inevitable and financially limited. Nigel Hawkins, utilities analyst with stockbroker Willem de Broe, said he was not surprised the government had acted. "The giant Selby coalfield was threatened without financial aid and that would be crossing the rubicon for the future of the coal industry."

In 1990, four years before coal was privatised, more than 67% of Britain's electricity was generated by coal-fired power stations while 0.5% came from gas.

But by 1998 under 33% of electricity was generated by coal while a similar figure, 33%, came from gas.

webTitle: Hand to mouth in the clinics the west forgot

fields.headline: Hand to mouth in the clinics the west forgot
fields.standfirst: News Analysis Even with IMF help, Tanzania's debt will cost $3m a week
fields.trailText: At Tandale clinic, the main medical facility in Manzese one of Dar es Salaam's poorest suburbs, the strains of running a health service on a shoestring show.
fields.body:
At Tandale clinic, the main medical facility in Manzese one of Dar es Salaam's poorest suburbs, the strains of running a health service on a shoestring show.

Eight medical staff, none with degree level training, look after 500,000 people. By Tanzanian standards, the people of Manzese are lucky.

The clinic is well stocked with drugs supplied by the Swiss government. In many rural areas dispensaries run out well before the year is over.

Tanzania's finance minister, Daniel Yona, could have been forgiven for failing to raise a cheer last week, when he heard that his country had finally completed the lengthy process of qualifying for the official debt relief scheme for the world's poorest nations.

Twenty years after the country first asked its first world creditors for help with its mounting foreign debt, Tanzania has had the annual interest bill on its loans mountain cut - by around $12m a year, or just 7%.

This will leave the country still spending $3m a week servicing debt, twice what it spends on healthcare.

Six years ago, Tanzania was named on a list of the world's 40 most heavily indebted countries. After years of foot dragging, a British-led campaign succeeded in persuading the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund that some of these countries were never going to be able to pay back what they had borrowed.

The bank and the fund responded by offering debt relief under strictly limited conditions. Countries which stuck to a six-year programme of economic reform laid down by the fund would qualify to have their debts reduced to "sustainable" levels under the heavily indebted poor countries initiative (HIPC).

But the measure of sustainability chosen by the Washington number crunchers was whether the country was financially able to service all its debt, not whether the money being siphoned off by western creditors might be better put to use elsewhere in the country.

Last year, three years into the debt-relief programme, only one country, Uganda, had had its loans burdens cut.

After a global lobbying campaign, the creditor nations promised a speedier and more generous programme. In return countries have promised to spend the proceeds of debt relief on poverty reduction.

Tanzania is among the first to qualify under the West's new-look debt relief effort; its case highlights many of the shortcomings of the new deal. By the fund's standards, Tanzania is one of its better performers.

After years of double-digit price rises, its inflation target of 5% is almost in reach, the government deficit is just 1.4% of GDP and growth this year is predicted to be around 4%.

But 10 years of tough economic reform has not translated into improvements in the everyday lives of the average Tanzanian.

School enrolment ratios are lower than they were in 1990, the country has the world's lowest transi tion rate from primary to secondary school and malnutrition among the under-fives is on the increase.

Fifty per cent of the population lives on less than a $1 a day and at current growth rates it will take 40 years to cut by half the numbers living in absolute poverty.

Despite the promise that the rewards of debt relief would be spent tackling these problems, local debt campaigners worry that hopes are being raised over what is actually a small sum of money.

"If you do the calculations, the amount of money released for poverty reduction is actually not very much," says Christopher Mwakasege, from Tanzanian Social and Economic Trust.

There are still more hurdles to jump over before Tanzania receives the full debt relief promised. It must complete a poverty reduction strategy paper to convince the bank and the fund that the money will be well spent.

Concerns are mounting that HIPC mark 2 is starting to look awfully like a re-run with all the flaws of the programme it replaced.

It had been hoped to have 10 or 11 countries into the programme by the time of the IMF-World Bank spring meetings and at least 25 by the end of the year. In the event, only four countries have so far embarked on the process.

Although the chancellor, Gordon Brown, welcomed the creation of an IMF-World Bank implementation group, which the UK had proposed as a way of slicing through Washington red tape, debt campaigners fear there is a danger of losing momentum.

They say no country has actually received any additional debt relief since G7 leaders pledged in Cologne last June to slash the debt burden of the world's poorest countries by $100bn.

Back in Dar es Salaam, the deputy head of the finance ministry, Gray Mgonja, is able to be a little more direct than his boss about what Tanzania would actually like from the West. "We want 100% cancellation," he says.

Although the chancellor, Gordon Brown, welcomed the creation of an IMF-World Bank implementation group, which the UK had proposed as a way of slicing through Washington red tape, debt campaigners fear there is a danger of losing momentum. They say no country has actually received any additional debt relief since G7 leaders pledged in Cologne last June to slash the debt burden of the world's poorest countries by $100bn. Back in Dar es Salaam, the deputy head of the finance ministry, Gray Mgonja, is able to be a little more direct than his boss about what Tanzania would actually like from the West. "We want 100% cancellation," he says.

webTitle: Hitachi looks to quadruple net sales

fields.headline: Hitachi looks to quadruple net sales
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Hitachi, the Japanese electronics company, announced plans yesterday to increase sales from internet-related business four-fold to 900bn yen a year (£5.3bn) by 2003.
fields.body:
Hitachi, the Japanese electronics company, announced plans yesterday to increase sales from internet-related business four-fold to 900bn yen a year (£5.3bn) by 2003.

Hitachi's president, Etsuhiko Shoyama, said in Tokyo that a new company would be launched next week to oversee net-related business in such fields as customer management and encryption technology.

Hitachi will also offer on line services to the financial, manufacturing and distribution industries, as well as to schools and colleges, and the government.

The subsidiary, Hitachi netBusiness, will be capitalised at about 400m yen, and will receive investment worth 30bn yen over the next four years.

Hitachi is a relative latecomer to the already crowded online commerce industry. Two of its biggest rivals - Fujitsu and NEC- both own established service providers, along with Sony, are among Japan's core internet stocks. In February, Toshiba said it, too, intended to expand its information technology business.

Shoyama was unperturbed by yesterday's ructions on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, which saw huge drops in the value of IT stocks listed on the Nikkei index.

"I don't think the stock price movements reflect uncertainty over the IT and Internet business," Shoyama said. "IT will continue to progress in Japan."

webTitle: Talk of betrayal as SNP shifts stance on independence

fields.headline: Talk of betrayal as SNP shifts stance on independence
fields.standfirst:
As the Scottish nationalists prepare a new strategy for the next general election, are they backtracking on their core commitment?

Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: When the leader of the Scottish National party, Alex Salmond, gave an after dinner speech at the Political Studies Association conference in London last week, members of the audience were struck by his subject matter.
fields.body:
When the leader of the Scottish National party, Alex Salmond, gave an after dinner speech at the Political Studies Association conference in London last week, members of the audience were struck by his subject matter.

"He was very keen to tell everybody about the Scottish parliament and how good it was," said Professor James Kellas, of Glasgow University. "But he didn't say much about independence."

The "I" word has become noticeable by its absence from SNP-speak. It was barely mentioned during the Ayr byelection when the nationalists pushed Labour into third place; and in the first six months of the Scottish parliament, Mr Salmond is said to have used it just twice during speeches.

With a recent strategy shift on how to approach independence, critics within the party and observers without have begun to question the leadership's commitment to the concept. "This is the very heart of what we're about and yet it has become almost a four-letter word," said one party member. "Is it any wonder some are feeling betrayed?" Next month, the SNP launches its Westminster election strategy with a new policy for securing full autonomy. Previously, the party planned to begin negotiations for independence as soon as they won an election in Scotland, before putting the final deal to voters in a referendum. Now they would hold a referendum immediately after a successful election, before any negotiations were started.

The change was approved at the party's national council last month but caused deep unrest among party fundamentalists, dismayed at what they see as an unwillingness to push the separatist message. Analysts say it is a significant shift which clouds the SNP's aims.

Professor John Curtice, of Strathclyde University, suggests the move marks a distinction between the SNP winning power, and pursuing independence. "It is difficult to square that with Mr Salmond's claim in his party conference speech that there would be independence by 2007."

Mr Salmond insists the change is simply to ensure a yes vote in a referendum which has a better chance of being won on principle than on detail.

"We have not watered down the commitment to independence in the slightest," he insised. "This makes the process of achieving independence more credible and more likely.

"The whole impetus of our politics is to demonstrate that independence is a better settlement for the Scottish people than devolution. Everything about the Scottish parliament this past year demonstrates that that is the case.

"It is not tackling the fundamental issues that the people of Scotland want to see tackled because it does not have the authority over them. We want a real parliament with real powers, better than the parliament we have got which is highly constrained and boxed in by Westminster."

Some say, however, that the SNP appears surprisingly fulfilled by the new parliament. The party has proved itself an effective opposition, harrying the beleaguered Labour-Liberal Democrat administration on key issues such as tuition fees and section 28. Mr Salmond enjoys a public approval rating of 50%, 6% higher than first minister, Donald Dewar; and a number of other SNP figures have emerged from his shadow as respected and credible spokespeople.

John Curtice believes "it is now not terribly clear what is the SNP strategy for moving from a devolved parliament to developing a case for independence.

"The strategy seems to be, we're now the opposition. When the government screws up the voters will come to us. But that's not necessarily the best recipe for securing a referedum. The opinion poll evidence is that independence is a little bit less popular now than it was. There is certainly no great move towards it."

Another leading SNP figure sees no contradiction between active participation in the devolved parliament, and seeking eventual independence.

"We see our role quite explicitly to champion the parliament, because logically people are not going to vote for more powers if they feel that partial powers have not been a success," said Andrew Wilson, SNP finance spokesman."The endgame has always been independence. That's the reason people like me joined the party. If you want to go from A to B and someone offers you a lift halfway, you are going to take it because it's nearer."

For those who listened to Alex Salmond's speech last week, however, it was not immediately clear that he saw the parliament as an inadequate staging post on the road to an independent Scotland. "He was eulogising the current constitutional settlement, praising PR and the committee system of the Scottish parliament," said John Curtice. "He seemed like a man who was really quite content."
