fields.trailText:
Good day
Paddy Ashdown. The former Lib Dem leader announced he will be publishing two volumes of diaries, including accounts of conversations with Tony Blair. fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Eli Lilly queasy as Prozac dips
fields.body:
Eli Lilly queasy as Prozac dips

Plunging British sales of Prozac "pick-me-up" pills depressed the US drugs corporation Eli Lilly in the first quarter. The company lost British patent protection over the drug in January. It said this was the primary reason for a 35% slump in Prozac sales outside the US to $88.2m (£55m).

A series of competitors, including the quoted company Bioglan Pharma, have raced to launch cheaper copies of the product. Eli Lilly still managed to increase its net profits by 35% to $845m, helped by strong Prozac sales within America.

Standard Life battle renewed

Britain's biggest mutual life insurance group, Standard Life, faces a fresh attempt to demutualise the company. A group of policyholders calling itself the Standard Life Action Group said it had decided to submit a revised "requisition" calling for conversion to a public company.

In February the insurer rejected a request from the action group for a vote on demutualisation, saying after consulting its legal advisers that it was invalid.

A conversion to a public company could trigger windfalls for policyholders originally estimated at between £5,000 and £6,300.

The action group said its new requisition and resolutions had been examined by lawyers who confirmed that they were valid.

Fred Woollard, spokesman for the group, said: "Standard Life has said that if it receives a valid resolution, then it will be put to the vote."

A Standard Life spokesman said the company was aware of the new requisition, but had not received anything yet.

Yes Television float still on ice

Yes Television, which yesterday postponed its £800m flotation to take account of the nervousness in the City, was last night continuing its wait and see policy.

Head of marketing at Yes Steve Garvey said the company had been encouraged by the performance of the market but would not make a final decision on the timing and pricing of the float until it had stabilised. "It hasn't been a bloodbath but we still feel we made the right decision," he said.

"One day's trading is certainly not enough to gauge what will happen."

Mannesmann sells off Atecs

Mannesmann's supervisory board has agreed to accept an offer from Siemens and Robert Bosch for the firm's industrial businesses division, Atecs Mannesmann, and not to pursue the planned flotation of the unit.

Vodafone Airtouch chairman Chris Gent said after the meeting that the price was €9.6bn (£6bn). Mannesmann said its two boards were "convinced that together with Bosch-Siemens, Atecs will strengthen its leading global position and exploit its growth potential".

Merrill, Schwab post records

Two of Wall Street's biggest brokerage firms - Merrill Lynch and Charles Schwab - reported record earnings for the first quarter. Merrill posted net income of $1bn (£600m) and Schwab $297m.

webTitle: Payout over fake TV guests libel

fields.headline: Payout over fake TV guests libel
fields.trailText: A television researcher accused of arranging for fake guests to appear on the BBC's Vanessa show accepted "large" libel damages in the high court in London yesterday.
fields.body:
A television researcher accused of arranging for fake guests to appear on the BBC's Vanessa show accepted "large" libel damages in the high court in London yesterday.

Deborah Price, 25, from Milton Keynes, Buckinghamshire, who is now a researcher on Cilla Black's Blind Date show, also received a public apology over an article in the Mirror newspaper in February last year concerning the show presented by Vanessa Feltz.

Ms Price's solicitor, David Price, told Mr Justice Eady that the article "disclosed that several guests who had appeared on the show purporting to relate true-life stories were in fact fakes who had invented the accounts which they presented to viewers".

One show featured a woman who said she wanted a divorce when she was not married, he said. "Another concerned two women who claimed they were sisters but were in fact unrelated."

Ms Price had arranged for the guests to appear on the show, he said.

"The article went on to allege that not only were the guests fakes, but also that Ms Price had known that they were fakes and had thereby deliberately deceived her employers and the viewers."

But Ms Price neither knew nor suspected that any of the guests were fakes. She took reasonable steps to verify their authenticity, "bearing in mind the time constraints imposed on her by her employers, the BBC", Mr Price said.

"The three fake guests all admitted that they had sought to deceive Ms Price into believing they were genuine, and stated that they had no reason to believe that Ms Price was aware that they were fakes." She was "devastated" by the article.

The defendant, MGN Ltd, publisher of the Mirror, now accepted that there was no truth in the allegation that she knew the guests were fakes.

The judge was told that Ms Price, who also received her legal costs, hoped she could now pursue a career in television production "without a stain on her reputation".

fields.headline: Millbank wary of Tory 'defeatism'
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Labour and the Conservatives were last night engaged in a game of bluff over a leaked Tory strategy document which purported to show that William Hague's advisers have abandoned any hope of winning the coming general election.
fields.body:
Labour and the Conservatives were last night engaged in a game of bluff over a leaked Tory strategy document which purported to show that William Hague's advisers have abandoned any hope of winning the coming general election.

Officials in Downing Street and Labour HQ at Millbank were at one in suspecting a deliberate Tory leak to yesterday's Mirror. It suggested that the expected election result in May, June or October 2001 will be "remarkably unchanged" from Tony Blair's 1997 landslide in terms of the share of the three main parties votes.

The Tory motive in engineering a "Losers" headline in Labour's most loyal tabloid would be to encourage voter apathy in the Labour heartlands - both on May 4 when crucial local elections take place and next year - Labour officials said. They believe that Mr Hague wants to lower expectations of politicians as a means of encouraging cynicism and stay-at-home apathy.

Mirror journalists - and some MPs - dismissed the Labour conspiracy theory on the leak. The Conservative leader and party officials offered a routine refusal to comment on any leaked documents, though party chairman, Michael Ancram, told BBC Online "we're not making headway in the polls, but we are on the ground".

That is true insofar as voters have returned Conservative candidates in council byelections and the Scottish parliamentary byelection at Ayr, as well as at last year's Euro election. But there was little doubt that a hard-headed assessment of the Tory wider electoral doldrums has been circulated among advertising agencies which are bidding to manage the Opposition's election accounts.

As reported, the assessment of Mr Hague's prospects, written by Rick Nye, the ex-SDP policy analyst in charge of Tory research efforts, read: "People do not feel that the Conservatives are a viable alternative to Labour at the moment. We are still seen as being too divided and out of touch."

Mr Nye, who wants to concentrate his party's fire on 1.5 m young "swing voters" - the sort of married-with-family people attracted to Tony Blair's message last time - is keen to exploit growing dissatisfaction with Labour's record, especially on vital public services like health, schools and transport. Labour is presented as "arrogant and out of touch", keen to inflict more "stealth taxes" on voters despite the buoyant economy, and failing to deliver on promises. But Mr Nye allegedly admits that none of this is making voters turn back to Mr Hague.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.standfirst: Richard Adams
fields.trailText: Richard Adams
fields.body:
 I'm probably breaking the law by mentioning this (and you're breaking the law by reading it, so law-abiding citizens look away now) but it's another leak from the Atomic Weapons Establishment in Aldermaston. A memo from Jim Barnett (with the wonderful job title of document manager) declares: "AWE place great store on providing and maintaining the highest standards of security" (although if it's been leaked to the Diary then security is not as high as it could be, Jim). He explains that sensitive documents should be divided into four categories: restricted, confidential, secret and top secret (the memo itself is restricted). "It is important that the originator of the material chooses the correct classification," writes Jim. "Assess how valuable the information would be to hostile intelligence. Remember that 'hostile intelligence' need not only be Russia and China, it can also include the media and protesters." So, the threats to civilisation as we know it are: the butchers of Chechnya, the butchers of Tiananmen Square, and, er, the Guardian Diary. Now please eat this item.

 Speaking of the butcher of Chechnya, President Putin himself was rather appropriately visiting the Imperial War Museum yesterday. But to show you can't move in London these days without being assailed by the mayoral elections, the first person Putin tried to shake hands with was a canvasser for Peter Tatchell.

 The latest publications list for Verso arrives, with news of a new book about the Guardian on the way! No, not the promised work by the sane and rational Paul Johnson, but one by Régis Debray, Tariq Ali, Perry Anderson and other well-heeled members of the New Left Review set, concerned at the Guardian's drift (among other things) into "a generally dependable mouthpiece for Downing Street". The authors are said to be readers who held therapy sessions at the Tavistock clinic, "in an attempt to overcome an overwhelming sense of alienation from their daily newspaper. They remain anonymous for therapeutic reasons." We ring publisher Colin Robinson to discuss serialisation rights, and he says the book came out of an email message group, with 20 or so contributors. "Nearly all of them have scores of one sort or another against the Guardian," he says. Now there's a surprise.

 Anyone tempted by an ad in a recent issue of Sunday Business newspaper for something called "The Rich List" (supposedly a database of wealthy individuals) may be tempted to hang on to their £450 after reading a wonderful article in the FT about the man behind it, "international wealth researcher" Lord de Chanson, or (as he used to be called when he lived in a council flat in Halifax) Craig Tuck, the name that he also appeared under in court in 1988 when he received a three-month jail sentence for accounting irregularities. The Sunday Times, who compile their own annual rich list, are looking at legal action to stop him using the name. When my colleague Kate Morris rings the good Lord himself for details (like where he got his title from), he becomes very coy. So anyone with any information on Lord de Craig, do please get in touch.

 Another public relations triumph for the Millennium Dome last week - it has now banned Big Issue vendors from selling their magazine outside the Dome's gates. Sam Hart, a reporter on the Big Issue, explained: "They told the vendor support team that they had a blanket ban on people collecting and street vendors - but when I called the Dome, press officer Adam Liversage was pretty stroppy, complaining 'Do you report every time one of your vendors gets turfed off a pitch?'" The company's decision is all the more weird as the Big Issue actually features inside the Dome, in the Self Portrait zone, and in a film in the Body zone "celebrating heroism and courage"!

No, not the promised work by the sane and rational Paul Johnson, but one by Régis Debray, Tariq Ali, Perry Anderson and other well-heeled members of the New Left Review set, concerned at the Guardian's drift (among other things) into "a generally dependable mouthpiece for Downing Street". The authors are said to be readers who held therapy sessions at the Tavistock clinic, "in an attempt to overcome an overwhelming sense of alienation from their daily newspaper. They remain anonymous for therapeutic reasons." We ring publisher Colin Robinson to discuss serialisation rights, and he says the book came out of an email message group, with 20 or so contributors. "Nearly all of them have scores of one sort or another against the Guardian," he says. Now there's a surprise.  Anyone tempted by an ad in a recent issue of Sunday Business newspaper for something called "The Rich List" (supposedly a database of wealthy individuals) may be tempted to hang on to their £450 after reading a wonderful article in the FT about the man behind it, "international wealth researcher" Lord de Chanson, or (as he used to be called when he lived in a council flat in Halifax) Craig Tuck, the name that he also appeared under in court in 1988 when he received a three-month jail sentence for accounting irregularities. The Sunday Times, who compile their own annual rich list, are looking at legal action to stop him using the name. When my colleague Kate Morris rings the good Lord himself for details (like where he got his title from), he becomes very coy. So anyone with any information on Lord de Craig, do please get in touch.  Another public relations triumph for the Millennium Dome last week - it has now banned Big Issue vendors from selling their magazine outside the Dome's gates. Sam Hart, a reporter on the Big Issue, explained: "They told the vendor support team that they had a blanket ban on people collecting and street vendors - but when I called the Dome, press officer Adam Liversage was pretty stroppy, complaining 'Do you report every time one of your vendors gets turfed off a pitch?'" The company's decision is all the more weird as the Big Issue actually features inside the Dome, in the Self Portrait zone, and in a film in the Body zone "celebrating heroism and courage"!

fields.headline: Coal fired
fields.standfirst: Byers bails out sterling's victims
fields.trailText: How many lumps does a "level playing field" have? Stephen Byers yesterday did something to even up energy supply by loosening controls on gas-fired power stations. But more gas is going to mean less coal, which in turn means further shrinkage in our pygmy coal industry and job cuts in Northumberland, Yorkshire and Nottinghamshire.
fields.body:
How many lumps does a "level playing field" have? Stephen Byers yesterday did something to even up energy supply by loosening controls on gas-fired power stations. But more gas is going to mean less coal, which in turn means further shrinkage in our pygmy coal industry and job cuts in Northumberland, Yorkshire and Nottinghamshire. So Mr Byers was moved simultaneously to announce a large handout for the private company which owns most of the pits. For a few months at least the miners' battle against both sterling's high value relative to the euro and the support given their French and German co-workers (under an agreement ratified by the Tories) will look a bit more like an even contest.

Thus Stephen Byers becomes de facto minister for the heartlands, which is coming to mean minister for bailing out those industries suffering additionally because of sterling. Miners, car workers, steel makers - what remains of Britain's mid 20th-century industrial base - bear the pain the governor of the Bank of England and, presumably, the chancellor think necessary to constrain inflation. If Norman Lamont did not sing in his bath then, he must now, hearing his cliches recycled. And the pain goes on. A study just published by the Rowntree Foundation shows how unemployed, sick and poor the ex-coalfield communities remain.

For coal, the government's formula was till now bracingly Thatcherite: let individual pits work out their own destiny in a competitive market. But the government finds people will keep applying tests of equity to its nostrums of efficiency. It is not fair that BMW can do in the UK what it cannot at home in Bavaria. It is not fair that coal competes against the exchange rate. Labour's response is not pretty. Industrial policy à la Byers has become a sequence of panicky packages. But measures such as yesterday's are imperative until the geological faults beneath the playing field are righted.

webTitle: Sinking cash calls leave City to pick up the bills

fields.headline: Sinking cash calls leave City to pick up the bills
fields.trailText: City institutions are likely to face big underwriting bills to bail out corporate fundraisings, which have slipped under water due to plunging share prices.
fields.body:
City institutions are likely to face big underwriting bills to bail out corporate fundraisings, which have slipped under water due to plunging share prices.

Among the largest cash calls underway is a £50m open offer of shares by Sanctuary, the entertainment group.

Sanctuary wants the money to buy a rival publisher, Castle Music, and is offering new shares at 73p.

Sanctuary's share price yesterday slumped 8p to 58p, however, making the issue look distinctly unattractive.

Stockbroker Investec Henderson Crosthwaite is underwriting the offer. Director Simon Grafftey-Smith said: "This is just down to general market sentiment - it's nothing to do with Sanctuary's prospects specifically."

He said Investec would only pick up a modest proportion of the shares, as it has signed up other institutions as sub-underwriters to take the rest.

Euro Sales Finance, a moneylender which provides bridging loans to businesses, is also raising £50m.

Its shares fell 80p to £13.75 yesterday, against an issue price of £14.75. The lead underwriter is Deutsche Bank, with other institutions acting as sub-underwriters.

Even Richard Branson's unquoted Virgin Group could be hit. Its personal products spin-off, Victory Corporation, is attempting to raise £9.7m to expand its cosmetics range. The shares closed yesterday at 3p, against an open offer of 5p.

fields.headline: Livingstone retreat on key pledges
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone yesterday backtracked on two key campaign pledges in the fight for mayor of London when he published his manifesto without firm commitments to congestion charges for cars or bond issues to finance the capital's tube system.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone yesterday backtracked on two key campaign pledges in the fight for mayor of London when he published his manifesto without firm commitments to congestion charges for cars or bond issues to finance the capital's tube system.

In an ambitious 21-page statement, the ex-Labour independent who remains clear frontrunner, declared that it is "time for Londoners to run their own affairs again" - and promised an open and inclusive style of government.

Not only will London have a new dot.com site where voters can read the minutes of mayor Livingstone's cabinet. In another eye-catching gesture lobbyists will not be granted passes to the Greater London authority's HQ or to meet its staff if the candidate has his way.

Mr Livingstone also wants to recruit 2,000 more police, improve the environment - including 10,000 "green" jobs - freeze tube fares, and investigate a 70p flat fare for the better system of buses he plans.

His rivals for mayor - all trailing below 20% according to polls while Mr Livingstone remains on 49% - have made similar pledges on health, the arts, minority rights and support for business, but not as widespread.

Labour, which has still not abandoned hopes that the trailing Frank Dobson may win the second round play-off, was quick to accuse its famous renegade of making £16bn worth of promises without the money to deliver them.

But £8bn worth of Labour's calculations comes from Mr Livingstone's commitment to use bond issues - secured against income stream from Whitehall grants and ticket prices - to finance modernisation of the London underground, a subject on which his manifesto sounds wary. It says "we should finance the investment needed to modernise the tube by the cheapest possible method, which the evidence indicates is raising bonds backed by a combination of fares and government grants".

That would give him a get-out if further analysis confirms what John Prescott insists, that his own public private partnership (PPP) for leasing the infrastructure - but not the trains - to private firms would prove at least £4bn cheaper.

In contrast to the Brent East MP's promises to introduce a £5-a-day congestion charge on cars entering central London his manifesto talks warily of "consulting widely about the best possible congestion charge scheme to discourage unnecessary car journeys... to commence during the middle of my term of office."

That makes him less vulnerable to what Labour is costing as a £2bn pledge.

fields.headline: Highland fling for love cheese
fields.trailText: The aphrodisiac qualities of a doomed Scottish cheese are to be celebrated in a musical to be performed during this summer's Highland Festival.
fields.body:
The aphrodisiac qualities of a doomed Scottish cheese are to be celebrated in a musical to be performed during this summer's Highland Festival.

Islay Dunlop cheese, banned by the Italians in the 1960s because of its potency, will cease to exist by the end of the year because the creamery that produces it on the Hebridean island is closing due to economic pressures.

Up to 30 jobs will be lost and more than 800 milking cows slaughtered or sold, leaving eight or nine months worth of maturing rounds.

The musical, Hard Pressed, is being put on at 14 civic centres and village halls in May and June, with two shows on Islay during the festival.

Toby Roxburgh, an Islay farmer, said the community had mixed feelings about the play. "Strong men here have been reduced to tears as a result of the body blow, and no wonder. When I was told of the planned 'Hard Cheese' tour, I did not known whether to laugh or cry."

Yesterday the show's director, Alan Craig Wilson, a former star of the BBC drama Taggart, said it would go ahead, although the creamery's closure was "nothing short of tragic".

"Some scenes have had to be rewritten, and I do hope that no one will take offence at the show, which essentially is a celebration of the resilience of remoter communities in the Highlands and Islands".

fields.headline: Untagged flocks will cost farmers
fields.trailText: Farmers will face fines of up to £5,000 if they fail to tag or tattoo their sheep and goats before they sell them for slaughter or to other breeding flocks, the government said yesterday.
fields.body:
Farmers will face fines of up to £5,000 if they fail to tag or tattoo their sheep and goats before they sell them for slaughter or to other breeding flocks, the government said yesterday.

Rules are to be introduced by the end of the year to avert the threat of an EU ban on Britain's £226m export trade in sheep meat and live animals.

The Ministry of Agriculture said the new tracing system for up to 40m sheep and 77,000 goats would also have benefits for the control of diseases, including BSE should it ever be found to have transferred from cattle to sheep.

Officials said they were keeping the extra burden to hard-pressed farmers to a minimum, with the cost of tags put at £12m the first year and £6m annually after that. In a consultation document, they made no attempt to quantify additional labour costs on Britain's 80,000 sheep farms but the system will not be as detailed or complicated as that already required for 11m cattle following the BSE fiasco.

Tags will cost an average 55p a sheep but with lambs selling at market for an average £45, the additional costs will have less impact than might have been feared in recent years.

Tagging should have been introduced under EU rules in 1995 but it was only at end of last year that Brussels warned of possible legal action against Britain.

The government believes the tagging will increase consumer confidence and allow closer checks on EU subsidies to sheep farmers worth up to £400m a year. It will be policed by local authorities, meat hygiene inspectors and vets.

Carol Lloyd, a National Farmers' Union spokeswoman, said: "We have to meet the terms of the EU directive or we face problems with our potential export market."

Opponents of live sheep exports who have been complaining that Britain was breaking the law which required animals to be traced back to the farm of their birth, welcomed the move. "It is clearly unacceptable to have a trade in breach of EU law on identification," said Peter Stevenson of Compassion in World Farming.

 Liberal Democrats yesterday challenged a recent Cabinet Office report that the countryside was "prosperous, contented and reasonably well served". The Lib Dems said only five of 73 education action zones were in rural areas, half of all rural parishes had no primary school, 75% of small parishes had no daily bus services, air pollution levels and ambulance response times were worse. They added long-term unemployment was rising and there had been little attention towards tackling racism.

webTitle: Scooters mark funeral of publican murdered in Istanbul

fields.headline: Scooters mark funeral of publican murdered in Istanbul
fields.trailText: An escort of scooters and a wreath of flowers spelling Dad in Leeds United's white, blue and gold marked the funeral yesterday of the first of the Istanbul murder victims.
fields.body:
An escort of scooters and a wreath of flowers spelling Dad in Leeds United's white, blue and gold marked the funeral yesterday of the first of the Istanbul murder victims.

Kevin Speight, a pub landlord and a scooter fan since he gave a girl a lift on one 15 years ago and went on to marry her, was honoured by hundreds of local people who lined the route to his parish church in Farsley, West Yorkshire, between Leeds and Bradford.

The Earl of Harewood, president of Leeds United, led an official party from the club, which Mr Speight, 40, had followed for more than two decades. Leeds goalkeeper Nigel Martyn and club manager David O'Leary were among the mourners.

Scooter and ice hockey pictures had to take second place to portraits and mementoes of the Premier League side on the walls of his Bay Horse pub in Farsley's main street.

Mr Speight's widow, Sally, broke down in tears as the scooters, ridden by his fellow enthusiasts, arrived with the cortege at St John's church, past the town's Liberal Club, whose balconies were draped with Leeds United shirts below a union flag at half mast.

Shops were closed as a mark of respect to a man described by Canon John White, the vicar of Farsley, as "friendly and generous - a good neighbour in every way".

Mr Speight, who leaves a son, George, seven and a daughter, Holly, two, died of multiple stab wounds after a gang of Turkish youths ran riot in central Istanbul on April 5.

Christopher Loftus, 35, the second victim of the incident on the night before Leeds United's Uefa Cup semi-final against Turkey's champion club, Galatasaray, will be buried today at Leeds parish church.

Four Turkish men have been charged with the murders, which have led to exceptionally tight security and a ban on Galatasaray fans for the second leg of the Cup tie on Thursday night in Leeds.

Turkey's interior minister announced yesterday that a squad of 11 police would accompany the Istanbul team to West Yorkshire, with 80 VIP ticketholders whose bona fides have been passed by Uefa.

fields.headline: Base for the boffins
fields.trailText: Dera is one of the country's biggest grouping of top boffins, with skills ranging from computing to biological warfare.
fields.body:
Dera is one of the country's biggest grouping of top boffins, with skills ranging from computing to biological warfare.

Its Porton Down chemical and biological defence centre will remain in government hands because its work is so security-sensitive. But its leading edge work on speech recognition systems could easily be exploited in both the civil and military fields.

Last year it licensed part of its computer voice recognition technology to NXT, a high tech company which had already used Dera technology to develop flat panel loudspeakers.

Dera had stumbled upon the flat panel technology when it was experimenting with materials to sound-proof helicopters.

fields.headline: Row over defence research sell-off
fields.trailText: The government is considering selling part of its defence research agency to a venture capital group to help prepare the business for flotation next year, sources revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
The government is considering selling part of its defence research agency to a venture capital group to help prepare the business for flotation next year, sources revealed yesterday.

Defence secretary Geoff Hoon said the defence evaluation and research agency Dera would be split, with the bulk of the business being privatised.

But, to satisfy American concerns, about a quarter of Dera - including the most security sensitive operations - is being retained by the ministry of defence.

Defence sources said that the government was concerned about whether it could prepare the business for flotation in time.

It is considering selling part of the business to a venture capital firm such as 3i to get help with the reorganisation and to provide the new company with some City credibility ahead of flotation. The Commons defence select committee has twice opposed the sale of Dera. Bruce George, the committee's chairman, yesterday opposed the split. "The co-operation which has been so strong with comparable organisations in the US might well be compromised," he warned.

Mr George blamed the sale plan on MoD cash-flow problems which stemmed from treasury budgets. He said that the treasury, not the MoD would be the main beneficiary of the sale.

The government intends to retain a golden share in the new company and prevent individuals or other companies owning more than 5% of its shares.

It will also restrict foreign ownership, probably to the 30% limit used when Rolls-Royce and British Aerospace were privatised.

The sale, which is likely to be carried out in a number of stages, is expected to realise at least £1bn for the Treasury's coffers.

If the government decides to go it alone, it will sell off a majority stake in Dera next year.

Dera, which employs about 12,000 people, has been earning profits of between £20m and £30m in recent years on a turnover of about £1bn.

Profits are expected to suffer in the first year or two as the MoD, its largest customer, demands greater value for money. Hundreds of jobs will be at risk.

The government faces a renewed "fat cat" pay round as a Dera becomes free to switch from civil service pay scales to those more common in the defence industry.

Unions attacked the plans, describing the partial sell-off as a "divorce dressed up as cohabitation".

Fiona Draper of the IPMS union said: "It will tie up defence researchers in red tape and prove unworkable. It will destroy science expertise in and out of MoD and endanger working relations between British scientists and the USA.

"Worst of all, it will fail in its primary purpose to transfer military technology to the private sector."

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: A knee-jerk bout of price slashing aside, London dealers had little to do yesterday until after lunch, when trading resumed in the US and investors over here got some indication about where prices were headed.
fields.body:
A knee-jerk bout of price slashing aside, London dealers had little to do yesterday until after lunch, when trading resumed in the US and investors over here got some indication about where prices were headed.

The early indication was that prices were going up - but not dramatically, and the result was some fast two-way action late in the day in the square mile, which eventually left the FTSE 100 183.5 points lower at 5,994.6.

With Wall Street getting a surer footing after the close of trading in London, expectations are that British share prices will open higher again this morning.

At the end of the day, trading volume looked rather respectable, with 1.7bn shares on the move - swollen by some active business in Vodafone Airtouch (down 14p at 286p) and BP Amoco (down 3p at 527p). The oil major is due to be reweighted within the Footsie today as it completes its £17bn takeover of Atlantic Richfield.

All eyes, of course, were on the big technology stocks - may of which confounded the sceptics by going up. Chip designer Arm Holdings , for example, crashed to £25.55 at one stage on the market's order board, but the price rebounded sharply, closing just 138p adrift at £30.68. Portable computing expert Psion , meanwhile, was being quoted at £20 at one point, but subsequently jumped to £28.02, 172p higher on the day.

Software group Sage turned in a similarly-impressive performance, adding 20p to 613p as American investment bank Merrill Lynch issued a "buy" recommendation. The company is considered to be one of the best quality stocks in its sector, and Merrill reckons the stock is worth 900p.

Baltimore Technology was another former high-flying tech stock which drew the attention of bargain hunters. Despite an opening quote of £47.00, the price quickly rallied to £58.30, up 500p, although earlier this year the shares were trading at an astonishing £150.00.

Against this, Easynet managed to lose 255p to 900p, Royalblue shed 225p to £14.00 and BATM Advanced Communications gave up 507p to £38.25. Biotech issues were also in the firing line as market makers slashed prices in the expectation that speculators were try to off-load holdings. Shire Pharmaceutical , for example, slumped from 899p to 737p, while British Biotech gave up 2p to 23p. Cambridge Antibody was being quoted at £14.75 at one stage in the day, but miraculously recovered to £19.25, unchanged on the day. Footsie member Celltech shed 55p to £10.38.

fields.headline: A way out for Mugabe
fields.standfirst:
South Africa is vital to Zimbabwe's future

Zimbabwe: special report
Movement for Democratic Change
Commercial Farmers' Union
fields.trailText: Morgan Tsvangirai, the leader of the main opposition movement in Zimbabwe, says that Robert Mugabe should be offered an honourable way out. But how? Stubborn, oblivious of the damage he is inflicting on his country and the suffering of the individuals caught up in the dramas he has manufactured, Mugabe has paid attention so far neither to threats nor inducements.
fields.body:
Morgan Tsvangirai, the leader of the main opposition movement in Zimbabwe, says that Robert Mugabe should be offered an honourable way out. But how? Stubborn, oblivious of the damage he is inflicting on his country and the suffering of the individuals caught up in the dramas he has manufactured, Mugabe has paid attention so far neither to threats nor inducements. He is unfazed by international criticism, by the suspension of aid, or by talk of sanctions. He treats offers of compromise, like Britain's expression of readiness to discuss compensation for commercial white farmers after a fair and efficient distribution of land, as concessions which he is under no obligation to match. Mugabe could have softened his policies on his return from abroad two days ago, as some elements in his government seemed to want him to do, but he chose not to do so.

He has written the script for the next chapter of his political life, and it casts him as a patriotic leader resisting an internal plot led by whites and black traitors and backed by outside forces, notably Britain, determined to destroy Zimbabwe's independence. Mugabe's script is mendacious, in the sense that the coalition between white businessmen, including farmers, and black opposition groups came into being only after his mismanagement of the country and the economy reached an intolerable point. It is a reaction, not a plot. But he is right that it represents a threat to him. It may be that his script still includes a bargain with his opponents, or for compromise with Britain and other international critics. But only on his terms. Mugabe still expects to win. The main reason his "veterans" are on the farms is so that they can coerce the farm workers, a fifth of the voters, into casting their ballots for Zanu-PF in the elections that are supposed to be held sometime in the coming months.

One question is whether there are substantial elements in the ruling party who feel Mugabe is taking Zimbabwe in the wrong direction. After all, most of the opposition originally came from the Zanu-PF fold. It might be a long wait for such defections, however. But there is one power that has the means and the prestige to change the situation decisively, which is why the news that President Thabo Mbeki is to make an official visit to Zimbabwe soon could be very important. South Africa has obvious moral leverage, and, at least in theory, physical leverage, too, in that it supplies most of Zimbabwe's electricity and fuel. President Mbeki is the chairman of Commonwealth, which gives him a mandate to start a process of mediation.

Finally, the South African leader has a very strong interest in seeing the land issue in Zimbabwe settled in a moderate way. If there were to be a wholesale distribution of white-owned farms in Zimbabwe, the impact on the delicate politics of land in South Africa would be enormous. A quiet South African intervention is the one thing that might persuade Mugabe to accept a package including a withdrawal of all or most of the squatters, British readiness to reconsider the compensation question, a firm date for elections, Commonwealth help in preparing for fair elections, and Commonwealth monitoring of the vote itself. Given the right impetus by South Africa and others, the Commonwealth Ministerial Action Group, which is due to meet in London at the beginning of May, should be able to set this in train. Better still, given the dangers, it would be a good idea if a Commonwealth mission including the new secretary general, Don McKinnon, and the Nigerian president, Olusegun Obasanjo, were to go to Harare earlier.

webTitle: Giant catamaran could be repaired in time for the big race

fields.headline: Giant catamaran could be repaired in time for the big race
fields.standfirst: Designers are confident they can fix the fault that put a new £4m craft back on the blocks
fields.trailText: After four years and £4m, it took only seconds to smash Pete Goss's dream of taking his revolutionary giant catamaran to the greatest ever round the world race .
fields.body:
After four years and £4m, it took only seconds to smash Pete Goss's dream of taking his revolutionary giant catamaran to the greatest ever round the world race .

Yesterday he revealed that it would take more than three months and several hundred thousand pounds to repair his state of the art craft, after a 40ft section of the port bow snapped off into the sea during trials three weeks ago.

The disaster appeared to end Mr Goss's hopes of competing in the ultimate sailing challenge. If the radical new design could not cope with the relatively calm waters off the Isles of Scilly, how could it ever cope with the 40ft waves of the southern oceans?

But the 62-strong team of designers and builders behind Team Philips have pinpointed the problem.

Contrary to what their many critics had claimed, it did not lie in any fundamental design flaw and they insist the problem can be fixed in time for the catamaran to reach Barcelona for the start of The Race, as it is known, the French organised non-stop circumnavigation of the globe due to start on the stroke of midnight on New Year's Eve.

Now, three weeks after disaster struck the world's largest carbon fibre structure the prognosis looks good.

The enormous catamaran - it measures 120ft by 70ft with enough space to park 80 cars between its hulls and is capable of 40 knots - was moved upstream from Dartmouth last week to its boatyard in the Devonshire town of Totnes to allow the team to get back to work if not, as many thought, back to the drawing board.

Mr Goss, the man behind the dream, has remained sanguine, displaying the kind of temperament which must come in handy for a man who has sailed around the world twice and crossed the Atlantic three times.

Despite having to pull out of the upcoming Jules Verne Trophy, he has insisted all along that the problem was nothing to worry about.

"It will take three or four months to fix the problem and something in the region of a couple of hundred thousand pounds. But there's always a price to pay with anything like this and right now the greatest price is time.

"Two things can happen when this kind of thing takes place: either it can all fall apart or everybody pulls together. We chose to work at the cutting edge of innovation and difficulties are inherent in that.

"Projects like this don't come wrapped in clingfilm on a supermarket shelf. But the whole aim was to win The Race and that hasn't changed."

The team of designers, led by Adrian Thompson, who conceived the revolutionary idea of a giant catamaran using wave piercing hulls with no supporting cross beams, hope to complete a detailed survey of the vessel by Friday.

What is already certain is that a change in the structural make-up of both hulls will be necessary to deal with the problem of side forces, which act like giant levers trying to snap the extended bows off.

The failure which led to the bow breaking off and a 15ft crack appearing in the star board hull lay in the bonding of a main carbon fibre "plank" which runs fore and aft on both sides of the hull and the hi-tech honeycomb core between the two skins of the hull.

This single plant of fibres requires perfect bonding with epoxy resin to the core, and when the laminate was curing in its mould, the heat generated caused air in the honeycomb to expand and corrupt the bond.

The remedy will include a series of frames and stringers to provide additional support, as well as the considerable rein forcement of the broken plank structures.

While work continues on the hulls, Mr Goss and his five crew members have continued their training, using one of the two 135ft masts, which has been set in concrete near the Goss headquarters.

The sponsors, led by electronics giant Philips, are clearly happy to continue to fund the adventure, and it is easy to see why.

With 500,000 visitors to the boatyard at Baltic Wharf in Totnes and 4m hits on the website since the project began, the catamaran - and the searing hole in its blue and silver hull - has become an even bigger crowd-puller since the latest setback, with letters of support arriving by the sackload every day.

It is not only the boat which is enjoying celebrity status. Mr Goss, who is married with three children, was already a household name in France after the former Royal Marine turned back in treacherous winds in the Southern Ocean during the Vendée Globe single-handed sailing challenge to rescue French yachtsman Raphel Dinelli, a feat for which he received the Légion d'honneur, France's highest gallantry award.

Although he also received an MBE in Britain, the fresh hordes of British autograph hunters have only served to boost the Team Philips crew.

Mr Goss said: "There's no doubt in my mind that we'll be there at the start of The Race on December 31. We can fix it, I have absolute confidence in that.

"People said it would never work and I suppose some of them will never be convinced until the boat crosses the finishing line."

fields.headline: Remote and unresponsive
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: An ICM poll for the Hutton commission shows that fewer than one in 20 believe the NHS provides such a good service that it could not be improved. Nearly two-thirds feel either that it needs to be "improved quite a lot" or that the NHS gives a poor service and needs "a great deal of improvement".
fields.body:
An ICM poll for the Hutton commission shows that fewer than one in 20 believe the NHS provides such a good service that it could not be improved. Nearly two-thirds feel either that it needs to be "improved quite a lot" or that the NHS gives a poor service and needs "a great deal of improvement".

Yet when ICM pollsters asked about "most valuable" national institutions, the NHS comes head, shoulders and torso above the rest. Almost two-thirds (63%) pick it as the UK's most valuable national institution, followed a long way behind by parliament (12%) and the police (11%). Among also-rans in our list were the BBC (4%) and royal family (3%), just ahead of the Bank of England and the social security benefits agency.

The founding principles of the NHS are clearly what inspires its special place in popular affections. Everyone (96%) believes in the right to "free medical treatment at the time of need", saying that this should be enshrined in a bill of rights for the UK. At present, of course, there is no such constitutional guarantee, as the controversy over postcode variations in treatment makes clear.

We asked people to choose between the status quo - trusting elected politicians to look after the NHS - and giving the NHS its own constitution, as proposed by the Hutton commission. Those aged 25 to 55 are more likely to say the NHS should have its own constitution to protect the principle of free medical care at the point of need; the young and pensioners are a little less concerned.

Despite its high public support, the NHS is not seen as responsively run. When we gave respondents two alternatives, only just over a third (36%) said the health service is "run in an open way and consults the public" while over half (56%) endorse the option that the NHS is remote and hard to influence.

So people want more democratic health authorities instead of government-appointed quangos. Middle-class (AB) people plump heavily (58%) for control by part-elected and part-appointed committees rather than by wholly elected health authorities. But people in the manual social grades are keener on all-elected bodies rather than mixed ones. On this issue, all social groups look certain to be disappointed. Like its predecessor, New Labour has set its face against elections in favour of continuing the patronage state under new ownership.

There are significant gender differences in attitudes. Women are more optimistic, with somewhat more responding that they have a lot of power over their treatment than those saying they had none at all.

When we asked how much power people feel that they should have over their medical treatment, however, the gender gap opened into a chasm. Some 45% of men say they should have "a lot of power" over treatment; the same proportion opts for "a little". But 64% of women want a lot of power (32% a little).

This gender divide dwarfs the influence of class, age and region; it is one of the most clear-cut male-female differences we have ever seen in survey data.

Two factors seem to explain the difference. First, women are much more likely to have dealings with the NHS throughout their lives, unlike men who more often seek medical care only at a moment of crisis. Second, men are still much more buttoned-up than women about both their emotions and bodies, and do not like to seem over-anxious or wimpish in the consulting room.

But women's greater contact with the NHS brings only a small increment in women's perception of health care as openly or responsively run. And women are even less willing than men to accept government appointees as legitimate managers of the local NHS or to see trust in national politicians as an adequate safeguard of our health rights.

The poll was sponsored by the Rowntree Reform Trust and based on a random sample of 1,004 adults.

 Patrick Dunleavy is professor of politics at the London School of Economics and and Stuart Weir is director of Democratic Audit at Essex University

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: Reporting from Brussels (page 5, April 13), we said the European Parliament had voted down by 287 to 202 environmental liability rules that would have held makers of genetically modified food responsible for damaging the environment or public health. In fact, it was for the measure that MEPs voted by that margin. (The proposal failed, however, as a majority of 314 was needed.)
fields.body:
Reporting from Brussels (page 5, April 13), we said the European Parliament had voted down by 287 to 202 environmental liability rules that would have held makers of genetically modified food responsible for damaging the environment or public health. In fact, it was for the measure that MEPs voted by that margin. (The proposal failed, however, as a majority of 314 was needed.)

Our magazine column Famous then, page 70, Weekend, April 15, said that before the 1988 Seoul Olympics swimmer David Wilkie considered a comeback bid "for a place in England's squad" at those games. It is Britain, not England, that sends a team to the Olympics (thus it was that at the 1976 Montreal Olympics, Wilkie's gold medal had been attributed to Britain rather than his native Scotland).

TV listings page 24, G2, showed last night's party election broadcast as scheduled to run 50 minutes on BBC2. The Labour party points out that it was, in reality, one of its shortest broadcasts ever, at just over two minutes.

We erred in listing George Orwell, page 19, April 5, among those who contributed essays to The God that Failed, the post-war collection of essays on communism.

An erroneous headline was added to a story about Sir Charles Gray, the judge in the recent Holocaust case launched by author David Irving, page 10, G2 Law, yesterday. It was not the Irving case but - as stated in the text - the 1994 Halcion sleeping-pill case that took 62 days in court and generated more than 36,000 pages of evidence. The Irving case took 32 days and generated 10,000 pages of documents excluding books.

fields.headline: Apology for undetected remains
fields.trailText: Police yesterday apologised to a couple who found the remains of one of their sons a month after a fire razed their home.
fields.body:
Police yesterday apologised to a couple who found the remains of one of their sons a month after a fire razed their home.

A search by Grampian officers had missed bones of Jack Dugan, five, who died with his brother, Toby, three, in the fire in Strathdon, Aberdeenshire, on January 21.

Their parents, Grampian PC Alan Dugan, 34, and his partner, Julie Tanner, 39, who suffered extensive burns as they tried to rescue their sons, made the discovery when they returned to lay flowers. The boys' bodies were exhumed for the further remains to be added to their grave.

An external inquiry into the way the Grampian force handled the incident concluded that mistakes had been made.

Grampian's chief constable, Andrew Brown, said: "It is clear from the report that the distress experienced by Alan and Julie at their tragic loss was considerably exacerbated by the failure to find Jack during the initial search. The force deeply regrets the additional distress and has apologised unreservedly."

Mr Brown said recommendations in the report, produced by a Tayside police team, included advice to individual officers.

webTitle: Labour tax plans will push up loan rates, warns Clarke

fields.headline: Labour tax plans will push up loan rates, warns Clarke
fields.trailText: The government last night fought off all-party criticism of Gordon Brown's tax policies which his Conservative predecessor, Kenneth Clarke, warned would help to push up both interest rates and sterling in the long run.
fields.body:
The government last night fought off all-party criticism of Gordon Brown's tax policies which his Conservative predecessor, Kenneth Clarke, warned would help to push up both interest rates and sterling in the long run.

As MPs began their annual debate on the finance bill, which implements Mr Brown's fourth budget, the chancellor's no 2, Andrew Smith, moved to head off such criticism in advance by confirming that up to £20bn of windfall revenue from the auctioning off of mobile phone licences will be used to pay off government debt - not to fuel public spending.

"The prudent thing to do with such a large income is to use it to reduce debt, and that is what our plans are," said Mr Smith, who is chief secretary to the Treasury. He spoke after the veteran Labour ex-Treasury minister, Robert Sheldon, had complained that the mobile phone receipts - once estimated at just £10bn - were not even mentioned in the budgetary guide, the so-called "red book."

With many Labour MPs keen to boost spending as election day approaches Mr Sheldon observed: "That's a large increase in the revenue. Not all of it will come in this financial year. But it should have some impact either on the expenditure or possibly on the revenue side."

Mr Smith stuck to the Brownite theme of "sound public finances" which he contrasted with Tory commitments to "reckless tax pledges for the few" - a reference to Michael Portillo's "tax guarantee" to cut income tax over a parliament.

The shadow Treasury secretary, David Heathcoat-Amory, took a different line of attack when he complained that Labour was spending £2bn a year more on central government services since 1997.

The former Tory chancellor, Kenneth Clarke, said "hand-wringing" ministers and Bank of England officials could not be indifferent to the damage to farming and manufacturing caused by the high level of sterling.

He urged Mr Brown to "return to his former girlfriend, Prudence" but warned that, in the long-term, the chancellor is loosening fiscal policy. Instead of helping the Bank to keep interest rates down, that would do the opposite, that would push sterling still higher, he warned.

Mr Clarke said the government was "very slowly losing control" of "an improving (economic) situation, a good situation".

"This government is turning to an old tax and spend government after all," he said.

webTitle: Private collection of silver, gold and mosaics given to Somerset House

fields.headline: Private collection of silver, gold and mosaics given to Somerset House
fields.trailText: Long after Sir Arthur Gilbert returns home to Los Angeles, he will be keeping an eye on the treasure at Somerset House, where the Gilbert Collection was formally declared open yesterday.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Long after Sir Arthur Gilbert returns home to Los Angeles, he will be keeping an eye on the treasure at Somerset House, where the Gilbert Collection was formally declared open yesterday.

The silver, gold, and mosaics are conservatively valued at £150m. It is regarded as the most extraordinary private collection in the world, rivalled only by the Vatican and the Hermitage, St Petersburg, museums.

The gift to the nation was the key to the £20.75m heritage lottery grant to rescue the 18th century splendour of Somerset House from 200 years of civil service files, and restore it as galleries and public spaces.

The collection includes objects made for popes and princes, such as jewelled snuff boxes made for Frederick the Great, a clock sent by Pius VII as a coronation present to Napoleon, and a pair of vases owned by Empress Josephine at Malmaison.

Dazzling silver and gold gates, given by Catherine the Great to a church in Kiev, were bought by William Randolph Hearst for San Simeon, the model for Xanadu in Citizen Kane - like many Hearst treasures they never came out of their crate.

Dozens of pieces are returning to Britain after being scattered in the country house sales of the 1960s.

Sir Arthur's is a fur-to-riches story: born in Golder's Green, north London, in 1913, he turned his back on the family fur business, taking his first wife's surname after a family rift. He was never, he points out,, the poor Jewish boy of legend: his elder brother, who stayed in the fur trade, once bought a Gutenberg Bible - and sold it at a profit.

Sir Arthur made his first fortune marketing evening gown designs by his first wife Rosalinde, and moved to California in 1949, and made another fortune in property. He started col lecting because he wanted some "nice things" for his new California house.

Sir Arthur was knighted last year in recognition of his munificence, but wanted to leave some more tangible reminder. The Gilbert name or initials are already on every door of the new galleries, but he felt it needed something more. He has created a replica of his office in Los Angeles - "but it's too small," he grumbled "my office is much larger, I was told this would be bigger" - complete with lifesize waxwork of himself in his usual working clothes, yellow tennis kit.

The collection was opened yesterday but building work continues. There will be guided tours until May 25, when it is fully opened.

fields.headline: Straw tells 3,000 Kosovans to leave
fields.standfirst:
Kosovo: special report
Refugees in Britain: special report
The issue explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: More than 3,000 Kosovan Albanians who were given temporary protection in Britain at the height of last year's war have been told they must leave from the end of this month, the home secretary, Jack Straw, confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
More than 3,000 Kosovan Albanians who were given temporary protection in Britain at the height of last year's war have been told they must leave from the end of this month, the home secretary, Jack Straw, confirmed yesterday.

The government's declaration of firm action against Kosovans who overstay came as a new Guardian/ICM opinion poll showed that the battle between Labour and Conservatives over asylum has had little impact on voters. When asked which party was talking the most sense about asylum, only 16% named Labour and 15% the Conservatives.

The poll results suggest that the conventional wisdom at Westminster that asylum is playing hard among the voters as the local election campaigns get under way is so far misplaced. The voters are also unimpressed by the charge that either or both of the two main parties are being racist when they talk about the problem of asylum seekers. Only 16% say the Conservatives are racist on asylum and only 5% think Labour is racist on the issue. The party political hostilities will resume tonight when the Conservative leader, William Hague, delivers an unapologetic lecture on "common sense on asylum" to the Social Market Foundation, an independent body that commissions research.

The poll findings came as Mr Straw disclosed that he is ready to take enforcement action against Kosovans who do not go back volunatarily. Some 4,427 Kosovan Albanians came to Britain last year under the UN's humanitarian emergency evacuation programme. So far 1,151 have gone back to Kosovo. A further 403 have visited to see the condition of their old homes under an "explore and prepare" programme. Of this group some 332 have come back to Britain.

Mr Straw said he believed it was now broadly safe for Kosovans of Albanian extraction to return. They had been given temporary protection for 12 months and that would start to run out for the group between April 28 and early June. Their permission to stay would not be renewed unless there were exceptional circumstances. "Enforcement action will be taken in due course against those who do not go back voluntarily," said the home secretary. Those who remain will be "overstayers" who will lose all benefits and face deportation.

Mr Straw also criticised the main charities, including Oxfam and Barnardos, who have boycotted the asylum voucher scheme because of his insistence that no change is given to those who use the vouchers. He claimed their criticism was based on the mistaken belief that asylum seekers were given only one voucher but there were several denominations down to 50 pence.

The ICM poll results showing that asylum has yet to make much of a party political impact on the public showed that 20% believe that none of the main parties make sense when they talk about asylum. Only 12% said the Liberal Democrats made the most sense and 36% said they did not know, suggesting they do not know the difference between the parties on the issue.

The second question about whether the main political parties were seen to be racist over the issue also failed to produce much response. Some 36% thought none of the parties were being racist and 42% did not have an opinion.

ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,203 adults aged 18 plus by telephone on March 14-15 this year. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

fields.headline: Nursery child 'tied to chair'
fields.trailText: The owner of a nursery tied a three-year-old child to a chair with a scarf because he would not sit down and force fed other children until they were physically sick, a court was told yesterday.
fields.body:
The owner of a nursery tied a three-year-old child to a chair with a scarf because he would not sit down and force fed other children until they were physically sick, a court was told yesterday.

Margaret Gloria Price, 58, who did not have any child care qualifications or training when she started the Playtime nursery in Brecon, south Wales, pleaded not guilty to 14 charges of child cruelty at Merthyr crown court.

It is alleged that Price was cruel towards several children, some as young as 12 months, in her care between November 1995 and March 1999.

The court was told that Price hit a young boy over the back of the head with a hard book because he would not listen to a story she was reading and forced a little girl to bite her own hand.

The jury, of seven men and five women, heard that in another incident she told a three-year-old boy: 'You are like a fat, lazy pudding that doesn't taste very nice" because he could not say his alphabet.

David Aubrey QC, prosecuting, told the court: "The initial facilities [at the nursery] were regarded as good. But the reality altered as time went by. We are talking about the deliberate, criminal ill-treatment of these children."

He said that her staff had described her as a "tyrant", a "bully" and said that she had created a "culture of fear in the nursery".

He told the court that Price had targeted particular children because she disliked their parents.

The case continues.

fields.headline: Animal test firm plans £25m flotation
fields.trailText: An Israeli biotechnology company that specialises in testing drugs on irradiated mice is hoping to raise about £25m by floating on the London stock exchange.
fields.body:
An Israeli biotechnology company that specialises in testing drugs on irradiated mice is hoping to raise about £25m by floating on the London stock exchange.

XTL Biopharmaceuticals was one of two healthcare companies that braved stock market turbulence yesterday with plans to go public.

Based near Tel Aviv, XTL destroys the immune systems of mice through radiation, then implanting human tissue so that drug tolerance can be tested.

Chief executive Michael Becker said: "This can reduce the need to test drugs on higher primates, such as chimpanzees."

XTL is developing a range of drugs in-house, including treatments for hepatitis B and C, and carries out tests for other pharmaceuticals companies.

XTL is likely to be valued at around £125m. However, it could face opposition from animal rights groups. Mr Becker admitted the company gets through several thousand mice a year.

"There's always a section of the population with whom no rational argument in favour of testing on animals will work.

"Obviously, I can't ask a mouse if its suffering pain but we do treat all our animals in a humane fashion."

Peterborough-based Weston Medical announced it expects to attract a price of £215m in its planned flotation.

Weston has developed a way of firing liquid medicines through the skin at high pressure without using a needle.

Chief executive Christopher Sammler said: "We are acutely aware of what's happening on the stock market but we did not consider delaying our move. We're very confident about the story we've got to tell."

Weston 's shares will cost 160p-195p. The firm hopes to raise £55m.

fields.headline: Allied Zurich ends London listing
fields.standfirst: Stock no longer FTSE-eligible
fields.trailText: Allied Zurich, owner of insurance groups Eagle Star and Allied Dunbar, is to relinquish its place in the FTSE 100 as a result of a move to simplify its complicated ownership.
fields.body:
Allied Zurich, owner of insurance groups Eagle Star and Allied Dunbar, is to relinquish its place in the FTSE 100 as a result of a move to simplify its complicated ownership.

The change, which will see the main stock market listing move to Switzerland, is intended to make it easier for the parent company, Zurich Financial Services, to complete mergers and acquisitions and appease US investors ahead of its planned stock market listing there.

To compensate British investors for its removal from the London index, holders of Allied Zurich shares will receive a special cash dividend of 40p a share.

The shares will no longer be eligible for inclusion in the FTSE 100 because of the decision to take the primary stock market listing to Zurich, although a secondary listing will be maintained in London.

The new structure - approved by three of Allied Zurich's major institutional shareholders - follows a prolonged period of confusion about the share movement of the two companies forming Zurich Financial Services, which was created when the Swiss-based company bought the financial services arm of British American Tobacco two years ago.

Under the terms of the merger, Zurich Financial Services was formed and owned 57% by Swiss investors through Zurich Allied and 43% by Allied Zurich.

The London shares have been trading at a discount to those in Switzerland.

Lord Cairns, chairman of Allied Zurich in London, will retire after the unification.

fields.headline: Lastminute gains belated defence
fields.standfirst:
Market forces
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Morgan Stanley finally broke its silence yesterday on the disastrous flotation of Lastminute.com, which has slumped in value by more than 70% since joining the market last month.
fields.body:
Morgan Stanley finally broke its silence yesterday on the disastrous flotation of Lastminute.com, which has slumped in value by more than 70% since joining the market last month.

The US bank, which acted as Lastminute's adviser, mounted a robust defence of the business, claiming it was heavily undervalued.

European internet analyst Michael Steib said: "The fundamentals of this business are very good and have not changed since flotation, regardless of the negative sentiment there has been.

"Lastminute has strong growth rates and has doubled its supplier numbers. You cannot grow your customer base without growing your suppliers, so this bodes well."

Mr Steib's remarks provided a rare boost to Lastminute's shares. After falling 37p during the morning, they bounced back to close level at 157p.

That leaves the market's highest-profile internet stock with a market value of £237m. Lastminute has £113m of cash in the bank, which it raised when it issued new shares. So the market believes its underlying brand and business is worth just £124m.

There is an increasing view that this price tag fails to reflect the power of Last minute's household name.

Martha Lane Fox and her business partner, Brent Hoberman, have managed to project Lastminute into the national consciousness despite relatively modest marketing so far. But its revenue remains meagre.

Lastminute is to report first-quarter figures within the next fortnight. Morgan Stanley forecasts sales of £4.9m and a pre-tax loss of £8m.

Another internet ticket agency, Ebookers, has a much higher base from which to build. It announced yesterday that its quarterly sales had jumped from £5.7m to £15.5m. However, it clocked up losses of £6.2m and is often compared to Lastminute.

But Ebookers' chief executive, Dinesh Dhamija, insists there are few similarities: "We are two very different propositions. We have a business. We have proprietary technology and sales more than five times greater than theirs."

Lastminute appears to have been punished for its initial high-profile optimism.

So the market believes its underlying brand and business is worth just £124m. There is an increasing view that this price tag fails to reflect the power of Last minute's household name. Martha Lane Fox and her business partner, Brent Hoberman, have managed to project Lastminute into the national consciousness despite relatively modest marketing so far. But its revenue remains meagre. Lastminute is to report first-quarter figures within the next fortnight. Morgan Stanley forecasts sales of £4.9m and a pre-tax loss of £8m. Another internet ticket agency, Ebookers, has a much higher base from which to build. It announced yesterday that its quarterly sales had jumped from £5.7m to £15.5m. However, it clocked up losses of £6.2m and is often compared to Lastminute. But Ebookers' chief executive, Dinesh Dhamija, insists there are few similarities: "We are two very different propositions. We have a business. We have proprietary technology and sales more than five times greater than theirs." Lastminute appears to have been punished for its initial high-profile optimism.

fields.headline: Focus Talisman House
fields.trailText: Talisman House, the financial services group, has not had the good fortune its title might suggest.
fields.body:
Talisman House, the financial services group, has not had the good fortune its title might suggest.

The 40% slump in the group's share price, since it announced its takeover of fund manager Farlake Group in February, saw it forced by the regulator to increase its bid despite having over 90% of shareholder acceptances.

When Talisman made its original 92-for-10 share offer to Farlake shareholders its bid was valued at £8.04 a share. On the same day Talisman bought a parcel of shares from an institutional stakeholder in Farlake for £7.16 each.

Talisman had included the cash alternative in its bid but had limited the maximum payout of cash to 23.5% of the offer.

As its share price slumped from around 80p at the time of the offer to as low as 35p last month, the value of Talisman's share offer dipped below the cash alternative.

Yesterday Talisman, which owns broking houses Seymour Pierce and Ellis & Partners, was forced to increase its share offer to 160-for-10 and also make its cash alternative 100% available to Farlake shareholders.

This saw shares in Farlake rocket 177p to 680p. Talisman was nudged 3p higher to 47p. Talisman says it knows of no reason for the collapse in its share price and blamed "volatile market conditions".

In the past week the com pany appointed as its executive chairman Keith Harris, the former chief executive of HSBC's investment bank. John Mackay, Talisman's chief executive, is a former deputy chief executive at HSBC Investment bank.

Talisman, which listed on the Alternative Investment Market in 1998, has chased Farlake not only for its £560m in managed private client funds but for its internet investment.

Farlake owns website funds direct which has a comprehensive listing of 1,600 units trusts providing performance information on those funds as well as on open-ended investment companies.

Talisman claim, even at yesterday's increased bid, they are still getting Farlake as a "bargain" but, given the unfavourable status of internet-related stocks in the past few weeks, the value of the website may be questionable.

webTitle: Short urges US to give more aid

fields.headline: Short urges US to give more aid
fields.trailText: Clare Short, the international development secretary, today attacks the US for its ungenerous record on aid for the world's poorest countries.
fields.body:
Clare Short, the international development secretary, today attacks the US for its ungenerous record on aid for the world's poorest countries.

Despite being the world's largest economy, the US is at the bottom of the league table of donor generosity, spending just 0.1% of its annual income on development assistance.

Ms Short's statement to the US Congress reads: "It is of course deeply disappointing that the US share is by some margin, the lowest of all members of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development."

The speech will be delivered by the permanent secretary of the international development department, Sir John Vereker, after flu prevented Ms Short from attending the meetings of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund.

Western aid budgets have fallen by a third over the last decade, a trend which Ms Short describes as dangerous. "It is shocking that at a time of growing abundance and gross inequality, the small sums devoted to aid are being slashed."

Britain's aid record puts it in the lower third of the league table of donors. Top of the table are Denmark, Norway, the Netherlands and Sweden - the only donors to spend more than 0.7% of their annual income on aid, the official UN target for development assistance.

fields.trailText:
Man charged with murder
A 48-year-old man was yesterday charged with the murder of an Asian shopkeeper in an alleged racist attack. Santokh Singh Sandhu, 42, also known as Peter Singh, died after an incident outside a hotel in Port Talbot, south Wales, on Saturday.
fields.body:
Man charged with murder
A 48-year-old man was yesterday charged with the murder of an Asian shopkeeper in an alleged racist attack. Santokh Singh Sandhu, 42, also known as Peter Singh, died after an incident outside a hotel in Port Talbot, south Wales, on Saturday.

Boys robbed of Pokémon cards
Two 13-year-old boys have been charged with robbery after £200 worth of Pokémon cards were stolen from two 10-year-olds who were threatened with a penknife in Swindon, Wiltshire. A police spokesman said:"We would remind parents to tell their children to leave their Pokémon cards at home when they go out to play."

Locks changed in jail key error
Locks in at least 225 cells at Long Lartin prison near Evesham, Worcestershire, are to be changed after a jail official took a master key home. The locks have to be replaced because the keys left the prison.

Advert scheme for phone boxes
Advertisements will play on a video screen as customers make calls from eight public phone boxes in a trial starting this week in Nottingham. The first adverts planned are a recruitment film for the army, one for Boots and a trailer for a movie based on the Asterix cartoon character.

Finger 'saved' in ice cream
Firefighter Mike Kane put the severed finger of a road accident victim into a tub of vanilla ice cream in the hope of keeping it cool enough to be sewn back on by surgeons. William Putnam, 25, an American serviceman, was freed from an overturned car at a service station forecourt off the A14, between Huntingdon and Cambridge.

New models for London season
Twenty first-time models stepped out last night at the start of London's social season at the Berkeley dress show in aid of the NSPCC.

webTitle: Northern Ballet director quits after less than a year

fields.headline: Northern Ballet director quits after less than a year
fields.trailText: The director of Northern Ballet Theatre has unexpectedly resigned after less than a year with the Leeds-based company, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
The director of Northern Ballet Theatre has unexpectedly resigned after less than a year with the Leeds-based company, it was announced yesterday.

Stefano Giannetti, whose adaptation of Great Expectations is touring the regions, announced his decision to his dancers last week but gave no reasons.

Giannetti, the fourth artistic director in the company's 30-year history, is now working on a project in Rome. He is expected to be back in Britain next month and will stay until Great Expectations ends its run in Cardiff in July.

In a statement, Bernard Atha, chairman of the ballet's board, said he had accepted Giannetti's decision with the greatest regret. "In the short time he has been here, he has improved the standard of dancing in the company, produced an excellent new ballet and supervised a most successful London season."

Giannetti is the second head of a big northern arts organisation to resign this month. Last week Antony Lewis Crosby quit suddenly as chief executive of the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra.

One source yesterday suggested that Giannetti may have resigned because of an overspend on the Great Expectations budget, though that theory was dismissed by a company spokeswoman.

Others said the Arts Council of England, which believes the company should be original and innovative, was unhappy about plans to revive Roland Petit's version of Coppelia. But a spokesman said: "This resignation is nothing to do with any pressure from the Arts Council."

One observer said: "This is quite a loss for the company. Giannetti seemed to have a vision, and ballet company directors are very hard to find."

Giannetti said in an interview this year: "I believe in art, I am not in this position for my ego. To be a leader is to the dancers, and I think it must serve them best to give them something they can do comfortably and be inspired by."

He succeeded Christopher Gable, who played LS Lowry in Gillian Lynne's ballet commissioned to mark the centenary of the artist's birth in 1987

Gable led the company for 11 years until his death from cancer in 1998 and won audiences for productions, including Dracula and a reworking of Swan Lake, which were strong on narrative and seen as more theatrical than classical. When Giannetti was appointed, Mr Atha said he had an "outstanding record as a performer, choreographer and teacher" and subscribed "to the Gable vision of dance theatre".

He trained in Rome and continued his studies in Paris and Cannes. He danced with companies in Hamburg, Basel, London and Zurich before becoming principal dancer and choreographer at the Deutsche Oper in Berlin.

His Great Expectations enjoyed moderate reviews.

The Guardian's critic, Judith Mackrell, praised the "clean-limbed, supple and unusually classical choreography," but added: "It's ironic that under Gable NBT were fine actors but underpowered dancers, while under Giannetti their dancing is much improved but they rarely get to act."
