fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Half Aborigines dead before 50
fields.body:
Half Aborigines dead before 50

Aborigines are three times more likely to die in infancy than other Australians, and about half of the rest will die before they reach 50, a study by the Australian Bureau of Statistics said yesterday.

The main causes of death among aboriginal adults are circulatory and respiratory disease, diabetes, cancer and injury. Deaths from murder and suicide are also much higher than for the rest of the population.
Reuters, Sydney

Former rebel leads Rwanda

Paul Kagame yesterday became Rwanda's first Tutsi president since independence in 1962, after an overwhelming vote from parliament and ministers.

The former vice-president, who led the rebel army which ended the country's 1994 genocide, had previously rejected the post for fear of antagonising the Hutu majority and confirming the perception that the Tutsis rule the country.
AP, Kigali

Cook speaks out on Kashmir

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, said yesterday that Britain shared India's security concerns over terrorism and hijacking in the country's Kashmir region.

Mr Cook earned an angry rebuke from the Indian government in 1997 for remarks on the Kashmir conflict but received a cordial welcome yesterday.
Luke Harding, New Delhi

48 held after Anwar protests

A Malaysian court yesterday remanded 48 people in police custody for up to six days as the authorities extended a crackdown on the opposition.

The clampdown follows protests on Saturday to mark the anniversary of the conviction of ex-finance minister Anwar Ibrahim.
Reuters, Kuala Lumpur

Toilet water to be recycled

California officials hope to turn toilet water into drinking water in an attempt to solve the state's water shortage problem.

A pilot programme could begin this week in the San Fernando Valley, The Daily News of Los Angeles reported. The water would undergo a five-year purification process before being combined with ground water.
AP, Los Angeles

webTitle: Equal right plea for cohabiting couples

fields.headline: Equal right plea for cohabiting couples
fields.trailText: Government measures encouraging marriage would be unlikely to reduce breakdowns among cohabiting couples with children, according to a new report.
fields.body:
Government measures encouraging marriage would be unlikely to reduce breakdowns among cohabiting couples with children, according to a new report.

The co-authors, Carol Smart and Pippa Stevens of the centre for research on family, kinship and childhood at Leeds University, said that "even though the government might wish to promote marriage as an ideal form of co-residence, it would not be ideal for many cohabitees".

It suggested it would be more beneficial to make the legal position of unwed couples more like that of married ones after cohabitation had evolved into a de facto marriage with the passage of time, bestowing more equal property and parental rights.

Such steps would need to be part of a much wider policy strategy "designed to support parenthood per se... the most important challenge will be to devise family polices which support married and unmarried, co-resident and separated parenthood".

According to recent estimates there were now more than 1.5m heterosexual cohabiting couples, mostly in their twenties and thirties. The connection between this and the decline of marriage was not straightforward, with some 70% of marriages now preceded by a period spent "living together". Nonetheless, data showed cohabitations did not last as long as marriages, and that marriages which began after cohabitation did not last as long as those which do not.

Most of the 20 men and women interviewed had been in cohabiting relationships which fell into one of two categories. In those based on "mutual commitment" the couple's relationship had usually been established before they lived together, they had some legal and financial agreements, any children had been planned, and both parties had expected the relationship to last.

These were the arrangements that most closely resembled marriage, yet they were also the ones in which marriage had been most explicitly rejected as unnecessary or ideologically undesirable. Government encouragement of marriage would have made no difference to such people. To them "marriage was an irrelevance", the report found.

Being married would not have assisted those in cohabitations characterised by "contingent commitment" either. These were marked by an absence of mutuality, often arising from unplanned pregnancies and founded on couples' belief they it was their duty to "give it a go". The report concluded that for these people "marriage was either far too risky (mostly for the women) or far too premature (mostly for the men)".

The report observed that interviewees said much the same things about why their relationships had broken down as people whose marriages failed, with women citing men's violence, drinking, sexual infidelity or lack of interest in parenting, while men complained of feeling excluded by a baby's arrival and trapped by domesticity.

Among the "mutually committed", whose relationships tended to have lasted longer, there was also the factor of simply "drifting apart" which also contributed frequently to divorce. The report also concluded that marriage would be no panacea for men or women who begin cohabiting more in hope of their partnership flourishing than in expectation: "The prospects for marriages based on contingency rather than mutuality seem just as limited and insecure."

 Cohabitation Breakdown is published by the Family Policy Studies Centre on behalf of the Joseph Rowntree Foundation

webTitle: Attack puts Iranian militants in the dock

fields.headline: Attack puts Iranian militants in the dock
fields.standfirst:
Shooting of presidential aide puts focus on Islamist reign of terror
More about Iran
fields.trailText: No one seemed to care when Mojtaba Mehrasebi was killed one evening in 1997 inside his car repair shop. Even after Islamic extremists sprayed bullets at the wreaths at his funeral, police and intelligence agents did not conduct an extensive investigation.
fields.byline: Geneive Abdo in Shahr-e Rey, Iran
fields.body:
No one seemed to care when Mojtaba Mehrasebi was killed one evening in 1997 inside his car repair shop. Even after Islamic extremists sprayed bullets at the wreaths at his funeral, police and intelligence agents did not conduct an extensive investigation.

But now the Mehrasebi murder has made headlines in Iran. The same network of Islamic militants who allegedly killed him and an estimated nine other people from this city near Tehran are accused of carrying out the attempted assassination of a close aide to the president, Mohammed Khatami.

It was once a closely-guarded secret that Shahr-e Rey is ruled by Islamic militias and extremist clerics intent on enforcing their moral codes. Now that secret is out.

Under threat from the reformist movement, the Islamic vigilantes are engaged in a religious war that is emblematic of the less violent battles under way throughout Iran.

The series of attacks in Rey, a downtrodden city where walls are covered with religious sayings from prominent ayatollahs, were carried out over the last several years in the name of Islam.

One woman was murdered because she was believed to be a prostitute. A video shop owner was shot, but survived. "Videos are worse than bombs," the extremists wrote on the shop walls before the attack.

A grenade was thrown into a pizza parlour which was known for allowing boys and girls to mingle together - which is officially illegal but is largely tolerated in Tehran.

Emboldened by the sermons from semi-official clerics in their heyyats, or religious societies, the extremists broadened their activities beyond the confines of Rey on March 12.

They allegedly shot Saeed Hajjarian, one of the masterminds behind the reformers' victory in February's parliamentary polls. Mr Hajjarian is in hospital in stable condition.

"The extremists are feeling the winds of reform and that's why they have become more aggressive," Mr Mehrasebi's son, Mohsen, 25, said.

He said his father was targeted for holding meetings of dervishes, Islamic mystics who are often at odds with orthodoxy.

"We have tried for two years to get justice. We wrote a letter to the president and the judiciary, but the authorities ignored us," he added.

"We gave our story to the newspapers when the murder happened but it was never printed. Now our story is in the news because a prominent person has been shot by the same gang who killed our father."

At least eight men, all from Shahr-e Rey, are being held in connection with the plot to kill Mr Hajjarian and are scheduled to go on trial soon.

Two are members of a division of the revolutionary guards which protects the government compound in Tehran. One is the son of a cleric who preaches in one of Shahr-e Rey's mosques. The man charged with pulling the trigger, Saeed Asgar, is a member of the basij - the volunteer Islamic militia - which controls this city. His father, a local education ministry official insists that his son was at home.

The activists are all well-known. "The guy who was the watchman in the Hajjarian shootings lives two doors from here," said Mehdi, a computer shop owner who declined to give his last name.

"He is a very religious person and the activities of this gang are carried out for ideological reasons - the police are terrified of them."

Mahmoud Kaveh, who owns a nearby video store, was shot shortly before the attack on Mr Hajjarian.

He had earlier received several written threats, one of which read: "In the name of the Almighty, dear Mr Kaveh, immediately remove the name 'video' from your shop." The letter was signed, "Hizbullah," a reference to Iran's most notorious Islamic extremists.

Ordinary Rey residents are left trying to stay clear of the extremists' path. "I have changed my vocation and closed my shop," reads a sign on Mr Kaveh's store.

Plots to kill or harm those deemed to have violated religious principles are concocted in a religious centre in Rey. Freelance and official clerics preach to hundreds of young men who gather there.

This week ceremonies were under way to mark Ashura, the Shi'ite mourning ceremony for the martyred Imam Hossein. A prominent cleric who is close to Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, is to preach this weekend at the climax of Ashura.

"Hundreds of motorcycles were on this street last night in front of the heyyat ," said a man who runs a kebab stand nearby. The motorcycles are the trademark of the basij . "But don't go there because they never allow women inside," he advised.

But fear pervades this city. "Even if those in jail are executed, it won't make a difference. There is a whole society of militants behind them," Mr Mehrasebi said.

"The extremists are feeling the winds of reform and that's why they have become more aggressive," Mr Mehrasebi's son, Mohsen, 25, said. He said his father was targeted for holding meetings of dervishes, Islamic mystics who are often at odds with orthodoxy. "We have tried for two years to get justice. We wrote a letter to the president and the judiciary, but the authorities ignored us," he added. "We gave our story to the newspapers when the murder happened but it was never printed. Now our story is in the news because a prominent person has been shot by the same gang who killed our father." At least eight men, all from Shahr-e Rey, are being held in connection with the plot to kill Mr Hajjarian and are scheduled to go on trial soon. Two are members of a division of the revolutionary guards which protects the government compound in Tehran. One is the son of a cleric who preaches in one of Shahr-e Rey's mosques. The man charged with pulling the trigger, Saeed Asgar, is a member of the basij - the volunteer Islamic militia - which controls this city. His father, a local education ministry official insists that his son was at home. The activists are all well-known. "The guy who was the watchman in the Hajjarian shootings lives two doors from here," said Mehdi, a computer shop owner who declined to give his last name. "He is a very religious person and the activities of this gang are carried out for ideological reasons - the police are terrified of them." Mahmoud Kaveh, who owns a nearby video store, was shot shortly before the attack on Mr Hajjarian. He had earlier received several written threats, one of which read: "In the name of the Almighty, dear Mr Kaveh, immediately remove the name 'video' from your shop." The letter was signed, "Hizbullah," a reference to Iran's most notorious Islamic extremists. Ordinary Rey residents are left trying to stay clear of the extremists' path. "I have changed my vocation and closed my shop," reads a sign on Mr Kaveh's store. Plots to kill or harm those deemed to have violated religious principles are concocted in a religious centre in Rey. Freelance and official clerics preach to hundreds of young men who gather there. This week ceremonies were under way to mark Ashura, the Shi'ite mourning ceremony for the martyred Imam Hossein. A prominent cleric who is close to Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, is to preach this weekend at the climax of Ashura. "Hundreds of motorcycles were on this street last night in front of the heyyat ," said a man who runs a kebab stand nearby. The motorcycles are the trademark of the basij . "But don't go there because they never allow women inside," he advised. But fear pervades this city. "Even if those in jail are executed, it won't make a difference. There is a whole society of militants behind them," Mr Mehrasebi said.

fields.headline: Computers 'enhance' Shakespeare's Bottom
fields.standfirst: Theatre to use virtual reality sets that react to actors
fields.trailText: It has taken nearly 500 years but the Shakespearean theatre is at last to get its first 3D Bottom in fairyland. Kent University is to stage a computer-enhanced version of A Midsummer Night's Dream that could change the way plays are performed for ever.
fields.body:
It has taken nearly 500 years but the Shakespearean theatre is at last to get its first 3D Bottom in fairyland. Kent University is to stage a computer-enhanced version of A Midsummer Night's Dream that could change the way plays are performed for ever.

Purists may scoff at the very notion of mixing the Bard with technology of the kind used for Lara Croft Tombraider games, but academics claim the virtual reality sets "are like nothing theatre audiences have ever seen before".

Unlike the special effects and 3D trickery used in the cinema, the virtual scenes being created for Shakespeare are "alive" and change every night, just as proper live theatre does, so no performance is the same as the next.

Mark Reaney said that by developing a series of cyber worlds not unlike those in which computer games are set, actors and directors can alter the setting on the hoof, opening avenues impossible to explore on film or in conventional theatre.

When the first audience files in to see A Midsummer Night's Dream in Canterbury in June, they will be given special 3D glasses through which to watch the changing backdrop projected on to three screens on stage. Professor Reaney said the actors will be free to perform normally because the set will move around them.

"We hope to have technicians sitting in front of the stage so they can react immediately to the actors' movements and take them through all sorts of different generated areas.

"It is all done in real time, it is not like a pre-set video. Nor is it like special effects in film - it is a true live theatrical experience.

"Because it is all stereoscopic, everyone in the audience sees the same scene no matter where they are sitting, so there is no problem with sightlines."

The sets get more wild and abstract as the characters venture deeper into the "cyberforest," just as the mythic Grecian wood Shakespeare wrote about gets more magical.

Anthony Rowe, design co-ordinator of the Royal Shakespeare Company, said he could see "huge commercial implications" for the technology, particularly in big West End musicals.

"Purely on gimmick value alone it would probably be a big hit with audiences. It is a very interesting experiment, though I am not sure how big an impact it will have outside those productions which have a lot of time and money."

There was one important area where no amount of wizardry could beat traditional theatre, he said. "An actor alone on stage can create the sort of magic that no technology can compete with.

"So often technical advances lose sight of that. The trend at the moment, in fact, is for more bare, pared-down sets which let the beauty of the writing come through."

Even Prof Reaney, who is based at the University of Kansas institute for the exploration of virtual realities, admits it has its limitations. "I am not saying this can or should take over from traditional sets, but it is there if people need it."

He has developed the technology in three plays in the US, where he found it was far from foolproof. "You can have situations, of course, where an actor moves and bumps into, or walks through a 3D image. But we're working on it."

fields.headline: Silence marks Cambodia's bloody anniversary
fields.standfirst: Reconciliation is official theme, 25 years after Pol Pot takeover
fields.trailText: The 25th anniversary of the brutal occupation of Phnom Penh by the Khmer Rouge, whose bloody rule cost the lives of at least 1.7m people, passed almost unnoticed in Cambodia yesterday, where officials insisted it was better to focus on "reconciliation".
fields.body:
The 25th anniversary of the brutal occupation of Phnom Penh by the Khmer Rouge, whose bloody rule cost the lives of at least 1.7m people, passed almost unnoticed in Cambodia yesterday, where officials insisted it was better to focus on "reconciliation".

Only a small, open-air meeting by the opposition leader Sam Rainsy at a memorial to the Killing Fields in a suburb of the capital recalled the occupation by Khmer Rouge guerrillas on April 17 1975, after pro-US forces had fled.

The Khmer Rouge victory ushered in a murderous four-year campaign that forced Cambodians back to the land and ruthlessly suppressed the country's intellectuals.

Mr Rainsy told journalists: "The spirit of the Khmer Rouge is very much alive. Pol Pot alone could not kill 2m people... the organisation was made up of military heads and officials, some of whom are now occupying top-ranking positions in Cambodia."

A government spokesman, Khieu Samarith, however, repeated the official line that it was better not to commemorate the occasion for fear of arousing a "spirit of revenge".

Cambodia's disregard for the anniversary contrasts with Vietnam's preparations to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the fall of the US-backed south Vietnamese regime on April 30 1975. At the time, many Cambodians welcomed the Khmer Rouge victory as a relief from years of civil war and US bombing campaigns which had killed thousands of civilians.

Cambodian education officials have also said that the Khmer Rouge's rule should be downplayed in the interests of fostering reconciliation.

Recent surveys show that young Cambodians know very little about their past: a standard secondary school textbook on Cambodian history contains 10 lines on the subject.

Half of Cambodia's population was born after the Khmer Rouge was driven out by Vietnamese forces in 1979. However, many young people are aware that their families suffered bitterly during that period and say they want to know more about the truth.

In 1998, government troops were closing in on Pol Pot, the Khmer Rouge's leader, when he died in his jungle hideout while under house arrest by the military commander Ta Mok, who is now in custody.

The Cambodian prime minister, Hun Sen, insists that his government is intent on prosecuting a small number of surviving Khmer Rouge leaders. But talks with the United Nations about forming a tribunal to hold the trials have dragged on for nearly two years, with the sticking point being who would control the tribunal.

The UN has said that the Cambodian legal system is not strong enough to administer justice on its own, while Mr Hun Sen has pushed for a majority of Cambodian judges and prosecutors.

Yesterday, the prime minister said he supported a formula which would allow the involvement of foreign judges in the trials of former Khmer Rouge leaders. "That formula is choosing two judges at the primary court and three judges at the supreme court... Three would be Khmer judges and two would be foreign judges, who would vote to solve disagreements of the co-prosecutors," he said.

Although he appeared to be trying to reach agreement with the UN yesterday, he has previously argued that preserving national concord is more important.

Several leading Khmer Rouge figures are likely to enjoy immunity from prosecution, including Khieu Samphan, who defected to the Phnom Penh government in 1998 and now lives securely in the former Khmer Rouge base at Pailin, near the Thai border.

Pailin is controlled by the regime's deputy premier, Ieng Sary, who defected earlier in 1996 bringing with him thousands of guerrillas. The former president of the Khmer Rouge's "parliament", Nuon Chea, who is thought to be responsible for hundreds of deaths and torture, also lives in Pailin.

A small number of independent Cambodians, mostly working for non-governmental organisations, continue to press for a fuller inquiry into the past. They point to the numerous mental health problems suffered by Cambodians who survived the 1975 to 1979 period.

fields.headline: If the chair fits...
fields.standfirst: He turns furniture into skirts and aeroplane wings into dresses. And now Britain's designer of the year is tipped to take over one of Europe's top fashion houses, Jil Sander.  Laura Craik meets Hussein Chalayan
fields.trailText: He turns furniture into skirts and aeroplane wings into dresses. And now Britain's designer of the year is tipped to take over one of Europe's top fashion houses, Jil Sander. Laura Craik meets Hussein Chalayan
fields.body:
'What do you think it was about?" Hussein Chalayan, 29, British designer of the year, crown prince of avant-garde fashion, the creative force behind Tse cashmere and prime candidate (if rumours are to be believed) for the chief designer's job at Jil Sander has a habit of deflecting questions back at you. I had asked him to explain the inspiration behind his last show, held at Sadler's Wells Theatre during February's London Fashion Week to huge critical acclaim.

Certainly, the show was a display of design genius: razor-sharp tailoring, innovative cutting techniques, stunning sculptural details... but what do I think it was about? Tricky one, that. Since the finale involved models donning sofa covers that turned into dresses and tables that turned into skirts, accompanied by a group of live Bulgarian singers (whose performance was projected through a television screen which formed part of the stage set), I wouldn't like to hazard a guess.

"It was about times of war, when peoples' houses are raided and they're told to leave in five or 10 minutes or they'll get killed. It was the idea of having to evacuate your home," says Chalayan, earnestly. "So the idea was to take a horrific situation like that and contradict it - to represent it in an almost beautiful way. The idea was to hide those possessions that mean a lot to you: hiding the clothes on chairs, turning the chairs into suitcases, and carrying them away. So it's like you've carried your environment with you."

And to think most designers' inspiration is "the 80s". Hussein Chalayan is deeper than that. A clumsy metaphor for his deepness can be found back in 1993, when he buried his degree collection in a friend's back garden, just to see what happened to the fabric. Fresh out of Central Saint Martins, he was awarded a window in the swanky London store Browns for his trouble - just like John Galliano before him.

His collection of two seasons ago was based on principles from the Cartesian world view (don't ask); previous shows have included dresses suspended by helium balloons, jackets that lit up with red dots like a flight path and electronically controlled petticoats whose skirts opened out like aeroplane wings coming in to land.

In lesser hands, this could be dismissed as pretentious twaddle. For who would wear an aeroplane wing skirt down the pub? In Chalayan's hands, however, it takes fashion for ward. This is fashion as performance art, as something to be marvelled at.

As buyers for Liberty, Harrods and Whistles will testify, Chalayan does wearable things, too. They wouldn't be stocking him this season otherwise. Nor would Topshop have commissioned him to design a range for its TS label: the collaboration is now over, but September will see him pep up the rails of an even more mainstream high street store. Marks & Spencer has asked him to design a range for its Autograph collection. See? Creativity and commerce can make happy playfellows. The latter facilitates the former, as Chalayan is well aware. "All my sponsors have been very nice."

Ask Chalayan even the simplest question and his brow furrows with a concern borne out of the importance of making himself clear. Who would he like to see as Mayor of London? "Oh god. Um. Livingstone. I think he should get it. I hope it happens. You never know until things happen... what you think could happen and the consequences of what really happens are unimaginable." What book is he reading? "I'm not reading a book at the moment, I'm reading bits of books. Usually I read theory books, and sometimes they can get so difficult that I don't have the heart to actually start... Maybe I should start reading novels. What are you reading?"

Chalayan lives to work. Most designers do. So painstaking, so relentless is the design process - from inspiration to sketchbook to fabric to dummy to model to catwalk to department store to bank balance - that only those dedicated to the point of obsession have the drive to survive. Chalayan doesn't know how many hours a day he works ("time just goes"), but it doesn't leave much time over for anything else. When you engage him in first date-style conversational gambits, his responses are apologetic and vague. Does he cook much? "Not as much as I would like to." Does he have a favourite TV programme? "I don't really watch TV. It's fun, but when you have time. It's quite sad, because a lot of people might talk about programmes that are on and stuff, and I've kind of missed out. 'Ali G said this, Ali G said that...' I haven't seen Ali G. Björk was taking the piss out of me the other day for not knowing who Ali G was."

Chalayan isn't name-dropping when he mentions his friend Björk, an early champion of his clothes. When he says he doesn't notice which celebrities wear Hussein Chalayan, you believe him. Celebrity is a distraction from fashion: during his acceptance speech at the British Fashion Awards, he made an earnest plea to the press not to value celebrity endorsement over genuine creativity (this after Posh Spice had received blanket coverage for modelling in the mediocre Maria Grachvogel show). "All the designers just work so hard; they deserved that space more than Posh Spice. Sometimes, this country is all about celebrities and football and pubs. I thought the fashion press might have been able to transcend that, but obviously the papers asked them to report on whatever was apt."

Chalayan should be used to Britain's obsessions by now: he has lived here since he was 12. But he retains the viewpoint of the detached outsider. The only child of Turkish-Cypriot parents (they divorced when he was five), he was a boarder at Highgate Boys School, north London - an experience he once likened to being in the army. "It was excruciatingly difficult, but I suppose I tried to channel it positively. I think I'm the kind of person who can make the best out of the worst situation." This early experience of upheaval might go some way to explaining the obliqueness of the theme behind his current collection. "I come from a split-up island where a lot of people had to leave their homes, so I guess it's an awareness I've always had, this idea of evacuation and then creating another life somewhere else."

Has he grown to love London now? "I still don't know if I feel comfortable in London. There are strong cultural differences. But it seems quite a liberal place. Compared with most European cities, it's a melting pot."

Cities, European and otherwise, are something Chalayan is an expert on: he travels extensively and frequently for the love of his work. As the designer behind the US cashmere company Tse since November 1998, he travels to New York up to 16 times a year, while last year alone he hosted exhibitions in Paris, Tokyo and Vienna. "A lot of people see travelling as glamorous. 'Oh, you jet-setter, you.' Such an annoying comment. Apart from exhausting, it's just unhealthy."

Will he continue to show his own collection in London for the foreseeable future? As one of the star attractions, his defection would be a sad loss. "You never know what's going to happen," says Chalayan ominously. "But at the moment I'm not planning to change." And will he stay with Tse for the next two years? "I don't know. I'm working with them right now."

It's easy to read too much into this, given that Chalayan has been mentioned in the fashion trade press as a contender to take over at Jil Sander. The German designer sold her name to Prada before quitting as head of her company after artistic differences with Patrizio Bertelli, the notoriously difficult chairman and husband of Miuccia. Chalayan's design philosophy would certainly fit perfectly with the luxurious, clean-lined minimalism of the Sander label, but Chalayan and Bertelli? It would be like mixing oil with water.

"There are very few companies that really understand their designers. Most of the time it's such an economic decision. I think the future is not necessarily to own people but to help people do what they can do well. Ownership is very much an 80s mentality. It's more about facilitating things for people."

Chalayan is adamant that he would never sell his own company. Can he confirm or deny the Sander rumours? "There's nothing going on at all," he says quietly. "I just don't want to comment on it. It's embarrassing to talk about." For him, or for them? "Both - for anyone. I'd rather you didn't say anything. The reality is that they're speaking to different people, and at this point it doesn't mean anything. Things only mean things when there's an offer."

Watch this space.

I think the future is not necessarily to own people but to help people do what they can do well. Ownership is very much an 80s mentality. It's more about facilitating things for people." Chalayan is adamant that he would never sell his own company. Can he confirm or deny the Sander rumours? "There's nothing going on at all," he says quietly. "I just don't want to comment on it. It's embarrassing to talk about." For him, or for them? "Both - for anyone. I'd rather you didn't say anything. The reality is that they're speaking to different people, and at this point it doesn't mean anything. Things only mean things when there's an offer." Watch this space.

fields.headline: The tomb raiders
fields.standfirst: George W Bush knew that he was destined for greatness when he was tapped on the back by a hooded figure and asked to join a secret society at Yale.  Oliver Burkeman on the Skull and Bones set
fields.trailText: George W Bush knew that he was destined for greatness when he was tapped on the back by a hooded figure and asked to join a secret society at Yale.  Oliver Burkeman on the Skull and Bones set
fields.body:
To the casual observer, there's nothing very extraordinary about the building at one end of High Street in New Haven, Connecticut, at the heart of the redbrick and sandstone of Yale University. The students lugging rucksacks from Starbucks to lectures and back to Starbucks don't give it a second glance. And there's certainly nothing to connect it to the frenzied campaigning for the US presidency: New Haven, a small city on the east coast, has been largely bypassed by the pre-election hyperactivity of candidates Bush and Gore.

Take a second look, though, and it begins to strike you that there is something rather sinister about the building, a mid-19th-century Gothic edifice with two tiny, boarded-up windows as the only features on its brooding facade, its heavy front doors sealed with two giant padlocks and an electronic security system. It comes as no surprise to learn that it is universally known at Yale as the Tomb, or that the identity of its architect - as if to add atmosphere - remains unknown. It seemed unlikely that anyone would answer when I knocked, and they didn't. The connection to America's presidential race, though, is a little less obvious. In a campaign during which aspects of Bush's past - in particular his alleged cocaine habit - have been exhaustively probed by the media, one episode has passed relatively unnoticed: Bush's membership of one of America's most powerful and aristocratic secret societies, to which the Tomb is home.

Bush was 21 in 1967 when, as a junior at Yale, he was "tapped" for membership in the Skull and Bones. The first the initiate knows of his nomination is when a black-cowled figure - a current member, known as a Bonesman - taps him on the shoulder and invites him to join. The gruelling initiation ceremonies that follow are the stuff of rumour throughout Yale's student body and, now, across the internet. The Tomb's interior decorations - said to include human remains and coffins - are believed to play a part. New recruits, according to another long-standing legend, receive a payment of $15,000 upon joining.

Officially, membership in this bastion of Wasp privilege lasts only a year, the final year at Yale, so that Bonesmen have left the university before they are tempted to talk of their experiences. But Bones alumni are everywhere in the American establishment: in Congress, the CIA, the courts, Wall Street and the media. President William Howard Taft, Time-Life tycoon Henry Luce and the financier Dean Witter, numerous politicians and university presidents were once numbered among them; today, members include judges, ambassadors, several senators and ex-senators - Massachusetts Democrat John Kerry and former Arizona Republican David Boren, for instance - and the leading conservative thinker William F Buckley Jr.

The most credulous (or satirical) conspiracy theorists would have you believe that the Tomb is the nerve centre of a worldwide conspiracy to - among other things - sell drugs, deal in nuclear secrets, disseminate propaganda for the 19th-century German philosopher GWF Hegel, smoke fine cigars and generally busy themselves with the construction of a new world order. But that the society's membership lists read like a roll call of east coast aristocratic privilege is a fact undeniable amid the paranoia and the parody.

What they actually do is another matter. In his door-stopping Yale: A History, the university's historian Brooks Mather Kelly makes only tantalising allusions. "Skull and Bones was, and remains, a strictly secret society," he writes. "Its purpose and programme were not revealed when it was founded, and have never since been known."

A 1976 article in Esquire magazine by the American journalist Ron Rosenbaum revealed much - including the ritual of the "sexual confessional", a practice that served to strengthen the bonds between Bonesmen as much as it irritated their girlfriends - but no member has ever gone public. Tradition requires that they leave the room if the society's name is even mentioned.

But now the Skull and Bones has been thrust unwillingly into the limelight, with the launch in the US this month of a movie transparently based on the group.

In The Skulls, Dawson's Creek star Joshua Jackson plays a blue-collar student coopted into an elitist society at an anonymous Ivy League campus, only to discover that its members are responsible for the murder of his best friend, a prying student journalist. The film has been universally panned - but then the conspiracy theorists could have told you all along that it would be. What we do know is this: the society was inaugurated in 1832 by a breakaway faction of the Phi Beta Kappa fraternity led by Alphonso Taft, who was later to become attorney general and the US secretary of war. Taft was appalled at the fraternity's plans to abolish its vows of confidentiality and initiated his own obsessively secretive alternative group. For two decades they met in rented rooms in New Haven, before transferring to the Tomb, and the building, which formerly occupied another site near Yale, was moved wholesale to its current location in 1911. In recent decades a small number of ethnic minority members and - in the 1990s - women have been tapped into the society's predominantly white male numbers.

And that is as far as it goes. As Patrick Pinnell writes in his architectural history of Yale, "Beyond basics, the fog gets thick very quickly... [As for] rumours about the society - its origins, its rituals, its occult puppetmastering of Yale, the country, the universe... if Bones listens to all that, it never answers."

George W Bush's lightning-fast ascendancy to the status of anointed Republican candidate owes most, of course, to the prior ascendancy of his father, but then he and his father before him were tapped for the Skull and Bones. Whether the society really provides the likes of the Bushes with access to invaluable contacts and networks of influence or merely fuels the plutocratic fantasies of America's wealthiest undergraduates remains a mystery. The man who may be about to become the most powerful Bonesman in the world certainly isn't telling.

fields.headline: £157,000 for asthma nurse
fields.trailText: A theatre nurse was awarded £157,000 damages yesterday after the powerful chemical she used to sterilise instruments caused her to develop asthma.
fields.body:
A theatre nurse was awarded £157,000 damages yesterday after the powerful chemical she used to sterilise instruments caused her to develop asthma.

The award to Fostina Brobbey, 58, who worked for 25 years at two hospitals in Manchester, was against the North Manchester NHS trust.

She developed occupational asthma five years ago while working at North Manchester general hospital, after contact with a disinfectant containing glutaraldehyde, known to cause asthma. In the September 1996 she had to retire due to ill health.

The trust contested her claim for damages for personal injury and losses, and was ordered to pay the compensation and costs after a four-day hearing at Manchester county court.

After the judgment Mrs Brobbey, from Ancoats, Manchester, said: "I am pleased with the ruling, but I really didn't want to give up work.

"Nursing was the only job I've ever done, and I really loved it... but I couldn't keep working because of the asthma. I still wake up coughing at night, unable to breathe."

The £157,000 award included damages for pain and suffering, past and future loss of earnings and loss of pension and loss of congenial employment. It is one of the largest ever given for asthma.

Hugh Robertson, head of health and safety at the public services union Unison, which supported her claim, said of Mrs Brobbey: "Another nurse lost to the NHS and many years of valuable experience wasted, all because of needless exposure to dangerous chemicals.

"There is no safe level of exposure to glutaraldehyde and no place for it in hospitals today. It is well known that it can irritate the skin, eyes, throat and lungs.

"I hope this case forces NHS trusts to look again at the use of dangerous chemicals in hospitals."

webTitle: Eurocorps to run Kosovo peace force

fields.headline: Eurocorps to run Kosovo peace force
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Moves towards closer European security and defence cooperation will get a boost today when Eurocorps, the French-sponsored multinational military grouping, takes over the running of the international peacekeeping force in Kosovo.
fields.body:
Moves towards closer European security and defence cooperation will get a boost today when Eurocorps, the French-sponsored multinational military grouping, takes over the running of the international peacekeeping force in Kosovo.

It is the first time in Nato's history that the alliance has entrusted an external operation to a unit which is not part of its integrated, US-dominated, command structure.

A Spanish general, Juan Ortuno, commander of Eurocorps, will take over K-For's headquarters in Pristina with a senior French officer as his deputy. He will command nearly 1,000 staff officers, including US, British, and Russian personnel.

The decision to give Eurocorps the task of controlling K-For after months of pressure from France and Germany has deep political resonance at a time when the US remains unhappy about EU plans for a European security and defence identity.

Eurocorps is a politically-driven creation from which Britain has kept its distance on the grounds that it is potentially divisive and more symbolic than militarily effective. Originally proposed by France, it now includes Germany, Spain, Belgium, and Luxembourg. It consists of 60,000 soldiers, based in Strasbourg, though it will contribute just 335 senior officers to the K-For headquarters, 30% of the total.

Eurocorps has never acted separately from Nato, and alliance officials insisted yesterday that K-For would remain Nato-led. K-For will revert to an integrated Nato command after six months.

The US remains sceptical about the EU's pledge to create an autonomous rapid reaction force of 60,000 soldiers, separate from Eurocorps, by 2003. Under this plan, the soldiers would be deployable within 60 days and be able to participate in peacekeeping operations for a year. Because of rotation needs, the plan would require up to 200,000 soldiers.

As Lord Robertson, Nato's secretary general, has pointed out, the European allies, with 2m mainly conscripted men and women under arms, had trouble fielding 40,000 soldiers for Kosovo.

The EU has agreed that its proposed force would be deployed in operations only after Nato has declined to do so.

Before the end of the year, the EU is due to hold its first "force generation" conference, where member states would be asked to make offers of troop numbers and equipment for the proposed rapid reaction force.

The US continues to express concern that the plan could be divisive, involve a new tier of bureaucracy, and that non-EU European allies could be excluded from decision-making.

The EU has recently set up a political and security committee and a military committee, as well as an international military staff attached to its Brussels headquarters.

The coming months will be decisive in helping to shape Nato's future, not least since France, keen to seize the opportunity for greater European independence in security affairs, takes over the EU presidency, on July 1.

webTitle: Congo airport death toll climbs to 109

fields.headline: Congo airport death toll climbs to 109
fields.trailText: The death toll from a munitions explosion at a civilian section of Kinshasa's Ndjili international airport has risen to at least 109 people, with 258 injured, according to a senior Congolese official. At least 55 of the injured remain in hospital.
fields.body:
The death toll from a munitions explosion at a civilian section of Kinshasa's Ndjili international airport has risen to at least 109 people, with 258 injured, according to a senior Congolese official. At least 55 of the injured remain in hospital.

"We are still going through the rubble, looking for dead bodies," the Kinshasa governor, Theophile Mbemba, said. Aid officials have broadly confirmed the figures.

Hundreds of people gathered outside the capital's only morgue yesterday, waiting to identify the bodies of friends and family members killed in the explosion.

A fire at the airport caused the explosion of ammunition which was in transit in the civilian part of the airport, completely destroying the customs area and blowing the windows out of the airport's main buildings.

The government has set up an inquiry and said it had not ruled out any explanation, even a criminal act.

Private aviation sources at the airport said yesterday that at least 10 planes had been damaged in the explosion, in addition to two aircraft that were completely destroyed. According to the source, three planes belonging to Congo Airlines, the largest private airline in the country, were severely damaged in the explosion.

An official with the United Nations military observer mission said that two of the mission's three planes were so badly damaged they would have to be replaced.

The mission, which has yet to be deployed, will monitor a ceasefire in the war between the government and rebels in the north and east. A new ceasefire came into force on Friday.

International airlines suspended flights after the explosion, but Belgium's Sabena airline has now resumed its normal schedule, with the first plane due to arrive in Kinshasa this morning.

The Congolese president, Laurent Kabila, who was on the scene only hours after the explosion, has declared a state of national mourning.

Mr Mbemba said that the government had released 7m Congolese francs (£489,000) to pay for the funeral expenses of the victims.

 Reuters in Kinshasa

webTitle: Italians seek to restore honour of Mozart rival

fields.headline: Italians seek to restore honour of Mozart rival
fields.trailText: The birthplace of music's most infamous composer will today attempt to persuade the world that Antonio Salieri did not poison Amadeus Mozart - more than 200 years after the myth took hold.
fields.body:
The birthplace of music's most infamous composer will today attempt to persuade the world that Antonio Salieri did not poison Amadeus Mozart - more than 200 years after the myth took hold.

The town of Legnago in northern Italy wants to recast Salieri as a sublime talent who encouraged his rivals and fed them ice cream, not arsenic.

As part of its attempt at rehabilitation, the town has lured historians and musicologists to a month-long festival of his work, starting today.

Organisers hope the beauty of Salieri's compositions, which are rarely performed, and an analysis of the evidence surrounding the poisoning claim will help him to be seen as a misunderstood genius, wrongly vilified.

Salieri's supporters blame an opera singer, Callisto Bassi, for starting the poison rumour soon after Mozart died of unknown causes in 1791, aged 35.

The Russian dramatist Pushkin immortalised the allegation in a play which in 1898 was turned into an opera - Mozart et Salieri - by Rimsky-Korsakov.

Peter Shaffer sealed the image of a mediocrity tormented by his younger rival in the 1979 play Amadeus. It was turned into an Oscar-winning film five years later, in which Murray Abraham portrayed Salieri as a sociopath, convincing a new generation that the Italian was a killer.

In Legnago, near Veneto, a sense of injustice burns. The locals, who say that for two centuries the town has been inhibited from celebrating a local hero, believe it is time to scotch the myth for ever.

Rudolph Angermuller, the director of the Mozart Foundation in Salzburg, is supporting their cause.

Salieri, born in 1750, was appointed court conductor in Vienna in 1788. He wrote 45 operas, including Tarare, and was hailed as one of the greatest composers of the age.

A favourite of the Hapsburg royals, he also wrote vocal, choral, instrumental and orchestral music, finding success across Europe.

Der Schauspieldirektor, by Mozart, and Salieri's Prima la Musica, Poi le Parole were jointly premiered at the Viennese court in 1786. The audience preferred Salieri.

Prof Angermuller said such success disproves the notion that Salieri, married with eight children, was consumed by envy after being eclipsed by Mozart. In reality he was a pedantic but generous mentor to contemporaries such as Beethoven and Schubert.

"He was abstemious but he had a weakness for ice cream and was always offering it to Schubert," Prof Angermuller told La Repubblica.

Mozart's widow sent her son Franz Xaver Wolfgang to study under Salieri. "Which mother would would make her son study under the murderer of her husband?" asked Prof Angermuller.

Towards the end of his life Salieri suffered a nervous breakdown and would sometimes accuse himself of killing Mozart, but his contemporaries dismissed it as raving.

He was given a magnificent funeral in 1825 and seemed destined for posthumous acclaim, but the rumours started by Bassi reached Pushkin.

The cause of Mozart's premature death remains a mystery. Possibilities include fever, TB or kidney failure. One theory says he was accidentally poisoned by doctors who were treating a fever.

Another theory suggests that Mozart died from a brain injury sustained when he fell over while drunk. Symptoms of nausea, headaches, weakness, paralysis and confusion were, some doctors believe, more consistent with brain injuries than poisoning.

Salieri's habit of writing operas which require expensive sets and casts also helps to explain why his music is rarely performed, said Prof Angermuller.

But the people of Legnago hope the situation will change. The town's Salieri festival continues until May 13.

webTitle: Deal keeps ban on ivory trade

fields.headline: Deal keeps ban on ivory trade
fields.trailText: Plans to restart the ivory trade between southern African states and Japan were put off for two years yesterday after a week of talks in Nairobi between the 37 "elephant range states".
fields.body:
Plans to restart the ivory trade between southern African states and Japan were put off for two years yesterday after a week of talks in Nairobi between the 37 "elephant range states".

The compromise prevented votes on conflicting resolutions with Kenya and India wanting to ban all trade in elephant products because of fears of renewed poaching and the southern African states wanting a resumption in trade because they have increasing herds.

The agreement will permit South Africa, Namibia, Botswana and Zimbabwe to trade in live elephants and their hides but not in ivory. That ivory question will be reopened in autumn 2002 when schemes to monitor the trade and keep a track on poaching will have been developed throughout Africa.

James Martin-Jones, from the World Wide Fund for Nature, said: "Essentially saving the elephant is an African problem and needs agreement of all 37 range states if it is going to work. This breathing space gives time for the proper monitoring systems to be put in place."

There has been tension since the last meeting of the 150 parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (Cites) agreed a limited sale of stocks of ivory to Japan. Kenya was convinced that even this limited lifting of the ban had increased poaching and threatened the herds on which it depends for its tourist industry. The four southern African nations had argued that selling ivory from culled animals and those that died naturally would pay for the upkeep of the large herds in the region.

It has taken Kenya a decade to raise its elephant population to 29,000, small by comparison with the 110,000-strong herd in Botswana.

The sale of elephant hide was agreed because it takes much longer for poachers to skin a dead elephant than to hack off its tusks.

A report by a Cites committee released yesterday said the one-off sale of southern African ivory had been a success. But Paula Kahumbe of the Kenya Wildlife Service, speaking for the Kenyan delegation, claimed the report was based on inadequate data.

webTitle: A competing horse has more independence

fields.headline: A competing horse has more independence
fields.trailText: Summer is not far off, so now's the time to plan all the seasonal events you've been looking forward to. Top of the list? Royal Ascot. How better to spend a summer's day than watching horses run around in the company of her Maj? A word of warning, however: you may end up feeling saddled yourself. A reader sent Sidelines this reply to a request for an application form: "Her Majesty's Representative at Ascot does not acknowledge the title Ms ... a married woman applying for herself should indicate her husband's forename." Gee-up, Ascot. A competing horse has more independence than a female spectator when it comes to names.

fields.headline: This time it's personal
fields.trailText: One Woman Against The Mafia
fields.body:
Rita Atrias was "afraid of absolutely nothing, probably because she had seen death so many times and at such close quarters". She was just 17 when the mafia killed her. Just seventeen. Such a pat phrase. There was no just about it.

Marco Amenta's enthralling film, One Woman Against The Mafia (C4), reminded one of another girl at another time. Of Lena Stolze, the Nasty Girl, a teenager growing up in post-war Germany, spat at in the streets because she'd had the temerity to uncover the Nazi past of her hometown. Rita's story is Lena's story because it's the universal tale of a young woman waking to the adult world and finding herself trapped in a web. This story begins at the end, as mafia stories do.

In Partanna, under the mummifying Sicilian sun, flies buzzed around a corpse, a sheet drenched in arterial blood. One month, the body under that sheet was Rita's father. The next month, it was her brother's. "Where I come from," Rita told her only trusted confidante, a diary, "it is better to kill your closest friend than go to the police."

Her family were being murdered by people they went to school with. Childhood friends turned mafia henchmen fighting a clan war. "These people have no heart and even less soul because they have been shaped by this culture since they were children. Their real mother is the mafia."

Unlike the transatlantic drug runners who took over the mafia in the early 90s, Rita's family were old-style mafiosi: they leaned on people; brokered peace as if they were cheap bit-players in a Mario Puzo novel; they talked hypocritically of hon our while suffocating their family; drawing everyone into a code of petty revenges.

"Oh God, why do you always take away the people I love?" Rita wrote in her diary, the blood of an eighteenth body in three months congealing in the sun. "Who is the one orchestrating this cruel destiny?" The incessant killing turned Rita against a deity that usually hides in Graham Greene novels. As capricious, inescapable and ungodly as the mafia.

One morning, Rita told her mother she was going to school. Instead, she took a bus to Sciacca to testify before Sicily's two highest anti-mafia judges, Falcone and Borsellino. Talking to them was like breaking through the web. Liberating herself but shaming her family.

A Girl Against The Mafia was an extraordinary film, making Hollywood's long history of formula mafia movies look like an indistinguishable mush of macho sentiment. Rita's words passed before our eyes, scribbled on children's A4 notepads. They lay languidly over pictures of small, stubbly men with hard, tired eyes - the mafiosi she helped convict - making silent curses to the camera as they were pushed into the backs of police cars.

Falcone and Borsellino could not talk in the film. The mafia had killed them in separate car bombs. Their replacements shuffled uneasily, smoking cigarettes, on a rooftop, Amenta questioning them as to what assurances of safety Rita had been given when she testified.

"You know what you must do girl." Falcone had said to her. "Once you have spoken to us. Get a map of Italy, cut out the triangle of Sicily, tear it up and forget it." Here was a story with no beginning and no end. No us and no them. When Falcone was blown up, Rita hid in Rome. Briefly, she discovered a kind of peace with a boyfriend. They were going to rent a flat, defiant of God and The Mafia.

"If you continue to collaborate," her mother told her, "I will have you killed." Once she had testified, Rita waited like a saint for the end. Her mother, as neck-high in blood as her father had been, did the "honorable" thing and had her daughter murdered. A justice meted out recently to Muslim daughters who flutter too close to independence.

In the end, this wasn't a story about the mafia at all, but the replacement of one faith with another. In a couple of years, modernity and feminism will soon be as immovable as the mafia once was. You could see it in the defiant faces of women at Rita's funeral. One said: "We can beat the mafia, the mafia is nobody."

In a sick, surreal twist of fate, Rita sat exams just before she was killed, writing an essay about the significance of the mafia for Italian culture. They killed my father and brother, she wrote - but then again, any of the candidates could have written that.

webTitle: Brothers killed on visit to father

fields.headline: Brothers killed on visit to father
fields.trailText: A father who was found dead with his two sons at their home had split up with his wife just a few months ago, neighbours said yesterday.
fields.body:
A father who was found dead with his two sons at their home had split up with his wife just a few months ago, neighbours said yesterday.

Police are working on the theory that Frank Fairless, 36, killed the boys at his home near Gainsborough, Lincolnshire, because he was depressed about the break-up of his marriage. He then hanged himself.

His sons Christopher, nine, and Oliver, six, were killed during their first overnight access visit to their father's house in Scotter since he split up with his wife, Claire.

The boys' bodies were found in their beds.

Police discovered all three bodies on Sunday evening after they received a call from James Forrington, the children's grandfather, who was concerned about their safety.

The boys had been picked up by their father at 9am on Saturday for an access visit. They had been due to be returned to their mother at 5pm the following day, but when they had not arrived by 6.15pm, her family contacted police.

Mr Forrington said: "We can't take in what has happened. We know as little as anybody else." At the time of the deaths, Mr Fairless's estranged wife was staying with her parents at their home a mile away.

Mr Fairless, a self-employed builder, built the detached cottage for his family four years ago. The couple named the property "Olverchris" cottage after their two sons.

The trio had been seen having lunch together at the Gamekeeper pub in Scotter on Saturday afternoon.

Neighbours said that they were horrified to hear of the deaths of the two boys and their father.

Brian Welch, 70, said: "Everybody here is stunned. They were a friendly family and always had time for a chat. The two boys were cheery little things and very pleasant - I can't believe that they are gone.

"Most of the houses around here have young families and all the children in the area play together. It was meant to be their dream home. He built it himself and named it after the two boys.

"We knew Frank and his wife had split up about six months ago, but we never imagined for one moment anything like this would happen."

Detective Chief Inspector Graham White, of Lincolnshire police, who is leading the inquiry into the three deaths, said: "The officers went into the house with both the boys' grandfathers and discovered the body of a man hanging in the garage.

"A further search of the premises revealed the bodies of two children lying in their beds under the covers, in separate bedrooms.

"I'm not aware of any signs of violence or a struggle. We are clearly looking at the possibility he has killed the children and then taken his own life."

He added: "From the family's point of view it is a completely devastating situation for them and it is very difficult to begin to comprehend how they are going to come to terms with it.

"It was the first time that Mr Fairless had the boys for an overnight stay."

A Home Office pathologist carried out postmortem examinations on the bodies yesterday.

DCI White said it was too early to say how the boys met their deaths, but he confirmed the police were not looking for anybody else in connection with the inquiry.

He added that a number of handwritten notes were recovered at the scene.

Mrs Fairless was last night being comforted by her family and specially trained police officers.

fields.headline: Class wars
fields.standfirst: Trading Places is a kids' docusoap following comprehensive pupils as they sample life at a private school. It may look like harmless entertainment but  Danny Leigh  thinks it brutally exposes the hypocrisy of our education system
fields.trailText: Trading Places is a kids' docusoap following comprehensive pupils as they sample life at a private school. It may look like harmless entertainment but Danny Leigh thinks it brutally exposes the hypocrisy of our education system
fields.body:
What you've just started reading is a rarity: a piece in a broadsheet newspaper written by the product of a state school.

Educated by the taxpayer, yet with a professional life dominated by posh kids, I often find myself pondering the truisms. You know, the ones about public schools breeding arrogance. Pomposity. Self-satisfaction.

That kind of thing.

Oh, and condescension. Insularity. Hubris. Lack of empathy. (And no, before you ask, I seldom waste my time on the fanciful chestnut that we spawn of the shared textbook have some kind of chip on our collective shoulder).

Which is probably why my ears pricked up at Trading Places (today, 5.10pm, BBC1), a spry pubescent docusoap wherein a quintet of pupils at Newcastle's Kenton Comprehensive - the "eighth biggest in the country" according to the cheerfully classless voiceover - mingle with the gentry-to-be at Dauntsey's, a blueblood barracks sprawled across a sizeable chunk of central Wiltshire.

Of course, said MacGuffin is itself the purest cliché, a Prince And The Pauper culture clash played strictly for laughs. Tune in for a giggle at shabby old Kenton, with its underfunded, overcrowded classrooms full of French crops and tracksuit tops, a Madness lyric made rowdy, teacher-baiting flesh. All the better for basking in the telegenic spectacle of the Dauntsey's trout stream, school boat - the Jolie Brise - and nine-hole private golf course: available, should any well-appointed family be eager to know more, for just £12,000 a year (if nothing else, the show makes great free advertising for its hosts' extramural facilities).

So far so-so. Stripped of any wider context, none of this amounts to more than a neutered, Easter holiday-friendly take on the ostensibly grown-up Living With The Enemy, where buying your offspring a head start is simply another bland parental lifestyle choice, like plumping for Petite Bateau rather than Gap Kids.

Except it isn't, is it? Despite the fond Blairite invocation of a Britain in which childhoods of all budgets are united by Pokémon and the internet, we remain a country where 7% of the populace gets fast-tracked from the age of five, while the remainder pin their GCSE hopes on the munificence of the crisp industry. Somewhere behind the show's ceaselessly jovial facade lurks the fact it still takes zeal (and luck) to avoid a career in retail after state school, and an even more impressive resolve to successfully come a cropper if mum and dad did shell out for prep. In a faux -egalitarian Jerusalem where every establishment bastion worth the name (Parliament, the legal system, the liberal media) is merely a fee-paying common room writ large, Trading Places suddenly takes on an entirely different complexion.

Barely have the Kenton five bumbled through the cod-Grecian pillars of their new alma mater, for example, before the chasm between theory and reality yawns beneath their feet. Look closely at the dead smiles of the Dauntsey's staff and you'll see the same nervous, pre-fab bonhomie usually reserved for young offenders on day release at a nursing home.

"And today," comes the cautious announcement at morning assembly, "we welcome five pupils from" - small intake of breath - "Kenton Comprehensive School, in" - slightly larger intake of breath - "Newcastle-Upon-Tyne. And, ah, good luck to you!" For both teachers and pupils, it appears, the arrival of the Geordie cuckoos in their luxuriantly feathered nest is less lightweight sociological experiment than trial-by-plebeian bad manners. "They all start shouting and swearing at each other", laments a fretful boarder. "It scares me."

For the oiks, moreover, the whole experience constitutes a hard lesson in the shape of things to come. "They're probably a lot more intelligent than us", remarks a Kenton refugee halfway up the gravel driveway of Dauntsey's Manor House, not a preconception likely to be reciprocated among the natives. Which is kind of the point: that the lurching chaos of your average comp lends its alumni precious little of the cold-eyed self-assurance necessary to compete in a world run by chaps (and the occasional chapette). As the patrician vowels of a pair of Dauntsey's prefects echo down the hallway en route to sorting out a dorm-room pillow fight - I'm not making this up - it's a reminder that no matter where you find yourself in adult life, a public schoolboy will be looking down on you.

Meanwhile, if anyone wants a peek into classroom practicalities, look no further than the awed incomprehension of the gatecrashers when presented with Dauntsey's array of enthusiastic, one-on-one tutors ("Hang on, back in a tick_ Fantastic !") Then shake your head dolefully as Nick - a Kenton prole whose insurrectionary dander soars inexorably throughout the programme - remonstrates with a gaggle of well-bred queue-jumpers at the tuck shop, only to be greeted with a mixture of bafflement and inveterate piss-taking.

Really, it's cruel. Cruel because the punchline is, of course, the five interlopers' eventual return to Kenton: away from the trout stream and the smiling, supportive teachers, back to being just another fun-sized headache among 1,999 others. And it's also sad. Sad that a show like Trading Places can still be made, that such a ridiculous, anachronistic fissure across the face of Britain can still exist.

Still, there's at least one sly moment of karmic high comedy on the horizon. At the same time next week, we're to be treated to the sight of five pupils from Dauntsey's sampling the state education system in scenic Newcastle-Upon-Tyne.

And you know something? I've got my video set already.

fields.headline: Danger zones
fields.standfirst: How journalists like  Rebecca Lovell learn the art of basic survival in a week
fields.trailText: How journalists like Rebecca Lovell learn the art of basic survival in a week
fields.body:
There was a huge explosion. "Get out of the fucking Land Rover" was spat in my face. None of us were about to argue against the balaclavas and kalashnikovs staring at us. I was pulled out of the vehicle and flung to the ground. My face was pushed into the dirt, a sack put over my head and tied around my neck. I tried to concentrate on controlling my breathing, which was suddenly very shallow and very fast.

Just a few hours into the six-day Hostile Environment and First Aid Training Course, I and nine other journalists were being kidnapped by eight terrorists/freedom fighters. But this wasn't Chechnya - it was Hampshire and the exercise was being acted out by ex-Royal Marines. Even though we all knew the scenario was staged, the huge adrenalin kick spinning round my body made it feel very real. Whimpers from one of my colleagues showed others felt an even greater sense of reality.

It's not the sort of risk assessment you learn from studying textbooks. Nobody knows how they might possibly react from sitting in the classroom. Of course the proof is out in the real world - not at a country mansion in Hampshire. One journalist was taken hostage while working in Somalia a few weeks after the course. She lived to come back and tell her harrowing tale.

The course is intended for people like journalists, oil and charity workers, who are going to work in dangerous environments. Places like Afghanistan, Sierra Leone, Chechnya - there are plenty of hot spots around the world. "What we do is open people's eyes, make them aware of the situation they are going into. If they come away with one snippet of life-saving information it's been worth it," says Paul Rees, the ex-Royal Marine who founded the course almost five years ago. Until relatively recently journalists were exposing themselves to the same risks as the military in the name of a good news story - with little or no equipment or training. It's not something any military organisation would consider.

No wonder some 250 reporters and broadcasters have met their deaths during the 1990s covering wars in foreign hell holes. Media organisations now rarely send their people in without some sort of survival guidance. Some 5,000 journalists have so far been through the week-long course in Hampshire.

Although an indication of how you might react in a crisis is useful, just as helpful is the basic first-aid training for which we were all awarded a Health and Safety Executive Four-Day First Aider At Work certificate, valid for three years. It doesn't matter whether somebody stops breathing on the battlefield in Kosovo or on the streets of Newcastle, the basic first aid is the same.

"Let's go for a walk around the grounds," was the dreaded phrase from the first aid instructor. We all knew we'd be putting the techniques we had learnt in the classroom into practise. Take the "landmine" scenario. As we approached a clearing in the woods two men were de-mining the ground.

Suddenly one landmine exploded. Chaos and carnage ensued. The casualty with his hand blown off was screaming, blood pumping out of the end of his arm at break-neck speed, going all over our clothes. A moment of confusion and then the training kicked in: stay calm, assess the danger, apply direct pressure to the injury, tightly bandage the wound, treat for shock and monitor breathing. After each exercise, the casualties who were all played by ex-Royal Marines, gave a de-brief.

"Five of you actually died by stepping on mines outside the safe zone."

"Don't just treat the one making the most noise. I had an airway to scream through - the guy next to me wasn't making a sound - that should ring alarm bells."

Over the six days there was a huge improvement in the confidence, knowledge and methods of all the participants.

Nobody goes into a dangerous environment hoping to end up a statistic. But even the bravest can do with awareness and first aid training. It's not just common sense. Some day any one of us may in a position to preserve someone's life.

webTitle: Danger signals not properly monitored before Paddington rail crash

fields.headline: Danger signals not properly monitored before Paddington rail crash
fields.trailText: The role of the railway inspectorate and the quality of data supplied by Railtrack about signals passed at danger before the Paddington rail crash were called into question yesterday by the health and safety executive.
fields.body:
The role of the railway inspectorate and the quality of data supplied by Railtrack about signals passed at danger before the Paddington rail crash were called into question yesterday by the health and safety executive.

Its report said the inspectorate failed to have a central system for collating intelli gence on the underlying causes of signals passed at danger.

It accused Railtrack of keeping "poor" data, a criticism which is bound to be examined by Lord Cullen, who is to chair the inquiry into the Paddington tragedy.

Yesterday's report could lead to a new transport safety body being set up, covering rail and civil aviation, a move already backed by the deputy prime minister and transport secretary, John Prescott.

In a statement to the Cullen inquiry, Jenny Bacon, the HSE's director general, said she regretted the amount of time taken for the Paddington signalling layout to be approved before the crash.

Dealing specifically with signal 109, which was passed by the driver of the Thames train on his way to a head-on collision with the Great Western express, Ms Bacon blamed Railtrack for "the inadequate risk analysis and assessment by Railtrack" of signal 109 and a poor follow up by the railway inspectorate.

"With the benefit of hindsight, the evidence suggests that until fairly recently more could have been done by HSE in relation to the railway to enforce health and safety legislation," she said.

The HSE report said there had been a number of incidents of failure to carry out the recommendations of accident inquiries. These included failure to implement a recommendation on signals passed at danger made by the report on the Watford train crash in 1996, in which one person died and several others were injured.

The HSE's report said signals passed at danger probably gave rise to the highest safety risk facing the industry. It had "a fragmented and untargeted approach" to dealing with these problems.

The HSE had been informed by the inspectorate that the quality of information supplied by Railtrack was poor, and "inspectors could do little with it".

The report said Railtrack was an acceptor of safety cases and a service provider and had a "complex relationship with train and station operating services". It went on: "This has the potential to create tension between commercial and safety considerations."

From May the inspectorate will become a division of the HSE and will be strengthened by additional inspectors with safety experience in other areas within the executive.

The inspectorate wants to raise its numbers by 10% but ideally would like to double its numbers.

Bill Callaghan, chairman of the health and safety commission, said: "These reports are strong and hard hitting. I know the HSE is eager to be as open as possible and to help Lord Cullen's inquiry in every way it can."

He admitted that the various safety measures taken in the industry over the past few years had not been enough, "and I am determined there will be further improvements."

webTitle: Gun law fear after death of a villain

fields.headline: Gun law fear after death of a villain
fields.standfirst:
Seven shootings in month linked to crime power struggle in Leeds
Gun violence in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Flowers and an ominous reference to a US gangster movie mark the scene of the latest in a spate of killings in an underworld power struggle which has brought gun law to Leeds.
fields.body:
Flowers and an ominous reference to a US gangster movie mark the scene of the latest in a spate of killings in an underworld power struggle which has brought gun law to Leeds.

Seven shootings in a month are being linked to a territorial struggle by armed criminals, culminating at the weekend with what appears to be the accidental killing of a notorious local figure in Meanwood, east Leeds. He died where the bouquets now rest against a concrete wall.

West Yorkshire police believe that Frank Birley, who had been released six months ago from a 14-year sentence for armed robbery and hostage-taking, was killed on Friday night when an accomplice on a "punishment raid" slipped and fired as he fell. A 17-year-old youth was shot in the leg just before Birley was killed and is under armed police protection.

Messages stuck to the flowers in Sugar Well Road where Birley collapsed fatally wounded, refer to him as King of New York - a title taken from the US crime novel and film - and in one case promise: "All will be reveled" (sic).

Birley, who was 33 and also known as Frank Gatt, is thought to have been trying to re-establish his position in Leeds.

He was released from prison after serving nine years for a £147,000 armed raid on a Blackpool jewellers which went wrong.

At his trial he was described as violent and dangerous after holding a 78-year-old woman and her 52-year-old daughter at gunpoint during a nine-hour police siege.

A retired engineer, Harry Hemsley, 66, described yesterday how he saw the man thought to be Birley's accomplice run past his drive after the killing.

Mr Birley said he and his wife were seeing visitors into a taxi. "A man came running out of the night waving a gun at me. He just said 'Get out of my way' and went past at what seemed like 100mph. This man wasn't panicking and looked as though he was in control - he could see we were no threat."

The alleged punishment raid on the 17-year-old which led to Birley's death shares a pattern with the previous six shootings. Craig Mirfield, 34, took a single bullet in the head as he tried to escape from a gunman in Gipton last month.

Clifton "Junior" Bryan, 29, was shot in Chapeltown Road. Seven years ago he was under police armed guard, after being ambushed and shot outside St James's University hospital in east Leeds.

Paul Garvin, assistant chief constable of West Yorkshire police, said that the shootings appeared to involve deliberately chosen targets.

Links are also being checked with a gunman's raid on a young couple's house in Seacroft, east Leeds, which left a man with powder burns after a shotgun went off during a struggle, and two shootings on the same day last week, which saw a 23-year-old man suffer minor gunshot injuries. The force's blue and white scene-of-crime tapes meanwhile went up again yesterday after the body of a 36-year-old local man was found slumped in the backyard of the Leeds Rifleman pub in Little London in the inner east end.

Police said that he had died of head injuries and the case was being treated as murder, but postmortem checks have yet to establish if firearms were again involved.

Police are also investigating rumours that a price had been put on Birley's head by one or more rivals who had flourished while he was behind bars.

Inspector Russell Clark said: "I think it's certainly an unusual situation we are dealing with here."
